summary: Frasers Hospitality Reit has secured S$370 million in bank loan facilities, comprising S$350 million in loans and a S$20 million revolving credit facility. The loan terms include conditions that the Reit manager must be a majority-owned subsidiary of Frasers Property and default provisions in case of changes to the Reit manager or ownership structure. The loan facilities may be affected if these conditions are not met, potentially impacting S$799 million in aggregate facilities.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Glencore's head of oil retires amid US probes; accident at its Congo mine kills at least 41
summary: Glencore's head of oil, Alex Beard, is retiring amid US probes into the company's activities. The US Department of Justice is investigating Glencore's role in obtaining contracts and compliance with the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and money-laundering statutes. Meanwhile, a collapse at a copper and cobalt mine in Congo killed at least 41 artisanal miners, with Glencore confirming 19 fatalities. The incident highlights the risks of artisanal mining in Africa, where thousands of illegal miners operate, and the need for preventative measures to secure large mines.

site_title: Singapore Airlines, Malaysia Airlines ink deal to expand code-sharing
summary: Singapore Airlines and Malaysia Airlines signed a memorandum of understanding to expand their code-sharing agreement, covering flights between Singapore and Malaysia. The enhanced ties may involve cargo, maintenance services, and expansion of code-share flights beyond existing routes. The agreement will also include subsidiaries SilkAir and Scoot, as well as Firefly, Malaysia Airlines' sister airline. The move aims to increase global connectivity and enhance service offerings for customers, with both airlines having extensive operations in the Asean region and worldwide networks.

site_title: Norway fund may offload US$1 billion stake in Glencore in shift away from coal
summary: Norway's $1 trillion sovereign wealth fund may divest its $1 billion stake in Glencore due to new, tighter ethical investing rules adopted by its parliament. The rules ban investments in companies mining over 20 million tonnes of coal annually or generating more than 10 gigawatts of power from coal. The fund's $1 billion stake in Glencore, as well as its holdings in Anglo American, RWE, and South32, may be sold to meet the new guidelines.

site_title: The Business of Storytelling
summary: Storytelling is gaining momentum in the corporate world as companies seek to boost their brand storytelling skills. Experts argue that with the vast amount of information available, people are becoming overwhelmed, and storytelling is essential for companies to reach an audience and be heard. Corporate leaders are being encouraged to tell compelling stories about their companies, using techniques such as the hero's journey, to create a healthy work culture and coherent public identity. Storytelling can also be used in therapy and counseling to help individuals deal with complex issues such as trauma and anxiety. Ultimately, a good story has the power to change lives and build relationships.

site_title: World's rich want more feel-good investments from their private banks
summary: The world's richest individuals, including family offices and foundations, are demanding more impact investments and philanthropy deals from private bankers. Annie Chen, chair of RS Group, urges banks to educate front-line staff on sustainable investing and allocate budget for impact investments. This comes as high-net-worth individuals plan to switch financial service providers due to dissatisfaction, with over one-third of wealth clients surveyed by Ernst & Young planning to switch within the next three years. Banks are responding by training staff and increasing assets under management in impact investing.

site_title: Star witness in US hedge fund trial admits he stole from mum
summary: A former trader and salesman, Frank DiNucci Jr., testified in the US trial of Premium Point Investments' co-founder Anilesh "Neil" Ahuja and former trader Jeremy Shor, admitting to helping inflate the firm's assets with false bond valuations from 2014 to 2016. DiNucci also admitted to stealing $10,000 from his mother's joint savings account in 2016. His testimony contradicts the defense's portrayal of Ahuja and Shor as unwitting victims of a scheme. DiNucci, who previously pleaded guilty to conspiracy, stated he valued assets improperly to keep his biggest client, Premium Point, happy.

site_title: Nike misses earnings estimates for first time in 7 years
summary: Nike Inc. missed earnings estimates for the first time in 7 years, with profit of 62 US cents a share, short of the 66-cent average projection. The company cited higher overhead expenses and a steeper tax bill as factors. Despite missing earnings, Nike's revenue met projections, and sales rose 4% to a record $10.2 billion in the fiscal fourth quarter. The company remains in a better position than most in the athletic-gear industry amid trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Disaster Relived
summary: HBO's Chernobyl has received the highest rating ever by global audiences, with an average rating of 9.6/10 from over 235,000 viewers on IMDb. The 5-episode historical drama, which tells the story of the 1986 nuclear accident in Ukraine, has been praised for its effective script, strong production values, and relevance to current events. Despite its bleak subject matter, the show has been widely acclaimed, with critics noting its gripping storytelling and exposure of the failings of the Communist system.

site_title: H&M shares jump amid good summer sales, shift to online
summary: H&M shares rose 10% amid strong summer sales, beating analyst forecasts with a 12% sales increase in June. The company plans to open fewer stores this year, reducing the number from 175 to 130, as it invests in e-commerce. Despite a pretax profit of 5.9 billion crowns and a shrinking gross margin, analysts see improvement in H&M's offer and expect a sales and earnings recovery.

site_title: Patron Saint
summary: The Kristang community in Malacca is celebrating San Pedro, their patron saint, with a festive event at The Majestic Malacca. The celebration, which includes traditional dishes and folk dances, takes place on June 29. Guests can enjoy a dinner package priced at MYR 638 for two, or dine at MYR 180 nett per person. The event aims to keep traditional rituals alive and is open to bookings through majesticmalacca.com.

site_title: Twitter adds warnings to rule-breaking tweets from public figures
summary: Twitter has announced it will add warning labels to tweets from public figures that violate its rules, including US President Donald Trump. The move aims to strike a balance between free expression and reducing harm caused by rule-breaking tweets. The policy applies to verified accounts with over 100,000 followers and will not be enforced retroactively. Twitter expects the cases to be rare and will use a cross-functional team to determine if a tweet is a matter of public interest. The move has been welcomed by some as a step in the right direction, but others warn it may not have a significant deterrent effect.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Dark data and why it should be dealt with
summary: Veritas' Value of Data study highlights the persistence of dark data despite security breaches and data protection regulations. Dark data, or unused and unanalyzed data, is a target for cybercriminals. According to Marcus Loh, senior director for technology practice, Asia-Pacific & Japan, Veritas, businesses must address this issue to mitigate risks. The study emphasizes the need for data management strategies to prevent data breaches and protect business operations.

site_title: Stanford University proposes US$3.4b housing plan in high-cost California area
summary: Stanford University has proposed a $3.4 billion housing plan in California, aiming to build 2,172 workforce housing units and 2,600 student beds in an area with high housing costs. The plan faces opposition from Santa Clara County officials, who express concerns about traffic congestion and affordability. The university plans to invest $1.1 billion in transportation improvements and other community benefits. The proposal is set to be considered by the county planning commission, with negotiations between the university and county officials having broken off in April.

site_title: Bitcoin almost wipes out its mega gain as swiftly as it came
summary: Bitcoin's price surged to nearly $14,000 on Wednesday, its highest level since January 2018, before rapidly declining in a matter of minutes after a cryptocurrency exchange reported an outage. The price drop accelerated Thursday, putting the coin back to nearly the same level as five days ago. The swift reversal prompted investors to lament the missed opportunity, with some attributing the decline to the "tight-knit market" and the rapid price swings. Bitcoin's price dropped as much as 18% on Thursday, with alternative coins also falling, highlighting the high volatility in the crypto market.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin's rise was meteoric this week - and its decline has been just as swift.

site_title: VW board puts Ford alliance on agenda for July meeting
summary: Volkswagen AG's supervisory board is set to discuss and potentially approve the next steps for an alliance with Ford Motor Co at its July 11 meeting. The alliance, announced in January, aims to cooperate on vans and pickup trucks, and may expand to include joint work on self-driving and electric-car technology. The agreement could be formalized at the meeting, marking a significant development in the partnership between the two automotive giants.

site_title: France sets 2050 carbon-neutral target with new law
summary: France has passed a law setting a 2050 carbon-neutral target, aligning with the 2015 Paris climate agreement. The law includes emission reduction targets, incentives for low-carbon energy development, and measures to renovate 7.2 million badly insulated homes. France aims to cut fossil fuel consumption by 40% by 2030, up from 30% today, and will force its remaining coal-fired power plants to close by 2022. This move places France among the first countries to adopt concrete measures to achieve carbon neutrality, following Britain's recent commitment to reach net-zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Apple design chief, Steve Jobs' confidant, leaving to start own firm
summary: Jony Ive, Apple's chief design officer and longtime collaborator of Steve Jobs, is leaving the company later this year to start his own design firm, LoveFrom. Ive spent nearly three decades at Apple, playing a key role in designing the iPhone and other successful products. The move is expected to have minimal impact on Apple's design process, with other executives taking over key roles. Apple shares fell 1.5% following the news, but the company plans to remain a primary client of LoveFrom for various projects.

site_title: Attilan could reacquire Hi-5 TV show in major deal with firm founded by MD, controlling shareholder
summary: Attilan Group, a Singapore-based investment firm, has entered a non-binding deal to acquire Tremendous Entertainment Group (TEG) for S$100m in cash and new shares. TEG owns the children's TV show Hi-5, and Attilan's managing director Jared Lim is also linked to the firm through his founding of Tremendous Asia Partners. The deal, which includes a S$5m share placement, aims to reacquire Hi-5 and help Attilan avoid compulsory delisting from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Oil edges higher ahead of G20, Opec meeting
summary: Oil prices rose ahead of a G20 meeting and an Opec meeting, with Brent crude futures increasing 6 US cents to $66.55 a barrel and US WTI crude futures rising 5 cents to $59.43 a barrel. Opec is expected to extend its output cut agreement, potentially deepening curbs. Investors await a US-China trade meeting and tensions between the US and Iran, which may impact the market. A US-China trade deal is possible, but US tariffs on Chinese imports remain a concern, and Iran's nuclear agreement deadline is approaching.

site_title: A 5G quantum world will change the insurance sector
summary: The rollout of 5G networks promises to revolutionize the insurance sector by enabling faster, more reliable data transmission and reducing latency to four milliseconds. This will facilitate the adoption of new technologies such as artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles, and smart manufacturing, leading to innovative insurance solutions. Insurers can digitize customer engagement using AI and AR, streamlining processes and improving claims submissions. The 5G network also supports IoT, enabling connected intelligent sensors and devices to share information and reduce preventable risks, leading to personalized, proactive, and predictive health insurance.

site_title: Boeing shares hit as regular finds new 737 Max issue
summary: Boeing shares plummeted 2.4% after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) identified a new issue in the 737 Max, which could slow the plane's return to service following two deadly crashes. The issue involves a microprocessor problem that impedes pilots' ability to regain control of the plane after activating a system. Boeing has disclosed few details, making it uncertain whether the issue can be addressed with a software update or requires a more significant upgrade. The FAA has not scheduled a test flight, and Southwest Airlines has pushed back its return-to-service timeline to October 1.

site_title: Freehold Bukit Timah condo Juniper Hill opens for sale on July 13
summary: Freehold Bukit Timah condo Juniper Hill will open for sale on July 13, with prices starting from S$1.6 million for a two-bedroom unit and S$6.1 million for a five-bedroom unit. Units range from 581 to 2,217 square feet, with prices ranging from S$2,600 to S$2,900 per square foot. The 12-storey development, featuring smart home provisions and concierge services, is expected to receive its temporary occupation permit in 2021 and deliver vacant possession by March 2022.

site_title: Crocodiles were once vegetarians, but it was just a phase
summary: A new study published in Cell Press found that ancient crocodiles were not always meat-eaters, but instead had plant-dominated diets. Researchers analyzed 146 teeth from 16 extinct species and discovered that some were omnivores, others specialized in plants, and still others were primarily carnivorous. The study suggests that these early crocodyliforms lived on different continents and at different times, and that their diets changed due to various evolutionary pressures. The researchers aim to further investigate the factors that led to this dietary diversification and the eventual disappearance of these plant-eating crocodiles.

images.alt_text: Crocodiles are sometimes described as living fossils for their close resemblance to their forebears who roamed the Earth during the age of the dinosaurs.

site_title: US: Boeing weighs on Dow as US stocks await trade talks
summary: US stocks rose ahead of trade talks between the US and China, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq advancing 0.4% and 0.7% respectively. Boeing weighed on the Dow, losing 2.9% after the FAA identified a new issue with the 737 Max. Despite this, other Dow companies like Walgreens and the Howard Hughes Corporation saw significant gains. Investors remain cautious ahead of the talks, with some expecting a positive outcome that could rally stocks.

site_title: Singtel JV launches new telco brand
summary: Singtel has launched Grid Mobile, its latest mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) in Singapore. The brand, aimed at millennials, leases frequency from Singtel and pays a wholesale rate, offering a contract-free plan with 20GB of data for S$24.90 per month. Grid Mobile's goal is to integrate mobile plans into consumers' lifestyles, similar to rival Circles.Life, which has also targeted the lifestyle segment. This is Singtel's seventh MVNO in Singapore, joining Zero Mobile and Zero1.

site_title: Hip To Be Square
summary: The Singapore Art Book Fair is back, hosted by the NTU Centre for Contemporary Art, featuring artist books, zines, and discussions. The fair, running from June 28 to 30, includes performances, panel discussions, and late-night parties. Notable speakers include Ute Meta Bauer, HG Masters, and Mark Rappolt. Admission is free, and the event showcases publishers and artists such as HOLYCRAP, The Institute of Critical Zoologists, and Basheer Graphic Books.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Art Book Fair 2019.

site_title: Equities climb on optimism ahead of G-20
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed 27.35 points higher, or 0.8%, at 3,328.60 on Thursday, driven by optimism ahead of the G-20 summit, where US and China are expected to reach a tentative truce. Regional markets, including Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea, also closed higher, while Malaysia bucked the trend. Investors were buoyed by US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments on a potential trade deal and President Trump's admission that a deal was possible by Saturday. However, market watchers cautioned against being overly optimistic, citing the need for a 10% breakthrough in the deal.

site_title: PM Lee to attend G-20 summit in Osaka, have bilateral meetings
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is attending the G-20 summit in Osaka, Japan, from Friday, where he will participate in discussions and have bilateral meetings with other leaders. The summit, themed to promote a free and open society, comes amidst trade and geopolitical tensions. Lee is accompanied by senior officials and will be acting Prime Minister, Teo Chee Hean, in his absence. The meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping is expected to be a key focus, with a failure to strike a trade truce potentially affecting the global economic outlook.

site_title: Sri Lanka tourism fighting back from Easter bombings: minister
summary: Sri Lanka's tourism industry is recovering faster than expected after the Easter Sunday bombings, with Finance Minister Mangala Samaraweera stating it has given a much-needed boost to the economy. The bombings on April 21 left 258 dead, including dozens of foreigners, prompting mass cancellations. Despite the initial setback, tourism has seen a significant recovery, with Samaraweera attributing the faster-than-expected recovery to the industry's resilience.

site_title: Singapore reviewing again 2019 growth forecast: MAS chief
summary: Singapore is reviewing its 2019 growth forecast again due to weaker-than-expected Q2 growth. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director, Ravi Menon, expects GDP growth for the year to be weaker than initially forecast, citing a softer external environment and ongoing trade conflict. The review comes after the government lowered the full-year growth forecast to between 1.5 and 2.5% in May. Menon notes that the Singapore economy is well-placed for a rougher ride ahead, with the financial system and corporate and household fundamentals remaining sound.

site_title: Indonesia court upholds Jokowi's victory in April presidential election
summary: An Indonesian court has upheld President Joko Widodo's victory in the April presidential election, rejecting a petition by challenger Prabowo Subianto. The Constitutional Court found a lack of evidence to dismiss Prabowo's appeal, ending months of uncertainty. The court's unanimous decision confirms Jokowi as the winner, putting an end to a highly contested election. The outcome maintains stability in Indonesia, the world's third-largest democracy.

site_title: Strong demand expected for one-north Gateway site launched for sale by tender
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a 5,778.7 sq m site at one-north Gateway for sale by tender, with analysts expecting strong demand for the zoned residential-with-commercial site. The site is estimated to yield around 165 housing units and has a maximum gross floor area of 14,447 sq m. Analysts predict top bids ranging from S$900 to S$1,200 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The site is launched under the confirmed list, with tenders closing on September 5.

site_title: Ibis Novena sold for nearly S$170m
summary: Alpha Investment Partners has sold the freehold Ibis Novena hotel in Singapore for nearly S$170 million, with a net yield of 3% and a price of around S$700,000 per room. The buyer is linked to Mohammed Saiful Alam, who controls Bangladeshi conglomerate S Alam Group and has previously acquired other hotels in Singapore. This sale comes after Alpha previously bought the hotel from the Kum family for S$118 million in 2013.

site_title: Europe: Shares hand back gains after White House dampens Sino-US trade optimism
summary: European shares closed flat on Thursday after White House comments dampened optimism over a potential Sino-US trade deal. Despite initial gains, the pan-European STOXX 600 index retreated as analysts warned against excessive optimism, citing China's reluctance to make concessions. The real estate and energy sectors led losses, while Germany's DAX outperformed, driven by Bayer's 8.7% rally. H&M and retail stocks also rose, while Chr Hansen fell 13.8% after cutting its revenue outlook.

site_title: Singapore telcos need more time to transform business model in digital era
summary: Singaporean telecommunications companies Singtel and StarHub face challenges in transforming their business models in the digital era. Despite investments in emerging areas such as cybersecurity, these services are still loss-making and require time to mature. The companies are struggling to balance shareholder value expectations with the need to nurture long-term growth. To address this, Singtel and StarHub may consider partnering with other companies or listing their new business units, and investing in creative management solutions and new technologies to drive transformation.

site_title: New generation reinventing the wok
summary: A new generation of hawkers in Singapore is emerging to ensure the survival and potential growth of the country's hawker culture. Despite challenges like manpower woes, young entrepreneurs are determined to succeed. They share lessons from their past experiences, such as teamwork and collaboration, to overcome obstacles. This new breed of hawkers aims to preserve Singapore's unique food concept and bring it to a new era.

site_title: US dollar holds gains as hopes rise for trade truce
summary: The US dollar held gains against other currencies due to hopes of a trade truce between the US and China ahead of their G-20 summit. The tentative truce supported buying of the dollar, which had weakened due to expectations of interest rate cuts and safe-haven currencies. The dollar index rose 0.1% to 96.351 before steadying at 96.222, while the euro remained unmoved despite a drop in Eurozone economic sentiment.

site_title: Economy accelerates in first quarter, but momentum fading
summary: US economic growth accelerated in the first quarter, with GDP increasing at a 3.1% annualized rate, unchanged from last month's estimate. However, domestic demand showed weakness, and the economy's momentum appears to be fading. The trade and inventory boost masked this weakness, and economists expect growth to slow further in the current quarter. The Federal Reserve has signaled interest rate cuts, citing rising risks to the economy, particularly from the ongoing trade conflict with China. The economy is set to mark 10 years of expansion in July, but the trade war is hurting business and consumer confidence.

site_title: AstraZeneca launches 'Cancer Can Give' drive
summary: AstraZeneca launched the "Cancer Can Give" movement in Singapore, a three-component initiative focusing on helping the elderly, imparting knowledge, and promoting sustainability. The movement will partner with various organizations, including the Singapore Cancer Society, to conduct interactive programs, tutorship-mentorship, and environmental conservation efforts. AstraZeneca also signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Singapore Cancer Society to provide greater care beyond treatment to cancer patients and fund public education and outreach efforts.

site_title: Social businesses led by women can fix any problem: Nobel winner
summary: Nobel laureate Professor Muhammad Yunus says social businesses led by women and young people can effectively solve the world's most pressing problems, including climate change and wealth inequality. These social enterprises, which use commercial means to tackle social and environmental issues, are growing globally, with companies seeking to demonstrate their commitment to people and the planet. Yunus notes that women and young people are often closest to these issues and can have the most impact, citing his own experience with microfinance and social businesses as evidence.

images.alt_text: Prof Yunis: "Social businesses are growing because people are frustrated with the conventional economy, the old way of doing business."

site_title: JPMorgan's fintech deal shows its Asia ambitions
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has taken a stake in Global PayEx, a Mumbai-based fintech firm, marking its first investment in an Asian financial technology firm. The move reflects the bank's strategy to boost its cash management services in fast-growing regional markets such as India and China. JPMorgan has earmarked $11.5 billion for technology investments in 2019, with a focus on transaction banking and emerging markets. The bank sees significant opportunities in India and China, with the Global PayEx service helping to simplify invoicing and payments in these markets.

site_title: Doggy's Day Out
summary: A popup event called Pup Club by Tayla Sorvete's will be held at Quayside on June 30, featuring a dog-friendly ice cream and pet accessories. Dogs can enjoy ice cream made from fresh fruits and probiotics, while their owners can receive a 15% discount at Les Bouchons. The event will also introduce new essential oils for pets, including calming scents like lavender and geranium. The event will run from 11am to 4pm.

site_title: Culture Vulture
summary: A new documentary, "The Black Godfather," is now streaming on Netflix, paying tribute to Clarence Avant, a music executive and entrepreneur credited with the success of artists like Sarah Vaughan and Lalo Schifrin. Avant used his sharp business acumen to shape black pop culture and beyond, securing a primetime slot for Barack Obama's 2004 Democratic convention speech. The film explores Avant's influence on music, Hollywood, and social justice, offering an untold story of a no-nonsense black American who stood up against racial prejudice in the 1960s.

site_title: Hyflux subsidiary restructures 617m yuan loan for China plant
summary: Hyflux's wholly-owned subsidiary Tianjin Dagang Newspring Co Ltd has successfully restructured a 617 million yuan (S$121.3 million) Bank of China loan for its seawater desalination plant in Tianjin province. The loan's maturity date has been extended by three years to 2026, with adjusted repayment terms. The restructuring aims to ease pressure on the plant's cash flow and is part of Hyflux's efforts to restructure its liabilities. The new terms also include a pledge of the desalination plant to Bank of China.

site_title: Minorities block Challenger's delisting; exit offer will lapse
summary: Minorities blocked Challenger Technologies' voluntary delisting, with 11.36% of shareholders voting against the resolution. The exit offer will lapse, and the offeror will not be able to make another offer in the next 12 months. CEO Loo Leong Thye expressed respect for the shareholders' decision, while Pangolin Investment Management's James Hay said the independent directors have "lost credibility" and the outcome is a "win for minorities and a loss for Digileap."

site_title: Beyond Meat's Asia ally takes mock pork to swine fever-hit China
summary: A Hong Kong-based startup, Green Monday, aims to capitalize on China's swine fever outbreak and government push for reduced meat intake by introducing lab-grown meatless pork. The product, made from pea, rice, shiitake mushroom, and soya bean, is seen as a perfect storm of factors, including plant-based meat's growing popularity and the need for alternative protein sources. With partnerships with major chains and e-commerce platforms in the works, Green Monday expects to stock its product in China by the end of the year, targeting a young, health-conscious, and globalized consumer pool.

images.alt_text: Plant-based meat is exciting investors with Beyond Meat's shares surging 542 per cent since its May listing.

site_title: Black Gold
summary: Calvisius, one of Italy's oldest farmed caviar producers, offers a five-course tasting menu at Buona Terra, priced at S$148, featuring their high-quality caviar extracted from farmed sturgeon breeds. The menu includes dishes such as decadent scrambled eggs topped with oscietra caviar and truffle croutons. Buona Terra is located at 29 Scotts Road and can be reached at 6733-0209.

images.alt_text: Buona Terra.

site_title: Cocktails: Shaking Things Up
summary: Singapore's bartenders are innovating with new cocktail menus, incorporating Asian flavors and ingredients. At Cool Cats, head bartender Nicola Paterno created 14 cocktails inspired by jazz and blues, while Edriane Sherwyn Lim at The Bar at 15 Stamford reimagines traditional rum cocktails. At Smoke & Mirrors, Jorge A. Conde incorporates unusual ingredients and techniques to create unique drinks. Meanwhile, Kavinn Raj at JAM at SIRI HOUSE combines cocktails with soul food, offering unusual pairings like gin and moringa. These innovative bars are pushing the boundaries of Asian bartending, appealing to the growing demand for unique and complex drinks.

site_title: Grab gets additional US$300m in funding from Invesco
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing giant, secured US$300 million in additional funding from Invesco to further its expansion efforts in the region. This brings Invesco's total investment to US$703 million, solidifying Grab's position as a South-east Asia technology leader. The funding will support Grab's expansion into financial services and mobility-enabled services businesses, including a potential move into banking. Grab has now raised US$6.5 billion in total capital since June 2018, with the latest investment coming after a US$1.46 billion raise from the SoftBank Vision Fund earlier this year.

site_title: When the winemaker dons a wet suit to fetch your US$100 tipple
summary: A Spanish winemaker, Crusoe Treasure, has created a unique wine aging process by storing bottles 20 meters underwater in the Bay of Plentzia. The bottles are aged for up to 18 months in the increased pressure and darkness, resulting in soft and silky wines with unique characteristics. The method is inspired by rescued champagne from shipwrecks and has gained praise from those who have tried it. The winery's bottles, priced between $60 and $100, often come with ocean debris attached, adding to their distinctive appeal.

site_title: Colonial quirk gives some HK men houses on the cheap
summary: In Hong Kong, a colonial-era policy allows male indigenous villagers to build small houses on their privately owned land without paying a premium to the government, a privilege not extended to women. The small-house policy, introduced in 1972, grants a one-time opportunity for eligible applicants to build a small house for less than one-tenth the price of a regular home. The policy has been challenged in court for its discriminatory nature, but a judge upheld the law, citing its intention to protect indigenous rights. The policy has been met with indifference from many indigenous women, who feel they are unfairly excluded from the benefits.

site_title: 'I'm in the 1 per cent. Please, raise my taxes'
summary: A wealthy individual, a self-described member of the 1%, advocates for a wealth tax to address income inequality in the US. The author, who has built two Fortune 500 companies, believes that the current tax code favors the wealthy and that a wealth tax could help alleviate poverty and reduce economic disparities. The author suggests that a wealth tax could be a key component of a broader plan to address issues such as the climate crisis and shrinking middle class.

site_title: Rejuvenate suspended companies through reverse takeovers
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has suspended 41 companies in the past three years, mainly due to financial distress or regulatory issues. Only one in eight suspended companies has relisted, leaving investors with significant losses. A reverse takeover could rejuvenate suspended companies, allowing existing shareholders to recoup losses or cash out at the traded price. SGX could make it easier for suspended companies to relist through less stringent requirements and faster tracking, benefiting shareholders and the exchange as a whole. This could increase the "listing shell" value of listed companies, making the exchange more attractive to listings.

site_title: Movie Art
summary: A documentary titled "24x36: A Movie About Posters" explores the art and passion behind creating movie posters, particularly from the illustrated era of classic films like Vertigo and Indiana Jones. The film highlights the decline of the industry with the rise of computers and the resurgence of passionate illustrators creating fan versions. The documentary screens at Chye Seng Huat Hardware Coffee on June 28.

site_title: Tight supply stokes China iron ore's record-breaking rally
summary: China's iron ore prices reached a record high of 838.5 yuan (S$165.17) a tonne on the Dalian Commodity Exchange, driven by concerns over tight supply and output cuts in China. The price surge follows a decline in stockpiles at Chinese ports, which are at their lowest since 2017. Resumption of full operations at Brazilian miner Vale SA's Brucutu mine is expected to boost supply, but shipping volumes may take 45-60 days.

site_title: Huawei received over US$1.4b in licence revenue since 2015
summary: Huawei has received over US$1.4 billion in licence revenue since 2015 and paid more than US$6 billion in royalties for intellectual property rights. The Chinese firm has been granted 87,805 patents, including 11,152 US patents, and has never been asked to pay damages. Huawei is fighting back against US export restrictions and is seeking to monetize its US patents, which could cost the firm US$30 billion in revenue annually. The company has also sued the US government over its defence law and is demanding licensing fees from US carrier Verizon.

site_title: Lean net imports drag Singapore fuel oil inventories to 3-week low
summary: Singapore's fuel oil inventories fell to a three-week low, reaching 22.837 million barrels, due to record low Western inflows. Net imports decreased 25% from the previous week to 339,000 tonnes, the lowest since May. Fuel oil inventories are expected to remain under pressure in the coming weeks, with arbitrage arrivals forecasted to remain low. This is attributed to record low Western inflows and high demand in East Asia.

site_title: Cabin crew urge Taiwan's Eva Air to resume talks amid week-long strike
summary: Taiwan's Eva Air cabin crew have been on strike for a week, cancelling hundreds of international flights. The strike, the longest in aviation history in Taiwan, has led to a revenue loss of about NT$1.34 billion. The union representing the flight attendants made concessions on demands, urging the airline to restart negotiations. Eva Air has filed lawsuits against the union, seeking a daily compensation of NT$34 million. The strike has disrupted flights to destinations in Asia, North America, and Europe, with nearly 300 flights cancelled since June 20.

site_title: Selegie Centre buyer seeks approval to build hotel
summary: Peak Tower Corporation, the buyer of Selegie Centre in Singapore, is seeking approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) to build a 175-180 room microhotel on the site. The proposal was initially rejected in March but the developer has submitted an appeal and amended plans. The hotel will feature a motorized bus turntable and a 40-seater coach bay to accommodate tourist customers. If approved, Peak Tower plans to partner with Hilton and Marriott to operate the hotel. The sale of Selegie Centre was completed in March for S$120 million.

site_title: Macron rules out changing French stake in Renault-Nissan
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has ruled out changing the cross-shareholding structure between Renault SA and Nissan Motor Co, citing the need to protect big companies and their employees. Macron stated that the current 15% stake held by the French government in Renault and Nissan's 15% stake in the French company without voting rights is "part of history" and will not be reviewed. This decision comes as the two companies face an open struggle for power since the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn, and amid efforts to repair their troubled alliance.

site_title: Crab Special
summary: Ministry of Crab, a renowned Sri Lankan restaurant, returns to Singapore for a two-night pop-up at the Shangri-la Hotel Singapore, ending on June 28. Chef-owner Dharshan Munidasa's five-course menu features Sri Lankan crabs and lake prawns, including pepper crab, crab liver pate, and baked crab risotto. The pop-up is priced at S$188 per person and can be reserved by calling 6213 4398 or emailing dining.sls@shangrila.com. This marks the second appearance of Ministry of Crab in Singapore, following its listing in Asia's 50Best Restaurants list.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka's star restaurant.

site_title: US jury rules that Huawei stole trade secrets from company founded by ex-employee
summary: A US jury has ruled that Huawei stole trade secrets from CNEX Labs Inc., a company co-founded by a former Huawei employee. The jury found that Huawei, but not its US research unit, had stolen CNEX trade secrets, and awarded no damages to the startup. The verdict rejected Huawei's claims that it was the victim and could provide ammunition to critics who say the company does not play by the rules in the global technology playground. Huawei has stated that it is evaluating the verdict, which comes amid a trade conflict between the US and China and ongoing criminal indictment against the company in the US.

site_title: Many things not to 'like' about Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency
summary: Facebook's proposed Libra cryptocurrency has sparked concerns over its impact on financial systems and stability. The global digital currency, backed by a reserve of real assets, could disrupt traditional banking systems and create new risks, including monetary instability and concentrated power. Regulators must assess the technical stability, openness to fraud, and potential for abuse, particularly given Facebook's questionable track record of responsibility. The Libra system's potential to usurp traditional banks and create a global, Facebook-dominated mono-bank raises significant concerns.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vibrant Group is in talks to dispose of Chinese coal miner Blackgold International Holdings due to the company's inability to provide complete financial statements. Vibrant posted a net profit of S$13 million in FY2019, while Epicentre Holdings faces financial risk if it must immediately repay a S$2 million loan tied to executive chairman Kenneth Lim's control. Boardroom Limited's takeover offer by Salacca has been extended to July 12, and Innopac Holdings has had its appeal for more time to satisfy listing requirements rejected by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Panellists say South-east Asia entrepreneurship poised to grow
summary: South-east Asia's entrepreneurial ecosystem is poised for growth, according to panellists at Innovfest Unbound 2019. Despite existing challenges, the region has fertile ground for entrepreneurship, with local companies developing cutting-edge technologies. The region is expected to become a major world economy, with Bukalapak co-founder Fajrin Rasyid predicting a significant increase in local entrepreneurs and tech talent. Experts emphasize the need for industry players to invest in digital skills and address potential challenges, such as global uncertainties and trade spats.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) announced a lease agreement with Google Asia Pacific for 344,100 sq ft of space at Alexandra Technopark, increasing occupancy to 93.7% and boosting FY2020-2021 DPU by 4.3-7.5%. Wing Tai Holdings (Wing Tai) is trading at a low forward price-to-book ratio, indicating a good position to weather residential headwinds, despite macro headwinds.

site_title: Milk Bar Revival
summary: A new diner, Capitol Milk Bar, has opened at the Capitol Kempinski in Singapore, reviving the classic Magnolia Snack Bar experience from the 1960s. The new diner retains its retro vibe with vintage posters, neon lights, and comfortable seating. Menu items are named after notable visitors to the Capitol Theatre, including Charlie Chaplin and Ava Gardner. The diner offers a range of milkshakes, sundaes, burgers, and hotdogs, including unique options like the Charlie Chaplin burger and Ava Gardner shrimp-filled brioche roll.

images.alt_text: Interior of Magnolia Snack Bar at Capitol.
Left: Capitol Milk Bar is where the old Magonolia Snack Bar used to be. Right: Stamford Burger, a fun take on the Ramly burger.
Left: Classic New Yorker hot dog. Right: Strike Me Pink Strawberry Milkshake, Milo Dino Milkshake and Nutella Milkshake.
Old school lollies and jellies.

site_title: Two's Company
summary: Singapore-based brands and designers collaborated on innovative projects. Supermama partnered with Lee Xin Li to create colorful porcelain plates featuring Singaporean icons. YTL Hotels and The Paper Bunny launched a collection of stylish totes, toiletries bags, and notebooks inspired by Pangkor Laut Resort. RE:ERTH, kāi, and Nodspark teamed up to create a beauty travel set for healthy skin and glamorous nails. Meanwhile, Supermama and Daisaku Sasage collaborated on a smaller, stainless steel coffee pot inspired by Singaporean kopitiam coffee pots. Other collaborations include Ministry of Design's Code, a leather accessory collection that can be assembled in various ways, and Choo Yilin and Scene Shang's lacquer jewelry boxes.

site_title: Now is not the time to cut interest rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates in the near future due to strong economic indicators, including elevated business sentiment, consumer confidence, and a low unemployment rate. Despite a potential fall-out from the US-China trade conflict, cutting rates would be seen as preemptive and potentially politically motivated, and could lead to moral hazard problems, undermine the Fed's credibility, and reduce its ability to respond to future economic downturns. The Fed's data-driven approach suggests that rates should remain steady, and any rate cut would be viewed as a market-driven decision rather than a response to economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Should the Fed cut interest rates in response to political pressure, it could dramatically undermine the Fed's credibility and even hurt the US dollar's status as a global reserve currency.

site_title: Spanish court rules Deliveroo riders are employees
summary: A Spanish court ruled that Deliveroo riders are employees, not self-employed contractors, in a ruling that could have implications for the gig economy. The decision affects 97 riders in Valencia, Spain, and is part of a larger dispute between Deliveroo and other gig economy groups over worker classification. The ruling could lead to increased costs for Deliveroo and potentially set a precedent for similar cases in other countries.

site_title: Nissan to cancel Ghosn's retirement, stock-linked compensation
summary: Nissan Motor Co has cancelled compensation benefits for former chairman Carlos Ghosn, including 4.44 billion yen (S$55.8 million) in retirement benefits and a 2.27 billion yen share-price-linked plan. The move comes as part of Nissan's efforts to distance itself from Ghosn after his arrest on charges of financial misconduct. Ghosn's total compensation reached 1.65 billion yen in the latest fiscal year, with 404 million yen paid to CEO Hiroto Saikawa, who has also agreed to return half of his compensation.

site_title: Property deals, smart estates stand to gain from tech
summary: Singapore is reviewing its Electronic Transactions Act to include the use of blockchain and smart contracts, aiming to foster business innovation and a trusted environment for digital transactions. The review includes plans to remove real estate transactions and trade bills of lading from the list of documents requiring hard copy. The changes are expected to reduce transaction periods and paperwork, while also supporting global electronic transferable records. The review also aims to update standards for electronic signatures and cover new technologies like blockchain and biometrics.

site_title: Drum It Up
summary: Indonesian filmmaker Garin Nugroho is set to direct the first large-scale theatrical commission by the Esplanade for its annual Pesta Raya. The epic musical, "The Prince And The Drum," tells the story of Prince Fatih's self-discovery journey through Southeast Asian percussion music. The production features 40 performers playing various instruments, including the kompang and jidur, and premieres at the Esplanade Theatre on June 29.

site_title: Can Trump beat the economy? It's all murky in the crystal ball
summary: US President Trump's re-election prospects are tied to the state of the economy, which has become the longest in US history, surpassing the record of 120 months set in the 1990s. If the economy remains strong, Trump's chances of re-election would be enhanced, but a mild recession could devalue his claim to economic control. Trump is building a Plan B, blaming the Federal Reserve for economic falters, and is attacking Fed Chairman Jerome Powell for raising interest rates too soon. The economy is sending contradictory messages, making it difficult to predict its future, and the outcome of the next presidential election may depend on the economy's performance.

site_title: SGX revamps to drive growth in multiple asset classes
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced a major reshuffle to drive growth in multiple asset classes. The move, led by CEO Loh Boon Chye, aims to capitalize on SGX's strengths in international multi-asset exchanges. Four business units will report to him, including Fixed Income, Currencies and Commodities, Equities, Data, Connectivity and Indices, and Global Sales and Origination. The exchange plans to expand in growth areas, achieve scale and efficiency in established markets, and enhance customer-centric delivery of investment and risk management solutions. The changes are seen as a forward-looking move to capture growth opportunities beyond equities and equities derivatives.

site_title: Eurozone bond yields rise on hopes of US-China truce
summary: Eurozone bond yields rose on Thursday due to mounting optimism for a US-China trade war resolution, prompting investors to sell safe-haven assets. German bond yields reached their highest levels in a week, with the 10-year yield reaching -0.278% and the 30-year yield at 0.30%. This surge is attributed to hopes for a trade deal ahead of the G-20 summit, with US President Trump stating a possible truce this weekend. The European Central Bank's potential introduction of a second round of quantitative easing is also being closely watched.

site_title: The Future Of Singapore Food
summary: A new generation of young Singaporean chefs, such as Chef Gan Ming Kiat of Mustard Seed, are redefining the country's culinary scene by creating their own interpretation of local cuisine. Despite being caught between traditional hawker food and fine dining restaurants run by expat chefs, these chefs aim to showcase Singapore's unique flavors and ingredients. With the help of mentors and initiatives like Magic Square, these chefs are pushing the boundaries of modern Singaporean cuisine, incorporating new ideas and techniques while staying true to their heritage.

site_title: Thomas Beattie
summary: Thomas Beattie, a serial entrepreneur, credits his discipline and sacrifice from playing professional soccer for his business success. After a devastating injury in 2015, he transitioned from sports to startups, co-founding Ovvy, a household services app, and investing in multiple startups. Beattie prioritizes finding the right people with the right skill set and values, such as hard work, passion, and sacrifice. He has no formal business education but relies on his athletic experience to guide his decision-making, including his regular 3am work sessions and emphasis on finding the "right people" to drive his ventures.

site_title: Carmaker PSA to decide on new Ellesmere work after final Brexit terms
summary: French carmaker PSA plans to build its next-generation Astra model in two European plants: one in Russelsheim, Germany, and the other in Ellesmere Port, UK. The decision for Ellesmere Port will depend on the final terms of the UK's Brexit exit and the acceptance of the New Vehicle Agreement. A final decision is expected to be made after these terms are confirmed.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$2b in developing electric vehicles in Indonesia
summary: Toyota plans to invest US$2 billion in developing electric vehicles in Indonesia over the next four years, starting with hybrid vehicles. The move is part of Toyota's goal to have half its global sales from electric vehicles by 2025. Indonesia is seen as a prime EV investment destination due to its abundant nickel reserves and government support. This investment follows other foreign carmakers, such as Hyundai and Mitsubishi, which have also committed to producing electric vehicles in the country.

site_title: Nissan, Dongfeng in talks to form fleet-management venture with Didi
summary: Nissan Motor Co and its Chinese partner Dongfeng Group are in talks with Didi Chuxing to launch a joint venture to manage car fleets for Didi's ride-hailing and car-sharing services in 12 Chinese cities. The venture would supply battery-powered, potentially driverless vehicles tailored to Didi's needs, helping Nissan meet China's electric vehicle production quotas. The partnership aims to address challenges in convincing consumers of electric cars' merits and meeting government subsidies' rollbacks.

site_title: Ecclestone proposes blueprint for F1 revival
summary: Former Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone proposes a blueprint to revive the sport, including the reintroduction of refuelling, equal engine allocation to all teams, and a new third world championship category. Ecclestone aims to address the sport's declining appeal, citing Mercedes' dominance and Lewis Hamilton's supremacy as key factors. His plan seeks to inject unpredictability and variety back into the sport, which has become a 'turn-off' for fans.

site_title: UK lawmakers seek to block no-deal Brexit by stopping government funds
summary: UK lawmakers plan to block a no-deal Brexit by amending finance legislation to cut off government funds unless parliament ratifies a deal or agrees to leave without a deal. The move, led by former Conservative Attorney General Dominic Grieve and Labour's Margaret Beckett, aims to deny funds to certain departments unless a deal is in place. Senior lawmaker Ken Clarke also supports the bid, citing the need for parliamentary consent before taking the UK out of the EU. The government has described the move as "grossly irresponsible."

site_title: Singtel, M1 bag public 5G trial projects
summary: Singapore's mobile network operators Singtel and M1 have been awarded pilot projects for public trials on industrial 5G uses, specifically smart port trials with state-owned operator PSA. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) made the announcement, with two projects awarded to the two operators.

site_title: SMEs optimistic for H2, but less than past years
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are cautiously optimistic about the third and fourth quarters of 2019, with the SBF-Experian SME Index rising to 50.8, up from 50.4 in the previous quarter. The overall sentiment has improved in all sectors except commerce and trading. This marks a gloomier outlook than previous second halves, but still indicates that companies expect business to improve in the next six months.

site_title: Air India plane makes emergency landing in UK after hoax bomb threat
summary: An Air India passenger plane flying from Mumbai to the US made an emergency landing in London after a hoax bomb threat call was made to Mumbai airport. The Boeing 777-337 was escorted by British fighter jets and landed safely at London Stansted Airport. There was no security threat, and the plane was directed to an isolated stand with police. The runway reopened after the precautionary landing, and British police were making inquiries. The incident occurred on June 27, 2019.

site_title: Vibrant evaluating disposal of Blackgold unit, posts FY2019 net profit
summary: Vibrant Group is evaluating the disposal of Chinese coal miner Blackgold International Holdings due to accounting irregularities and falsified accounts. A special audit report found Blackgold had grossly inflated sales figures and fictitious mining fees, leading to a net loss of S$93.1 million in FY2018. Vibrant's FY2019 net profit of S$13 million was driven by a drop in other operating expenses and increased revenue, mainly from the Master-Riviera Project in China. The group is in discussions with "relevant parties" to resolve the matter.

site_title: Singapore sets sights on being 5G innovation hub
summary: Singapore has pledged S$40 million to fund research and innovation in 5G applications, aiming to become a global hub for secure 5G services. The initial funding will focus on six clusters: maritime operations, urban mobility, smart estates, manufacturing, public sector applications, and consumer sector. A public 5G open test-bed will be set up at the Infocomm Media Development Authority's Pixel facility, and cyber security will be a key area of research. The government aims to develop resilient 5G networks integral to national security and create up to 10,000 tech jobs in three years.

site_title: As virtual banking looms in Singapore, incumbents must prove digital mettle
summary: Virtual banking is set to arrive in Singapore, prompting incumbents to adapt. Analysts warn that simply reducing costs is not enough; they must actively grow their top lines through digital means. The key issues are how incumbents utilize technology to boost revenue and the sustainability of efficiency gains from digitalization. To fend off large fintechs, incumbents must demonstrate their ability to innovate and drive growth, rather than just cutting costs.

images.alt_text: MAS says it is still reviewing whether to issue virtual bank licences to fintech firms in Singapore.

site_title: Good Scents
summary: A new fragrance store, Amaris, aims to break down the barrier of luxury perfumes by offering an open concept experience, allowing customers to smell various scents. Edouard Dorize, business development manager of Aura Prestige, believes that the only way to find a fragrance is to smell multiple options, similar to wine appreciation. The store, launched in Singapore last December, seeks to educate customers about the world of fragrances, making it more accessible to those intimidated by prices and exclusive stores.

site_title: Japan warns UK PM rivals: No-deal Brexit could end investment honeymoon
summary: Japan's Foreign Minister Taro Kono warned UK's new Prime Minister that a no-deal Brexit could disrupt 35 years of Japanese investment in Britain, potentially ending the "honeymoon period". Kono urged both Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt to avoid a no-deal Brexit, citing concerns from companies like carmakers Nissan, Toyota, and Honda. Japan has invested over £60 billion in Britain and some firms are already moving operations out of the country due to concerns over tariffs, customs delays, and new bureaucracy.

site_title: Indonesia court rejects appeal against Jokowi's re-election
summary: Indonesia's Constitutional Court has unanimously upheld President Joko Widodo's re-election, rejecting a petition by challenger Prabowo Subianto that disputed the official result. The court cited a lack of evidence to dismiss Subianto's appeal, ending months of political uncertainty. The ruling allows Widodo to focus on economic reforms, particularly in the face of the US-China trade war, and is seen as a step towards healing the country's divide. Widodo is set to be sworn in for a second five-year term in October with an increased coalition majority in parliament.

site_title: India beats US in WTO renewables case
summary: World Trade Organisation judges have sided with India in a dispute against the US over subsidies for renewable energy companies. India had complained that US states provided unfair benefits to American producers, which discriminate against foreign companies. The US can appeal, but a prolonged period of legal limbo is likely due to a WTO appellate body crisis caused by the Trump administration's refusal to approve new judges. A decision cannot be delivered before a December deadline, potentially casting the case into limbo.

site_title: BASF to cut 6,000 jobs to drive down costs amid slowdown
summary: BASF, a German chemical company, is cutting 6,000 jobs worldwide to reduce costs amid a slowdown in demand for chemicals used in industries like cars and electronics. The move is expected to generate 300 million euros in savings and help the company achieve a 2 billion-euro earnings boost. CEO Martin Brudermueller aims to simplify the company and focus on higher-margin products by working closely with customers. The restructuring is part of a broader effort to adapt to changing markets and reduce interfaces within the organization.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.79 points lower to 1,672.70 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 1.8 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 369 to 350.

site_title: Second Chance Properties Q3 net profit up 12.5% to S$2.34m
summary: Second Chance Properties, a Mainboard-listed company, reported a 12.5% increase in net profit to S$2.34 million for the third quarter ended May 31, 2019. Revenue rose 2.6% to S$9.96 million, driven by an 18.3% rise in revenue from the apparels business and a 3.6% rise in revenue from the gold business. The company also recorded a smaller loss on fair valuation of financial assets. An interim dividend of 0.4 Singapore cent per ordinary share was declared, payable on July 15.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close higher ahead of G-20
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on June 27, 2019, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.19% and the Topix index rising 1.23%. The gains were attributed to a halt in the yen's appreciation, ahead of the Group of 20 summit and key US-China trade talks.

site_title: Airlines urge regulators to work together to return 737 MAX to service
summary: Airlines worldwide are urging regulators to coordinate on measures to bring the grounded 737 MAX jetliner back into service, amid a new technical glitch and supplier concerns. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) called for global alignment on technical requirements and timelines, citing the need for coordinated efforts to restore public confidence. The grounding of over 300 MAX jets and a delivery halt has caused cancellations and high leasing bills, with airlines warning of potential disruptions beyond the end of the summer period.

site_title: India regulator tightens rules for pledged shares, mutual funds
summary: India's market regulator, SEBI, has tightened rules for pledged shares and mutual funds to protect minority shareholders and retail investors. Promoters must disclose reasons for pledging shares above 20% of the total share capital or 50% of their shareholding. SEBI also capped royalty payments to related parties and ordered companies to get shareholder approval for payments above a certain threshold. The regulator tightened risk management and prudential norms for liquid mutual funds to protect retail investors, including requiring at least 20% in liquid assets.

site_title: US GDP first-quarter growth unrevised at 3.1%
summary: The US economy experienced a 3.1% annualized growth rate in the first quarter, unchanged from its previous estimate. Despite this, domestic demand weakened, with consumer spending revised down to a 0.9% rate and business investment on equipment declining at a 1.0% rate. The trade deficit narrowed, and inventories contributed less to GDP than initially reported. The Federal Reserve signals interest rate cuts as early as July due to rising economic risks, particularly from the ongoing US-China trade conflict.

images.alt_text: US economic growth accelerated in the first quarter, the government confirmed on Thursday, but the export and inventory boost to activity masked weakness in domestic demand, some of which appears to have prevailed in the current quarter.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific acquires retail building in Tokyo for 6b yen
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings acquired a retail building in Tokyo's Ginza district for 6 billion yen (S$75.7 million), excluding consumption tax. The purchase is made through a unit of Nigella SG, a newly-acquired investment holdings and property investment firm. Roxy-Pacific's wholly-owned subsidiary RPV Two Pte Ltd acquired 53.07% of Nigella SG for 1.1 billion yen, with the rest owned by TE2 Development and other investors. The acquisition's cost will be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings.

site_title: India says present business environment not good for Air India sale
summary: India's junior civil aviation minister, Hardeep Singh Puri, stated that the current economic environment is not suitable for the sale of Air India in the "immediate near future" due to volatile crude prices and exchange rate fluctuations. The government plans to revisit the sale once global economic indicators stabilize.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally more than 1%
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged over 1% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism ahead of a key meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.42%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also increased. The rally is seen as a positive sign for the ongoing trade war resolution, with investors hoping for progress.

site_title: Innopac's appeal for more time to exit financial criteria watch-list rejected
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Innopac Holdings' appeal for more time to exit the financial criteria watch-list. Innopac will provide updates on its exit offer proposal by July 4, 2019. The company has been on the watch-list since June 3, 2016.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at open on tech boost
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains in technology shares, despite uncertainty over the outcome of a key US-China G20 meeting on trade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose slightly, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.20% and 0.37%, respectively. Despite the slight increase, investors remained cautious due to the lack of clarity on the trade talks outcome.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday, lifted by gains in technology shares, ahead of a key G20 meeting where the United States and China will discuss trade but lack of clarity on the outcome kept investors on the sidelines

site_title: South Korea: Stocks finish higher on trade truce expectations
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index closed 0.59% higher at 2,134.34 on Thursday, driven by expectations of a US-China trade truce and chipmakers' gains after Micron Technology reported a demand recovery. The KOSPI has risen 4.57% this year, with chip shares extending their rally. Analysts attributed the gains to Micron's output cut, which boosted chip shares.

site_title: Ford to cut 12,000 jobs in Europe by end of 2020
summary: Ford plans to cut 12,000 jobs in Europe by the end of 2020 to return the business to profit amidst stagnant demand and record investments in low-emission vehicles. The company has ceased production at three Russian plants, closed plants in France and Wales, and reduced shifts at factories in Spain and Germany. These cost reductions aim to streamline model portfolios and overcome the challenges of investing in electric, hybrid, and autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, will review its 2019 economic growth forecast due to the US-China trade war, expecting a weaker Q2. The MAS managing director, Ravi Menon, stated that the government will maintain its property cooling measures, but the market has become more sober. The government will invest S$40m in 5G innovation and restructure the stock exchange, SGX. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.8% on Thursday on Sino-US trade truce optimism.

site_title: Closing date of offer for Boardroom extended to July 12
summary: The closing date of Salacca's S$0.88 per share exit offer for Boardroom has been extended to July 12, 5:30 pm. As of June 27, 88.13% of Boardroom shares are controlled or set to be acquired by Salacca. Boardroom has also announced its intention to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange's mainboard due to a free float drop below 10%. A substantial shareholder has given an irrevocable undertaking to vote in favor of the delisting if any shareholder meetings are convened.

site_title: Controversial South America-Europe trade deal 'up in the air'
summary: A contentious trade deal between the EU and South American trade bloc Mercosur remains uncertain, with key negotiators locked in talks over the highly sensitive beef market. Despite "constructive exchanges," the deal's future is uncertain, with opposition in Europe and cracks among European governments. Pro-trade members, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, support the deal, citing economic benefits, while anti-trade groups, including beef farmers, demand an immediate halt to talks due to Brazil's deforestation. The EU hopes to seal the deal before the end of the current commission's term later this year.

site_title: Epicentre's ability to operate as going concern likely hit if forced to repay loan
summary: Epicentre Holdings faces a material impact on its ability to continue as a going concern if it is forced to repay a S$2 million loan owed to Julique Capital. The loan is tied to executive chairman Kenneth Lim's control of subsidiary Epicentre Pte Ltd. After discovering Lim's reduced shareholding in the group, Epicentre must notify Julique Capital, potentially triggering immediate loan repayment. This development raises concerns about the company's financial stability.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.8% on Thursday on Sino-US trade truce optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reversed losses and gained 0.8% on Thursday, driven by optimism over a US-China trade truce ahead of the G-20 summit. The truce was seen as a positive development, with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin suggesting a trade deal was 90% complete. However, experts warned investors not to be overly optimistic, citing the unpredictability of US President Donald Trump. Financials and tech stocks led the gains, with DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and Micron Technology rising.

site_title: Europe: Equities advance at open with focus on G20
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, driven by optimism over potential framework agreements on US-China trade talks at the G20 summit. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 added 0.5%, and Paris' CAC 40 won 0.1%. Analysts attribute the gains to expectations of progress in trade talks, which may alleviate market concerns about the ongoing trade war between the US and China.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, with all eyes on the Group of 20 summit and key trade talks between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping.

site_title: Nico Steel gets 1-year extension to exit SGX watch list
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted Nico Steel Holdings a one-year extension to exit the bourse's watch list by September 4, 2020, after the metals supplier demonstrated healthier cash flow. Nico Steel reported a pre-tax profit of US$469,000 for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2019, and a positive operating cash flow of US$798,000. The company had initially been placed on the watch list in 2016 with a deadline of September 4, 2019.

site_title: Challenger calls for 2nd trading halt, corrects EGM resolution notice
summary: Challenger Technologies, a consumer electronics retailer, has issued a regulatory update after a second trade halt on June 27, 2019. The company corrected an error in its previous announcement stating that its voluntary delisting resolution had passed, when it actually did not. The delisting failed due to 11.36% of shareholders voting against the resolution, rendering the exit offer invalid and preventing the offeror from making another offer for 12 months.

site_title: S-E Asia a good region to build tech, entrepreneurial ecosystem: panellists
summary: S-E Asia is an attractive region for building an entrepreneurial ecosystem, according to panellists at Innovfest Unbound 2019. The region has 600 million people with existing problems to be addressed, allowing entrepreneurs to bloom. Key industries are seeing growth, including tech talent, with multinational companies bringing skills to the region. However, challenges such as tensions between the US and China must be addressed, and regional companies are poised to solve regional problems, adding value to technological solutions.

site_title: US apartment vacancy rate flat at 4.7% in Q2: research firm
summary: The US apartment vacancy rate remained flat at 4.7% in Q2, according to research firm Reis Inc. Vacancy rates rose in 26 of 79 metros, while existing home sales have fluctuated at higher levels than 2018. The national average asking rent and effective rent increased 4.3% each in Q2. Despite low net absorption and new construction levels, the apartment market is expected to add more units than last year, with construction slowing in 2020.

site_title: India faces weak monsoon rains, raising fears for crops, economy
summary: India is facing below-average monsoon rains, with 24% less rainfall than the 50-year average, raising concerns about crop production and the economy. The monsoon is crucial for India's farm output and economic growth, with about 55% of arable land relying on rain-fed agriculture. If the rains don't improve, India could face a crisis, impacting crop harvests and rural demand, with companies vulnerable to losses. The sowing of summer crops has been delayed, and farmers are praying for normal monsoon rains to avoid a repeat of the 2018 drought.

site_title: Gojek appoints chief data officer as super app rivals zero in on data science
summary: Gojek appoints Gautam Kotwal as group chief data officer to manage the company's overall data strategy and teams across various business intelligence, data engineering, and data science functions. The move comes as the ride-hailing giant and rival Grab intensify their focus on data science to pursue super app ambitions in South-east Asia. This strategic appointment is part of Gojek's efforts to strengthen its data science capabilities, following the hiring of Leslie Teo, former chief economist of GIC, to work on data science at Grab.

site_title: Australia's Scentre sells Sydney office towers for A$1.5 billion
summary: Australia's Scentre Group sold its Sydney office towers for A$1.52 billion to US-based private equity firm Blackstone Group. The sale also included a 299-year leasehold interest. The deal will result in a dilution of 0.4 cents per security to funds from operations in 2019, but the forecast distribution remains unchanged at 22.60 cents per security. Scentre also announced an A$800 million share buyback program.

site_title: China urges US to cancel sanctions on Huawei as Trump-Xi meeting looms
summary: China urges the US to cancel sanctions on Huawei, a commerce ministry spokesman said, as US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to meet for talks on trade. The US has put Huawei on an export blacklist, citing national security issues, while Huawei denies its products pose a security threat. China opposes the US abuse of export controls and urges cooperation, warning that it would consider designating foreign firms as "unreliable" if they adopt discriminatory measures against Chinese entities. A possible trade deal could be reached at their meeting in Japan.

site_title: ASEAN offers silver lining as dark clouds hover over the horizon
summary: ASEAN is emerging as a growth engine despite global economic uncertainties, including US-China tensions and Brexit. The region has consistently outperformed the world economy since 2000, driven by a large and youthful population, rapid technology adoption, and modernized payment systems. The rollout of 5G is expected to further boost growth, enabling businesses to innovate and increase financial inclusion. Supply chain reconfiguration in favor of ASEAN is also expected to have a positive impact, with companies diversifying their operations to avoid US tariffs.

site_title: Grab gets additional US$300m in funding from Invesco
summary: Grab secures US$300 million in additional funding from Invesco, bringing the total investment to US$703 million. This funding will help Grab expand its financial services and mobility-enabled services businesses, solidifying its position as a South-east Asia technology leader. Grab has now raised US$6.5 billion in total capital between June 2018 and the end of this year, with earlier investments including US$1.46 billion from the SoftBank Vision Fund.

site_title: Hot Stocks: Singapore tech stocks up after Micron Q3 profit guidance beat forecasts
summary: Singapore-listed technology stocks rebounded on Thursday after Micron Technology posted stronger-than-expected earnings guidance for the third quarter. The chipmaker's shares surged 13.3% on Tuesday, boosting sentiment among tech stocks in Singapore. Venture Corporation, Hi-P International, UMS Holdings, and AEM Holdings also saw gains, with some analysts attributing the rally to hopes that Micron's guidance could influence other companies to beat expectations.

site_title: Singapore to review 2019 growth forecast as trade war bites; weaker Q2 expected: MAS
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, plans to review the country's 2019 economic growth forecast due to the impact of the US-China trade war. The forecast, initially set at 1.5-2.5%, is expected to be weaker in Q2, with a global slowdown partly caused by trade tensions. The review comes after Maybank Kim Eng Research predicted a "shallow technical recession" in the third quarter. The MAS has left its policy settings unchanged, but a revised forecast may be necessary if the economy shows further signs of weakness.

site_title: SGX in 10th spot globally by IPO proceeds for Q2
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) took 10th place globally by IPO proceeds for the second quarter of 2019, primarily due to two sizeable real estate investment trust (Reit) IPOs. The Reits raised US$1.0 billion in proceeds, with SGX accounting for 61% of IPO proceeds in the Asean region. Global IPO activity fell 12% by volume to 266 IPOs and 27% by proceeds to US$22.3 billion year to date, with Asia-Pacific dominating global IPO activity. The global IPO market is showing continued signs of a slowdown despite the entry of unicorn IPOs.

site_title: Osaka rolls out red carpet, not red-light district for G20
summary: Osaka, Japan, is preparing to host the G20 leaders summit by showcasing its modern amenities and unique culture. The city has introduced special toilets, a granny rap video, and G20-themed dishes, such as takoyaki with garnishes from participating nations. Even local brothels have closed temporarily to maintain a "squeaky clean" image. With 32,000 police officers and 60 coastguard ships deployed, the city is taking measures to ensure safety and security during the summit, which is expected to attract around 30,000 officials and journalists.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,325.01, up 0.72% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.72% on Thursday, led by a tentative truce between the US and China ahead of their G-20 summit. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,325.01, with DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank gaining 1.9% and 1.4%, respectively. Other Asian markets, including China, South Korea, and Hong Kong, also saw gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 186 to 124 on the Singapore bourse, with banking stocks and TEE International advancing.

site_title: Slumbering FX confounds traders, prompts fear of rude awakening
summary: Currency markets are experiencing a period of listlessness, with the head of European foreign exchange sales at Nomura stating that there's no point in calling clients due to the lack of exchange rate swings. This has led to a shift in focus towards other investment opportunities, such as bonds. The quiet markets have also raised concerns about the potential for a "rude awakening" for investors.

site_title: Attilan inks MOU to buy family entertainment content producer; to seek shareholders' nod for transfer to Catalist
summary: ATTILAN Group has signed a non-binding MOU with Tremendous Opportunity Fund I LP to acquire family entertainment content producer Tremendous Entertainment Group (TEG) for S$100 million. The acquisition will be funded by cash and new Attilan shares, with the deal classified as a "very substantial" or "reverse takeover" according to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) listing manual. Attilan will seek shareholder approval for the acquisition and transfer from the mainboard to the Catalist board, with the deal expected to move the group's business towards family entertainment content and improve financial growth and investor interest.

site_title: Bukit Timah's Juniper Hill to open for sale from July 13; prices start from S$1.6m
summary: Bukit Timah's Juniper Hill condo is set to open for sale on July 13, with prices starting from S$1.6 million for a two-bedroom unit and S$6.1 million for a five-bedroom unit. Units range from 581 to 2,217 square feet, with prices ranging from S$2,600 to S$2,900 per square foot. The 12-storey, 115-unit development features two and three-bedroom apartments, as well as five units on the top floor, offering buyers a range of options in the Bukit Timah area.

site_title: Challenger's voluntary delisting blocked by 11.36% vote; exit offer to lapse
summary: Challenger Technologies' voluntary delisting attempt failed after 11.36% of shareholders voted against the resolution, blocking the exit offer.
