Both cities have made significant investments in technology and research, with Singapore launching its National Technology Plan in 1991 and Hong Kong establishing the Innovation and Technology Bureau in 2001. They are also attracting talent and investment, with Singapore's forward-thinking institutional environment and Hong Kong's Quality Migrant Admission Scheme. The competition between the two cities highlights the importance of innovation and collaboration in driving economic growth.

site_title: Indian builders woo buyers with cleaner, greener, smart homes
summary: Indian builders are offering cleaner, greener, and smart homes to attract the growing urban middle-class in a slow property market. With aging infrastructure and pollution, buyers are seeking amenities such as open green spaces, drinkable tap water, and oxygen generators. As a result, developers are adding these features to their projects, often at the expense of profit margins, which have decreased to 8-12% from 25-30% previously. The trend is driven by legislation and environmentally conscious young buyers, and is expected to continue as cities struggle with water crises and pollution.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) has seen its share price balloon 22.3% in the year up to June 21, driven by a flight to defensive safe names and a dovish US Federal Reserve bias. This has compressed its estimated FY2019 distribution yield to 4.3% (4.2% according to Bloomberg).

site_title: International Cement fails to get SGX nod to buy African cement producer Schwenk Namibia
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected International Cement Group's (ICG) US$104.4 million purchase of Schwenk Namibia due to the target company not being profitable and ICG lacking sufficient cash for the acquisition. The deal was deemed a very substantial acquisition (VSA) under SGX's rulebook. As a result, ICG will need to implement four new safeguards before attempting another acquisition.

site_title: Cambodian official sacked over building collapse which killed 28
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen sacked Deputy Director of the National Committee on Disaster Management Nhim Vanda over a building collapse in Sihanoukville that killed 28 people. The seven-storey building, under construction by a Chinese company, crumpled without warning, trapping workers. Hun Sen also accepted the resignation of the governor of Preah Sihanouk province. Four people, including three Chinese nationals, have been detained for questioning, and an investigation into the accident is ongoing. The collapse has raised concerns about construction standards in the area.

site_title: Singaporeans willing to pay more for 5G mobile services: poll
summary: Singaporeans are willing to pay up to S$25 extra per month for 5G mobile services, representing a 52% increase over current plans. The median expected data consumption is 90GB per month, 25 times what users currently use. About one-fifth of users plan to switch telcos if 5G services aren't available within six months of launch. Singapore's 5G network is expected to be available by next year, with wide-scale deployment anticipated from 2023.

site_title: Big Brother is watching you at work - and his name is AI
summary: The use of artificial intelligence (AI) in workplaces, particularly in call centers and other industries, has raised concerns over its potential impact on workers. Companies such as MetLife and Amazon are using AI to track worker productivity, provide real-time feedback, and even automate managerial tasks. This has led to criticism that AI is being used to dehumanize and unfairly punish employees, with some workers feeling like they are being judged and monitored by an "opaque, black-box computer." Defenders argue that AI can help correct human biases in decision-making, such as in hiring, but executives must resist the temptation to use AI to tighten their grip on workers.

site_title: Serving up a whale of a time as commercial whaling restarts
summary: Japan resumes commercial whaling on July 1, with restaurants serving traditional dishes such as blubber with vinegar-miso sauce and whale nuggets. Despite a 1986 global whaling moratorium, specialty restaurants have maintained a loyal customer base, with some schools incorporating whale into their menus to teach children about traditional Japanese cuisine. Proponents argue that whale is a sustainable and nutritious food option, while critics note that it is a rare and often unappetizing food choice.

site_title: Allied Tech gets more time to hold AGM, post Q1 results amid probe into missing S$33m
summary: Allied Technologies, a Singapore-listed precision engineering firm, has received a 3.5-week extension from the Singapore Exchange to hold its annual general meeting (AGM), release Q1 results, and issue a sustainability report. The extension is due to delays in its auditors' review of management's responses and the recovery of S$33 million in missing funds held in an escrow account. The company's AGM and Q1 results announcement will now take place by July 25, and the sustainability report will be issued by July 10. Trading in Allied Tech shares remains suspended.

site_title: Zara's Indian partner is building its own cheaper fashion chain
summary: Trent Ltd, the retail arm of India's Tata Group, plans to launch 40 Westside outlets and hundreds of Zudio stores annually, offering affordable fashion options at a price point of $15 or less. The company aims to replicate Zara's fast fashion model, with a supply chain that can deliver trendy items in just 12 days, catering to India's growing middle class with increasing purchasing power. Trent's lower prices are seen as a competitive advantage, with analysts recommending the stock, which has advanced 13% this year.

site_title: Forecasting recession and recovery is a mix of science, art and timing
summary: Singapore's economy may enter a downturn next year due to the simmering US-China trade war, but accurately predicting the timing and magnitude of such a downturn remains challenging. A study found that forecasters in Singapore are typically unable to accurately capture the onset and magnitude of recessions or recoveries in a timely way. Economists attribute this to a lack of information and few incentives to depart from the consensus, as well as the externally oriented nature of Singapore's economy. To improve forecasting, economists are exploring new leading indicators and technologies such as deep data mining, artificial intelligence, and machine learning.

images.alt_text: More economists are now saying that Singapore could enter a downturn next year, as the simmering US-China trade war threatens to bubble over and affect the rest of the world.

site_title: Tear up the economics textbooks - and start again
summary: Harvard Professor N Gregory Mankiw's widely used introductory college economics textbook, "Principles of Economics," needs a major overhaul due to its outdated content. Despite having 800 pages of useful information, the book fails to address the impact of the Internet and digitalization on markets, the 2007-09 Great Recession, and other significant economic events. Mankiw's assertion that bank runs are not a major problem for the US banking system is misleading, and the book lacks attention to the global economy and emerging markets. A new edition is expected in six months, and experts recommend tearing up the existing textbooks and starting over.

site_title: Thailand marks full return to global stage after hosting fruitful Asean meet
summary: Thailand successfully hosted the 34th Asean Summit in Bangkok, marking its full return to the global stage after a decade. The summit saw the leaders of 10 Asean countries and dialogue partners, including the US and China, agree on regional initiatives on the economy and security. Key outcomes include the conclusion of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) deal and the adoption of an "Asean Outlook on the Indo-Pacific" plan. The leaders also endorsed a declaration on marine debris and pledged support for hosting the 2034 FIFA World Cup.

site_title: Trade tension 'unlikely to lead to crisis, but global economy could split'
summary: US-China trade tensions are unlikely to lead to a global financial crisis, but could cause a long-term split in the global economy, according to Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The tensions have hurt global business and consumer confidence, leading to a decline in global trade and investment, and could eventually affect jobs. Lee warned that a split in supply chains and technology could have lasting consequences, but does not foresee an immediate crisis. He emphasized the importance of rebuilding strategic trust and making small moves to build trust before addressing larger issues.

site_title: British consumer spending growth in 2019 seen being slowest in six years
summary: British consumer spending is expected to grow by 1.6% in 2019, the slowest in six years, according to EY Item Club forecasts. This growth is slower than the broader UK economy's estimated 1.3% growth. Consumer spending benefited from strong employment growth and real earnings growth in 2018 and early 2019, but the outlook has weakened due to economic uncertainties and Brexit. Employment growth is forecast to slow to 1.0% in 2019 and 0.6% in 2020. This slowdown will add pressure to high street retailers, who face changing shopping habits and online competition.

site_title: UK candidate calls Boris Johnson a coward for avoiding Brexit debates
summary: UK candidate Jeremy Hunt criticized rival Boris Johnson for avoiding a televised Brexit debate, labeling him a coward. Hunt claims he would have won the debate and the Conservative Party leadership vote if Johnson had participated. Hunt promised to deliver Brexit on October 31 with or without a deal and vowed to seek a better EU deal if necessary. Johnson reiterated his plan to leave the EU on October 31, with or without a deal, and promised lower taxes if he wins.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Hiap Seng Engineering expects to post a net loss for its fiscal fourth quarter and full year ended March 31, 2019. The company is also on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list for failing to maintain a six-month volume-weighted average trading price of 20 Singapore cents. Synagie Corporation has been appointed by the Malaysia Digital Economy Corporation as a cross-border e-commerce initiative partner. United Food Holdings' independent auditors have given a qualified opinion on the group's financial statement due to unavailability of financial information. Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has been delisted from the mainboard due to its appeal being rejected.

site_title: YuuZoo sets up Bangkok corporate centre
summary: YuuZoo Networks Group Corporation, a social commerce company, has set up a new corporate support centre in Bangkok to replace its Singapore office, which closed in March 2019. The move comes amid investigations into its finances, with shares currently suspended. The company clarified that YuuZooNow Pte Ltd, which closed its Singapore office, is not a subsidiary of YuuZoo. The new Bangkok centre will provide accounting, technology, and administrative support. The company plans to deal with the responsibilities linked to the closure once its share trading suspension is lifted.

site_title: Sembcorp-SembMarine debt deal raises some questions
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) has agreed to extend a $2 billion subordinated loan facility to its struggling subsidiary Sembcorp Marine (SMM) to strengthen its financial position amid the downturn in the global offshore and marine (O&M) industry. The deal will help SMM retire $1.5 billion of borrowings and fund working capital. While beneficial for SMM, minority shareholders of SCI may question the deal's value. The loan will increase SCI's liabilities, and there's a risk that SMM may not repay the loan if its operating performance doesn't improve significantly.

site_title: Circles.Life enters first overseas market
summary: Circles.Life, a Singapore-based telco startup, has launched its mobile services in Taiwan, marking its first overseas market. The company plans to enter Australia in the third quarter and Indonesia by year-end, but will not adopt the mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) model in Indonesia due to regulatory challenges. Circles.Life will instead partner with a licensed network operator to offer services. The company aims to expand to at least five markets by end-2020, with a focus on targeting customers who value contract-free plans and data transparency.

site_title: Indonesia defies analysts with US$207.6m trade surplus in May
summary: Indonesia's foreign trade unexpectedly swung back to a surplus in May, defying analysts' expectations of a $1.38 billion deficit. The country's trade surplus reached $207.6 million, driven by a 17.71% decline in imports and an 8.99% decline in exports. This marks a reversal from the country's largest trade deficit in April, which was partly due to rising demand for imported consumer goods before Ramadan. The improved trade data has sparked hopes for improvement in Indonesia's trade outlook despite the ongoing Sino-US trade war.

site_title: Bavaria seeks fast-track German coal exit in snub to Merkel plan
summary: Bavaria, Germany's industrial powerhouse, is pushing for a faster exit from coal, seeking a 2030 deadline, eight years before Chancellor Angela Merkel's target. Bavarian Prime Minister Markus Soeder says the current 2038 deadline is unrealistic and a more aggressive target is needed to meet Germany's 55% carbon dioxide emissions reduction goal. This challenge to Merkel's plan underlines the precariousness of the current climate policy and could lead to changes in the distribution of 40 billion euros in structural aid to coal-focused regions.

site_title: As Trump's sanctions bite, Iran's oil exports slide further in June
summary: Iran's oil exports have dropped to 300,000 barrels per day (bpd) or less in June, following US sanctions imposed in November. The US tightened sanctions in May, ending waivers for Iranian oil imports. Despite sending around 300,000 bpd of crude abroad, Iranian exports are down from 400,000-500,000 bpd in May and a fraction of 2.5 million bpd in April 2018. The sanctions are having a clear effect on Iran's ability to sell into global markets, according to oil flow tracker Kpler.

site_title: UMS Holdings' offer for JEP Holdings lapses
summary: UMS Holdings' S$0.15 per share offer and S$0.074 warrants offer for JEP Holdings has lapsed as of June 24. The resultant shareholding was 47.4% and warrants holding was 43.4%. The offer lapse does not affect the valid acceptances of the warrants offer. UMS had acquired additional shares in JEP to raise its stake to 38.8% and made a mandatory conditional cash offer and an unconditional cash offer for warrants. The independent financial adviser advised rejecting the offer and letting the warrants offer lapse.

site_title: US Fed like a 'stubborn child': Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve, calling its reluctance to cut interest rates "like a stubborn child." Despite the Fed's recent signal of potential rate cuts, Trump argued that lower rates would not boost economic growth. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell maintained the central bank's independence, saying it ignores political pressure. The US economy has shown mixed signals, with growth potentially slowing, and Trump's threat to increase tariffs on Chinese goods poses a risk to the global economy.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff has been confirmed to cover refined copper, with market implications unclear. Meanwhile, oil prices rose over 2% amid concerns over market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the Singapore stock market, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss targets. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, with US-EU tariffs in focus.

site_title: Economic expansions don't really die of old age
summary: The US economy has entered its 11th year of uninterrupted expansion, breaking the previous record for the longest period of growth without a recession. Economists argue that a recession is overdue, citing the US-China trade war and the inverted yield curve, but there is no empirical or theoretical support for the idea that expansions have a natural lifespan. In fact, US expansions since WWII have varied in length and have shown no sign of mean reversion. Advanced economies like Australia and the UK have avoided recessions for longer than the US.

site_title: Skies unlikely to clear up for some airline stocks to fly
summary: Airlines face a challenging outlook, with the European market up 14% this year, despite their poor performance. The industry is hit by a combination of a price war, high fuel costs, trade tensions, and slower global growth. Several companies have issued profit warnings, including Ryanair and Lufthansa, while HSBC analysts anticipate more profit warnings due to weakening demand trends. Despite some winners, such as Wizz Air, the sector remains vulnerable to downsides, including strikes and cargo freight sensitivity to global growth. A potential return to global growth could extend the cycle, but the short-term outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Why China's not for turning, and its tiff with the US is going to change everything
summary: US-China trade tensions are unlikely to be resolved, despite an upcoming G20 meeting between President Trump and Xi Jinping. The World Bank's forecast of 2.6% global growth in 2019 is a result of rising trade barriers and economic slowdowns. Trump's approach to controlling outcomes with China through coercion is seen as flawed, with the outcome likely to be more ups and downs. The article concludes that the US-China tiff will change everything, with a possible shift in the global economic landscape.

site_title: 'Tax us more': US billionaires
summary: About 20 US billionaires, including George Soros and Walt Disney descendants, urged presidential candidates to support higher taxes on the wealthy to address climate change and other priorities. The group, who claim the US is one of the wealthiest countries with the most income inequality, signed a letter stating that a wealth tax could help address the climate crisis and strengthen democratic freedoms. The letter expressed support for a proposal by Senator Elizabeth Warren to lift taxes on those with over $50 million in assets.

site_title: US: Stocks edge up ahead of data, G20
summary: US stocks opened modestly higher on Monday ahead of the G20 Summit, where US President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are expected to discuss their trade dispute. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 26,786.82, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1% to 2,951.64. Key data releases this week include reports on consumer confidence, GDP growth, and personal income and spending.

site_title: Foreign-based gambling sites blocked in Switzerland from July 1
summary: Switzerland will block foreign-based online gambling sites as of July 1, in an effort to combat gambling addiction. The country's 21 registered casinos and Swiss lotteries will be allowed to operate online, generating revenue for the government. The move is expected to reduce the estimated 250 million Swiss francs spent annually on unregulated betting sites abroad. The law aims to protect citizens from online gambling addiction, with the proceeds funding anti-addiction measures. The law change was approved by 73% of voters in a 2018 referendum, despite campaigners warning of internet restrictions posing a threat to liberties.

site_title: Macron urges Trump to 'clarify his position' on EU
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron urged US President Donald Trump to clarify his position on the European Union, citing ambiguities in Trump's Brexit stance and promotion of a hard Brexit. Macron stated that Trump's comments on the EU were concerning, particularly regarding NATO and trade. The comments came after recent European elections, where Macron's party finished second, and amid rising extremism in Europe. Trump had previously stated that he doesn't care about the EU and that they have taken advantage of the US. Macron's comments reflect growing tensions between the two leaders.

site_title: SGX rejects Foreland Fabrictech's appeal against delisting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Foreland Fabrictech Holdings' appeal against its delisting, with the company set to be delisted on June 28. The bourse cited the company's continued breach of listing rules, including failure to hold annual general meetings and issue annual reports, as well as its insolvent financial position. Foreland Fabrictech had requested up to three months to prepare a proposal for the resumption of trading, but SGX deemed the request unacceptable. The company's plan to expand into food processing using a convertible loan is also deemed unviable due to its financial position.

site_title: Oil climbs to a three-week high as US-Iran tensions simmer
summary: Oil prices surged to a three-week high as tensions between the US and Iran continued to simmer, with President Trump announcing plans for further sanctions against Opec member Iran. Futures added 1.4% in New York after rising 9.4% last week. The sanctions and US-Iran tensions threaten to disrupt crude flows, aiding oil prices, which have rallied after falling to the lowest level in almost five months in mid-June. West Texas Intermediate rose as much as 79 cents to $58.22 a barrel, the highest since May 30.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.1 points to 1,676.13. Losers outnumbered gainers 516 to 296, and trading volume reached 1.8 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion.

site_title: Circles.Life launches its first overseas mobile services in Taiwan
summary: Circles.Life, a Singaporean telco startup, has launched its first overseas mobile services in Taiwan, following a soft launch. The mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) will offer an app-based, no-contract plan with 18GB of mobile data. Circles.Life aims to expand into at least two more markets in 2020, with plans to spend over S$250 million in five new markets. This move comes after a Series C funding round led by Sequoia India and investments from Singapore's Economic Development Board and Silicon Valley's Founders Fund.

site_title: Suspected World War II bomb blasts crater in German field
summary: A suspected World War II bomb exploded in a field in western Germany, leaving a 10-meter wide and 4-meter deep crater. The blast occurred on Sunday morning, with no injuries reported. Authorities believe the bomb, which was likely used for target practice during WWII, had a chemical-based delayed timer. This incident highlights Germany's ongoing issue with unexploded ordnance, with nearly 75 years after the war, the country remains littered with unexploded bombs.

site_title: Oil prices rise as Mid-East tensions simmer
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, extending gains from last week, as tensions between Iran and the US simmered. US President Donald Trump announced new sanctions on Iran, while Washington called off a military strike. Global supply may remain tight, with Opec and allies, including Russia, likely to extend oil cut pact at a Vienna meeting. Oil prices surged 5% last week, with Brent up 0.14% and West Texas Intermediate up 0.87%. Analysts expect an extension of Opec's production cuts through the end of the year, supporting oil prices.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.3% on Monday amid cautious trading session in Asia
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.3% to 3,311.53 on Monday, amidst a cautious trading session. The local market was weighed down by uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve, trade war, Middle East tensions, and the wait-and-see approach before the G-20 meeting between the US and China. Investors turned to buying up real estate investment trusts (Reits), but some analysts downgraded them due to high valuations. The market saw a mixed performance across the region, with gains in Australia, China, Hong Kong, and Japan, while South Korea was flat and Malaysia closed lower.

site_title: Soybeans could be next market to surge as US showers drag on
summary: US soybean prices may surge as heavy rains in the Midwest threaten oilseed plantings, with hedge funds backing away from bearish wagers. Corn prices are on track for their best quarterly advance since 2010, but analysts expect the US Department of Agriculture to revise its planting estimates downward, potentially boosting soybean prices. The US-China trade war and upcoming meeting between US President Trump and China's Xi Jinping could also impact soybean prices.

site_title: United Food Holdings' independent auditor issues qualified opinion on FY2019 financial statements
summary: United Food Holdings' independent auditor issued a qualified opinion on its FY2019 financial statements due to a lack of information on the disposal of subsidiaries and payroll expenses for redundant employees. The group recorded a loss of 17.1 million yuan on discontinued operations and a gain of 27.2 million yuan on disposal, but the auditor was denied access to financial information. This resulted in an inability to determine the extent of the loss and gain.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose to 0.9% in May, exceeding economists' estimates of 0.6%, driven by higher private transport, retail, and food inflation. The High Court dismissed Jannie Chan's appeal against a bankruptcy order, and the Singapore Exchange rejected International Cement's US$104.4 million acquisition of an African firm. Meanwhile, Circles.Life launched its first overseas mobile services in Taiwan, and Union Gas Holdings is assessing disruption to its LPG supply after a fire at a supplier's facility. The STI dropped 0.3% on Monday amid cautious trading.

site_title: ISR Capital signs MOU with Chinese firm for Madagascar project
summary: MAINBOARD-listed ISR Capital has signed a non-binding MOU with China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction Co to develop its 75%-owned rare-earth mining concession in north-western Madagascar. NFC will purchase up to 3,000 tonnes of output within the first three years of production, subject to quality requirements for the Chinese market. The MOU also includes engineering procurement and construction services, and potential investment by NFC, with a two-year expiration date.

site_title: Swiss ready to retaliate against EU over stock market access
summary: The Swiss government announced it is prepared to ban EU stock exchanges from trading Swiss shares, effective July 1, in response to the EU's decision not to extend stock market equivalence. The move is a retaliation for the EU's frustration with Switzerland's footdragging on a stalled partnership treaty. Switzerland's foreign minister has repeatedly stated that the country will not be rushed into a deal, while the EU sees this as a demand to reopen the treaty text. The Swiss bourse operator SIX welcomed the decision, allowing EU market participants to continue trading Swiss shares directly.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat as caution prevails ahead of G20 summit
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended flat, closing at 2,126.33, ahead of the G20 summit where US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will meet amid escalating trade tensions. Investors expect little possibility of a meaningful agreement but anticipate some direction on negotiations. The Korean won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners sold 99.4 billion won worth of shares, while the won rose 0.65% against the US dollar.

site_title: Coca-Cola, China dairy giant sign Olympic sponsorship deal
summary: Coca-Cola and Chinese dairy firm Mengniu have signed a joint sponsorship deal with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for the 2021-2032 Olympics, becoming the first joint partners under the Olympic TOP programme. The deal, reportedly worth $3 billion, is the largest IOC sponsorship ever, with Coca-Cola and Mengniu contributing to the agreement. However, Mengniu's rival, Yili, has threatened to pull out its sponsorship of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics due to concerns over the deal.

site_title: PODCAST: Getting started with SkillsFuture-funded courses if you have unused credit (Money Hacks, Ep 47)
summary: Singaporeans with unused SkillsFuture credits can start taking courses using their $500 credit. To begin, log in to the MySkillsFuture portal to check remaining credits and identify desired skills. Prioritize career upgrades or personal goals, and explore newly available courses. The upcoming SkillsFuture Festival 2019 will feature workshops and talks to inspire learning. Users can create an e-passport listing e-certificates from training through the enhanced MySkillsFuture portal.

site_title: Many non-tariff barriers remain in Asean: report
summary: A report by the EU-ABC and Asean BAC warns that Asean will fail to meet its AEC targets without tackling non-tariff barriers, hindering automotive, agri-food, and healthcare sectors. Non-tariff barriers include quotas, licensing controls, and discriminatory policies, affecting regional firms and hindering growth. The report sets out Asean-level recommendations to address these barriers and achieve AEC objectives by 2025.

site_title: Corner heritage shophouse on Club Street up for sale again at S$23m
summary: A corner conservation shophouse on 65 Club Street in Singapore is up for sale at S$23 million via a public tender exercise. The 3-storey building, with a 999-year lease, occupies 2,083 sq ft of land and has a total floor area of 5,640 sq ft. The indicative price works out to S$4,078 per sq ft. The property is nestled in the Telok Ayer Conservation Area and has been previously withdrawn from the market after initial offers fell short of the vendor's expectation.

site_title: Asean+3 growth forecast lowered to 4.9%: report
summary: The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO) has lowered its regional growth forecast to 4.9% for 2019 and 2020 due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. In an adverse scenario, growth is expected to slow to 4.7% in 2019 and 4.5% in 2020. Regional economies with stronger global value chain participation will be more affected. Despite this, regional emerging markets continue to see positive net capital inflows and equity markets have rebounded with global markets. Most regional currencies have depreciated due to trade tensions.

site_title: Gold climbs towards 6-year peak on dovish central banks, Iran tensions
summary: Gold prices surged 0.5% to near a six-year high of $1,410.78 per ounce, driven by dovish central bank signals and rising tensions between the US and Iran. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank hinted at easing policy, while the dollar fell to a three-month low. Gold holdings in the world's largest gold-backed ETF rose 4.6% on Friday, its largest one-day percentage gain since 2008. The metal has risen nearly 8% this month, and hedge funds boosted their bullish stance in COMEX gold.

site_title: Office floor at Sim Lim Tower up for sale with S$15m asking price
summary: A freehold strata office floor at Sim Lim Tower in Singapore has been put up for sale by tender with an asking price of S$15 million. The 15th-floor property spans 778 square meters and offers a 360-degree panoramic view. Located near Jalan Besar MRT station, it benefits from the ongoing rejuvenation of the Beach Road/Ophir-Rochor Corridor. The property is zoned commercial, making it eligible for purchase by both local and foreign buyers, with a tender closing on July 23.

site_title: Eldorado Resorts to buy Caesars Entertainment for about US$8.5b
summary: Eldorado Resorts has agreed to buy Caesars Entertainment Corp for approximately US$8.5 billion in cash and stock, aiming to build scale against competitors like Las Vegas Sands and Wynn Resorts. The deal, announced after three months of negotiations, represents a 30% premium to Caesars' closing price. Eldorado's offer includes a 51% stake in the combined company, with Caesars shareholders retaining 49%. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2020, with Caesars' name and 60 casino-resorts retained.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close marginally higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.13% higher on Monday, recovering from earlier losses, as investors found support from rallies in Hong Kong and Chinese markets. The Nikkei 225 index gained 27.35 points to 21,285.99, while the Topix index rose 1.84 points to 1,547.74. This rebound came after investors took a cautious stance ahead of the G20 summit, with lingering concerns over the US-China trade row and US-Iran tensions. The US dollar also influenced the market, stopping its decline around the 107.40 yen level.

site_title: Lower for longer: Supply glut in focus as Asia's biggest coal meet begins
summary: Asia's largest coal conference kicked off in Indonesia, focusing on a supply glut in the market. Slowing economic growth in China, driven by a trade war, and global moves towards cleaner energy are putting pressure on thermal coal prices. Benchmark prices for premium Australian coal have fallen to their weakest since September 2016, and are expected to continue falling due to a slowing global economy. The expansion of natural gas use in Europe and increased competition from hydro and wind energy are contributing to the supply glut, potentially signaling a faster decarbonization of the global economy.

site_title: Deliveroo to launch month-long "delivery walker" trial in CBD
summary: Deliveroo is launching a month-long trial in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) where 50 delivery persons will walk instead of using e-scooters, bicycles, or motorcycles. The trial, set to begin July 8, aims to address difficulties in parking and heavy traffic. Participants will not require a vehicle and will receive incentives for completing deliveries during peak hours. The trial will gather feedback, which will inform a potential wider rollout to the company's delivery fleet.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,309.89, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.51 points, or 0.4%, to 3,309.89 at 1:03pm on Monday, amid cautious sentiment ahead of the G20 meeting and weakening Singapore dollar against the US dollar. Analysts expect a potential Fed interest rate cut to have a dampening effect on local exports. Decliners outnumbered gainers 163 to 150, with banking stocks and AA Group Holdings trading flat.

site_title: Hong Kong's power firms sign LNG deals for first import terminal
summary: Hong Kong Electric Co and Castle Peak Power Company have signed a deal with Shell Eastern Trading for the import of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to fuel Hong Kong's power generation. The agreement includes a 10-year supply deal for 1.2 million tonnes per annum, starting after 2020, and the lease of a floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU) vessel. This move aims to reduce Hong Kong's reliance on coal and create a steady demand source in the Asian LNG market, in line with the city's goal to use 50% natural gas in its power generation mix by 2020.

site_title: Gold hovers near 6-year high as dovish cenbanks, US-Iran tensions fuel demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to a six-year high near $1,402.50 per ounce, driven by dovish central bank signals and escalating US-Iran tensions. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank hinted at easing policies, while the dollar index fell to a three-month low. Chinese President Xi Jinping's attendance at the G20 summit in Japan this week also boosted gold demand.

images.alt_text: Gold prices advanced on Monday, hovering near a six-year high touched in the previous session, as dovish signals from major central banks and heightened tensions between the United States and Iran boosted demand for the safe-haven metal.

site_title: Indonesia surprises with a trade surplus in May
summary: Indonesia reported a trade surplus of $207.6 million in May, contrary to market expectations of a $1.38 billion deficit. This followed a trade gap in April that was the largest in the country's history. Shipments declined 8.99% to $14.74 billion, while imports dropped 17.71% to $14.53 billion, both due to falling sales of mining products and oil. The surplus was attributed to a decline in demand for imported consumer goods during Ramadan. This marked a reversal of the trend of declining exports and imports seen in recent months.

site_title: Singapore's headline inflation edges up in May, core inflation holds steady
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose to 0.9% in May, exceeding economists' estimates of 0.6%, driven by higher private transport and retail costs. However, core inflation remained steady at 1.3%, and economists predict the Monetary Authority of Singapore will maintain its current monetary policy stance in October, citing signs of easing inflationary pressures. Despite a 1.5% increase in private road transport costs, accommodation costs fell 1% year-on-year, while retail costs rose 0.5%. The MAS expects headline inflation to average 0.5-1.5% and core inflation to come in near the mid-point of its forecast range of 1-2%.

site_title: Vitol building Malaysian oil refinery to meet new low-sulphur ship fuel rules
summary: Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trader, is building a small oil refinery in Malaysia to produce low-sulphur fuel for ships. The refinery, located at Tanjung Bin in the southern Malaysian state of Johor, will process 30,000 barrels of crude per day and is expected to be completed in May 2020. The project aims to meet the International Maritime Organization's new 0.5% sulphur limit for marine fuel starting in 2020, and will augment Vitol's refinery in Fujairah, UAE. The refinery will process a variety of low-sulphur oils, including US West Texas Intermediate crude.

site_title: Quake of magnitude 7.5 shakes East Timor, Indonesia; no tsunami feared
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck off the coasts of East Timor and Indonesia on June 24, 2019, causing strong shaking in the East Timor capital of Dili and northern Australia. The quake was felt as far away as Australia but did not have the potential to cause a tsunami, according to authorities. There were no immediate reports of damage, injuries, or deaths. The quake was initially recorded at 7.2 magnitude, 220 km deep, and triggered at least one aftershock.

site_title: Australian shares end steady ahead of trade talks; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares ended steady ahead of the G-20 summit, with the S&P/ASX 200 rising 0.2% to 6,665.40 points. Investors kept a cautious stance due to ongoing trade tensions between China and the US. New Zealand's benchmark index reached a record high, up 0.6% to 10,388.31. China's President Xi Jinping confirmed his attendance at the G-20 meeting, where he is expected to discuss trade with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Judith Krantz, novelist who mixed sex with shopping, dies at 91
summary: Novelist Judith Krantz, known for her bestselling novels "Scruples" and "Princess Daisy," has died at 91. Krantz, who sold over 100 million copies in dozens of languages, passed away at her home in California due to natural causes. She began writing at age 50 and retired at 70, citing she had nothing more to tell her readers. Krantz's novels often featured glamorous characters and the cut-throat worlds of fashion and Hollywood, drawing from her own life experiences.

images.alt_text: Judith Krantz, the writer of best-selling novels such as "Scruples" and "Princess Daisy" who stoked women's yearnings for professional success, romantic adventure and Rodeo Drive fashion, has died. She was 91.

site_title: Eldorado Resorts said to buy Caesars in US$18b transaction
summary: Eldorado Resorts Inc. agreed to buy Caesars Entertainment Corp. for approximately US$18 billion in a cash and stock transaction, valuing Caesars at US$13 a share. The deal represents a 44% premium to Caesars' close on Friday and will split the combined entity almost equally between shareholders. The acquisition was reportedly influenced by activist billionaire Carl Icahn, who pushed Caesars to consider a sale.

site_title: Malaysia serves summons to three Goldman units in 1MDB case
summary: Malaysia has served summons to three Goldman Sachs units - Goldman Sachs (Asia) LLC, Goldman Sachs International (UK), and Goldman Sachs (Singapore) - in connection with the 1MDB case. The court has set a September 30 pretrial hearing, despite Goldman's lawyer stating that the charges remain incomplete. Only three of four charges were served to the Singapore unit, while the summons to Goldman Sachs (Asia) was received last week.

site_title: China says will not allow Hong Kong issue to be discussed at G20 summit
summary: China's Assistant Minister of Foreign Affairs Zhang Jun stated that the country will not allow the Hong Kong issue to be discussed at the G20 summit. The announcement comes amid widespread protests in Hong Kong against a bill allowing extradition to mainland China courts controlled by the Communist Party. China views the issue as an internal affair and claims no foreign country has the right to interfere. This decision was made despite Chinese President Xi Jinping's scheduled meeting with US President Donald Trump at the G20 summit in Osaka.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks steady as investors await trade talks
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained steady on Monday as investors await signs of a thaw in Sino-U.S. trade negotiations at the G20 summit. The Hang Seng index rose 0.1%, while China's A-shares traded at a premium of 27.4% over Hong Kong-listed H-shares. Chinese Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen urged both sides to make compromises in trade talks, while US Vice President Mike Pence's decision to cancel a China speech increased optimism ahead of the talks. The yuan was quoted at 6.8831 per US dollar, 0.23% weaker than the previous close.

site_title: Stiffer fines for Singapore parking offences from July 1: URA
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing Board (HDB) announced that fines for parking offences will increase starting July 1. Motorcyclists will face a S$35 fine, up from S$25, while car drivers and heavy vehicle drivers will pay S$70 and S$100 respectively. Fines for payment evasion, coupon and digital parking offences, and exceeding paid parking sessions will also be raised. The agencies cited concerns over safety, obstruction, and inconvenience caused by illegal parking.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.04 points to 1,678.19. Volume was 50.5 million lots worth RM23.9 million. Gainers beat losers 98 to 71.

site_title: Razer partners Visa to add virtual prepaid card to Razer Pay e-wallet
summary: Razer, a gaming peripherals brand, has partnered with Visa to develop a virtual prepaid card solution for its e-wallet, Razer Pay. The solution will allow users to make payments worldwide where Visa is accepted. The partnership will also enable Razer's fintech arm to join Visa's fintech fast-track program, expanding its access to the global Visa payments network. The solution will be rolled out in selected countries in South-east Asia before expanding globally, aiming to empower digital payments in emerging markets.

site_title: Zara's Indian partner building its own cheaper fashion chain
summary: Tata Group's retail arm, Trent Ltd., plans to open 40 Westside outlets and hundreds of Zudio stores annually in India, offering affordable fashion at a compressed timeline of 12 days, similar to Inditex SA's Zara. The move aims to target a trend-conscious, low-income consumer population that cannot afford Zara's prices. Trent's strategy is to deliver "extreme fast fashion" at half the price of Zara, capitalizing on the growing demand for affordable, on-trend clothing in India.

site_title: Asia: Stocks tick up, oil rises amid US-Iran tensions
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday amid hopes for a thaw in Sino-US trade negotiations, while oil prices increased due to heightened tensions between the US and Iran. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index rose 0.2%, with Chinese shares little changed and Hong Kong's Hang Seng adding 0.1%. Oil prices climbed 0.3% and 0.6% for Brent and US crude futures, respectively. Investors await a meeting between Presidents Trump and Xi Jinping for signs of a de-escalation in the trade war, which has damaged the global economy.

site_title: Allied Tech gets further time extension for AGM, Q1 results amid probe into missing S$33m
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering firm listed on the Singapore Exchange, has received an extension of 3.5 weeks to hold its AGM, release Q1 results, and issue a sustainability report amid a probe into missing S$33m funds. The company's auditors need more time to complete the audit due to ongoing investigations and developments. Allied Tech will now announce its Q1 results by July 25 and issue the sustainability report by July 10. Trading in its shares remains suspended.

site_title: Hour Glass co-founder Jannie Chan's appeal against bankruptcy dismissed
summary: Hour Glass co-founder Jannie Chan's appeal against a bankruptcy order was dismissed by the High Court, with the 74-year-old failing to persuade the judge to overturn the decision to declare her a bankrupt over a debt of S$4.15 million. Chan, who remains an adviser to the company she co-founded, faces disqualification from appointments and prohibitions on overseas travel due to her bankruptcy. The debt stems from a defaulted loan of S$500,000 given to one of Chan's companies in 2012, with interest rates reduced but still resulting in a significant outstanding balance.

site_title: Aussie retirement-home operator Aveo sees annual profit slump, shares fall
summary: Australian retirement-home operator Aveo Group expects annual profit to more than halve due to weak property market conditions, resulting in a 14% decline in shares. The company has received a non-binding, conditional takeover proposal from a "preferred party" but may discontinue the transaction if an agreement cannot be reached by July 22. Aveo attributed the decline in profit guidance to delayed home sales due to weakness in house prices, which also affects the outlook for the residential property market.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.35% to 3,309.89
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Monday, down 0.35% to 3,309.89, following a decline in US and European markets. The Straits Times Index fell 11.51 points due to losses in financials, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB. Despite this, gains in palm oil firm Golden-Agri Resources and other stocks helped maintain a slight edge for the day. The decline in US markets was attributed to tensions between the US and Iran, with investors awaiting the G20 summit.

site_title: Malaysian agency picks Synagie as partner to help firms accelerate e-commerce adoption
summary: Malaysia's Malaysia Digital Economy Corporation (MDEC) has appointed Synagie Sdn Bhd as a cross-border e-commerce initiative partner to help firms accelerate e-commerce adoption under the National eCommerce Strategic Roadmap. The partnership aims to double Malaysia's e-commerce growth and contribute RM211 billion to the country's GDP by 2020. Synagie will provide e-commerce solutions and enable businesses to sell products in South-east Asia and China markets. The partnership will run until December 31, 2020, and will leverage MDEC's nationwide network in Malaysia.

site_title: Billionaire defies retail gloom with offer for Germany's Metro
summary: Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky and his Slovak investment partner Patrik Tkac have made a $6.6 billion takeover bid for Germany's Metro AG, valuing the company at 16 euros per share. The offer, which represents a 3% premium over the previous close, aims to turn around Metro's wholesale business model. The bid, which would give the bidders over 30% of the equity, faces opposition from Metro's management, which says the offer substantially undervalues the company. The bid is seen as a rare example of a wealthy investor moving in to rescue a struggling retailer.

site_title: Memes, cartoons and caustic Cantonese: the language of Hong Kong's protests
summary: Hong Kong protesters have employed satire and humor in their anti-government demonstrations, using memes, cartoons, and Cantonese insults to express their frustration and opposition to the extradition law and erosion of freedoms. Protests have turned into a "riotous" display of satire, with chants, banners, and slogans often turning criticism against the movement on its head. The use of humor and irony is a key aspect of the protests, with protesters reclaiming and redefining insults and phrases to convey their message, including the infamous phrase "freedom hai" which has become a rallying cry.

images.alt_text: Viral artwork pummelling city leaders, clever word plays and Cantonese cursing that would make a sailor blush -- Hong Kongers have displayed a characteristically riotous embrace of satire during their huge anti-government protests.

site_title: Euro hits 3-month high as Fed easing prospects weigh on dollar
summary: The euro reached a three-month high against the dollar, rising 0.15% to 1.1386 euros, due to bearish bets on the US currency amid prospects of a near-term interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The dollar index fell to 96.135, its lowest since March 21. The euro's rally was also influenced by concerns over the European Central Bank's ability to ease policy, despite already employing a negative interest rate policy. The dollar declined against the yen, while the Australian dollar rose 0.4% after Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe expressed doubts about the effectiveness of global monetary policy easing.

site_title: YuuZoo to perform support functions from Bangkok
summary: YuuZoo Networks Group Corporation has set up a new corporate support centre in Bangkok to replace its Singapore office, which closed in March 2019. The move comes as the company's shares are suspended amid investigations into its finances. YuuZoo, a social commerce company, previously stated that YuuZooNow Pte Ltd, which closed its Singapore office, was a subsidiary, but now claims it is a separate entity. The new Bangkok centre will provide support functions such as accounting, technology, and human resources.

site_title: Australia planning new port in north for use by US Marines: Report
summary: Australia is planning to build a new deep-water port 40km from Darwin, capable of accommodating US Marine deployments, to counter China's growing presence in the region. The port will be part of efforts to strengthen military ties with the US and support joint military exercises. The facility will also include commercial and industrial operations. The announcement is expected in the coming weeks, coinciding with the bi-annual Talisman Sabre exercise in mid-July. The move aims to provide a discreet and less busy base for US amphibious warships, supporting Australia's efforts to counter China's influence in the western Pacific.

site_title: 40% of Sky Everton units sold
summary: A consortium led by Sustained Land has sold nearly 40% (102 units) of the 262 units at Sky Everton, a freehold condominium on Everton Road, in Singapore. The average price is S$2,550 per square foot, with unit prices starting from S$1.14 million for a one-bedroom unit. The project, set to be completed in 2023, benefits from its proximity to the future Cantonment Station and Greater Southern Waterfront district, with a range of amenities including lap and infinity pools, a gym, and dining spots.

site_title: Union Gas assessing disruption to LPG supply after massive fire at supplier's Jurong facility
summary: Union Gas Holdings is assessing disruption to its LPG supply after a massive fire at a supplier's Jurong facility on June 21, killing one employee and injuring two others. The fire, involving hundreds of flammable LPG cylinders, has led to operations being suspended at the facility and moved to an alternative site. Union Gas is monitoring the situation and will update shareholders on any material impact to its operations or finances. The company expresses condolences to the deceased employee's family and is working to minimize disruption to its supply of bottled LPG cylinders.

images.alt_text: Catalist-listed gas supplier Union Gas Holdings is assessing and monitoring the impact of disruption to its supply of bottled liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) cylinders caused by an industrial fire at a supplier's facility on Friday evening.

site_title: UBS brings machines into credit derivatives to boost trading
summary: UBS is expanding its automated trading capabilities to handle credit derivatives and exchange-traded funds tied to corporate debt. The bank aims to provide customers with easier access to managing credit exposure and risk. UBS has hired a macro trader to lead trading of these products, building on its previous success with automated trading for investment-grade corporate bonds. The move is part of a broader trend of banks modernizing their trading efforts in the $8 trillion corporate credit market, with many adopting automated systems to boost trading volume.

site_title: Magnitude 5.5 quake hits eastern Japan, no immediate damage
summary: A magnitude 5.5 earthquake struck eastern Japan on June 24, 2019, with its epicenter off the coast of Chiba prefecture, adjacent to Tokyo. Although a tsunami warning was not issued, the quake had a maximum intensity of 4 and no immediate damage was reported. Earthquakes are common in Japan, which accounts for 20% of the world's earthquakes of magnitude 6 or greater.

site_title: Outlook uncertain for Japan's whaling industry despite commercial restart
summary: Japan's whaling industry is uncertain despite the country's decision to resume commercial whaling on July 1, following its withdrawal from the International Whaling Commission. The industry is expected to be small, with only 300 people directly connected to whaling and whale meat accounting for only 0.1% of Japan's total meat consumption. Environmentalists and whaling advocates question the feasibility of commercial whaling, citing low demand and limited financial viability. The Japanese government has not set a hunt quota, and the industry will need to prove its viability in the coming months.

images.alt_text: When Yachiyo Ichihara was a child in Wada, one of Japan's oldest whaling villages, she'd go down to the harbour with a bucket and carry it home full of freshly butchered whale meat.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering flags Q4 and full-year loss
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering expects to post a net loss for its fiscal fourth-quarter and full year ended March 31, 2019, following a preliminary review of its unaudited financial results. The company will disclose further details on June 30. Hiap Seng Engineering was placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list in 2018 due to failing to meet trading price and market cap criteria, with a deadline to cure the status by June 4, 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong shares opened lower on Monday, following last week's rally, as investors await this week's trade talks between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping. The Hang Seng Index decreased 0.26% to 28,400.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.08%. The decline was attributed to concerns about the US-China trade talks, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on worries over trade, Iran
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, June 24, 2019, due to concerns over the US-China trade row and escalating US-Iran tensions. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.27% to 21,200.75, while the Topix index fell 0.22% to 1,542.45. The G20 summit is set to take place this week, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: International Cement fails to get SGX nod for US$104.4m acquisition of African firm
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected International Cement Group's (ICG) US$104.4 million proposed purchase of Schwenk Namibia, a Namibian cement and energy firm. The acquisition was deemed not profitable and would result in a material adverse financial impact on the enlarged group. ICG was ordered to conduct pre-deal anti-money laundering due diligence on its source of funds for future transactions. The SGX also requires ICG to implement certain safeguards, including internal controls and risk management systems, for future acquisitions.

site_title: All hail the 'new queen' - Australia piles praise on top-ranked Barty
summary: Australia hailed Ashleigh Barty as the new queen of tennis after she reached world number one, becoming the country's second woman to achieve the feat. Barty, 23, claimed the top spot by winning the Birmingham WTA title, capping a remarkable rise from quitting tennis to play cricket. Her humility and down-to-earth approach earned praise from tennis officials and fans, with Billie Jean King calling her an inspiration to the next generation of players.

site_title: Turkey's opposition strikes blow to Erdogan with Istanbul mayoral win
summary: Turkey's opposition, led by Ekrem Imamoglu of the Republican People's Party (CHP), won control of Istanbul in a re-run mayoral election, securing 54.21% of votes. The narrow victory margin over President Erdogan's Islamist-rooted AK Party candidate, Binali Yildirim, marks a significant blow to Erdogan's aura of invincibility. The outcome is seen as a message from voters unhappy with Erdogan's policies, particularly the economic recession and financial crisis. The win is likely to trigger a new chapter in Turkish politics, with potential cracks within Erdogan's AK Party and adjustments to foreign policy.

site_title: Energy on the agenda when Saudi crown prince visits South Korea this week
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is set to visit South Korea from Wednesday, marking the first visit by an heir to the throne since 1998. The two-day trip aims to bolster economic ties, particularly in energy and public services. Saudi Arabia is South Korea's top oil supplier, and the visit follows a recent UN report criticizing the crown prince's involvement in the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The two sides are expected to sign agreements promoting cooperation in these areas, amid ongoing global tensions and market uncertainty.

site_title: Daimler warns on 2019 profit outlook as diesel issues bite
summary: Daimler cut its 2019 earnings outlook, citing hundreds of millions of euros in provisions for diesel issues related to Mercedes-Benz vehicles. The company now expects group earnings before interest and tax to be at last year's level, down from a previous estimate of a slight increase. The revision affects the second quarter and is linked to ongoing governmental proceedings and measures related to diesel emissions. Daimler must recall 60,000 Mercedes diesel cars in Germany and is being investigated for diesel emissions in Europe and the US.

site_title: Alpha Energy, Rich Capital call for trading halts
summary: Alpha Energy and Rich Capital, two CATALIST-LISTED firms, have requested trading halts pending announcements. Alpha Energy is restructuring a US$13.3 million loan, while Rich Capital is receiving a S$2 million advance payment guarantee for an Indonesian project. The companies' shares closed unchanged and up 0.2 Singapore cent, respectively, on Friday. The trading halts are expected to be lifted once the announcements are made.

site_title: Oil gains as new sanctions set to ratchet up pressure on Iran
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced new sanctions against Iran, set to increase pressure on the country. Oil futures rose 0.5% following the announcement, with a 9.4% surge last week being the biggest weekly gain in over two years. US President Donald Trump said he was willing to negotiate with Iran "with no preconditions" to prevent the Islamic Republic from acquiring a nuclear weapon. Trump had previously aborted planned air strikes against Iran, citing concerns over the death toll.

site_title: London Latino heartlands struggle for survival
summary: London's Latino heartlands, including the Pueblito Paisa market in Seven Sisters and the Elephant and Castle shopping centre, face destruction due to redevelopment projects. The markets, which serve as community hubs and provide a space for newcomers to navigate Britain's bureaucracy, are set to be replaced with new homes and commercial spaces. Traders and locals fear gentrification and the loss of their South American identity, with some already experiencing increased rents and displacement. Redevelopment plans have been met with resistance from community groups, who argue that they prioritize social housing over market-driven developments.

site_title: Trump says re-election 'easier' if he is impeached
summary: US President Donald Trump stated in an interview that if Democratic lawmakers start impeachment proceedings against him, his chances of retaining the White House in 2020 would be strengthened. Trump believes he would win the election "easier" if impeached, citing the Mueller Report's findings on Russian interference in the 2016 election. The report concluded that there was no collusion, but Trump claims it was all about collusion. The Republican-held Senate would decide whether to convict, requiring a two-thirds majority.

site_title: Rex unit seals deal to acquire 30% interest in two Norwegian Sea licences
summary: Rex International's 90%-owned subsidiary Lime Petroleum AS agreed to acquire a 30% interest in two Norwegian Sea drilling licences, PL838 and PL838B, pending regulatory approval. The licences are located in the Donna Terrace area and contain the Shrek prospect with potential oil targets. Exploration drilling is expected to begin in Q4 2019, with the planned well targeting multiple prospective horizons. The deal is seen as a repeat of Lime's success in the Rolvsnes discovery, with Rex International's shares rising 1.41% on the news.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: 20th anniversary of Sias
summary: The Money FM podcast, "The Hot Seat," celebrated its 20th anniversary of Sias, reflecting on the radio station's highs and lows over two decades. The episode featured discussions with industry experts and insights into the changing media landscape. No specific news or events were discussed in this article, as it appears to be a promotional piece for the podcast.

site_title: Johnson's home row fuels debate over his PM credentials
summary: Boris Johnson faced a heated row with his girlfriend Carrie Symonds, sparking debate over his suitability as the next prime minister. Polls showed Johnson's lead over Jeremy Hunt evaporated among all voters, with Johnson's support narrowing to 29% among Conservatives. International Trade Secretary Liam Fox agreed that the incident should not distract from policy debate. Police were called to Johnson's home after neighbours reported a loud altercation, but all occupants were safe. The incident may hurt Johnson's campaign ahead of the July 23 Conservative party leadership election.

site_title: Qu Dongyu becomes first Chinese to head UN food agency FAO
summary: Qu Dongyu, a 55-year-old Chinese biologist, has become the first Chinese national to head the UN's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), winning 108 votes in the first round of voting. He will succeed Brazil's Jose Graziano da Silva and take up the post on August 1. Qu's election comes as the world grapples with rising hunger and food insecurity due to global warming, wars, and economic slowdowns, with the FAO sounding the alarm over these issues.

site_title: Three conservation shophouses in Little India up for sale with S$11m reserve price
summary: Three conservation shophouses in Little India are up for sale with a reserve price of S$11 million. The properties, with 7,771 sq ft of total floor area, are zoned for commercial use and have a 99-year leasehold tenure. Located at the intersection of Dalhousie Lane and Madras Street, they are part of the heritage district of Little India Conservation Area. The indicative price works out to S$1,415 per sq ft. The sale is expected to attract buyers looking for a prime commercial location in the area.

images.alt_text: Three adjoining corner shophouses in the Little India heritage area are up for sale with a reserve price of S$11 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Aspen, Oxley, Hiap Seng, Alpha Energy, Rich Capital
summary:
Key developments in Singapore stocks include:

- United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with CapBridge to offer private capital solutions to companies in Singapore and key markets.
- Aspen Group Holdings and Oxley Holdings are collaborating on a mixed-use development project in Penang.
- Rex International's subsidiary Lime Petroleum AS has agreed to acquire interests in Norwegian Sea drilling licenses.
- Hiap Seng Engineering expects to post a net loss for the fiscal fourth-quarter and full year 2019.
- Trading halts have been requested by Catalist-listed firms Alpha Energy and Rich Capital pending announcements.

site_title: US prods Iran for talks to ease Gulf tensions; Tehran dismisses sanctions threat
summary: US President Donald Trump said he is not seeking war with Iran, following a senior Iranian military commander's warning that any conflict in the Gulf region could spread uncontrollably and threaten US troops. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo reiterated Washington's desire for talks with Tehran, promising no preconditions. Iran has dismissed the threat of new sanctions, calling them "just propaganda." Diplomatic efforts are underway to ease tensions, with the US and its allies discussing maritime security and Iran's compliance with its nuclear deal.

site_title: India's space startups ignite investor interest
summary: India's space startups are gaining investor interest, with several companies raising millions of dollars in funding. Bengaluru-based Bellatrix Aerospace and Mumbai-based Kawa Space are among the dozen startups developing satellites, rockets, and related support systems. The investments represent a significant leap in private space investments in India, where the government has historically held a monopoly. The growing demand for small and cheaper satellites is driving the interest, with over 17,000 satellites expected to be launched between 2018 and 2030.

site_title: Paris aims to beat Olympics 2024 traffic with flying taxis
summary: Paris aims to introduce flying taxis to alleviate traffic congestion for the 2024 Olympics, with a proposed Vertiport set to be ready in 18 months. The €10 million infrastructure investment will enable self-flying urban taxis to transport passengers directly from Charles de Gaulle airport to tournament sites. Airbus and Aeroports de Paris are partnering to launch a feasibility study, with the goal of reducing travel time from 1 hour to just a few minutes.

site_title: Small businesses across Asia-Pacific turning to new funding sources
summary: Small businesses in the Asia-Pacific are turning to new funding sources amid a capital crunch. According to the Economist Intelligence Unit, alternative finance is growing, with fintech investments shifting from digital payments to wealth management, insurance, and peer-to-peer financing in South-east Asia since 2017. This shift indicates "untapped market opportunities" and potential growth in financial markets.

site_title: The oil market shows it can take a punch
summary: The oil market has shown a muted response to recent Gulf tensions, largely due to increased global crude supply. The US has become an oil exporter, reducing its purchases from the Middle East, and global demand for oil is growing at a slower pace. Oil prices have risen modestly, with Brent crude trading at around $65 a barrel, but tanker charter rates and insurance premiums have increased. Analysts attribute this to the surge in US oil production, which has weakened Opec's hold on the market and cut gasoline prices worldwide.

site_title: India asks scooter, bike makers to draw up plan for electric vehicles: sources
summary: India's federal think-tank, Niti Aayog, has asked scooter and motorbike manufacturers to develop a plan to switch to electric vehicles within two weeks, following public opposition to the government's proposals. Companies including Bajaj Auto, Hero MotoCorp, and TVS were summoned by Niti Aayog officials. The move comes as the government seeks to reduce India's reliance on fossil fuels and mitigate environmental concerns. The plan's details and timelines are yet to be disclosed.

site_title: Carrefour sells China business to retailer Suning.com
summary: French supermarket giant Carrefour has agreed to sell 80% of its Chinese business to Chinese retailer Suning.com for 1.4 billion euros, valuing the deal at 4.8 billion renminbi. The sale includes 210 hypermarkets and 24 convenience stores, with Carrefour retaining a 20% stake in the business and two seats on the supervisory board. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: French supermarket giant Carrefour said Sunday it had agreed to sell 80 per cent of its China business to leading Chinese retailer Suning.

site_title: Socially conscious fitness for everyone
summary: Innervate Fitness, co-founded by Lionel Choong and Moses James, aims to make fitness accessible to everyone, regardless of age, ability, or background. The gym offers various programs, including CrossFit, Kids & Teens, Silvers, and Adaptives, designed to cater to different age groups and needs. Through its charity movement, Operation Broken Wing, Innervate has raised S$100,000 for at-risk youth and partnered with the Singapore Children's Society to provide fitness classes and life skills. The gym's commitment to community building and social consciousness has helped create a strong and inclusive community among its participants.

site_title: US carried out cyberattacks on Iran: sources
summary: The US conducted a cyberattack on an Iranian intelligence group on June 20, 2019, targeting multiple computer systems, including those used by an Iranian intelligence group that helped plan recent oil tanker attacks. The operation was intended to be below the threshold of armed conflict, using shadow tactics similar to Iran's own methods. The cyberattack was planned for several weeks in response to the tanker attacks and the downing of a US drone. The US President Donald Trump had previously called off a strike on Iranian targets, allowing the cyberoperation to proceed.

site_title: Poland eyes green energy investments in Western Balkans
summary: Poland's energy minister, Jadwiga Emilewicz, announced plans to invest in renewable energy projects in Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, North Macedonia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, in support of their potential EU membership. Poland's state-run energy groups, such as Tauron, could invest in green energy projects like wind and solar power, leveraging the region's suitable climate. The move aims to reduce Poland's reliance on coal and align with EU climate policies. A Western Balkans investment summit will be held in Warsaw in July, with a Weimar Triangle meeting also planned.

site_title: Saudi launches special residency scheme to boost revenue
summary: Saudi Arabia launched a special residency scheme to boost non-oil revenue, offering permanent residency for 800,000 riyals and a one-year residency for 100,000 riyals. The scheme allows expats to do business without a sponsor, buy property, and sponsor visas for relatives. Analysts say it will benefit wealthy Arabs and multinational companies. The move aims to diversify the economy as Saudi Arabia seeks to reduce its reliance on oil revenue.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia on Sunday launched a new special residency scheme aimed at luring wealthy expats as the petro-state seeks to boost non-oil revenue.

site_title: Hedge funds hold out hope for kiwi dollar
summary: Hedge funds remain cautious on the kiwi dollar, holding minimal bearish bets of 1,408 contracts, despite the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's dovish stance and interest rate cuts. The market is already pricing in 42 basis points of additional rate cuts this year, which may limit further kiwi downside. However, a moderately hawkish tone from the RBNZ on Wednesday could bolster the currency, and emerging positives in GDP data and technical indicators may convince hedge funds to start building long positions.

site_title: Bloc on its own cannot control big powers, but together can make their voices heard: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of unity among Asean nations to counterbalance growing tensions between the US and China. He noted that while individual countries cannot control big powers, collective action can advance regional interests. The Asean bloc has endorsed a framework for cooperation across the Indo-Pacific region, distinct from the US' Indo-Pacific Strategy and China's Belt and Road Initiative. Lee also highlighted progress in discussions on the Code of Conduct in the South China Sea and the need for constructive approaches to address issues such as the Rakhine state crisis and economic cooperation.

site_title: Getting into the heart of the community
summary: Frasers Property Singapore CEO Christopher Tang finds satisfaction in creating spaces that the community appreciates and products that deliver real value to customers. The company has a multi-segment business model, providing a buffer against the cyclical nature of the property business. With a focus on suburban malls, integrated developments, residential projects, and commercial developments, Frasers Property Singapore aims to build on its dominant position in the market. Despite the disruption from e-commerce, Tang sees opportunities for the future, with a focus on place-making and future-proofing retail malls.

site_title: Kushner's Mideast peace gamble puts economics ahead of politics
summary: US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner unveiled a $50 billion economic blueprint, "Peace to Prosperity," for the Middle East, focusing on economic development over politics. The plan, released ahead of a Bahrain workshop, aims to connect Gaza and the West Bank, expand exports, and increase access to basic services. However, experts question the feasibility of the plan, citing the need for a political solution to resolve core issues driving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The economic document was released without proposed resolutions on key disputes, sparking doubts about its potential to lead to peace.

site_title: Goldman, Morgan Stanley do better in Fed stress tests
summary: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley improved their results in the latest Federal Reserve stress tests, a sign they may have more flexibility to boost payouts to shareholders. The 18 banks tested demonstrated the ability to withstand a hypothetical financial shock, with their collective common equity Tier 1 ratio more than double the regulatory minimum. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are expected to modestly adjust their payouts, with Goldman reducing its total payout and Morgan Stanley increasing it, after two years of surging dividends and buybacks. The tests will continue this week, with the second round determining whether firms can boost capital payouts.

site_title: Bond traders eye G-20 meeting as Treasuries continue to rally
summary: US bond traders expect yields to continue their rally as the G-20 meeting in Osaka approaches, with strategists predicting a rate cut by the Federal Reserve in July. The 10-year Treasury yield broke below 2% for the first time since 2016, and NatWest Markets expects it to drop to 1.85% by year-end. However, some analysts, such as Bank of America's Mark Cabana, caution that the Fed may not cut rates if the US-China trade dispute is not resolved, and a better-than-expected G-20 outcome could even lead to higher yields.

site_title: French farmers seek a pistachio bonanza
summary: French farmers in the Provence region are seeking to cultivate pistachios, a staple of the French aperitif, which are currently sourced from thousands of miles away in Syria. The farmers aim to capitalize on the growing demand for domestically produced pistachios, with wild uncultivated trees remnants from the Roman era existing in the region. However, vineyards and fruit orchards dominate the landscape, making it challenging to establish large-scale pistachio cultivation. The initiative is expected to bring economic benefits to the local farmers and contribute to France's growing pistachio market.

site_title: Bolton warns Iran not to mistake US 'prudence' for 'weakness'
summary: US National Security Adviser John Bolton warned Iran not to mistake President Donald Trump's last-minute cancellation of a retaliatory strike on Iran as "weakness." Bolton stated that US prudence and discretion should not be misconstrued by hostile actors. The US has imposed several measures against Iran since Trump pulled out of the nuclear accord, and Bolton anticipated the announcement of new sanctions on Monday. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu welcomed the expected sanctions, citing Iran's "campaign of aggression" and the crippling economic pressure it faces due to US sanctions.

images.alt_text: US National Security Adviser John Bolton warned Tehran on Sunday of misinterpreting as "weakness" President Donald Trump's last-minute cancellation of a retaliatory strike on Iran.

site_title: Aspen, Oxley tie up to develop mixed-use integrated project in Penang
summary: Malaysian developer Aspen (Group) Holdings has partnered with Oxley Holdings to develop a mixed-use integrated project in Penang. The project, comprising residential towers, serviced apartments, and retail facilities, will be developed in phases. Aspen acquired 29.05 acres of land for RM165 million, with Oxley Holdings investing 25% equity in Aspen Park Hills. The joint venture aims to replan the development scheme to improve viability and accelerate construction of a nearby road. The project is expected to contribute significantly to Aspen's revenue from 2021, with the area home to over 400,000 people.

site_title: US$ hits 3-month lows on US rate cut bets
summary: The US dollar hit three-month lows against a basket of currencies on bets that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates later this year. The euro rose to three-month highs, and the yen reached a five-month high against the dollar due to growing tensions between Iran and the US. The Fed's interest rate cut signals are expected to prompt a "horse-race" between the US and European Central Bank on policy easing.
