The Australian dollar firmed to US$0.6926, up 0.8% for the week, while the New Zealand dollar rose to US$0.6590, a 1.5% gain. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to cut interest rates soon, with futures indicating a 72% chance of a July rate cut. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's policy meeting on June 26 is also under pressure to ease rates, with a 31% chance of a quarter-point cut.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Friday; STI up 0.02% to 3,315.23
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.02% to 3,315.23 on Friday, following a rally in the US market overnight. The Straits Times Index edged up 0.72 points as about 53.9 million shares worth S$83.7 million changed hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 106 to 38, with Ascott Reit being the most actively traded security. The US market saw a 1% gain in the S&P 500 and 0.9% in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, driven by a rally in oil-linked shares and dovish sentiment from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Retro Kicks
summary: Nike is releasing a capsule collection inspired by the hit series Stranger Things, set to debut on June 27 with a green and orange color scheme and references to Hawkins High. The collection will include PE-inspired sweatshirts and tees, as well as throwback sneakers featuring the Cortez, Blazer, and Tailwind silhouettes. A second drop, the OG Pack, will follow on July 1 with a red, white, and blue color scheme and special firework display sock liners. The collection will be available at NikeLab Dover Street Market Singapore and on Nike.com.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Cromwell E-Reit, Straits Trading, Del Monte
summary: Keppel Corp secured a 850 million yuan (S$170 million) green loan for its Seasons City project in China. Cromwell E-Reit acquired three French and three Polish properties for 239.6 million euros (S$366.9 million), aiming to increase distribution per unit. Straits Trading Co's Straits Real Estate entered a logistics partnership in South Korea with IGIS Asset Management. Del Monte reported a 13.3% year-on-year drop in Q4 sales to US$432.6 million, but saw earnings more than double to US$6.3 million for the quarter.

site_title: US-Iran showdown may only intensify
summary: The US and Iran are engaged in an escalating standoff after Iran shot down a US spy drone in the Strait of Hormuz, with tensions heightened by President Trump's "maximum pressure" campaign to cripple Iran's economy. Despite Trump's calls for talks, Iran has rebuffed overtures, and analysts predict further escalation unless incentivized otherwise. Hardliners on both sides are pushing for a tougher stance, raising concerns of all-out war and a potential conflict spiraling out of control.

site_title: Renault and Nissan end standoff over post-Ghosn governance
summary: Renault and Nissan have reached an agreement on governance overhaul following the Carlos Ghosn scandal, allowing Renault to back the changes in exchange for representation on oversight committees. Renault's chairman Jean-Dominique Senard and CEO Thierry Bollore will sit on Nissan's new committees. The deal confirms a spirit of dialogue and mutual respect within the alliance, which was strained after Ghosn's arrest. Nissan will create three oversight committees to prevent financial misconduct, and the reforms will be put to a vote at Nissan's annual shareholders' meeting next Tuesday.

site_title: UN Khashoggi report piles pressure on Saudi crown prince
summary: A UN report by special rapporteur Agnes Callamard has implicated Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, citing "credible evidence" of a large-scale operation warranting further investigation and financial sanctions. The report, released last October, has cast renewed pressure on Western allies to suspend arms sales to Saudi Arabia, with the US Congress voting to block a $8.1 billion arms deal. The report's findings have also sparked anti-Saudi sentiment in the US Congress, with Riyadh's relationship with Washington seen as non-negotiable.

site_title: Walmart to pay US$282m to settle US bribery probes: agency
summary: Walmart agreed to pay $282 million to settle US probes over bribery allegations from 2000 to 2011, as it rapidly expanded operations in Brazil, China, India, and Mexico. The company pleaded guilty to a criminal charge and agreed to pay $138 million to the Justice Department and $144 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Walmart claimed the probes predated its efforts to enact a global anti-corruption compliance regime, but the company has spent over $900 million on compliance efforts since 2011.

site_title: Gold scales near six-year peak on dovish Federal Reserve signals
summary: Gold prices reached a near six-year high on June 21, 2019, after the US Federal Reserve indicated it could cut interest rates as early as July, prompting a sharp decline in the dollar and US Treasury yields. Spot gold rose 0.4% to $1,392.81 per ounce, with US gold futures up 0.1% to $1,398.10 an ounce. The Fed's dovish signals, combined with monetary policy easing from the Bank of Japan and Bank of England, led to a decline in 10-year Treasury yields and a weekly loss for the dollar against major currencies.

images.alt_text: Gold prices climbed to a near six-year high on Friday after the US Federal Reserve indicated earlier this week that it could cut interest rates as early as July, prompting a sharp fall in the dollar and US Treasury yields.

site_title: EU leaders to hold June 30 crisis summit on bloc's top jobs
summary: EU leaders will hold a crisis summit on June 30 to decide on names for the bloc's top jobs after failing to reach an agreement. The European Council president, Donald Tusk, stated that there was no majority on any candidate, indicating a stalemate in the selection process. The summit comes after lengthy talks in Brussels.

site_title: Fragrance Group offers to buy back up to S$30m of its S$100m due-2021 notes
summary: Fragrance Group, a Singapore-based property developer, is offering to buy back up to S$30 million of its S$100 million 4.75% unsecured notes due November 2021. The repurchase will start on June 21 and end on July 5, with the option to end earlier if the available amount exceeds the cap. The company has not recommended tendering the notes, and the repurchase price will be the daily prevailing market price, including accrued interest, capped at 97% of the principal amount.

site_title: French auto giant PSA opens factory in Morocco
summary: French auto giant PSA has opened a factory in Morocco to assemble 100,000 cars per year, aiming to double sales in the Middle East and Africa region. The factory, which will increase annual capacity to 200,000 units, was built in four years and will create 2,500 full-time jobs. PSA's move follows Renault's 2012 entry into Morocco, which has created 7,000 jobs and exports cars to 74 countries, with a goal of producing 500,000 units by 2022.

site_title: Iran slams 'provocative' act by US after drone incident
summary: Iran has condemned the US for a "provocative" act after shooting down a US drone it claimed entered its airspace in "full stealth mode." The US calls the incident an "unprovoked attack" in international airspace. The drone was destroyed by a surface-to-air missile 34km from Iran. The downing comes amid heightened tensions between the two nations, with Iran denying involvement in recent tanker ship attacks. Iran reserves the right to defend its territory, while the US warns of potential consequences.

site_title: Apple says US tariffs on China would backfire
summary: Apple has warned the US administration that proposed tariffs on Chinese imports would be counterproductive, hurting its competitiveness and reducing its economic contributions. The company, the largest US corporate taxpayer, fears the tariffs would "tilt the playing field" to non-American rivals. Apple is set to invest $350 billion in the US over five years, but the tariffs would reduce its economic contributions. The proposed tariffs cover all of Apple's major products, including iPhones, and could boost Chinese rivals.

site_title: Third car tycoon detained in Algeria in graft case
summary: Algerian authorities have detained a third automobile tycoon, Hassen Arbaoui, in an investigation into corruption, money laundering, and abuse of power. Arbaoui heads the Global Group, which assembles vehicles for Kia and Hyundai. This is the third car tycoon detained, following Mahieddine Tahkout and Mourad Oulmi, who were detained earlier this month. The detentions come as several prominent politicians and businessmen linked to ousted President Abdelaziz Bouteflika face corruption charges since his forced resignation on April 3.

site_title: US FTC objects to Qualcomm submission of Apple documents in antitrust case
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) objected to Qualcomm's submission of internal Apple documents in its antitrust case, citing it as "improper, unfair, and prejudicial." The documents, which outlined Apple's goals to "Create Leverage by Building Pressure" and "Hurt Qualcomm Financially," were submitted to US District Judge Lucy Koh in opposition to a sweeping antitrust ruling. The FTC had no formal chance to object to the submission, but argued that it could have potentially been used to discredit Qualcomm's case. Qualcomm is fighting to freeze the ruling, which could alter its business model.

site_title: UK to review how financial regulators work together: Hammond
summary: British finance minister Philip Hammond announced plans to review how the country's financial regulators work together to ensure the competitiveness of the sector as the UK leaves the European Union. The review aims to coordinate the roll-out of new rules and manage the impact of regulatory change from different agencies, in response to calls from businesses. Hammond emphasized the need for the UK to maintain its reputation as a dynamic and innovative place to do business.

site_title: Airbus demands chance to bid for IAG's surprise Boeing 737 Max order
summary: Airbus has demanded a chance to bid for IAG's surprise order of 200 Boeing 737 Max jets, worth over $24 billion, after the airline stunned the industry with the deal. Airbus had previously signed a smaller order for A321XLRs with IAG, and the company's chief commercial officer Christian Scherer expressed frustration over the Boeing deal, urging IAG to run a competition for the planes. The move comes as Boeing seeks to secure supplier profits for the next decade due to the grounding of the 737 Max, which has damaged competition between planemakers.

site_title: Airbus seals deals with big buyers in wake of Boeing's surprise MAX sale
summary: Airbus has sealed deals with major buyers, including Indigo Partners and American Airlines, for its new A321neo and A321XLR jets, a day after Boeing announced a surprise order for 200 737 MAX jets. The deals demonstrate Airbus' competitiveness in the market, despite the 737 MAX crisis. Airbus aims to carve out new routes for airlines with smaller planes, while Boeing faces increased competition in Asia. The deals also highlight the ongoing rivalry between the two planemakers, with Boeing seeking to capitalize on the move and secure further support for the embattled MAX.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit six-week highs as BoE bolsters Federal Reserve-fuelled rally
summary: European stocks rose to six-week highs on June 20, driven by dovish signals from the Bank of England and Federal Reserve, as well as optimism around US-China trade talks. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.4%, with most country indices in the black, despite concerns over interest rate hikes from the Bank of England. The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee cut second-quarter growth forecasts to zero, easing market fears of a rate hike. The rally also boosted shares in Italy, Germany, and Switzerland, while tumbling euro zone bond yields pressured banking stocks.

site_title: Banks spend US$1t on digital, but few benefit, study says
summary: Global banks have invested US$1 trillion in digital technology over three years, but only 19 out of 161 largest retail and commercial banks have successfully transformed into "digital-focused" banks. These banks saw a 0.9 percentage point increase in return on equity (ROE) between 2011 and 2017, while the least digitally focused banks saw a 1.1 percentage point decline. The gap in ROE is expected to widen through 2021, with "digital active" banks experiencing little change.

site_title: Pressure mounts on YouTube to better protect young users
summary: Consumer and child protection groups are calling for YouTube to better protect young users from inappropriate content, citing concerns over data collection and lack of shielding from explicit material. The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether YouTube adequately protects children, which could lead to fines and other remedies against Google. Critics argue that the main YouTube site is not adequately enforced, allowing children to access content intended for older users. The issue is part of a broader challenge facing online services to balance openness with harm prevention.

site_title: Slack tops US$19b value in trading debut after shunning IPO
summary: Slack Technologies went public with a direct listing, bypassing the traditional IPO process, and its shares soared to a market value of $19.5 billion. The company's shares opened at $38.50 and closed at $38.62, with investors largely avoiding the expected first-day pop. Slack's CEO, Stewart Butterfield, cited the company's need for cash and desire to avoid diluting existing shareholders as reasons for the direct listing. The move is seen as a successful test of this type of listing, with shares trading within 10% of the opening price, and has the potential to catch on more widely in the future.

images.alt_text: Slack Technologies took a different route on Thursday, and saw its shares soar as it went public without an IPO.

site_title: Oil jumps 5% on Iran tension, potential US Federal Reserve rate cut
summary: Oil prices surged 5% on Thursday after Iran shot down a US military drone, raising concerns of a military confrontation between Tehran and Washington. Expectations of a potential US Federal Reserve rate cut also supported prices, with Brent crude rising 4.3% to $64.45 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 5.4% to $56.65 a barrel. Tensions between the US and Iran have been escalating, with the US blaming Iran for attacks on tankers in the Strait of Hormuz.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record on dovish Federal Reserve, rally in oil shares
summary: The S&P 500 closed at a record high of 2,954.18 on June 20, 2019, driven by a rally in oil-linked shares amid US-Iran tensions and a dovish Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also reached new highs, with the Dow gaining 0.9% and the Nasdaq advancing 0.8%. The record-breaking close marked a positive sentiment shift amidst ongoing US-Iran tensions and uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Trump, Trudeau mend fences at White House meeting
summary: President Donald Trump hosted Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the White House to mend fences after last year's diplomatic meltdown and push for the still-unratified North American free trade deal, known as the USMCA. The two leaders expressed strong support for the agreement, which would bring significant jobs and wealth to the countries. Canada's legislature ratified the deal, while the US Congress is the final hurdle. Democrats have expressed concerns over worker protections, but Trudeau said he will answer questions from lawmakers, amid a looming presidential election.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump (left) hosted his Canadian counterpart Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Thursday to mend fences after last year's diplomatic meltdown and to push the still un-ratified North American free trade deal.

site_title: China iron ore soars to record; gold and other precious metals surge
summary: China's iron ore surged to a record high of 831 yuan (S$165) a tonne on the Dalian Commodity Exchange, driven by Rio Tinto's lower Pilbara shipment guidance and Vale's resumption of Brucutu mine operations. This follows a favorable ruling from an appeals court allowing the Brazilian miner to fully resume operations within 72 hours. Meanwhile, gold prices surged 2% to their highest in over five years, with US gold futures reaching US$1,397.70 an ounce, amid expectations of possible interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Moving towards luxury
summary: Mazda's new 3 model marks the brand's efforts to become a premium version of itself, differentiating it from Japanese rivals. The design focuses on "reducing visual noise" and features a unified, cohesive form, typical of luxury cars. The interior boasts improved quality, with uniform backlighting and tactile feedback. The infotainment system, Mazda Connect, is comparable to that of a Lexus, with an 8.8-inch screen and lag-free performance. While some inexpensive elements remain, design ingenuity minimizes their visibility, hinting at a future where Mazdas will challenge luxury brands.

site_title: Set Sail Through Romantic Japan
summary: A 8-night cruise on Costa neoRomantica from Japan to Taiwan offers a unique experience, with stops in Kobe, Kochi, Miyakojima, and Taiwan. The ship features Italian/European cuisine, a 4,400sqm Samsara Spa, and various activities, including a Captain's Cocktail hour and Senior Officers' Dance. The itinerary includes four to eight-hour stops in each port, allowing passengers to sample local food, culture, and attractions. With prices starting from S$479 per person, the cruise is a great option for those seeking a relaxing getaway with a mix of relaxation and exploration.

site_title: Life On The Dotted Line
summary: Yayoi Kusama's film "Kusama: Infinity" explores her journey as a successful artist, overcoming trauma, family discouragement, and sexism in the art world. The documentary, directed by Heather Lenz, showcases her radical art vision and will screen on June 22 at Capitol Theatre. This film kicks off the eighth edition of the Design Film Festival, held in September.

site_title: South African president admits economy 'extremely weak'
summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa described the country's economy as "extremely weak" in his state-of-the-nation address, citing severe challenges including stagnant growth, high unemployment, and a struggling state power supplier Eskom. The president announced emergency funding for Eskom, which faces serious financial and operational problems, and vowed to revive the economy. Unemployment remains near-record highs, with young people facing a national crisis, and the country's GDP contracted by 3.2% in the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: Show me the profitability
summary: Startups are burning through cash despite facing threats to survival, with some going public with no profits in sight. Market valuations are being stretched by expectations, and some investors view loss-making companies as a new normal. A poll by The Business Times Weekend will discuss the "cash-and-burn" model, where startups rely on investment to sustain themselves until profitability. This approach raises questions about the sustainability of startup valuations and the feasibility of achieving returns.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - The Liveability Challenge 2019 winners
summary: The Liveability Challenge 2019, co-hosted by Eco-Business and Temasek Foundation Ecosperity, held its grand final and awarded six teams with up to S$1 million in project development funds, exclusive crowdfunding campaigns, and mentorships for innovative energy and circular economy solutions for cities in the tropics. The winning team, Sophie's Kitchen, was joined by Lim Hock Chan from the organisers.

site_title: A Regal Feast
summary: The Dalmore, a single malt specialist, opens its doors to the public for the first time with the Royal Feast, an immersive dining experience on June 26. The four-course menu priced at S$188 is paired with selected whiskies from the Dalmore range, led by Global Single Malt Whisky Specialist Stephen Martin. The evening features dishes such as chilled lobster cocktail and Maple Leaf Farms duck with chanterelle mushrooms, ending with dark chocolate and whisky tart and a night cap of The Dalmore King Alexander III. Bookings can be made via email or dbbistro.com/singapore.

site_title: Oil jumps 3% to US$63 as Iran shoots down US drone
summary: Oil prices surged 3% to above US$63 a barrel on June 20, 2019, following Iran's downing of a US military drone, raising concerns of a military confrontation between the US and Iran. The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cut and declining US crude inventories also supported prices, with Brent crude up US$1.73 at US$63.55 a barrel. A potential Opec+ production cut and US-China trade dispute are expected to have a significant impact on oil prices.

site_title: Tales To Tell
summary: The third edition of Storyfest, an annual gathering of storytellers, will be held at the Arts House, featuring master storytellers from around the world. The event includes sessions on storytelling for creative communication, leadership and storytelling, and ancient tales told by expert narrators. Adults can also participate in courses led by CEOs and coaches, including David Novak's storytelling course. Storyfest aims to showcase the power of stories in both personal and professional settings.

site_title: Thomas Heatherwick
summary: Thomas Heatherwick, founder of London-based design practice Heatherwick Studio, has created innovative and eye-catching projects over the past 25 years. His designs often focus on function and context, rather than aesthetics alone. Recent projects include the Google headquarters in London and California, and his first residential project, Eden, in Hong Kong, which features hanging gardens and a natural, back-to-nature feel. Heatherwick believes his work aims to improve the built environment and connect people with nature, rather than simply being gimmicky. He is currently working on the Changi Terminal 5 project with KPF Associates, aiming to create a human-scale design for the airport.

images.alt_text: "I Love it when we can find new visual languages that come out from the peculiarity of that one problem." ~ Thomas Heatherwick.

site_title: Trade disputes prevail as region's leaders meet
summary: Southeast Asian leaders are set to discuss the impact of the US-China tariff war at a Bangkok summit, with Beijing pushing for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade pact. The pact, which includes 10 Asean economies and several other countries, aims to draft Asian-Pacific trade architecture. However, negotiations have become stuck over environmental and labor protections. Disputes over the South China Sea and Myanmar's treatment of Rohingya Muslims are also likely to be on the agenda. The summit comes as the US-China trade spat continues to cast doubts over the future of free trade.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian emerges as suitor for DBS Vickers' remisier base
summary: UOB Kay Hian has emerged as a suitor for the remisier base of DBS Vickers, with negotiations underway to transfer the 150-odd remisiers and retail equity trading representatives as a group. The move is part of DBS Bank's revamp of its retail stock-brokerage operations, aimed at providing customers with more value-added propositions. The sale follows a series of townhall meetings and feedback sessions with DBS Vickers' employees, who were initially offered new roles in the bank but some declined. The consolidation of the brokerage industry in Singapore has led to deregulation, reduced commissions, and the rise of online trading.

site_title: Specific muscle lets your dog give you that look
summary: Scientists have identified a specific muscle, the levator anguli oculi medialis, in dogs that allows them to raise their inner eyebrows, resulting in a distinctive facial expression. This "AU101: inner eyebrow raise" is more frequent and intense in dogs than wolves, who lack this muscle. Researchers believe humans may have unconsciously favored dogs with this trait through selective breeding, potentially influencing their behavior and interaction with humans. Further studies are needed to understand the meaning behind this expression and how it varies across breeds and upbringing.

site_title: Indonesia plans more tax breaks to lift GDP growth
summary: Indonesia plans to offer more tax breaks to boost investment and accelerate economic growth, following a disappointing first quarter GDP growth of 5.07% that fell short of expectations. The country's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, stated that the government's 5.3% growth target may not be achievable. The tax breaks aim to stimulate investment and improve the business environment, but no specific details on the tax cuts were provided.

site_title: BOJ holds fire on policy, but joins Fed in warning of mounting global risks
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping its short-term rate target at -0.1% and buying government bonds, amid a gloomy global growth outlook. Despite this, the BOJ warned of increasing global risks, including trade tensions and US economic policies, and is leaning towards ramping up monetary support. Analysts expect the BOJ to ease policy further, with half of those polled predicting a cut in the coming months. The BOJ's decision was influenced by the US Federal Reserve's dovish outlook, which has led to a strengthening yen against the dollar.

images.alt_text: For the moment, analysts expect the Bank of Japan in Tokyo (above) to strengthen its forward guidance and pledge to keep current ultra-low rates longer than it promises.

site_title: Sartorial queen
summary: Chinese couturier Guo Pei showcases 29 of her best designs at the Asian Civilisations Museum, featuring extravagant and luxurious creations with historical and cultural references. Each dress took anywhere from 2,000 to 50,000 hours to make, with some designs inspired by traditional Chinese pottery and imperial attire. The exhibition aims to rebrand the museum as a craft and design museum, engaging a new generation of visitors and showcasing Guo's use of fashion to express culture and human emotions. The exhibition runs until September 15, 2019.

images.alt_text: (Left) The Palace Flower gown. (Right) "To me, fashion should be an expression of culture, tradition and heritage of civilisations." ~ Guo Pei.
Guo Pei found inspiration from porcelain for the Blue-And-White Porcelain dress.
The Snow Queen gown.
Three of Guo's ornate creations.

site_title: Hyundai previews its biggest and smallest SUVs right here in Singapore
summary: Hyundai has previewed its largest and smallest SUVs, the Palisade and Venue, in Singapore ahead of its global distributors' conference. The Palisade, the brand's flagship SUV, measures 4.98 meters long and seats up to eight adults, featuring a 200 horsepower turbodiesel engine or 277-295 horsepower petrol engines. In contrast, the Venue is a compact SUV with a 1.6-litre gasoline engine and a self-developed continuously variable transmission, aimed at young adults or small families. Both vehicles are set to be sold in Singapore in the long-term.

site_title: Sunvic unit staves off legal action as guarantor to loan
summary: Yixing Yinyan, a subsidiary of Sunvic Chemical, has avoided legal action by signing a supplemental agreement with Jiangsu Donglai Real Estate Development and Yixing Futao Credit. The agreement sets a June 30, 2020, repayment date for the 180 million yuan loan, with Jiangsu Donglai as the primary debtor. This move prevents a potential lawsuit and allows the parties to resolve the loan repayment issue.

site_title: Pavilion Energy buys Iberdrola's portfolio of LNG assets
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-owned company, acquired Iberdrola's portfolio of liquefied natural gas (LNG) assets for 115 million euros, subject to adjustments. The deal includes four million tonnes per annum LNG contracts, a UK LNG terminal, and a time-charter of a newbuild LNG vessel. Pavilion Energy CEO Frédéric Barnaud stated that the acquisition brings prime assets in Europe and the Atlantic Basin, enabling the firm to play a greater role in energy transition and offer competitive solutions to customers. The deal is part of Iberdrola's 3.5 billion euro non-strategic asset rotation plan.

images.alt_text: Mr Barnaud (left) and CEO of liberalised business at Iberdrola Aitor Moso, at the signing ceremony on Thursday.

site_title: Icelanders in shock as tourism collapse hits economy
summary: Iceland is facing a tourism collapse, with forecasts predicting a 17% drop in visitors for 2019, and a 24% decline in May. The collapse of Wow Air has sent shockwaves through the economy, with 315 workers being laid off at Reykjavik's international airport. The country's unemployment rate has risen to 3.6%, and hotel owners are feeling the pinch with overnight stays falling 5% in April. Despite concerns, Iceland's central bank is well-prepared to weather the storm, with ample policy space to cut rates if necessary.

site_title: Mazda 3 2.0 Sedan review: Mazda's impressive sedan could even make Lexus worry
summary: Mazda's seventh-generation Mazda 3 sedan has been redesigned with a focus on universal appeal, prioritizing human-centered design over performance. The result is an impressive product that raises the bar for mainstream sedans. The car boasts curves reminiscent of Italian designs and a minimalist aesthetic, with a refined interior and reduced visual noise. The 2.0-liter engine provides smoothness and ease of use, making driving a cinch even on challenging roads. With its human appeal and potential for competitive pricing, the Mazda 3 may even make Lexus worry.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) shares rallied 9% in the past week, reaching a 9-day winning streak. Despite a 15.6% drop in May, the bank's 10-year net profit CAGR remains 7.7% and dividend distribution grew 7.2%. Analysts maintain a buy recommendation for UOB, with a fair value of S$28.90. In contrast, GSS Energy's shares fell after the company sold 80% of its oil & gas arm for US$1, indicating poor performance in its business.

site_title: Spain is latest battleground for global affordable housing
summary: Spain's Socialist government has struggled to control rising rents, with May's annual rent increase accelerating to 7.5% despite rent-cap measures. The rules, enacted in March, limit annual rent increases to the inflation rate, but landlords are expected to raise rents after the five-year cap. Economists warn that the limits may backfire, with landlords starting new contracts at higher initial rents or converting properties into short-term rentals, driving up rents. The challenge is part of a global trend of governments struggling to address affordable housing issues.

site_title: Plans for the Future
summary: A Singaporean family, who had lived in the same neighbourhood for over 20 years, decided to rebuild their detached house in Serangoon Gardens to accommodate their changing needs. The rebuilt 6,400 sq ft home features a three-storey high atrium to draw in natural light, a unique open steel staircase, and an ensuite bathroom in each child's bedroom. The renovation also includes larger bedrooms, a spacious living room, a cosy family area, and a compact but efficient kitchen. The family is thrilled with the result, stating that the home now has more usable space and can last them for many years.

site_title: Demand for private equity strong, but size may work against returns
summary: Private equity investment appetite remains strong despite concerns over its potential impact on returns. Historically, PE investments have provided attractive returns, but the macro environment, including the US-China trade conflict, is causing uncertainty. The demand for PE funds has reached an all-time high, with over 3,900 funds seeking $1 trillion in funding, and mega funds are driving fundraising activity. However, research suggests that mega funds' returns may not be as impressive as expected, as larger funds are limited to investing in more mature companies, potentially leading to disappointing performance.

site_title: New Citroen C5 Aircross and revamped showroom promise magic carpet comfort
summary: Citroen unveiled the new C5 Aircross sport utility vehicle in Singapore, focusing on ride comfort as its major feature. Developed under the Citroen Advanced Comfort program, the car boasts innovative seats and suspension systems, offering a "magic carpet ride." The C5 Aircross is priced at S$136,999 and comes with features such as self-parking assist, panoramic sunroof, and 19-inch wheels. The launch coincides with the opening of a newly-renovated showroom in Singapore, aiming to revamp the brand's sales in the region.

site_title: US-China trade truce is becoming less - not more - likely
summary: US President Donald Trump's chances of reaching a comprehensive trade deal with China are decreasing, despite a possible "agreement to agree" at the upcoming G-20 summit. The "best alternative to negotiated agreement" concept suggests Trump's best-case scenario is looking better, making a deal less likely. Both sides would benefit from a more open Chinese market and stronger intellectual property protections, but changing market conditions and Trump's mood may encourage hardliners to hold out for more concessions, reducing the prospects for a comprehensive agreement.

site_title: Humming economy is Trump's main asset
summary: President Donald Trump announced his re-election bid before thousands of supporters in Orlando, Florida, expressing confidence in beating a Democratic challenger and winning a major electoral victory. Trump's speech echoed his 2015 campaign rhetoric, criticizing Democrats and the mainstream media. He portrayed himself as a victim of a "witch hunt" and allegations of "collusion" with Russian officials, aimed at reversing the outcome of the 2016 presidential election. Despite his declining approval ratings, the economy remains a strong asset for Trump.

site_title: Time For Something New
summary: Watch brands are releasing new models throughout the year to keep things fresh. Notable releases include the Chanel J12, featuring a new automatic movement and enlarged dial, and the Omega Speedmaster Apollo 11 Moonshine Gold 50th Anniversary Limited Edition. Other brands, such as Vacheron Constantin, Franck Muller, and Jaeger-LeCoultre, are celebrating anniversaries and milestones. Meanwhile, Bvlgari and Tudor are marking Chinese New Year with special collections. These new releases and celebrations highlight the ongoing evolution of the watch industry.

site_title: Navigating the ripple effects of GDPR in the Asia-Pacific
summary: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) has had a significant impact on businesses worldwide, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. Introduced over a year ago, GDPR has led to a global conversation around consumer privacy, transforming the way businesses operate. Countries such as China, India, and Malaysia have updated their data protection regulations, and Singapore has introduced initiatives to strengthen data portability and innovation. Companies must now comply with both national and GDPR requirements, with about 33% of Singapore companies believing GDPR impacts their organization. To ensure compliance, businesses can take three concrete steps: engaging with customers and regulators, implementing secure-by-design practices, and leveraging technology solutions.

site_title: Cooking For The Earth
summary: Kausmo, a new dining concept by chef Lisa Tang and restaurant manager Kuah Chew Shian, aims to reduce food wastage by using imperfect produce. The six-course tasting menu, priced at S$75, features dishes such as wild fish congee and local trevally with braised daikon. The restaurant, located at Shaw Centre, offers a unique approach to sustainable dining, encouraging customers to appreciate the value of every ingredient. By rescuing edible but not-so-pretty produce, Kausmo raises awareness about food wastage and promotes a more mindful approach to cooking and consumption.

site_title: China tells top global CEOs it will 'further open up'
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang pledged to further open up the country's economy during a meeting with top global CEOs, amid trade tensions with the US. The meeting aims to address concerns over an uneven playing field, intellectual property theft, and entry barriers. Li promised to make China more attractive to foreign investors, relaxing restrictions on access to more fields. The move comes as the US imposes tariffs on Chinese goods, threatening China's status as a manufacturing hub. The meeting with CEOs of 19 multinational companies also came ahead of a G-20 summit between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: SBI Offshore may have breached Catalist rules: report
summary: A report by KordaMentha found that SBI Offshore may have breached Catalist listing rules during a 2014 share placement. The company failed to disclose that a placee, Millennium Marine, provided a promissory note instead of paying in cash. SBI Offshore also failed to disclose the use of placement proceeds and made unauthorized write-offs, including a 17.3 million yuan write-off to subsidiary JSBI. The company plans to seek legal advice on potential breaches and breaches.

site_title: Live Long and Prosper
summary: Singapore's first vertical farm, Sky Greens, has been certified for organic vegetables grown in urban environments. Located in Lim Chu Kang, the farm uses metal towers and a water-pulley system powered by rainwater to produce 10 times more vegetables than traditional farms. The farm's nutrient mix includes recycled coffee grounds, and about half a tonne of mini cai xin and xiao bai cai are harvested daily, sold at FairPrice Finest outlets. This innovative approach aims to make sustainability a part of everyday life through healthy and sustainable food production.

site_title: BoE warns of heightened prospect of a no-deal Brexit
summary: The Bank of England warned that the prospect of a no-deal Brexit has increased, affecting the UK's economic outlook. The central bank kept interest rates unchanged at 0.75% due to volatile UK data and Brexit-related market effects. The UK's economic fate remains tied to the EU withdrawal process, with a potential default to World Trade Organization rules if a deal is not reached. Analysts predict no immediate interest rate hikes due to falling inflation and dovish central bank comments.

site_title: Sake Spotlight
summary: The Sake Festival Singapore, organized by Orihara Shoten, is set to take place on June 22 at Suntec City Convention Centre. The seventh edition will feature over 460 sake and liquors from 52 brands and companies, with last admission at 4:30pm. Attendees can sample limited-edition sake cups and labels, including collaborations and new market releases. Food options will include Okinawan soba and Japanese dishes, with tickets available for S$40 via SISTIC or S$50 at the door.

site_title: Price of electric cars still shocking
summary: The article discusses the high cost of electric cars, which remain out of reach for many consumers. The Kia Niro EV, launched in Singapore, boasts impressive features such as 204 horsepower and 455km range on a single charge. Despite its eco-friendly credentials, the car's battery charging costs around S$15. The article highlights the need for EVs to become more affordable for the masses, rather than remaining exclusive to wealthy individuals.

site_title: Body and soul
summary: The M1 CONTACT Contemporary Dance Festival features a doublebill of international artists, including Denmark's Kitt Johnson and Japan's Shintaro Oue. Johnson's "Stigma" has received rave reviews for its dark and enigmatic performance about the stigma of having a symbol burnt into one's skin. Meanwhile, Oue's "Dan-su" combines dance and dialogue to explore new forms of physical expression. The performances will take place on June 20-21 at 8pm at the Esplanade Theatre Studio.

site_title: China Nasdaq-style tech board draws spinoff listings
summary: China's SSE STAR Market, a Nasdaq-style tech board, has attracted at least nine companies to spin off units domestically. Since its launch, Western Metal Materials and Lepu Medical Technology Beijing have seen significant price increases after announcing their plans. This new market option is a significant development, offering companies a domestic listing alternative. The SSE STAR Market is expected to become a hub for companies to spin off parts of their businesses, potentially increasing liquidity and market access for Chinese companies.

site_title: Terry O'Connor to step down as Courts Asia CEO
summary: Terry O'Connor, CEO of Courts Asia, will step down on July 1 and become an executive adviser. He has led the company for 20 years, transforming it into an omnichannel retailer with stores in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Courts has been acquired by Japanese electronics retailer Nojima Corp, and O'Connor expressed his desire to support the group in an advisory capacity. The company is now in the process of hiring a new group CEO and has been delisted from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Less may be more as Inditex cuts stores but boosts space in home market Spain
summary: Inditex, the world's largest clothing retailer, has cut 297 stores in its home market of Spain by 15% since 2012, but increased overall selling space in the country by opening or expanding flagship outlets. This strategy, which has not resulted in store staff cuts, may be a risk as shoppers increasingly prefer online shopping. Despite this, Inditex's net retail space in Spain increased in the last financial year, bucking the trend of store closures in the industry. The company's plan could determine whether combining online sales with a large store network can prevail in mass-market fashion.

site_title: Cafe of Memories
summary: Old Habits Cafe & Boutique in Singapore's Telok Blangah neighbourhood offers a unique experience, serving old-fashioned root beer floats and selling toys from the childhoods of its owner, Donovan Goh. The cafe is filled with nostalgic memorabilia, including ViewMaster reels, mechanical clocks, road signs, and toys from the 1980s. Goh's collection has grown over a decade and includes rare items, such as an enamel Milkmaid signboard, which is being sold for at least S$2000. The cafe attracts toy and vintage collectors, as well as locals looking for a nostalgic treat.

site_title: If experts know so much, why don't people trust them?
summary: A 2019 article discusses the UK's distrust of experts, as stated by then-minister Michael Gove. This sentiment is echoed globally, with politicians using anti-expert rhetoric to build support. The article notes that experts are often targeted with derogatory terms, such as "eggheads" and "nerds." The distrust of evidence-based policies and experts is attributed to populist politics, where politicians capitalize on public dissatisfaction with perceived elitism. This phenomenon is seen across countries and contexts, highlighting a growing divide between those who value expertise and those who distrust it.

site_title: Time to rethink wine criticism
summary: Wine criticism, dominated by Robert Parker for 30 years, is being reevaluated as a system that may not be the most useful for consumers. Critics focus on individual bottle reviews, which can be influenced by context and personal biases. A more effective approach might be to evaluate wine producers, their styles, and methods, providing consumers with longer-lasting and more informative recommendations. This shift could empower consumers to make their own informed decisions and break their dependence on critics' reviews.

site_title: Renault, Nissan join Waymo for driverless mobility services
summary: Renault and Nissan have teamed up with Waymo, the autonomous vehicle unit of Alphabet, to explore driverless mobility services in France and Japan. The three companies will research commercial, legal, and regulatory issues related to providing driverless transportation-as-a-service offerings. Renault and Nissan plan to create joint ventures to develop driverless mobility services in their home markets, with the possibility of expanding to other countries, including China. The agreement does not include operation of such services, but leaves room for Waymo to take a stake in the firms.

site_title: Cream of the Crop
summary:

The local F&B industry sees the opportunity as a chance to boost tourism and create awareness for local chefs. Top chefs and restaurants, including Odette and Nouri, are expected to benefit from the exposure. However, the guide's voting system has been criticized for being subjective and prone to manipulation, with some restaurants allegedly gaming the system to secure a spot on the list. The guide's organizers assure that the process is monitored and anonymous.

site_title: Bungalow in Belmont Rd selling for S$39.8m
summary: A newly-completed, fully furnished freehold bungalow in Belmont Road, Singapore, is being sold for S$39.8 million, working out to S$2,653 psf. The two-storey property features six bedrooms, a swimming pool, home theatre, and a wine cellar. The sale is the 16th Good Class Bungalow transaction this year, totaling S$313.3 million, and is expected to be similar to the first half of 2019 in terms of volume and sales value. Experts predict a drop in transactions in the second half of 2019 due to global uncertainties and a narrowing of the official Singapore GDP growth forecast.

images.alt_text: The Belmont Road house has an attic, roof terrace and a basement for 10 cars. It also has six bedrooms, a guest room, gym, pool and wine cellar.

site_title: US mortgage applications fall from 33-month high
summary: US mortgage applications declined 3.4% last week to 511.8, the lowest reading since September 2016. Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 4.14%, up two basis points from the prior week. Refinance applications fell 3.5% to 1,888.8, while home purchase applications decreased 3.5% to 268.6. Despite rising rates, refinance activity remained high, with the refinance share of mortgage activity at 50.2%.

site_title: T-Mobile prepares for Boost auction if Dish Network talks stall
summary: T-Mobile prepares for a potential auction of its prepaid brand Boost Mobile if talks with Dish Network stall. Goldman Sachs, advising T-Mobile, plans to send out books to prospective buyers in two weeks. Despite Dish remaining the frontrunner, Goldman is preparing for an auction due to uncertainty over the sale's details. T-Mobile and Sprint's merger faces regulatory approval, with the US Department of Justice recommending a block. The company hopes to reach an agreement with the Justice Department by early next week.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Land secured a 850 million yuan (S$170 million) green loan for the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City development. City Developments lowered its takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels to 43.48% due to a minority shareholder disposing of shares. Meanwhile, the US market experienced a decline in stocks amid tariff threats, and NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Investment in 5G will further dent finances of Indian operators
summary: India's telecom operators face a significant financial challenge with the upcoming 5G rollout, with estimated costs ranging from US$59 billion to US$70 billion. The investment will further dent the finances of operators, which are already in the midst of efforts to pare debt. Despite the potential for increased revenue streams, the high cost of spectrum pricing poses a significant challenge, with some carriers considering deferring the purchase or buying at a later date. The 5G technology has the potential to revolutionize connectivity and drive India's digital economy, which could reach US$1 trillion by 2025.

site_title: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong faces 13 fresh charges, and is denied bail
summary: Singaporean lawyer Jeffrey Ong faces 13 new charges related to alleged fraud, bringing the total to 22. Ong, 41, was denied bail after investigators revealed he fled Singapore on May 13, leaving behind unauthorized withdrawals of clients' money, and was found hiding in Malaysia. The charges allege Ong forged bank statements to deceive a lawyer, Chan Yi Zhang, into believing $4.86 million was still held in escrow. Ong's case will be heard again on July 11.

site_title: This S$752k Mercedes-AMG is aimed at those who 'win at life'
summary: The Mercedes-AMG GT 4-Door Coupe, priced up to S$751,888, is a high-performance sedan targeting individuals who prioritize style and performance over size and comfort. The car boasts an 8-cylinder engine with 639 horsepower, accelerating from 0-100km/h in 3.2 seconds. Its rival, BMW's 8 Series Gran Coupe, is expected to launch soon with a price tag of over S$620,000, competing with Porsche's Panamera in the high-end market. Both cars aim to appeal to the "driven and ambitious" individual who values performance and style.

site_title: Value opportunities for real estate in Asia-Pac cities and beyond
summary: Real estate investors are shifting their focus to value-added strategies in Asia-Pacific cities and beyond due to a low-growth, low-inflationary environment with low interest rates. This environment creates opportunities for active real estate strategies to thrive, with core and opportunistic strategies being less effective. Value-added investors can generate higher returns through stronger capital growth, active management, and repositioning buildings through refurbishments or renovations. Three key cities to consider are Tokyo, Seoul, and Melbourne, with strong demand for repositioned properties and potential for rental growth. Global diversification is also recommended to achieve better risk-adjusted returns.

site_title: Oracle investors breathe a sigh of relief on rising sales
summary: Oracle's shares rose 5% after the company reported its first year-on-year increase in total revenue in five years, driven by growth in cloud-based applications and a 12% increase in cloud licence and on-premise licence sales. The company forecast sales growth of up to 2% in the current period and reported an adjusted profit of $1.16 per share. Oracle's alliance with Microsoft aims to stay competitive in the cloud-computing space. The company has been focusing on its star products and cutting costs, with an adjusted operating margin of 47%, the highest in five years.

site_title: ST Engg-Airbus JV secures job to convert A321 passenger jet into cargo freighter
summary: ST Engineering's joint venture with Airbus, Elbe Flugzeugwerke (EFW), has secured a letter of intent from US-based aircraft leasing company BBAM for an A321 converted freighter. The passenger aircraft will be converted into a 14-pallet cargo configuration in mid-2020.

site_title: New chef shines at Black Swan
summary: Chef Alysia Chan's menu at The Black Swan emphasizes minimizing food waste and responsible sourcing, showcasing dishes such as creamy, beer-infused venus clams and a hearty, charred wagyu rib eye. A set lunch menu offers a broccoli and avocado salad and a lobster main course, with a vegetarian option of charred sugarloaf cabbage that falls short. The restaurant's Art Deco interior remains a familiar, retro touch, but the new chef's focus on wholesome, holistic food is a welcome change. The Black Swan has earned a 7-star rating for its culinary efforts.

site_title: EU nations aim high with plan to tax air travel
summary: European Union nations are discussing a plan to tax air travel as part of the EU's goal to become carbon neutral by 2050. The Netherlands and France aim to end tax exemptions on jet fuel and plane tickets, with the Netherlands planning to introduce a 7.50 euro ticket tax for departing passengers from 2021 if no EU deal is reached. Research suggests that higher air travel taxes could lead to a reduction in emissions, with a one percent increase in ticket prices expected to result in a one percent decrease in demand.

site_title: BOE warns on heightened no-deal Brexit prospect
summary: The Bank of England warned that the prospect of a no-deal Brexit has risen since May, increasing downside risks to UK growth and intensifying global trade tensions. The central bank kept interest rates unchanged at 0.75% despite volatile UK data partly due to Brexit effects. The UK's economic outlook depends on the nature and timing of EU withdrawal, with a no-deal Brexit resulting in trade relations governed by World Trade Organization rules. Analysts expect no interest rate hike in the near future due to falling UK inflation and dovish central bank statements.

site_title: STI gains as Fed confirms dovish stance
summary: The US Federal Reserve confirmed its dovish stance, opening the door for impending rate cuts. This news boosted regional equity markets, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 26.34 points or 0.8% to 3,314.51. Markets in Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and South Korea also ended higher. The confirmation of a likely meeting between the US and China at the G-20 summit next week added to the positive sentiment.

site_title: Keppel Land secures first green loan for Tianjin Eco-City project
summary: Keppel Land secured its first green loan of S$170 million for the Phase 1 development of Seasons City in the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City. The five-year loan, disbursed by HSBC Group China, will be used to finance energy-efficient and sustainable features, including solar energy and chillers. The project aims to achieve over 9 million yuan in annual energy and water savings. This is the first green loan granted by HSBC China for a property project in mainland China.

site_title: Sri Lanka to charge police for 'lapses' over Easter attacks
summary: Sri Lankan authorities have ordered criminal charges against nine police officers for "lapses" before the Easter Sunday suicide bombings that killed 258 people. The Attorney General found the officers liable for criminal negligence after an inquiry commission appointed by President Maithripala Sirisena found they failed to act on warnings ahead of the April 21 bombings. The officers will face criminal investigations for their alleged negligence.

site_title: Fitness clusters emerge in US malls
summary: Fitness clusters are emerging in US malls, with wellness-based retail enterprises replacing traditional stores. Boutique fitness studios, such as Pilates, yoga, and indoor cycling, are attracting consumers willing to invest in their physical health. Landlords are partnering with these studios to create a curated mix of fitness and wellness options. This trend is driven by the desire for group exercise and community, as well as the need for recovery from intense workouts. Entrepreneurs are capitalizing on this demand, opening studios focused on recovery and wellness services.

site_title: Iraq officially invites pope to visit
summary: Iraq's President Barham Saleh has officially invited Pope Francis to visit the country, despite security concerns. The invitation comes after Pope Francis expressed interest in traveling to Iraq in 2019. The visit would aim to promote peace and unity among different religions, as Iraq is the birthplace of Abraham. Pope Francis has a history of visiting Muslim countries, including the UAE, Turkey, and Egypt, and has made boosting ties between Christianity and Islam a key part of his papacy. The visit would be a significant milestone in Iraq's healing process.

site_title: Britain broke the law on Saudi arms exports, court rules
summary: A UK court ruled that Britain broke the law by allowing arms sales to Saudi Arabia that may have been used in Yemen's war, potentially violating human rights legislation. The decision does not immediately halt arms exports but puts a stay on granting new export licenses to Saudi Arabia, Britain's largest weapons purchaser. The court found the government failed to assess whether the Saudi-led coalition had committed violations of international humanitarian law during the Yemen conflict. The UK International Trade Minister, Liam Fox, plans to appeal the judgment and will not grant new licenses for export to Saudi Arabia and its coalition partners.

site_title: Tesla analysts warn on demand, profits as quarter nears end
summary: Tesla analysts warn that demand for the company's cars may be below expectations, with Goldman Sachs analyst David Tamberrino predicting a "downward path" for the shares. The second quarter's deliveries are expected to be lower than initially thought, with some analysts forecasting 88,900 units. The company's international rollout is seen as a key factor, but also expected to hurt margins. Shares have fallen nearly 34% this year, and analysts maintain a sell rating on the stock, with price targets ranging from $158 to $190.

site_title: Mercurius gets deadline extension till end-Aug to keep listing status
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment, a Catalist-listed company, has received a deadline extension from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) until August 30 to demonstrate its business viability and retain its listing status. The extension comes after the company announced plans to acquire a 50% stake in a Thai hotel property, the Sheraton Phuket Grand Bay Resort, and form a joint venture with the property developers. If Mercurius fails to complete the joint venture by the deadline, it may be deemed a cash company under listing rules.

site_title: SBI Offshore may have breached Catalist rules, review finds
summary: SBI Offshore may have breached Catalist listing rules in a 2014 share placement, according to a KordaMentha review. The company failed to disclose a promissory note from a Chinese investor instead of cash payments, and also didn't disclose the use of placement proceeds. Additionally, SBI Offshore failed to disclose an advanced payment of 10 million yuan to a subsidiary and a write-off of 17.3 million yuan. The company's auditors found the write-off was unauthorized and owed the parent nothing. SBI Offshore plans to seek legal advice on potential breaches.

site_title: Singapore, Jordan partnership can deepen Asean-Mid East links: Chan
summary: Singapore and Jordan are strengthening their partnership, with Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing stating that a deeper collaboration will expand companies' reach in Asean and the Middle East. The digital economy is a key area for the two countries to transcend their geography. The minister invited Jordanian companies to participate in Singapore's FinTech Festival and Networked Trade Platform, and the two countries signed at least six memorandums of understanding. The partnership aims to promote trade, investment, and cooperation in areas such as energy generation and consumption.

site_title: HK lets protesters' deadline to scrap extradition bill pass
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam suspended the extradition bill, but protesters' demands for its complete withdrawal, dropping charges against arrested protesters, and police accountability remain unmet. The deadline set by protesters to scrap the bill has passed, setting the stage for new demonstrations. The city's pro-democracy camp is gearing up for an annual march on July 1, calling for public participation. Beijing has expressed support for Lam's decision but has been angered by Western criticism of the legislation, which could impact Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms.

images.alt_text: A few protesters gathered outside government headquarters in Hong Kong on Thursday. The activists have pledged to surround the Legislative Council on Friday if their demands are not met.

site_title: Straits Trading unit expands logistics footprint with Korea partnership, Aussie buy
summary: Straits Trading's unit, SRE, has entered a partnership with IGIS Asset Management in South Korea to invest in logistics facilities, committing KRW110 billion (S$127 million). The joint venture will develop a 190,000 sq m facility, with construction expected to start in July 2019 and completion by 2021. Separately, SRE's Integrated Logistics Partners will acquire a land parcel in Adelaide, Australia, for a build-to-suit project targeting completion by Q3 2020. The expansion aims to capitalize on positive macro trends in urbanization, retail, and infrastructure spending.

site_title: Straits Trading unit targets S Korea, Australia logistics deals
summary: Straits Trading's unit, Straits Real Estate, has partnered with IGIS Asset Management in South Korea and Commerical & General in Australia to invest in logistics facilities. The partnership aims to deploy up to KRW400 billion in South Korea and acquire a land parcel for a build-to-suit project in Adelaide, Australia. The projects are expected to extend the weighted average lease expiry of Straits Trading's portfolio to 8.8 years, driven by positive macro trends such as urbanization and infrastructure spending.

site_title: Shedding light on the HK protests
summary: The documentary "Joshua: Teenager Vs. Superpower" on Netflix sheds light on Hong Kong's 2011 student protests against China's national education programme, led by 14-year-old activist Joshua Wong. Wong's efforts sparked a movement, and his case is eerily relevant to recent protests in Hong Kong. The documentary reveals how Wong's activism, along with his friends, grew city-wide opposition and ultimately led to a massive protest in 2014. The film highlights the power of individual action in effecting change, with Wong's own experiences and contributions to the cause.

site_title: Foreigners continue to remain net sellers of Japan stocks for sixth week
summary: Foreigners sold a net 190.65 billion yen (S$823.4 million) worth of Japanese stocks for the sixth consecutive week, citing Sino-U.S trade tensions. Despite local shares gaining 1.1% and 0.9% in the Nikkei and Topix indexes, respectively. Japanese investors, however, continued their sixth straight week of net purchases, buying 232.5 billion yen of overseas equities. This trend suggests a mixed sentiment among investors, with foreigners exiting Japanese stocks and Japanese investors seeking diversification through international investments.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG C 43 4Matic Coupe review: Why the best C-Class AMG model isn't the most expensive one
summary: The Mercedes-AMG C 43 4Matic Coupe is considered the best C-Class AMG model for keen drivers, offering a fun and engaging driving experience. Its 390hp engine provides smooth acceleration and responsive handling, making it suitable for both twisty roads and straight-line performance. While it may not be as powerful as the C 63 S, the C 43 is a more comfortable and less volatile option, making it easier to live with daily. A facelift has updated the car's interior, but its features are largely cosmetic. The C 43 is available in Singapore for S$350,888.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Managing partner Jeffrey Ong of JLC Advisors was denied bail and slapped with 13 more forgery charges. Temasek-owned Pavilion Energy acquired Iberdrola's LNG assets for $176.2 million. Sunseap secured a $43 million green loan to install solar power systems on rooftops in Singapore. ST Engineering's joint venture converted an A321 passenger jet into a cargo freighter. Commodities trading firm Noble Group took a stake in Australian rare earths developer Arafura. Singapore shares gained 0.8% as the US Federal Reserve confirmed a possibility of rate cuts. The news came as Vietnam was surprised by Trump's tariff announcement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.89 points to 1,675.43 on Thursday, driven by a volume of 2.3 billion lots worth RM2.3 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 470 to 351.

site_title: US: Dovish Fed sends Wall Street higher, S&P 500 hits record intraday high
summary: The US stock market saw a significant surge on June 20, 2019, with the S&P 500 hitting a record intraday high, driven by expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve to address growing economic risks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 161.38 points, or 0.61%, to 26,665.38, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also reached new highs. The market optimism was fueled by signs of a possible rate cut as early as next month, providing comfort to investors.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks chalk up fourth straight gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by speculation the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates next month. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.23% to 28,550.43, while the Shanghai Composite Index rallied 2.38% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 1.95%. These gains were attributed to the Fed's indication of possible interest rate cuts, which boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Terry O'Connor to step down as Courts Asia CEO from July 1
summary: Terry O'Connor will step down as Courts Asia CEO on July 1, transitioning to an executive adviser role. He will oversee stakeholder relationship management and integration process. O'Connor has led Courts for 20 years, transforming the company into an omnichannel retailer and expanding into Malaysia and Indonesia. He expressed his desire to relinquish operational responsibilities and support the group in an advisory capacity following the buyout by Japanese retailer Nojima Corp. Courts is now in the process of hiring a new group CEO.

site_title: Business-class seats on points just became pricier at Qantas
summary: Qantas has announced a 15% increase in points needed for a business-class seat on domestic or international flights in September, and a 9% increase for upgrades from economy. The airline aims to address issues with limited reward seats and high booking costs. However, it will add over 1 million extra reward seats and cut points required for international economy seats by up to 10%. Additionally, carrier charges on international bookings made with points will be reduced by up to 50%. This marks the first increase in points needed for business-class travel in 15 years.

site_title: Australian shares hit 11-year peak on fresh rate cut hopes, NZ edges down
summary: Australian shares reached an 11-year peak on June 20, 2019, as hopes for US and local rate cuts boosted demand for stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% to 6,687.40, driven by expectations of possible rate cuts as soon as July. Global equity markets surged after the US Federal Reserve signaled possible rate cuts this year.

site_title: Freehold Sky Everton condo at former Asia Gardens site to open for booking on Saturday
summary: Freehold Sky Everton condo, located at the former Asia Gardens site, will open for booking on Saturday with prices starting from S$1.14 million for a one-bedroom unit. The 36-storey single tower condo has 262 units, ranging from 463 sq ft to 2,228 sq ft, and will feature four levels of facilities. The development is expected to be completed in 2023 and is a two-minute walk from the upcoming Cantonment MRT station.

site_title: JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong denied bail, slapped with 13 more forgery charges
summary: Singaporean lawyer Jeffrey Ong, managing partner of JLC Advisors, was denied bail after being slapped with 13 fresh forgery charges. He faces a total of 22 charges, including unauthorized withdrawals of client funds and forgery of bank statements. Ong was charged in connection with missing S$33 million funds held in escrow by JLC Advisors and was found to have traveled to Malaysia to avoid tracking. A judge rejected his bail application, citing him as a "high flight risk."

site_title: Flash: Jeffrey Ong denied bail, slapped with 13 more forgery charges
summary: Jeffrey Ong, managing partner of JLC Advisors, was denied bail on Thursday due to high flight risk. He was found with a stolen Malaysian passport and faces 13 additional forgery charges, totaling S$32 million in unauthorised transactions. Ong had previously been charged with forgery and cheating.

site_title: European stock rally on Fed rate cut signal
summary: European stocks rallied on June 20, 2019, after the US Federal Reserve signaled a potential interest rate cut. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.8%, and Paris' CAC 40 increased 0.6%. The rally was seen as a response to the Fed's signal, although a Bank of England announcement also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Temasek's Pavilion Energy acquiring Iberdrola's portfolio of LNG assets for 115m euros
summary: Temasek-owned Pavilion Energy has acquired Iberdrola's portfolio of liquefied natural gas (LNG) assets for 115 million euros, subject to adjustments. The portfolio includes long-term sale and supply LNG contracts, regasification assets, and a time-charter of a newbuild MEGI LNG vessel, totaling around four million tonnes per annum. The deal aims to enhance Pavilion Energy's global reach and competitiveness, enabling it to play a greater role in the energy transition and offer solutions to customers and suppliers.

site_title: Iran says has shot down US drone over its territory: TV
summary: Iran's Revolutionary Guard claimed to have shot down a US "spy drone" over its territory after it entered Iranian airspace, according to Iranian state television. The US-made Global Hawk surveillance drone was reportedly brought down in the southern coastal province of Hormozgan. The incident occurred on June 20, 2019.

images.alt_text: Iran's Revolutionary Guard said on Thursday it had shot down a US "spy drone" over its territory after it violated Iranian airspace, according to Iranian state television.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise slightly amid caution on trade talks; won up 1.2%
summary: South Korea's Kospi index rose 0.31% to 2,131.29, driven by a 1.2% gain in the Korean won against the dollar. Despite the US Federal Reserve's dovish signal, investors remained cautious ahead of the G-20 summit, where trade talks between the US and China are expected to take place. The benchmark bond yield fell sharply, and foreigners were net sellers of 13.8 billion won worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: Irrevocable undertakings for M&C shares CDL does not own dip to 43.48%
summary: City Developments (CDL) secured irrevocable undertakings for 43.48% of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) shares, down from 43.58%, after minority shareholder IVA disposed of 117,437 shares. CDL launched a takeover bid in June, offering 685 pence per share, valuing M&C at £2.23 billion. The offer is a higher cash bid than CDL's previous attempt in December 2017, which was blocked by M&C's minority shareholders. The deal aims to secure control of M&C.

site_title: Recycled bikes from Singapore, Malaysia get Myanmar kids to school
summary: Myanmar children, many living in poverty, now have easier access to education thanks to 10,000 recycled bikes donated by entrepreneur Mike Than Tun Win. The bikes, shipped from Singapore and Malaysia, were previously in "graveyards" after bike-sharing companies pulled out. Mike plans to distribute 100,000 bikes over five years, aiming to keep kids in school longer and give them a chance to escape poverty. The initiative, called "Lesswalk", has already reached 200 students in Yangon and will expand to Mandalay and Sagaing regions later this month.

site_title: Noble Group to take stake in Australian rare earths developer Arafura
summary: Commodities trading firm Noble Group is set to take an 8% stake in Australian rare earths developer Arafura through a $7.2 million share offering, underwriting $23.2 million. The investment is Noble's second in a rare earths project, following its 12.5% stake in Canada-listed Mkango Resources. The move aims to capitalize on growing demand for rare earths in high-tech industries and electric vehicles, amid supply concerns due to China's potential reduction in shipments.

site_title: Malaysian construction headed for a rebound: Report
summary: Malaysia's construction sector is expected to rebound, driven by government infrastructure mega-projects and domestic initiatives. Analysts UOB Kay Hian predict a 1.5% increase in contractors' costs due to higher ready mixed concrete prices, but this will be passed on to future contracts with minimal margin erosion. Companies with limited reliance on government projects and those involved in private sector projects are likely to benefit, while mid-cap construction companies with high overheads may struggle. The sector's growth visibility remains clear, particularly for turnkey contractors and sub-contractors.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.8% as Fed confirms rate cut possibility
summary: The US Federal Reserve confirmed the possibility of rate cuts, boosting equity markets, including Singapore's Straits Times Index, which rose 0.8% to 3,314.51. Other regional markets also ended higher, following the confirmation. This positive sentiment follows previous rallies in Singapore stocks, ahead of GDP data and other market events.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical unit staves off legal action as guarantor to 180m yuan loan
summary: Sunvic Chemical's wholly owned subsidiary Yixing Yinyan has avoided legal action as guarantor to a 180 million yuan loan by signing a supplemental agreement. The agreement extends the repayment date to June 30, 2020, and prevents lender Yixing Futao Credit from initiating legal proceedings before then. This comes after Yixing Futao Credit initially sent a letter of demand for payment in November 2018, following Jiangsu Donglai Real Estate Development's failure to repay the loan on October 15, 2018.

site_title: Del Monte Q4 earnings double to US$6.3m on stronger US margins
summary: Del Monte's Q4 earnings more than doubled to US$6.3 million, driven by a 15.9% gross margin for its US subsidiary, thanks to a strategic price increase and divestiture of a low-margin business. Q4 sales dropped 13.3% to US$432.6 million, mainly due to the divestiture and lower sales in the USA and Philippines. The company posted a full-year net income of US$20.3 million, a turnaround from a US$36.5 million loss a year ago. Del Monte plans to diversify beyond canned goods and introduced new products in refrigerated and frozen categories.

site_title: Renault CEO Bollore has no plans to reduce Nissan stake
summary: Renault CEO Thierry Bollore stated that reducing Nissan's stake is not part of the company's agenda. Despite Nissan's plan to urge Renault to cut its 43.4% stake, Bollore emphasized the importance of continuing to improve the alliance. Renault and Fiat Chrysler are seeking to resuscitate their failed merger plan and secure Nissan's approval. The two companies are set to meet in early July to discuss their partnership, with Bollore describing the talks as "massive." The 20-year-old alliance has been strained since Carlos Ghosn's arrest, and Nissan is due to hold a shareholder meeting on June 25.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US rate-cut hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, driven by hopes of US interest rate cuts. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.60%, while the Topix index rose 0.30%. The US central bank's signals of potential rate cuts boosted market sentiment, leading to modest gains on Wall Street.

site_title: Indonesia plans more tax breaks to lift GDP growth
summary: Indonesia plans to cut several taxes to boost investment and accelerate economic growth. The country's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, announced plans to reduce the luxury sales tax threshold for houses and apartments, cut the income tax rate for infrastructure-related securities to 5%, and introduce a "super deductible tax" incentive. However, a plan to trim the corporate tax rate to 20% still requires parliamentary approval. The move aims to lift Indonesia's GDP growth, which may be hard to reach, as the country's first-quarter growth expanded 5.07% from a year earlier.

site_title: BOJ holds fire on policy, warns of heightening global risks
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping short-term rates at -0.1% and a pledge to guide 10-year government bond yields around zero percent. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned of heightening global risks, including protectionism and uncertainty over US economic policies. The BOJ expressed concerns over the escalating US-China trade war and its impact on the global economy, while many policymakers remain wary of expanding stimulus due to limited ammunition.

site_title: A US$222b manager shifts to cash on worries trade war will spread
summary: A US$222 billion wealth manager, Pictet Wealth Management, has increased its cash holdings to 15% due to concerns that the US may impose tariffs on Europe, potentially disrupting the global economic recovery. The firm's chief investment officer, David Gaud, warns that such tariffs would be "very destructive" amid economic weakness in Italy and Brexit. The move comes as US President Donald Trump has threatened to target European countries and China with tariffs, and global equities have experienced a 6.2% decline in May.

site_title: Trump briefed on missile strike in Saudi Arabia, spokesman says
summary: US President Donald Trump has been briefed on a missile strike in Saudi Arabia, where Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthis claimed to have struck a power station in Al-Shuqaiq city. The Houthis have increased missile and drone attacks on Saudi cities in the past two weeks. There was no immediate confirmation from Saudi authorities. The US is closely monitoring the situation and consulting with partners and allies.

site_title: Banks to fight over US$18 trillion held by the poorest of the rich
summary: Banks are shifting focus to serving the US$18 trillion held by the poorest of the rich, with 76 million people and growing, as declining margins push them to seek wealth further down the scale. Wealth managers, fintechs, and online brokers are competing to serve this affluent segment, which is expected to grow at 6.2% over the next five years. New technology is allowing lenders to service this segment more efficiently, but traditional private banks often over-serve clients, leading to reduced engagement and potential "orphaned" clients.

site_title: Trade disputes to dominate as Asean meets in Bangkok
summary: Southeast Asian leaders will discuss the impact of the US-China tariff war at the Bangkok summit, focusing on trade and regional economic issues. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) pact, which includes 10 Asean economies and major Asian nations, is a key topic. The trade war has driven manufacturers to flee China to Southeast Asia, but negotiations for the RCEP deal have become stuck over environmental and labor protections. Disputes over the South China Sea and Myanmar's treatment of Rohingya Muslims are also expected to be discussed.

site_title: Delta Air not expecting flight cancellations as result of tech issue
summary: Delta Air Lines stated it won't expect flight cancellations due to a technical glitch affecting booking, check-in, and boarding services.
