site_title: Australian shares end at best in over 11 years as US-China resuming trade talks
summary: Australian shares reached their best level in over 11 years, closing 1.2% higher at 6,648.1 on the S&P/ASX 200 index, driven by the resumption of US-China trade talks, expectations of lower US interest rates, and a dovish tilt from the European Central Bank. US President Trump's announcement that officials from both sides would prepare for his meeting with China's President Xi Jinping during the G-20 summit in Japan next week boosted Australian resource stocks.

site_title: Japan says G-20 summit to debate trade including WTO reform
summary: Japan's G-20 summit in Osaka will focus on trade discussions, including WTO reform. The summit comes as trade tensions have intensified, and the G-20 countries have warned of taking further action. Japan's vice-finance minister Masatsugu Asakawa stated that there's a shared understanding among G-20 economies to accept exchange-rate moves driven by monetary policies, as long as they're not currency manipulation. Japan, as this year's G-20 chair, will lead the discussions.

site_title: Manila co-working space to grow by 10% a year: Colliers
summary: Manila's co-working space market is expected to grow by 10% annually for the next three years, driven by a tight office market, mobile workforce, and multinational corporations seeking lower operating costs. The flexible workspace area in the city increased by 14% in 2018 to 3.8 million square feet, according to Colliers. Industry consultancy Colliers predicts steady growth as foreign and local players enter the market, with a focus on corporate demand and small business boom.

site_title: In his remit: African fintech entrepreneur helps migrants move money
summary: Ismail Ahmed, founder of WorldRemit, is revolutionizing the remittances business by offering migrant laborers a more convenient and affordable way to send money home. The global remittances market is sizeable, with $689 billion in 2018, and personal transfers are crucial for recipient families. Ahmed's company is leveraging technology to lower costs, with the global average cost of sending $200 remaining high at around 7% in 2019. He aims to increase the share of cashless or digital remittances from 10% to 40-60% in the next few years.

site_title: AnAn International seeks further time extension to hold FY2018 AGM, release Q1 FY2019 results
summary: ANAN International Ltd has applied for a further extension to hold its FY2018 AGM and release Q1 FY2019 results, initially due on June 28. The company is seeking more time due to outstanding matters, including a pending appeal against a Singapore High Court winding up order related to a US$170.4 million claim by VTB Bank. The appeal is scheduled for November 2019. ANAN International's shares remained flat at S$0.004. The company is still finalizing its audited group accounts for FY2018 and the Independent Auditor's Report to the Members.

site_title: Blockchain platform Zilliqa teams up with payments startup Xfers
summary: Blockchain platform Zilliqa has partnered with payments startup Xfers to implement distributed ledger technology in payments processing. Xfers will utilize Zilliqa's smart contracts to make payments more efficient and transparent for its 500,000 users. The partnership aims to leverage blockchain technology to speed up cross-border transactions. Zilliqa's platform can process 2,828 transactions per second, surpassing Ethereum and Bitcoin. The collaboration also includes a 12-week incubation program, ZILHive, to support projects building on the Zilliqa blockchain.

site_title: 6 out of 11 'super penthouses' now for sale in the world are in Singapore: List Sotheby's
summary: Six out of 11 super penthouses currently for sale worldwide are located in Singapore, according to List Sotheby's International Realty. The largest in Singapore, the Wallich Residence, spans 21,108 sq ft and features a private garden, pool, and cabana. Only six super penthouse transactions took place in Singapore between 2006 and 2019, with the most recent sale being a 10,300 sq ft duplex penthouse for S$60 million in 2017. The global market also features a 37,674 sq ft penthouse in Monaco priced at US$335 million.

site_title: Facebook faces pushback from Washington over crypto project
summary: US lawmakers are pushing back against Facebook's plans to create a new cryptocurrency, Libra, citing concerns over data protection and potential money laundering risks. House Financial Services Committee chairman Maxine Waters urged the company to halt development until Congress and regulators can examine it. Lawmakers also questioned whether Libra will have adequate oversight, with some calling for hearings and others expressing concerns over Facebook's ability to dominate new industries. The company plans to launch Libra in 2020.

site_title: Toyota snub dents Saudi Arabia's manufacturing drive
summary: Saudi Arabia's efforts to lure Toyota to build a car plant have stalled due to high labor costs, a small domestic market, and a lack of local supplies. Toyota concluded that the project would require huge subsidies to be viable, and the company has rebuffed Riyadh's overtures. The kingdom's national industrial strategy aims to create 1.6 million manufacturing and logistics jobs by 2030, but securing a deal with a major automaker like Toyota is a key target. Saudi Arabia has also struggled to attract other carmakers, with Jaguar Land Rover shelving a deal in 2012 and Nissan reportedly considering a contract manufacturing deal without the Nissan brand.

site_title: Trump's bid to block Deutsche Bank subpoena shifts to higher court
summary: US President Donald Trump has asked a federal appeals panel in Manhattan to block House Democrats from obtaining his financial records from Deutsche Bank AG and Capital One Financial Corp. Trump claims the subpoenas seek "enormous volumes of documents" and are politically motivated. A three-judge panel of the Second Circuit appeals court could hear arguments as early as August, with a potential US Supreme Court review. If Trump loses, Congress may gain insight into his family finances, potentially delaying the banks from turning over documents.

site_title: Two in five Singapore employees will look to change jobs in 2019: Randstad
summary: Two in five Singapore employees, or 39%, plan to change employers in 2019, driven by a desire for a limited career path. Millennials (43%) and Gen X employees (41%) are most likely to make the switch, with younger workers seeking pleasant work environments and training, while mature workers value flexibility and strong management. Attractive salary and benefits remain the top criteria, followed by good work-life balance, job security, and career progression.

images.alt_text: Thirty-nine per cent of employees in Singapore, or roughly two in five, plan to change employers this year, and of them, 40 per cent say a 'limited career path' is their key motivating factor.

site_title: Trump continues to poke Federal Reserve as policy meet opens
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to make its latest policy announcement, with most Fed watchers expecting no interest rate change but a possible downward shift. President Donald Trump has continued to pressure the Fed, criticizing their recent rate hikes and demanding an interest rate cut to boost the economy. Trump has hinted at possibly demoting Fed Chief Jerome Powell, who must walk a tightrope between economic necessity and political pressure. The Fed may signal a rate cut, potentially the first in a decade, amid signs of a slowing global economy and trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore companies lagging in upskilling offerings; white-collar staff say they lack expertise to do job well: reports
summary: Singapore companies are lagging in providing upskilling opportunities to their employees, with two-thirds of professionals feeling daunted by industry changes and only 17% satisfied with learning and development offerings. A survey found that time is the main barrier, and employees feel they lack expertise to do their job well, with 74% of white-collar workers feeling ill-equipped. The top three rising skills in Singapore are blockchain, workflow automation, and human-centred design, which are in high demand and driving competition for candidates with these skills.

site_title: Trump launches 2020 reelection campaign, calling US 'envy of the world'
summary: US President Donald Trump officially launched his 2020 reelection campaign in Orlando, Florida, calling the US economy the "envy of the world." Trump promised to "keep America great again" and vowed to defeat Democratic opponents who seek to "destroy" the country. Despite dismal early poll numbers, Trump remains buoyed by strong job growth and the loyalty of his right-wing base. Key states, such as Florida, will be crucial in the election, and Trump has focused on populist and nationalist issues, including immigration and trade.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump launched his 2020 reelection campaign on Tuesday, whipping up a crowd of at least 20,000 with a nationalist boast about the US economy being the "envy" of the world and warning that opposition Democrats want to "destroy" the country.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge on renewed trade hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged over 2% at the open on Wednesday after US President Donald Trump said he had "very good" talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping on trade, indicating a possible restart of negotiations ahead of a meeting next week. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.64% to 28,224.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.87% to 2,944.12. The positive momentum in Hong Kong shares was largely driven by renewed hopes of a trade deal between the US and China.

site_title: Singapore shares open sharply higher on Wednesday; STI up 1.17% to 3,276.49
summary: Singapore shares surged 1.17% to 3,276.49 on Wednesday, following a US stock rally and hopes for a G-20 breakthrough in US-China trade talks. The Straits Times Index rose 37.76 points, with gains outnumbering losses 125 to 21. Key movers included DBS, UOB, and OCBC, while Rex International and Y Ventures led the gains. Regional markets, including Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong's Hang Seng, also rose, while Shanghai declined.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS up 3.02% after OCBC Investment Research upgrades it to 'buy' on price correction, strong fundamentals
summary: DBS shares rose 3.02% to S$25.55 after OCBC Investment Research upgraded it to 'buy' on Wednesday, citing strong fundamentals and a sharp price correction. The bank has seen its net earnings grow 10.6% CAGR over the last 10 years and its dividend payout increase 7.9% CAGR. OCBC noted DBS's dividend yield of 4.8% and fair value at S$29.18, making it an opportune time to accumulate shares. The upgrade follows a Moody's report that banks will defend their market share against fintech competitors.

site_title: Independent startup accelerator Accelerating Asia to close US$5m pre-seed VC fund in July
summary: Singapore-based startup accelerator Accelerating Asia is set to close its US$5 million pre-seed VC fund in July. The fund will invest in over 40 high-growth startups in Asia, with participating startups receiving US$100,000 in funding and office space in Downtown Singapore. The first group of startups, comprising 10 firms, includes companies from Bangladesh, Indonesia, Malaysia, Pakistan, and the Philippines, focusing on Big Data, e-commerce, and logistics. The accelerator program, supported by Enterprise Singapore, aims to support startups through a three-month program followed by a Demo Day in San Francisco and Silicon Valley.

site_title: China rejects claims fracking caused Sichuan quake: state media
summary: Chinese officials have rejected claims that fracking caused a deadly 6.0 magnitude earthquake in the southwestern province of Sichuan, which killed 13 people and injured nearly 200. The quake-prone region is home to extensive fracking operations, but experts say there is no concrete scientific evidence to prove a connection. Wang Haitao, director of the China Earthquake Networks Center, stated that there is "no sufficient evidence" to link the quake to shale gas exploration. The US Geological Survey has also found that fracking is the cause of only a small number of induced earthquakes in the US.

site_title: Trade tensions kick Asian business confidence to 10-year low
summary: Asian business confidence plummeted to a 10-year low in the June quarter, with a Thomson Reuters/INSEAD survey finding the Asian Business Sentiment Index at 53, down from 63 in the previous quarter. The US-China trade war, Brexit, and a slowdown in the Chinese economy are cited as major risks to business. For the fourth straight quarter, companies in the region cited the global trade war as the chief risk, with many manufacturers looking to move production out of China due to supply line disruptions. The survey suggests a true slowdown in growth is underway.

site_title: Tiny houses entice budget-conscious Americans
summary: In the US, a growing number of Americans are opting for tiny houses, with most measuring less than 40 sqm, due to their minimalist appeal and smaller carbon footprints. The tiny homes revolution gained momentum after the 2008 financial crisis and the coming-of-age of millennials. As a result, budget-conscious buyers are snapping up these homes, marking a shift away from the traditional "bigger is better" mentality.

images.alt_text: In a country that nearly always believes bigger is better - think supersize fries, giant cars and 10-gallon hats - more and more Americans are downsizing their living quarters.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines MH17 crash probe set to name suspects
summary: International investigators are set to announce charges against several suspects in the downing of Malaysia Airlines MH17 over eastern Ukraine in 2014, killing all 298 people on board. The Dutch-led probe, which found the BUK missile originated from a Russian military brigade in Kursk, will first inform families and then hold a press conference to unveil "developments in the criminal investigation." This breakthrough comes nearly a year after the investigators linked the missile to Russian forces.

site_title: Japan exports slide for 6th month as trade troubles knock demand
summary: Japan's exports declined 7.8% in May, marking a sixth consecutive month of falls, due to weakened demand from China and the impact of the US-China tariff war. The slowdown in exports poses risks for Japan's economy, which is heavily reliant on trade. Analysts predict the economy may stop expanding this year, and the Bank of Japan is expected to keep monetary policy steady but signal readiness to ramp up stimulus if needed. Weak global demand and faltering earnings at Japanese companies also raise concerns about the economy's outlook.

site_title: Slack primed as latest unicorn to make market debut
summary: Slack Technologies, a cloud-based software company, is set to debut on the market with a direct listing, bypassing the traditional initial public offering (IPO) process. The company, valued at around $17 billion, reported a 66.7% revenue increase in the latest quarter, but remains unprofitable. Despite the mixed performance of ex-unicorn companies like Uber and Lyft, investors remain keen on growth stories, as seen in the success of companies like Beyond Meat, which has multiplied in value since going public. The direct listing allows Slack to cut down on fees to investment bankers and avoids share dilution, but also exposes shares to greater volatility.

site_title: Demoting your staff? Think again
summary: A study by Robert Half found that nearly a third of business leaders in Singapore have demoted an employee, with the top reasons being a failed promotion attempt (46%), poor performance (37%), and organizational restructuring (15%). Only 2% of demotions were voluntary. The study suggests that companies should clearly communicate the reason for demotion and provide support to affected employees. Employees who were demoted should focus on staying professional, seeking new skills, and gaining constructive feedback for improvement.

site_title: Xi hails friendship with North Korea in state newspaper
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has written an opinion piece in North Korea's official newspaper, praising their "irreplaceable" friendship. The visit comes as Xi is set to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, amid soured US-North Korea nuclear negotiations. Xi expressed a willingness to contribute to regional peace and stability, and highlighted the 70th anniversary of Beijing-Pyongyang relations. The trip is seen as a signal to US President Donald Trump of Xi's influence and backing for Kim, with the visit scheduled just before the G-20 summit in Japan.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend global rally as Trump fuels trade deal hope
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday after US President Donald Trump's comments on phone talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping, fueling hopes of a trade deal to end the China-US trade war. Trump said the two leaders would meet at the G-20 next week, and analysts see strong incentives for both leaders to re-engage. The rally also followed comments from European Central Bank head Mario Draghi hinting at interest rate cuts to support the eurozone economy. Markets extended gains globally, with Hong Kong up 2%, Tokyo 1.7%, and Shanghai 1.4%, amidst optimism about the potential trade deal and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: South Korea's Korean Air to buy 30 Boeing 787 planes for US$9.67b
summary: South Korea's Korean Air Lines has signed a memorandum of understanding to purchase 30 Boeing 787 planes for $9.67 billion. The airline will buy 20 787-10s and 10 787-9s to expand its fleet. This is the first purchase of a 787-10 model by a South Korean carrier, marking a significant addition to the Dreamliner family.

site_title: BlackRock is shorting the Australian dollar
summary: BlackRock is shorting the Australian dollar, betting the Reserve Bank of Australia will cut interest rates to as low as 0.5% to revive the struggling economy. The Aussie is expected to decline further, potentially falling to 65 US cents next year, with BlackRock's head of fixed income, Craig Vardy, predicting the RBA will ease rates to 50 basis points. Other investors, including Franklin Templeton and JPMorgan Chase, also expect the RBA to lower interest rates to boost the economy.

site_title: Healthy living can't prevent cancer
summary: Researchers have found that random "bad luck" plays a significant role in cancer development, alongside inherited genetic predispositions and environmental carcinogens. Clusters of mutated cells in healthy tissue have been discovered, which can lead to cancer when combined with genetic mutations. While this discovery may seem alarming, it emphasizes the importance of vigilance and research in minimizing risk, rather than giving up on preventive efforts. Medical technology, such as early intervention and screenings, can help mitigate the risk of cancer, and scientists may one day harness the power of evolution to prevent cancer.

site_title: Airbus seeks new partners to expand in US space market
summary: Airbus is seeking new partners to expand its presence in the US space market, with potential plans to build components for a lunar programme and produce parts for NASA's Orion spacecraft. The company has already ramped up production of satellites for start-up OneWeb in Florida, giving it leverage in the US market. Airbus Defence and Space chief executive Dirk Hoke expressed frustration with European leaders' lack of a unified vision for space ambitions, citing the need for sovereign access to space and defence.

site_title: Facebook takes on the world of cryptocurrency with 'Libra' coin
summary: Facebook has unveiled its new global cryptocurrency called Libra, aiming to bring over a billion "unbanked" people into the financial system. The Libra coin plan, backed by financial and non-profit partners, represents an ambitious new initiative for the world's biggest social network. A prototype of Libra has been released as an open source code for developers, with a real-world asset reserve to maintain its value stability. The Libra Association will oversee the blockchain-based coin, while Facebook is building a digital wallet called Calibra. The move has raised questions about regulation and sovereignty, with lawmakers calling for a pause on development.

site_title: Euthanasia law comes into effect in first Australia state
summary: Australia's Victoria state has implemented euthanasia laws, allowing terminally ill patients to end their lives with assisted suicide. The laws, introduced in 2017, provide a "dignified option" for patients with less than six months to live or certain life-threatening conditions. The scheme includes safeguards such as an independent review board and a coroner, with 12 expected users in the first year and up to 150 annually thereafter. The move marks a "bold change" in the country's approach to assisted dying, with no other state having implemented similar laws.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.85 points to 1,654.61. Volume reached 67.79 million lots worth RM35.6 million, with 171 gainers outpacing 43 losers.

site_title: China to block pork imports from Canadian firm: Xinhua
summary: China has suspended pork imports from Canadian firm Frigo Royal after traces of a banned feed additive, Ractopamine, were found in its shipments, amid a diplomatic row between the two countries. This move is seen as retaliation for Canada's detention of a Huawei executive and other diplomatic tensions. Chinese customs will intensify inspections of Canadian pork and return or destroy any problematic products. The decision is the latest in a series of trade restrictions imposed by China on Canadian goods, including a ban on canola imports earlier this year.

site_title: Rolls-Royce boss laments Brexit distraction at Paris Airshow
summary: Rolls-Royce CEO Warren East expressed frustration over Brexit distractions at the Paris Airshow, three years after the UK's EU departure vote. Brexit uncertainties have dominated discussions, keeping the industry on edge despite a delayed departure until October 31. East stated that Brexit has been a "hugely disruptive" distraction for aerospace companies, which rely on integrated supply chains. He expressed skepticism about preparing for the October deadline, considering the uncertainty and potential for a "no-deal" Brexit.

site_title: Canada PM approves controversial oil pipeline expansion
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau approved the expansion of a pipeline to move crude oil to the Pacific coast, despite environmental and indigenous concerns. The project, which was initially approved in 2016, will increase oil shipments by 890,000 barrels per day. Construction may resume within months, with the first shipments expected shortly after. The pipeline's future profitability is uncertain, with Finance Minister Bill Morneau stating it will be sold once commercially viable, with profits rolled into renewable energy projects.

site_title: Boeing goes from humble to high-fives with showstopper Max deal
summary: Boeing overcame a difficult start to the Paris Air Show with a major deal, signing a letter of intent with British Airways owner IAG for 200 single-aisle Max planes, valued at $24 billion. The order, which includes the 737-8 and 737-10 models, is the largest ever placed for a single-aisle model in Europe and marks a significant endorsement for the Max after two deadly crashes grounded the aircraft. The deal comes after Boeing landed a smaller order for 20 787 Dreamliners from Korean Air Lines, and CEO Dennis Muilenburg is confident the Max will return to service before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The Paris Air Show is typically an Airbus stronghold, where the European company unveils its biggest orders, relegating Boeing to bit player.

site_title: UK's Corbyn to back second Brexit referendum: The Times
summary: British opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn is set to back a Labour party move to support a second Brexit referendum in all circumstances. The move aims to address voter frustration over the Brexit deadlock. Corbyn's stance is seen as a shift from his previous stance, where he only suggested keeping the option of another Brexit vote on the table. This move could pose a dilemma for the party's supporters, many of whom backed Brexit.

site_title: Europe wary as Facebook takes up cryptocurrency challenge
summary: European financial leaders expressed caution after Facebook announced a cryptocurrency called Libra, with French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire stating that Libra could never replace sovereign currencies and requiring guarantees to prevent misuse. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney echoed concerns, saying the new currency would need to withstand strict regulation. Analysts warned that Facebook faces a significant challenge to win regulatory approval, and EU counterparts remain wary of the social media giant's increasing influence.

site_title: AIA Singapore's wealth managers to get training, IBF certification meant for private bankers
summary: AIA Singapore has partnered with Nanyang Technological University's Wealth Management Institute to provide training and IBF certification to its wealth managers, similar to private bankers. The Certified Private Banker (CPB) programme, developed by WMI, will equip managers with competencies to serve high net worth clients. AIA's personal wealth managers who complete the Client Advisor Competency Standards Assessment and CPB Level 1 will be eligible for the "Wealth Management - Relationship Management - Private Banking" certification under the IBF Standards Level 1, enhancing their capabilities and competitiveness.

site_title: Thief saws off Marilyn Monroe statue in Hollywood
summary: A thief sawed off a statue of Marilyn Monroe in Hollywood, California, on Sunday. The statue, which depicted Monroe in her iconic pose from "The Seven Year Itch," was part of an artwork celebrating women in film. Authorities recovered some prints at the scene, but no arrests have been made yet. The statue was removed from the Ladies of Hollywood Gazebo on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. The incident is being referred to as the "Marilyn caper of 2019."

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infra Trust, Keppel Reit, Raffles Education, Sembcorp Industries
summary: Keppel Infra Trust proposed issuing S$100 million of subordinated perpetual securities at 4.75% to refinance borrowings and general working capital. Keppel Reit's subsidiary Ocean Properties secured a S$505 million secured green loan facility, with potential for cross-default if Keppel Reit's manager ceases to be a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation. Raffles Education and Sembcorp Industries were not mentioned as having new developments.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on hopes of G-20 trade breakthrough
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.19% on Wednesday, following upbeat comments from the US and China on trade ahead of the G-20 Summit. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 249.40 points to 21,222.11, while the Topix index rose 1.07% to 1,544.97. The gains extended Wall Street's rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Johnson fends off dwindling British PM rivals in TV debate
summary: Boris Johnson solidified his lead in the UK leadership race, securing 126 of 313 Conservative MPs' votes in a second-round ballot. Johnson, a Brexit figurehead, defended his position, stating that Britain "must come out" of the EU by the new October deadline. His rivals, including Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove, and Rory Stewart, failed to gain significant ground, with Stewart expanding his support base but still trailing behind. A final round of voting will narrow the list to two contenders, who will face a vote by the party's 160,000 grassroots members next month.

site_title: Historic US drug bust nets 16 tonnes of cocaine
summary: US authorities seized 16 tonnes of cocaine, valued at over $1 billion, in a historic bust aboard a ship at Philadelphia's Packer Marine Terminal. The cocaine was found in seven containers on the MSC Gayane cargo ship, which was leaving for Europe. Members of the ship's crew have been arrested and federally charged. The seizure comes after a previous haul of nearly 1.5 tonnes of cocaine in March, and highlights the ongoing issue of cocaine use in the US, which is the world's largest consumer of illegal drugs.

site_title: Beyond Meat shorts may be close to tipping point as losses mount
summary: Short sellers of Beyond Meat are struggling with increasing borrowing costs, with fees exceeding $2 million per day. Despite a 35% stock advance in the past five trading days, short sellers are close to a "tipping point" of capitulating due to high costs. Experts predict a potential stock borrow rate of over 100% as demand increases and supply decreases. This could lead to a short squeeze, where short sellers are forced to cover their positions, potentially impacting the stock's price.

site_title: Oil climbs over US$1/barrel on US-China trade deal hopes, Middle East tension
summary: Oil prices rose over $1 a barrel on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a US-China trade deal and rising tensions in the Middle East. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 3.8% to $53.90 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose 2% to $62.14 a barrel. The US and China are set to resume trade talks at the G-20 summit in Japan, and the US plans to send more troops to the Middle East amid concerns over Iran's nuclear program.

site_title: American Airlines in talks for up to 50 A321XLR jets: sources
summary: American Airlines is in talks to purchase up to 50 Airbus A321XLR extended-range narrow-body aircraft, including some converted from existing orders. The deal, if confirmed, could be announced at the Paris Air Show, but a decision timeline remains unclear. The A321XLR has a range of 4,700 nautical miles, potentially disrupting Boeing's mid-market twin-aisle jet plans. American Airlines has spent over $25 billion on modernizing its fleet, including a purchase commitment for 100 A320neo aircraft.

site_title: Airbus jumps ahead with US$13b worth of orders on the first day; Boeing flounders
summary: Airbus secured $13 billion in orders on the first day of the 2019 Paris Air Show, surpassing Boeing's sales. The major orders came from Air Lease Corp and Virgin Atlantic Airways for Airbus' A321XLR and A330 wide-body jets. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury expressed confidence in the company's sales, citing "very strong demand" for its A320 family of single-aisle jets. Boeing's 737 Max remains grounded, and its planned mid-market jet, the 797, is on hold due to the Max crisis.

images.alt_text: The Airbus logo adorns a drone on the opening day of the 53rd International Paris Air Show at Le Bourget Airport near Paris on Monday.

site_title: India's first Reit up 21% since March listing
summary: India's first Reit, Embassy Office Parks Reit, has outperformed peers by 21% since its March listing, driven by a low interest rate environment. The Reit, backed by Blackstone Group, operates 33 million square feet of office space and has tenants like Microsoft and Rolls-Royce. Analysts expect compound annual growth in rental income of 16% through 2023. The Reit's strong performance is attributed to the benign interest rate environment in India, with further easing expected.

site_title: Google pledges US$1b for housing crisis in San Francisco Bay area
summary: Google has pledged $1 billion to address the severe housing crisis in the San Francisco Bay area. The initiative, led by CEO Sundar Pichai, aims to repurpose over $750 million of Google's land for housing and support the development of 15,000 new homes. The company also pledged a $250 million investment fund and $50 million through its philanthropic arm to build at least 5,000 affordable housing units and support nonprofits focused on homelessness and displacement.

site_title: Merkel says she's 'fine' after trembling spell
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel dismissed concerns about her health after visibly trembling at an official ceremony, attributing it to dehydration in the heat. Merkel, 64, said she had drunk three glasses of water and was fine. Her spokesman explained a similar incident in 2014, where she briefly stopped an interview due to a drop in blood pressure. Merkel is set to leave politics in 2021, marking the end of her 15-year term.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singaporean stocks showed mixed performance. ComfortDelGro's public transport business is expected to drive earnings growth, with organic growth in Singapore and acquisitions aiding its recovery. ESR-Reit has entered a joint venture to acquire a logistics hub, with plans to redevelop the space. Trump's 50% copper import tariff is also affecting global markets, with oil prices rising over 2%.

site_title: Trump-Xi meeting planned for G-20 raises hope for trade truce
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping plan to meet at the G-20 summit in Japan, raising hopes for a truce in the ongoing trade war between the two countries. The leaders had a "good" conversation, with Trump stating they will discuss leveling the playing field for US farmers, workers, and businesses. Xi emphasized the benefits of cooperation, saying both countries will gain by working together rather than fighting. The meeting comes after worsening tensions and steep tariffs on hundreds of billions in exports, with Trump warning there are "no guarantees" of a resolution.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump and China's Xi Jinping said Tuesday they plan to meet next week at the Group of 20 summit in Japan, raising hopes for a truce in an increasingly damaging trade war between the world's top two economies.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 enjoys best day in 4 months after Draghi's "appetiser"
summary: The FTSE 100 index in London reached its best one-day gain in four months, closing 1.2% higher after European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi hinted at further stimulus if required. This boost came as the ECB meeting concluded and ahead of the US Federal Reserve's two-day meeting, which may lead to interest rate cuts. Other sectors, including mining, healthcare, and retail, also saw gains, with Ashtead and Tesco rising 6.1% and 3.7%, respectively.

site_title: Summit faces stalemate as Europe haggles over top jobs
summary: European leaders are expected to clash over top jobs at a summit on Thursday, with France and Germany at loggerheads. The European Commission, European Central Bank, EU parliament, European Council, and head of foreign policy are up for grabs, with no clear candidate to replace Jean-Claude Juncker. The summit may break the stalemate, but an agreement with the EU parliament is uncertain, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel backing Frans Timmermans and French President Emmanuel Macron opposing Manfred Weber.

site_title: Miracle of 'Wild Boars' rescue transforms Thai cave into tourist draw
summary: A Thai cave that was once a serene mountain destination has become a tourist draw after the 2018 rescue of 12 young footballers and their coach, dubbed the "Wild Boars" rescue. Over 1.3 million people have visited the site since the rescue, with plans to build facilities and infrastructure around the cave. The rescue's global media frenzy has transformed the area into a major tourist attraction, with tourists taking selfies and purchasing souvenirs. The site has also become a hub for lottery ticket vendors, capitalizing on the perceived good fortune linked to the boys' survival.

images.alt_text: Visitors posing for photos in front of a statue of Saman Gunan, the Thai diver who died trying to rescue the 12 boys from the "Wild Boars" football team and their coach who were trapped in the Tham Luang cave last year.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on hopes of G-20 trade breakthrough
summary: US stocks rallied on Tuesday as upbeat comments on trade between the US and China ahead of the G-20 summit in Japan lifted market sentiment. US President Donald Trump said he had a "good" conversation with China's Xi Jinping, raising hopes for a trade deal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.4%, the S&P 500 gained 1.0%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.4%. European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi also signaled interest rate cuts, further boosting stocks.

site_title: Fostering closer trade relations through food and more
summary: The Italian Chamber of Commerce in Singapore (ICCS) has launched a new event, Food Innovation, as part of its Italian Food and Beverage fair. The event aims to foster closer trade relations between Italy and Singapore through food and beverages. ICCS has also appointed a new board, led by President Alberto Maria Martinelli, with expertise in various sectors represented by Italian companies in Singapore. The chamber's services include business development, events, and networking opportunities, with a focus on helping Italian and Singaporean companies expand their businesses in each other's markets.

site_title: SMEs' next big investment push: transformative technology
summary: A new EY report found that small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in South-east Asia (SEA) are expected to prioritize transformative technologies such as AI, machine learning, and blockchain by 2022, with 80.7% of businesses identifying these technologies as a top investment priority. Currently, 77.2% of SMEs focus on current technologies, with 74% investing in fixed assets. The trend is driven by e-commerce, e-banking, and e-wallets, and 68.2% of businesses are investing in online payments.

site_title: In Germany, activists battle food waste with dumpster diving
summary: Activists in Germany are engaging in dumpster diving, taking unsold food from supermarkets, despite it being considered theft and carrying penalties of up to hundreds of euros. Hundreds of activists across the country are fighting against food waste, citing the issue of 11-18 million tonnes of food being discarded annually. A petition calling for decriminalization of dumpster diving has gained 1.5 million signatures, and some cities, like Hamburg, are considering legalizing the practice. The issue has sparked debate about the environmental impact of food waste and the need for companies to provide unsold goods to charity.

site_title: Trump blasts Draghi, China for weak currencies to gain edge
summary: US President Donald Trump accused European Central Bank President Mario Draghi and China of weakening their currencies to gain an economic advantage. Draghi had announced potential monetary stimulus, causing the euro to drop 0.2% against the dollar. Trump claimed this was an unfair advantage for the euro area and China, and his tweets were seen as a distraction from the upcoming Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Fed is expected to cut borrowing costs this year, and Trump's criticism of Draghi and China adds to the tension ahead of a G-20 summit next week.

site_title: Investors going into risk assets on hopes of monetary easing
summary: Investors are pouring into risk assets, such as corporate bonds, amid hopes of monetary easing from the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank to counter global economic slowdown. Credit investors are driving a record risk rally, with high-grade and junk indexes reaching fresh highs, and interest-rate risk near all-time highs. However, if central banks disappoint, the risk of a sharp decline is high, according to strategists, who warn that the market's "crazy rich" valuations may become even more expensive.

site_title: EU trade surplus with US expands
summary: The European Union's trade surplus with the US increased to 48.2 billion euros in the first four months of 2019, while its deficit with China widened to 62 billion euros. This could further strain global tensions amid ongoing trade disputes between the US and EU over China's trade practices. The EU's overall goods trade deficit grew to 21.7 billion euros, with the eurozone's trade surplus narrowing to 15.7 billion euros in April.

site_title: Science suffers collateral damage as US-China tensions rise
summary: US visa denials for Chinese academics and intensified scrutiny of alleged links to Beijing are causing a chilling effect on long-standing research collaboration between the two countries. The US Department of Energy blocked its scientists from participating in foreign government talent recruitment programs, citing national security concerns. This move is part of a clampdown by Washington on what it describes as espionage and technology theft through academic contacts. The impact on research collaboration is expected to be severe, with researchers warning that the trade war-turned-technology war will disrupt talent exchange between China and the US.

site_title: Investor pressure drives regional venture funds to sustainability deals
summary: South-east Asia's venture capital firms are increasing their sustainability efforts to meet investor demand, with 96% of private equity and VC firms in the region reporting increased environmental, social, and governance (ESG) efforts in the past three to five years. Investors, including development finance institutions and pension funds, are driving this trend, citing climate change and a socially conscious millennial generation as key drivers. Despite challenges in data standardization and transparency, ESG investments are not necessarily less profitable, with median returns in ESG-related sectors in the Asia Pacific being 3.4 times that of other sectors from 2014 to 2018.

site_title: Indonesia must get infrastructure financing model right
summary: Indonesia aims to fund its ambitious $412 billion infrastructure plan for 2020-2024, with 65% of the budget to come from government or state-owned enterprises and the rest from the private sector. However, the country's high external debt of $387 billion poses a significant challenge. To avoid a repeat of the 1997 Asian financial crisis, Indonesia needs to develop a well-conceived infrastructure financing model, prioritize operational efficiency, and build trust among stakeholders. Failure to address these issues could weaken the rupiah and impact sovereign ratings, hindering the country's growth potential.

site_title: HK chief executive apologises for extradition crisis, vows to stay on
summary: Hong Kong chief executive Carrie Lam apologized for the city's political unrest, attributing responsibility for the controversy and disputes to herself. The extradition bill, which would have allowed extraditions to mainland China, has been suspended indefinitely, with Lam suggesting it will expire by July next year if it doesn't make the legislative council. Despite her apology, protesters remain unsatisfied, demanding the bill's full withdrawal and Lam's resignation.

site_title: Germany helps Europe car market to first gain in 9 months
summary: European car registrations rose 0.04% to 1.44 million in May, driven by a 9.1% increase in Germany. The German market benefited from trade-in incentives for older diesel cars, while the UK declined 4.6% and Spain fell 7.3%. Despite a fragile market, carmakers like BMW and PSA Group saw gains, but face pressure to sell more electric and hybrid cars due to upcoming EU regulations.

site_title: Seoul goes for renewables, to close more coal plants
summary: South Korea plans to accelerate its transition to renewable energy, aiming to close more coal-fired generators and broaden operating caps. The country aims to boost renewable energy to up to 35% of total energy supplies by 2040, but may miss its existing target of 20% by 2030, reaching around 17%. The move comes as the government faces pressure to reduce carbon emissions and meet its Paris climate accord targets, despite concerns about the high cost of reducing coal's share of energy output.

site_title: Bond investors gearing up for another QE by ECB
summary: Bond investors are preparing for another potential wave of quantitative easing from the European Central Bank, driven by a desire to stimulate the region's flagging economy. The ECB has kept deposit rates negative, and many believe policy makers may revisit QE to stimulate growth. Debt from nations with longer-term securities, such as France, are outperforming in the latest rally. Investors are also betting on a drop in longer-maturity yields relative to near-term rates, with some favoring trades targeting a fall in Spain's 30-year yields. A restart of QE is not yet set in stone, but market speculation is increasing as the global trade conflict and record-low inflation expectations continue.

site_title: Tariff man's bark is worse than his bite
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to impose tariffs on Mexico if it didn't halt the flow of migrants from Central America, sparking a global trade crisis. Mexico and the US eventually reached an agreement, but at a high cost, including a breach of global trade rules and a weakening of the system. The tariffs would have severely disrupted North American auto industries and had devastating effects on Mexico's economy. Trump's actions have alienated Mexico, threatened global growth, and opened a Pandora's box, potentially leading to the fragmentation of the global economy.

site_title: China's May new home prices rise fastest in 5 months
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.7% in May, the fastest pace in five months, according to Reuters calculations based on National Bureau of Statistics data. This increase complicates the government's efforts to control the housing market as it rolls out more stimulus for the slowing economy. This marks a reversal of the previous month's 0.6% rise and the quickest pace since December. The data suggests housing markets are still under pressure, despite the government's efforts to stabilize them.

site_title: Evonik to make more animal feed ingredients here
summary: Germany-based chemicals giant Evonik Industries has launched a new plant in Singapore to produce methionine, a protein component used in animal feed supplements. The plant, which cost around 500 million euros, is expected to double annual capacity to 300,000 tonnes and produce more than two-fifths of Evonik's global methionine. The move is seen as a strategic expansion for the company, which aims to tap into the growing demand for animal nutrition in the region. The new facility is also expected to add over 100 jobs to Evonik's existing workforce in Singapore.

site_title: SGX's move to suspend stocks a case of 'damned if you do, damned if you don't'
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has suspended numerous stocks, with many struggling to recover. A review of suspended companies found that only about one in four were delisted, while one in eight made a successful reverse takeover (RTO) or met the free-float rule, allowing them to rejoin the bourse. However, the process often takes years, with some companies remaining suspended for over eight years. The SGX's tough stance on suspending trading is seen as both necessary for maintaining market integrity and a "death knell" for struggling firms, with turnaround stories scarce, leaving investors in a state of uncertainty.

site_title: Protests fail to dampen HK's love of property
summary: Hong Kong's love for property remains strong despite the city's largest protests in history, with an estimated 2 million people taking to the streets to protest a controversial extradition bill. New condominium developments were oversubscribed, and property prices reached a record high. Market watchers are confident about the outlook for the property market, citing ample liquidity and a shortage of new stock supporting home values. Protests are unlikely to prompt a collapse in home prices, with some buyers regaining confidence after the government suspended the extradition bill.

site_title: Changi Airports Intl CEO to exit; MD of asset management to take over
summary: Changi Airports International (CAI) announced the departure of its CEO, Lim Liang Song, effective July 1, 2019, who will be succeeded by Eugene Gan, managing director of asset management. Gan has over 18 years of experience in the aviation industry and will oversee CAI's airport investment, asset management, and consultancy businesses. CAI chairman Kee Teck Koon expressed confidence in Gan's leadership and credited Lim's leadership for the company's significant growth.

site_title: US startup accuses ex-engineer of copying headset for China firm
summary: US startup Magic Leap Inc has accused former engineer Xu Chi of stealing its technology to create an augmented reality device for China-based company Nreal. Xu, who left Magic Leap in 2016, is accused of breaching contract, fraud, and unfair competition. The lawsuit claims Xu exploited confidential information to develop a prototype of mixed-reality glasses similar to Magic Leap's designs. Magic Leap alleges Xu's company, Nreal, unveiled its own augmented reality glasses at a Las Vegas trade show, sparking concerns over intellectual property theft by Chinese companies.

site_title: Singapore market a hive of activity
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 30.74 points or 1% to close at 3,238.73, driven by high expectations of a dovish US interest rate outlook ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. Trading volume reached 1.47 billion securities, with real estate investment trusts (Reits) and property developers benefiting from lower borrowing costs. However, ESR Reit faced a heavy sell-off due to a discount in its private placement units. Financials and telecom stocks also surged, led by DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and NetLink NBN Trust.

site_title: Sanofi turns to Google in search for better treatments
summary: Sanofi partners with Google to utilize artificial intelligence and deep analytics tools to analyze its large database of real-world data to find better treatments for patients. The partnership aims to improve understanding of key diseases and patient outcomes, with Sanofi also moving its business applications to Google's cloud computing platform and using AI to enhance operations. This collaboration combines Sanofi's biologic innovations with Google's industry-leading capabilities, with the goal of accelerating the discovery of new therapies and giving people more control over their health.

site_title: ECB will ease policy if inflation doesn't pick up: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi stated that the bank will ease policy if inflation does not return to its target of 2% if it doesn't pick up. Draghi emphasized that the ECB has "considerable headroom" for additional stimulus, including cutting rates, adjusting guidance, and asset purchases. The comments led to a decline in the euro and bond yields, with markets pricing in 15-20 basis points of rate cuts. Draghi also dismissed concerns over the potency of asset purchases, citing the ECB's flexible legal powers.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank (ECB) will ease policy again if inflation does not rise back to its target, its president Mario Draghi said on Tuesday, reinforcing expectations for even more stimulus in the coming weeks.

site_title: ESR-Reit raises S$100m from upsized private placement at lower end of price range
summary: ESR-REIT has raised S$100 million through an upsized private placement, issuing approximately 194.2 million new units. The placement was at the lower end of the initial price range. The joint global coordinators and bookrunners, Citigroup Global Markets Singapore and RHB Securities Singapore, oversaw the process. The funds will be used for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Dangerous times for shipping and seafarers
summary: A surge in attacks on ships and seafarers has raised concerns globally. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has expressed alarm over a doubling in attacks in the Gulf of Guinea region, with a marked increase in kidnapping for ransom and armed robbery incidents. The incidents follow earlier attacks off the Strait of Hormuz, highlighting heightened tensions in the region. Authorities in Nigeria are being urged to take action to solve the problem, with the shipping industry and seafarer groups calling for international cooperation and naval protection. The Strait of Hormuz remains a crucial global trade route.

site_title: Sea zones and floating cities: a prime opportunity for Singapore
summary: Singapore can transform its international economic relevance by developing floating charter cities (FCCs) in special governance zones. Beijing's plans to transform the Greater Bay Area into an integrated economic hub directly competes with Singapore's role as an Indo-AsiaPac command and control centre. FCCs can leverage Singapore's strengths in infrastructure financing and maritime engineering, while offering partner nations a stake in the region's prosperity and stability. Designating a small area of Singapore's sea space as a sandbox for testing regulations governing floating structures could help address constraints. Singapore has the potential to host floating cities and reorient its maritime infrastructure to meet the growing demand for seaborne trading volume.

site_title: Building tomorrow's digital businesses
summary: Governments, manufacturers, and financial institutions are racing to adopt digital technologies to remain competitive. The digitization of industries has been a key priority for governments in Asia, with initiatives like China's Made in China 2025 and India's Digital India program. A recent study found that Asia-Pacific's GDP can gain US$292 billion if all financial services institutions embrace digital transformation. Digital businesses are becoming increasingly reliant on data and analytics to deliver customer experiences and gain a competitive advantage. However, cybersecurity and governance risks remain a concern, particularly in the banking and finance sector.

site_title: Expect a market brawl if Fed doesn't show it's ready to act: analysts
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision this week is expected to be met with market volatility, with traders anticipating a dovish turn to prove the Fed is ready to act on rate cuts. Investors are looking for a combination of statements and policy changes to demonstrate the Fed's willingness to cut rates, but excessive changes could raise alarm. If the Fed sticks to its "patient" stance, riskier assets may slide and yields could sink further, while a rate cut could lead to a relief sell-off and repricing of the market, with the 10-year yield likely to remain within a range of 2% and 2.40%.

site_title: TrickleStar ends Catalist debut at S$0.34
summary: TrickleStar, a Singapore-based company, made a positive debut on the Catalist board, ending the day at 34 Singapore cents, a 30% gain from its IPO price of 26 Singapore cents. The company raised S$2.4 million through the placement of 15 million new shares, with plans to use the funds for product development, acquisitions, and working capital. TrickleStar aims to increase market share, develop new markets, and deliver value to shareholders. The company's market capitalization is approximately S$21.3 million, bringing the total companies listed on the Catalist board to 218.

site_title: Commissioner of Charities trains its sights on charities that branch into business
summary: The Commissioner of Charities in Singapore is focusing on charities that branch into business, providing guidance to ensure they do not undermine their charitable purposes and maintain good governance. The office will stress the need for an arm's-length relationship between charities and their business subsidiaries. This comes as the sector collected S$2.65 billion in donations in 2017, with religious groups and education sectors receiving significant sums. The Commissioner aims to boost the charity sector through governance reviews, education, and campaigns such as the Safer Giving initiative.

site_title: Alibaba puts CFO in charge of strategic investments unit in major management reshuffle
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has made its most significant business reshuffle since co-founder Jack Ma's retirement, expanding Chief Financial Officer Maggie Wu's role to oversee strategic investments. Wu will take over from executive vice-chairman Joe Tsai, who will support her in her expanded role. This move aims to more tightly integrate Alibaba's investments into its overall ecosystem amid slowing growth.

images.alt_text: Alibaba is investing in new business lines such as cloud computing as a boom in its core e-commerce has peaked and revenue growth slows.

site_title: Engineering vital as Singapore enters next phase of development: SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of engineering in Singapore's development, citing the country's infrastructure and opportunities as a key driver. He encouraged young people to pursue careers in engineering and the sciences, highlighting examples of engineering marvels such as Jewel Changi Airport and the latest innovations from start-ups like BeeX. Teo believes engineering will become increasingly crucial as Singapore enters its next phase of development, presenting exciting challenges for young engineers and scientists.

site_title: India to review data storage rules that irked US tech firms
summary: India will review its data storage rules that require foreign payment firms to store payments data locally, following concerns raised by US tech companies like Mastercard and the US government. The rules, mandated by the Reserve Bank of India last year, have been a point of contention in the ongoing trade tensions between India and the US. The government has assured industry representatives that it will look into the concerns and consider changes to the rules, which could impact business models and investments of foreign companies.

site_title: Top Glove Q3 profit falls 36.5% on higher latex cost, stiff competition
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysia-based rubber glove manufacturer, reported a 36.5% decline in net profit to RM74.7 million in its third quarter to May 31, due to higher latex costs and intense competition. Revenue rose 8.1% to RM1.19 billion, and the company attributed the drop in net profit to a 22% increase in natural rubber latex prices. To offset the increase, Top Glove increased its average selling prices, which will be reflected in the fourth quarter. The company will also be added to the Hijrah Shariah Index on June 24.

site_title: Y Ventures shares climb 34%, prompting another SGX query
summary: Shares of Y Ventures, a Singapore-based e-commerce retailer, surged 34.3% on Tuesday to a two-month high of S$0.137, amid active trading. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried the company about the unusual price movements, but Y Ventures replied it did not know of any possible reasons or information not previously announced. This is the second SGX query in three months, following a 41.3% surge in April.

site_title: When dead companies don't die
summary: The global economy is experiencing its longest, weakest recovery on record, with the US and worldwide growth rates nearly a point below the average for post-war recoveries. This is attributed to the unintended consequences of huge government rescue programs, which have continued since the recession ended, favoring big companies over smaller ones. Low interest rates have led to the growth of "zombie firms" that don't earn enough to survive, competing with healthy companies for capital and labor. This has resulted in a decline in competition and a rise in inequality, with entrepreneurs facing tougher conditions.

site_title: Australian grocer Coles eyes A$1b in savings, shares jump
summary: Coles, Australia's second-largest grocery chain, plans to cut A$1 billion in costs over four years by automating manual tasks and reducing duplication. The move aims to offset rising labor and energy costs. Shares in Coles jumped following the announcement, as the company looks to technology to drive cost savings and improve efficiency.

site_title: Trump says having 'extended meeting' with Xi at G20 summit
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a positive phone conversation with Chinese President Xi Jinping, paving the way for an "extended meeting" at the G20 summit in Japan. The two leaders will discuss trade tensions, with Trump potentially imposing additional $300 billion tariffs on Chinese goods. The meeting aims to ease worsening trade war tensions and resolve differences between the world's top two economies.

site_title: Hong Kong leader signals end to extradition bill, but refuses to step down
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has signaled the end of a controversial extradition bill, but refused to step down. In a press conference, Lam apologized for the turmoil caused by the bill and stated that it would not be re-introduced if public fears persist. This marks a significant policy reversal, with the approval of China's Communist Party leaders, and presents a challenge for Chinese President Xi Jinping. Critics argue the bill would undermine Hong Kong's independent judiciary and rule of law, while protesters demand its complete scrapping.

site_title: Suspending trading a necessary evil, but more visibility can help long waits
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has 41 long-suspended stocks, the highest in three years, with about 5% of listed companies not trading for over a year. Financial distress and regulatory breaches are common reasons, but more visibility for investors is needed. The market regulator is tightening enforcement, and stricter deadlines could be considered to give investors an exit opportunity. Improving visibility and providing more details on lifting suspension conditions would also help shareholders assess progress. A balanced approach is necessary, balancing the need for restructuring with the importance of price discovery.

site_title: Heiress and jeans queen Gloria Vanderbilt dies at 95
summary: Gloria Vanderbilt, a renowned heiress, designer, and artist, died at 95 after a battle with stomach cancer. Known for her tumultuous love life, high-profile flings, and iconic designer jeans, Vanderbilt was a chronicled socialite of her era. She was a painter, writer, and designer, and her brand expanded to include fashion, fragrances, and linens. Vanderbilt was also a mother, wife, and friend, as described by her son Anderson Cooper, who called her "an extraordinary woman who lived life on her own terms."

site_title: Investors seek higher premiums for risky Aussie mortgage bonds
summary: Investors in Australian mortgage bonds are seeking higher premiums for riskier tranches due to concerns of a potential property downturn and increasing home loan defaults. Investors are paying up to 40 basis points more for lower-rated and unrated mortgage-backed securities, a significant shift from recent stable spreads. The demand for safer mortgage debt suggests a major economic shock is unlikely, despite a slowing economy and record-high household debt to income ratios.

site_title: Kep Infra Trust to issue S$100m 4.75% subordinated perp securities
summary: KEPPEL Infrastructure Trust (KIT) plans to issue S$100 million of 4.75% subordinated perpetual securities, with net proceeds used for refinancing borrowings and general working capital. This is the second tranche of KIT's S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, following a S$200 million issue on June 12. The securities will be issued on June 25, with OCBC Bank as the sole lead manager and bookrunner.

site_title: Utico extends deadline for Hyflux binding agreement
summary: Utico, a UAE utility company, has extended the deadline for its binding agreement with Hyflux to June 27, after the initial deadline of June 17 expired. This comes after Hyflux met key milestones for information submission and subsequent discussions. Utico aims to acquire Hyflux as a going concern, with a long-stop date set to ensure all stakeholders, including creditors and shareholders, are protected. The company is committed to a win-win resolution with a plan for a quick transaction process and a potential exit option, including a 50% cash redemption for small PNP holders.

site_title: Amateur quants are suddenly everywhere in China
summary: Thousands of amateur quants in China are leveraging cheap computing power and free online software to build trading algorithms previously reserved for market pros. JoinQuant, a DIY quant platform, has seen its user base grow to over 180,000, a four-fold increase since 2016. This trend reflects China's growing interest in quantitative investing, as individual investors capitalize on accessible technology to participate in the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a long-term agreement to install 6.3 megawatt peak rooftop solar panels at Experia Events' Changi Exhibition Centre. Keppel Reit obtained a S$505 million secured green loan facility, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust proposed issuing S$100 million of subordinated perpetual securities for refinancing and working capital purposes. Meanwhile, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Fortis Healthcare drops plan to sell stake in RHT Health Trust, trustee manager
summary: Fortis Healthcare has decided to close the bidding process for a potential sale of its stake in RHT Health Trust (RHT) and its trustee manager RHT Health Trust Manager (RHTTM). Despite an open invitation to interested parties, no firm proposal was received, and no binding agreement was reached. Fortis now plans to consider other options, including winding up RHT or identifying a new business for a possible new listing. The trustee manager will continue to evaluate options, including a possible six-month extension for a new listing.

site_title: China earthquake kills 12, injures 134
summary: A 6.0 magnitude earthquake struck south-west China, killing 12 people and injuring 134. Over 4,000 homes were damaged or collapsed, with 12 buildings destroyed. Rescuers pulled six bodies and seven survivors from wrecked buildings, and over 50 people were being treated in hospitals. The area experienced multiple aftershocks, including a 5.1 magnitude quake. This is the latest in a series of earthquakes to hit Sichuan province, where a 2008 quake killed 87,000 people.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens at six-week high on hopes of dovish Fed
summary: US stocks opened at a six-week high on June 18, 2019, driven by dovish calls from the European Central Bank, which raised expectations of a similar accommodative stance from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.45%, the S&P 500 gained 0.59%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.97%. The strong opening was attributed to the ECB's decision to cut interest rates, sparking hopes for a similar move by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: London named Europe's top hotspot for 'tech for good'
summary: London has been named Europe's top hotspot for developing technology to solve environmental and social problems, according to EU-funded research by Nesta. The city ranked first in a list of 60 European cities for fostering digital social innovation, with Amsterdam ranked second. London's infrastructure, skills base, and varied funding landscape contributed to its top ranking, with examples of tech for good ventures including mobile food sharing apps and 3D-printed splints. The research highlights the city's ability to support tech for good businesses, but also notes that other cities, such as Poland and Romania, have potential for growth.

site_title: Japan unveils moves to prevent car crashes caused by elderly
summary: Japan has introduced measures to prevent car accidents caused by elderly drivers, following a series of crashes involving children. The government will conduct an emergency safety inspection of school commuting routes by September and promote cars with emergency stopping devices. A new driving license category for elderly people is also being considered, allowing them to operate only cars equipped with emergency stopping devices. The move comes after several tragic incidents, including a car crash that killed two toddlers and injured others. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe emphasized the need for safe school commutes.

site_title: SembMarine, Rex International, CAO average 16% total returns in 2019 to date
summary: SembCorp Marine, Rex International, and China Aviation Oil Singapore (CAO) have achieved an average 16% total return in 2019, with combined market capitalization of S$4.4 billion. The stocks have shown high volatility, averaging 8.9% gains over the first 10 sessions of June. The three companies' trading turnover averaged S$14 million per day, with SembCorp Marine ranking 30th, Rex International 51st, and CAO 73rd. The benchmark price of crude oil has fluctuated, impacting the O&G businesses, with global growth concerns offsetting supply concerns.

site_title: Oil surges on optimism for economic stimulus, Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices surged 4.5% in New York as investors became optimistic about economic stimulus from the European Central Bank. Opec and its allies are set to discuss an extension of production cuts in mid-July, with Russia and Iran making progress toward resolving a standoff. The European Central Bank's potential stimulus move boosted market sentiment, reversing earlier declines. West Texas Intermediate rose $2.24 to $54.17 a barrel, while Brent gained $1.75 to $62.69 a barrel.

site_title: Annica inks MOUs with Perak's state economic development corporation
summary: Annica Holdings, a Catalist-listed oil and gas company, signed Memorandum of Understandings (MOUs) with Perak's state economic development corporation, PKNP, to explore and build large-scale solar photovoltaic projects and supply natural resources. The MOUs also include agreements for PKNP to supply mining sand and other natural resources to Annica's customers. The collaborations aim to boost Annica's business in the renewable energy sector and explore other business opportunities in Perak.

site_title: Raffles Education unit enters settlement agreement for 700m yuan Hebei deal
summary: Raffles Education has entered a settlement agreement for a 2013 deal to divest Hebei land and property due to "incomplete implementation" of an option agreement. The agreement involves selling 70% of a joint-venture firm to Langfang He Ying Real Estate Development at an exercise price of 700 million yuan. Raffles Education has been paid 460.8 million yuan, with the remaining 239.2 million yuan remaining unpaid. The settlement does not require shareholder approval.

site_title: Strong quakes strikes northwest Japan, tsunami warning issued
summary: A 6.8-magnitude earthquake struck northwest Japan's Niigata prefecture, causing strong shaking and prompting a 0.2-1.0 meter tsunami warning. The quake occurred at 10:22pm local time, 10 kilometers deep, with no immediate reports of damage. Tokyo Electric Power Co's nuclear plant was not affected. The USGS reported a magnitude of 6.5, and areas hardest hit by the quake could not be contacted by telephone.

site_title: IAG signals intent to buy 200 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft
summary: International Airlines Group (IAG) has signed a letter of intent to buy 200 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft, worth an estimated $24 billion. The deal comes as Boeing battles to regain trust after two crashes killed 346 people. IAG plans to use the aircraft by its airlines, including Vueling, LEVEL, and British Airways, to diversify its fleet. The agreement follows Boeing's apology for the crashes and comes as regulators are expected to approve the aircraft's return to service in the coming months.

site_title: New York rent rules pose risks for apartment lenders, Fitch says
summary: New York's rent stabilization laws pose a credit risk to lenders financing capital improvements to regulated apartment properties. The laws severely limit rent growth and capping improvements, potentially lowering property values. This decline in value poses a risk for "highly leveraged" borrowers, who may struggle to refinance loans after their duration. Fitch Ratings considers the exposure to such loans to be incrementally credit negative, unless specific creditor protections are implemented.

site_title: Bond investors dust off crisis playbook as Draghi spurs QE bets
summary: Bond investors are preparing for potential quantitative easing (QE) from the European Central Bank (ECB) by buying debt of nations like France and Italy, which could benefit from ECB purchases. President Mario Draghi has hinted at the possibility of interest-rate cuts and QE to stimulate the region's economy, which is struggling due to the global trade conflict and low inflation expectations. Investors are factoring in a rate cut to September and expect further easing if the economic outlook worsens.

site_title: Draghi's stimulus hints put ECB in Trump's crosshairs
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Mario Draghi signaled a possible policy reversal, hinting at additional stimulus if inflation fails to accelerate. Draghi's comments, seen as dovish, led to a drop in the euro and euro zone bond yields. The ECB has been preparing for policy tightening but has been hindered by a global trade war and limited policy ammunition. Draghi's comments also drew criticism from US President Donald Trump, who accused the ECB of weakening the euro to gain an unfair trade advantage. The ECB will study its options before making a decision, with policymakers set to meet on July 25.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank (ECB) will ease policy again if inflation fails to accelerate, ECB President Mario Draghi said on Tuesday, signalling one of the biggest policy reversals of his eight-year tenure and provoking the ire of US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks snap 4 sessions of losses; all eyes on Fed, Trump
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.38% on Tuesday, snapping a four-session losing streak, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting and US President Donald Trump's re-election campaign speech. The benchmark Kospi index closed at 2,098.71 points. The won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield fell. Investors are also watching the US-China trade issue, with Trump expected to reveal his vision during the speech.

site_title: Roche wins Japan approval for personalised cancer drug Rozlytrek
summary: Swiss drugmaker Roche has received Japan's approval for its personalized cancer drug Rozlytrek (entrectinib), targeting patients with NTRK fusion-positive solid tumours across 10 cancer types. This marks a milestone in Roche's push into personalized cancer medicines, which requires genetic profiling to identify eligible patients. While Roche has not yet secured US and European approvals, the company hopes for approval elsewhere "as soon as possible".

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end with healthy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1% on Tuesday, driven by anticipation of a crucial Federal Reserve meeting, and ending at 27,498.77. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, 0.09% and 0.16% respectively. The gains come ahead of the Fed meeting, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Alibaba reshuffles management; CFO to oversee strategic investment unit
summary: Alibaba has reshuffled its management, with CFO Maggie Wu taking over strategic investments and acquisitions from executive vice-chairman Joe Tsai. The supermarket division, Freshippo, will become a standalone business, and DingTalk will be merged into the cloud unit. The changes, effective from Tuesday, aim to guarantee innovation and invest in Alibaba's future. This move follows the company's co-founder Jack Ma stepping down last year, allowing CEO Daniel Zhang to replace him as chairman. Alibaba is also considering raising up to $20 billion through a Hong Kong listing to boost its investment war chest.

site_title: Utico extends deadline for binding agreement with Hyflux to June 27
summary: Utico, a UAE utility firm, has extended the deadline for entering a binding agreement with Hyflux to June 27, up from June 17. The water treatment firm informed Hyflux of the matter in a bourse filing.

site_title: Gloria Vanderbilt, jeans queen, dies at 95
summary: Gloria Vanderbilt, fashion icon and entrepreneur, died at 95. Her eponymous jeans line, introduced in 1977, revolutionized denim and became a cultural phenomenon. By merging high-end style with accessible fashion, Vanderbilt transformed the industry and paved the way for designers like Carolina Herrera and Tory Burch. Her legacy extends beyond her jeans, as she redefined the narrative of a troubled childhood and became a symbol of female empowerment and reinvention.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 1% on Tuesday ahead of key Fed meeting
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to close at 3,238.73, driven by gains in real estate investment trusts, financials, and telecom stocks. The market's positive performance is attributed to expectations of a dovish US Federal Reserve meeting, with investors seeking rate cuts. Other Asia-Pacific markets, including Australia, China, and Hong Kong, also posted gains, while Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 0.7%. The rally marked the fifth consecutive day of gains for Singapore stocks ahead of the upcoming GDP data release.

site_title: UN calls for 'independent' probe into death of Egypt's Morsi
summary: The UN human rights office called for an "independent inquiry" into the death of Egypt's former President Mohamed Morsi, who died while in state custody. Morsi, Egypt's first democratically elected president, was overthrown in 2013 after a brief term in power. Concerns have been raised about his detention conditions, including access to medical care and lawyers. The investigation must examine whether the conditions of his detention contributed to his death. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Rupert Colville, emphasized the need for a prompt, impartial, and transparent investigation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 14.36 points to 1,652.76. Volume reached 2 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 428 to 357.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine, Rex International and CAO averaged 16% total returns in 2019 to date
summary: Sembcorp Marine, Rex International, and China Aviation Oil Singapore (CAO) have averaged 16% total returns in 2019, with combined market capitalization of S$4.4 billion. The three stocks have shown high volatility, with Rex International's annualized volatility nearing 80%. The companies are impacted by oil prices, with crude oil prices rising from US$45 per barrel to US$66 per barrel in 2018 and back to US$52 per barrel in 2025.

site_title: European stocks waver at open
summary: European stocks wavered at the start of trading on Tuesday, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and the G-20 summit. The FTSE 100 rose 0.2% to 7,369.50 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 shed 0.1% each.
