Analysts expect the Fed to give hints about its first rate cut in over a decade, but are cautious due to market expectations and ongoing US-China trade talks. The G-20 summit is seen as a key event for trade negotiations.

site_title: Sembcorp to install, operate over 15,000 rooftop solar panels at Changi Exhibition Centre
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a long-term agreement to install, own, and operate over 15,000 rooftop solar panels with a total capacity of 6.3 megawatt peak at the Changi Exhibition Centre. The system is expected to produce 7,840 megawatt hours of power annually, reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 3.2 million kg annually. The installation is expected to power the onsite operations at the centre and any surplus power will be channeled to the grid, contributing to a sustainable future.

site_title: Elton John to receive France's top honour
summary: Rock legend Elton John is to be awarded France's highest civilian honour, the Legion d'Honneur, by President Emmanuel Macron on Friday. The 72-year-old singer will receive the award as part of his farewell tour, which includes stops in Paris, Lille, Bordeaux, and Nimes. Elton John has used his stardom to promote gay rights and AIDS causes, and his charity, the Elton John AIDS Foundation, has raised over $400 million since its establishment in 1992. Macron's office praised Elton John as a "piano virtuoso and true showman" who has given voice to the LGBT community.

site_title: World Bank lends US$918m for Pakistan tax reforms
summary: Pakistan and the World Bank signed a $918 million loan agreement to support the economy and reform the tax system. The loan will contribute to a sustainable increase in domestic revenue by broadening the tax base and improving compliance. The program aims to increase tax to GDP ratio to 17%, raise active taxpayers to 3.5 million, and reduce compliance burden. The funds will also be used for higher education and revenue mobilization in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province. The move aims to stabilize Pakistan's wobbly economy, but analysts doubt the government's ambitious tax revenue target of 5.55 trillion rupees.

site_title: Finland's Tieto in US$1.5b deal to buy Nordic peer Evry
summary: Finnish technology firm Tieto has agreed to pay $1.51 billion in cash and shares to acquire Norwegian competitor Evry, creating a digital consultancy with 24,000 employees and annual revenues of nearly 3 billion euros. The deal, announced on June 18, 2019, will give Evry's owners a 37.5% stake in the new company and is expected to reduce costs by 75 million euros annually. Completion of the transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to take place in the fourth quarter of 2019 or early 2020.

site_title: French drugmaker Sanofi, Google to use data tech for innovations
summary: Sanofi, a French healthcare company, has teamed up with Google to use data technologies to develop innovative treatments and improve health services. The partnership aims to combine Sanofi's biologic innovations with Google's capabilities in cloud computing and artificial intelligence to give people more control over their health. This will enable Sanofi to research and develop personalized treatment approaches and identify accompanying technologies to improve results.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore business leaders have demoted nearly a third of employees, according to a Robert Half poll. Changi Airports International CEO Lim Liang Song is departing and will be succeeded by Eugene Gan. Evonik Industries expanded its Singapore footprint despite a slowdown in growth due to the US-China trade war. ESR-Reit raised S$100m through a private placement. OUE subscribed for all shares of an Indonesian investment holding firm. Sunseap Group entered a joint venture to develop solar projects in Taiwan. Singapore shares rose 1% ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, with expectations of a dovish Fed.

images.alt_text: Nearly a third or 30 per cent of business leaders in Singapore have demoted an employee at their company, according to findings from an independently commissioned study by specialist recruitment consultancy Robert Half.

site_title: Bali United scores in stock market first for South-east Asian club
summary: Bali United, a Southeast Asian football club, made history by becoming the first South-east Asian club to go public on the stock market. The initial public offering (IPO) raised 34.3 million Singapore dollars, with the team's parent company jumping nearly 70% in value. The move aims to increase the club's profile and attract more fans, with Indonesian Football Association officials expressing support for the initiative.

site_title: Alibaba puts CFO in charge of investment in major management reshuffle
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has announced a significant management reshuffle, with CFO Maggie Wu taking over strategic investments and Executive Vice-Chairman Joe Tsai supporting her. The move aims to bolster investment focus amid slowing growth. As Alibaba invests in new business lines like cloud computing, Wu will integrate investments into its overall ecosystem. The changes are effective immediately, with Tsai remaining executive vice-chairman. The reshuffle comes as the company considers raising up to $20 billion through a Hong Kong listing to boost investment funds.

site_title: Changi Airports International CEO to depart; will be succeeded by MD of asset management
summary: Changi Airports International (CAI) CEO Lim Liang Song will step down on July 1, 2019, and be succeeded by Eugene Gan, Managing Director of asset management. Lim will move on to pursue personal interests after leading CAI since 2011. CAI is a wholly owned subsidiary of Changi Airport Group.

site_title: Businesses using 'returnship' programmes to address diversity: Hays
summary: Businesses are using "returnship" programs to address diversity and bring professionals back into the workforce, particularly women who leave to raise families. These programs offer paid placements that may lead to permanent employment, and companies such as PayPal, Unilever, and Microsoft are adopting this strategy. To make returnship programs attractive, companies are offering part-time or flexible roles and providing support to help professionals transition back into the workforce. The goal is to create a more representative workforce that mirrors the customer base, and to address skill shortages and diversity gaps.

site_title: Trump says US to begin removing 'millions' of illegal migrants
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the country will begin removing "millions" of illegal migrants next week, citing Guatemala's preparation to sign a safe third country deal. The move comes amid a surge in migrant arrivals from Central American countries. The US has allocated $370 million in aid to El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras, but will now only provide funds if the countries take concrete actions to deter undocumented migrants. Trump also praised Mexico's efforts to stop migrants from reaching the US border.

site_title: Beijing-backed candidate announces bid to lead casino hub of Macau
summary: Ho Iat Seng, a Beijing-backed candidate, has announced his candidacy to lead Macau, the world's largest gambling hub, in the upcoming elections on August 25. Ho, a 60-year-old Macau-born politician, aims to promote economic diversification and participate in national plans for the Greater Bay Area. He is Macau's only member of China's National People's Congress and has the backing of the enclave's political elite. The elections will determine the territory's chief executive, who will work with mainland authorities and play a key role in awarding new casino licences.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,235.46, up 0.86% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.86% to 3,235.46. The real estate investment trust (Reit) ESR-Reit fell 6.20% after announcing a private placement to raise S$100 million. Advancers outnumbered decliners 186 to 122, with 763.74 million securities worth S$589.18 million changing hands.

site_title: World's top bicycle maker says era of 'Made in China' is over
summary: Taiwan-based bicycle maker Giant Manufacturing Co has shifted production of US-bound orders out of its China facilities due to the US-China trade war, citing a 25% tariff on Chinese-made bicycles. The move, which began in response to Donald Trump's tariff threat in September 2018, is part of a growing trend of global firms diversifying production away from China. Giant now has one plant each in Taiwan and the Netherlands, and is seeking a partner in South-east Asia. The company's willingness to relocate production has boosted its stock price, which soared 9.8% on Monday.

site_title: Visa, Mastercard, PayPal join Facebook in forming crypto effort
summary: Facebook's new digital currency, Libra, is set to launch next year and may compete with payment giants Visa, Mastercard, and PayPal. The three companies are working together as part of the Libra Association, which will give them a say in managing the cryptocurrency. Libra is a stablecoin that aims to avoid massive value fluctuations and can be used for everyday transactions. Industry experts say the partnership is strategic, with payments companies wanting to shape the new currency and avoid disruption. The launch is expected to be years away, but the earlier companies participate, the more time they have to adapt.

site_title: Hot stock: Y Ventures shares jump 22.5%, prompting 2nd SGX query in 3 months
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried Catalist-listed Y Ventures on "unusual price movements" in its shares after the counter surged 22.5% in morning trade, marking the second SGX query in three months. Y Ventures replied that it is unaware of any possible reasons for the increase and confirmed compliance with listing rules. The company's shares jumped to 12.5 Singapore cents at the midday break before further increasing to 13.2 cents at the end of the day.

site_title: UK plans new powers to fine firms exploiting loyalty
summary: The UK government plans to give the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) new powers to fine companies that exploit customer loyalty, particularly in the mortgage, insurance, and mobile phone markets. The move aims to deter firms that charge "loyalty penalties" and serve as a deterrent to those that use "subscription traps" such as unfair terms and hard-to-exit contracts. The CMA's investigation found millions of people overpaying by £4 billion annually, and vulnerable individuals, including the elderly and those on low incomes, are more at risk.

site_title: Japan unveils moves to stop car crashes caused by elderly
summary: Japan unveils measures to prevent car accidents caused by elderly drivers, following a string of crashes involving children. The government plans to introduce emergency brakes, vehicle-free zones around schools, and emergency stopping devices in cars. Tokyo will conduct a safety inspection of school routes by September and study car-sharing and autonomous vehicles. The government may also introduce a new driving licence category for elderly people, allowing them to operate only cars with emergency stopping devices. These measures aim to ensure safe school commutes and address the issue of elderly drivers.

site_title: Airbus jumps ahead in Paris while Boeing flounders
summary: Airbus dominated the first day of the 2019 Paris Air Show, securing $13 billion in orders for new jets while Boeing's 737 Max program was idle after two deadly crashes. Airbus also introduced a long-range narrow-body, the A321XLR, which is positioned to compete with Boeing's planned midmarket airplane. Despite Boeing's efforts to reassure customers, Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury expressed confidence in the company's positive Paris Air Show, citing "very strong demand" for its A320 family of single-aisle jets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower amid lingering concern over trade
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.72% on June 18, 2019, due to lingering concerns over the US-China trade war. The Nikkei 225 index lost 151.29 points to 20,972.71, and the Topix Index declined 11.07 points to 1,528.67. Investors remained cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, which may provide further hints on a potential rate cut. The dollar strengthened against the yen, and some blue-chip exporters, including SoftBank Group, were affected by profit-taking.

site_title: British PM hopefuls begin crucial week of votes
summary: British Prime Minister hopefuls Boris Johnson, Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove, Dominic Raab, Sajid Javid, and Rory Stewart are set to face off in a crucial week of votes to replace outgoing leader Theresa May. Johnson won the first round of voting, securing 114 MPs, but opponents warn of economic chaos if Britain leaves the EU without a deal. The outcome could determine the conditions for the UK's departure from the EU on October 31, with the final two candidates to be decided by the end of the week.

site_title: China renames, restructures railway corporation in reform push
summary: China has renamed and restructured its national railway corporation, China State Railway Group (CR), as part of its efforts to implement market-oriented reforms. The company was previously known as China Railway Corporation (CRC) and has a registered capital of 1.7 trillion yuan. The new structure aims to centralize management, promote market-oriented operations, and possibly attract private investment. The move follows Beijing's efforts to reform state-owned enterprises and address the company's growing debt, which reached 300 billion yuan in 2019.

site_title: Indonesia ferry sinking leaves at least 15 dead
summary: At least 15 people have died after a passenger ferry sank off the Indonesian island of Java, according to police. The 10m long traditional vessel was carrying around 50 people when it overturned in rough seas near Madura island, East Java. Search and rescue teams found 13 bodies, with 31 survivors, and are searching for at least three people still missing. The incident is suspected to be caused by the boat being overloaded, with maritime accidents common in Indonesia due to poor safety standards.

site_title: Sunseap in joint venture to develop solar projects in Taiwan
summary: Sunseap Group, a Singapore-based solar energy company, is partnering with Pacific Green Energy Co Ltd to develop solar projects in Taiwan. The joint venture, Pacific Sunseap Energy Ltd, aims to develop over 100 MWp of solar projects in the next three years. This marks Sunseap's expansion into the Taiwanese market, following its recent foray into China. The company has a pipeline of projects in several countries, including Cambodia, the Philippines, and India.

site_title: In Germany, activists battle food waste with dumpster diving
summary: In Germany, activists are battling food waste by dumpster diving, with some participating in raids under the cover of night to collect unsold food items. The practice is considered theft, but activists argue it's a necessary step to address the country's 11 million tonnes of annual food waste. The movement has gained momentum, with petitions calling for the government to decriminalize dumpster diving and require supermarkets to donate unsold goods to charity. Despite concerns over health risks, activists believe the issue requires immediate action to address global warming and feed the world's growing population.

site_title: Australian shares end at over 11-year peak on RBA cues; NZ inches up
summary: Australian shares reached an 11-year peak, closing 0.6% higher at 6,570.0 on the S&P/ASX 200 index, driven by dovish cues from the Reserve Bank of Australia. Financial stocks, including Commonwealth Bank and CSL Ltd, rose 1.6% and 1.8% respectively. Healthcare stocks also gained, while gold stocks rose 1.5%. New Zealand shares inched up 0.2% despite a drop in consumer stocks.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise after RBA points to more cuts; New Zealand steady
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,553.70, driven by the Reserve Bank of Australia's indication of further policy easing to boost the economy. Healthcare and gold stocks led the gains, with CSL and Newcrest Mining rising 1.1% and 1% respectively. New Zealand shares traded sideways, with industrial and telecommunication stocks offsetting losses in consumer stocks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.78 points to 1,636.62 at 9:01am, amid no specific news or events mentioned in the article.

site_title: Berlin poised for rent freeze to curb rocketing rates
summary: Berlin's city government is set to agree on a draft law that would include a temporary 5-year rent freeze, affecting 1.4 million properties. Landlords seeking to raise rates above 50 cents per square meter must obtain official approval. The measure aims to curb gentrification and prevent residents from being priced out, with the SPD pledging to champion rent controls nationwide. The proposal faces opposition from Chancellor Merkel's centre-right bloc, which has voiced skepticism about rent caps, and the influential property-owners association Haus und Grund, which has urged landlords to raise rents.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.23% in early trade on Tuesday, extending gains from the previous day, as investors awaited a key Federal Reserve policy meeting. The Hang Seng Index rose to 27,289.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight gains. The gains come as investors shift cautiously ahead of the Fed's policy meeting.

site_title: Can home cooking reverse the obesity epidemic?
summary: Researchers challenge the notion that home cooking can reverse the obesity epidemic, citing obstacles faced by low-income and middle-class families. Studies show that ultra-processed foods, often cheap and convenient, are consumed by these families in increasing amounts. A new book, "Pressure Cooker," highlights the difficulties of healthy eating, including lack of time, money, and access to fresh produce. Experts argue that policies supporting families, such as universal childcare and free school meals, are needed to address these issues.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise as Federal Reserve meeting looms
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as investors await the Federal Reserve meeting, but gains were limited due to ongoing geopolitical tensions and the China-US trade war. Weak US manufacturing data, including a contraction in New York state, added to concerns. The US central bank's monetary policy decisions are expected to impact the world's top economy. Despite US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, and Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: ESR-Reit raises S$100m from upsized private placement at lower end of price range
summary: ESR-REIT has raised S$100 million through an upsized private placement, issuing approximately 194.2 million new units at a price of 51.5 Singapore cents per unit, at the lower end of the initially announced 51.5-52.5 cents range. The placement was managed by Citigroup Global Markets Singapore and RHB Securities Singapore, with the order book closed on Tuesday morning.

site_title: Soaring corn prices pinch Brazil meatpackers amid Chinese meat bonanza
summary: Brazilian pork and poultry processors, who have benefited from strong exports to China amid the African swine fever outbreak, are feeling the pinch as corn prices soar in Brazil. Corn prices rose 25% in Chicago and 15% in Brazil, mirroring a 2016 drought-driven supply squeeze. Companies such as BRF SA and JBS SA are watching their profit margins, with BRF securing 12-month corn purchasing deals. Despite a large domestic corn crop, exports are expected to be record-high, reducing local supplies and affecting meatpackers.

site_title: Data analytics company GeoSpock opens Asian HQ in Singapore
summary: GeoSpock, a Cambridge-based data analytics company, has established its Asian headquarters in Singapore, with plans to expand its operations in the region. The company aims to add up to 30 new employees in commercial, technical, and data science roles over the next two years. This move is seen as an opportunity to further develop partnerships and identify growth opportunities in smart cities, IoT, and enterprise sectors. CEO Richard Baker believes that Asia will be a key region for growth, driven by the increasing population and need for data-driven decision-making.

site_title: Australia mortgage arrears rise to 2010 highs: RBA official
summary: Australia's mortgage arrears have increased to 2010 levels, but remain below risk thresholds. According to the Reserve Bank of Australia, arrears are driven by weak income growth, housing price falls, and rising unemployment. Despite this, households have sufficient income to meet their mortgage commitments, with around two-thirds of borrowers having prepayment buffers. The strong labor market and lending standards are expected to keep arrears rates stable, with the risk of financial system instability low. Arrears may continue to rise in the short term, but overall, the situation is not concerning.

site_title: Grow faster, grow stronger: speed-breeding crops to feed the future
summary: Plant breeders are racing against time to develop faster-growing crops to meet the world's increasing food demand. Researchers are using "speed breeding" techniques to accelerate the process, which involves tightly controlling light and temperature to induce early flowering. This method has been shown to produce up to six generations of crops in a year, compared to traditional methods that yield one or two. Combining speed breeding with gene editing and genomic prediction can create a pipeline of new crops, say researchers, who hope to improve food security and benefit farmers in developing countries.

images.alt_text: The answer to unlocking access to credit in rural South-east Asia may lie in digital payments, says Grow Asia's Paul Voutier.

site_title: Evonik expands Singapore footprint even as trade war bites into growth
summary: Germany-based Evonik Industries, a chemicals giant, has expanded its Singapore footprint despite the trade war between the US and China affecting its growth. Executive board chairman Christian Kullmann stated that business growth levels surpass economic expansion, citing steady growth in healthcare segments. The new specialty chemicals plant in Singapore marks the company's commitment to the region, despite cooling growth in the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: Evonik's second DL-methionine plant in Singapore. The group noted that its investment for the Singapore plant made for the group's largest single investment so far.

site_title: US releases new photos it says incriminate Iran in tanker attacks
summary: The US military released new photos that allegedly incriminate Iran in the June 13 tanker attack on the Kokuka Courageous in the Gulf. The photos show an unexploded limpet mine being removed by Iranians from a patrol boat. The Pentagon claims this evidence proves Iran's involvement, while Tehran denies any involvement and suggests the US may have orchestrated the attack to increase pressure. The US has not provided an explanation for why the Iranians allegedly removed the mine while being observed by US forces.

site_title: BP rig zigzags North Sea in chase with Greenpeace ship
summary: A BP drilling rig in the British North Sea has been forced to turn away twice from its destination after a high-sea chase with a Greenpeace vessel protesting climate change. The rig, Paul Loyd JNR, was attempting to reach the Vorlich oilfield to start its drilling campaign, but was thwarted by the Arctic Sunrise vessel. Greenpeace aims to stop BP from drilling new oil wells in the North Sea, while BP claims it has secured an injunction against the Arctic Sunrise vessel to protect its operations and people. The rig is now heading west towards Peterhead.

site_title: One in three Singapore bosses have demoted employees: Robert Half poll
summary: One-third of Singapore bosses (30%) have demoted an employee, according to a Robert Half poll. The most common reasons were employees not succeeding in a new role (46%), poor performance (37%), and organisational restructuring (15%). Only 2% of demotions were voluntary, and 54% of demoted staff handled the news professionally. Companies should clearly communicate the reason for demotion, and employees should stay professional and focus on new skills.

site_title: BOJ to debate overseas risks at this week's rate review: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda announced that the central bank's board will discuss heightening overseas economic risks at its upcoming rate review. The review, starting on Wednesday, aims to guide monetary policy considering the impact of overseas economic changes on Japan's economic outlook and inflation target. Kuroda emphasized the BOJ's commitment to achieving its inflation target despite potential risks. The review comes amid global economic uncertainty, including the US-China trade tensions and slowing GDP growth in China.

site_title: Global Invacom buys Apexsat's technology for 250,000 euros
summary: Global Invacom has acquired Apexsat's technology for 250,000 euros, expanding its product suite and enabling it to manufacture products for the LEO and MEO satellite communication constellations market. Apexsat's systems feature integrated tracking and positioning software, fibre-based command and control systems, and rotation and elevation systems suitable for tracking satellites and UAVs. The acquisition is expected to contribute to Global Invacom's financial performance and broaden its customer base.

site_title: EQM raises cost, delays timing of Mountain Valley natural gas pipeline
summary: EQM Midstream Partners LP has raised the estimated cost of its Mountain Valley natural gas pipeline from US$4.6 billion to US$4.8-US$5.0 billion, with a delayed completion to mid-2020 due to ongoing legal and regulatory challenges. The pipeline, designed to deliver 2 billion cubic feet per day, was initially estimated to cost US$3.5 billion and be completed by the end of 2018. The company has submitted a land exchange proposal to the federal government to enable the pipeline to cross the Appalachian Trail, which is now expected to face environmental group challenges.

site_title: Police kill gunman who opened fire on US courthouse
summary: A 22-year-old man, identified as Brian Clyde, opened fire on a Dallas federal courthouse on Monday, causing no deaths or injuries. Clyde, wearing a military uniform and bulletproof vest, fired from a sidewalk before being killed by police in a gun battle. Witnesses reported 10-15 shots were fired in a few minutes. Police later destroyed Clyde's vehicle, and his motives remain unclear. Clyde had recently finished a university course and had served in the army from 2015 to 2017.

site_title: Salvini in Washington to stress Italy's closeness to Trump administration
summary: Italian Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini visited Washington, meeting with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Vice-President Mike Pence, to stress Italy's closeness to the Trump administration. Salvini discussed shared visions on Iran, Venezuela, and the Middle East, and defended massive tax cuts despite concerns about Rome's soaring debt. He also distanced himself from Italy's participation in China's "New Silk Road" and criticized the EU's weaknesses. Salvini's visit aims to strengthen ties between Italy and the US, aligning with the Trump administration's populist views.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher; STI up 0.09% to 3,210.92 on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.09% to 3,210.92 on Tuesday, with about 38.7 million shares worth S$67 million changing hands. ESR-Reit traded down 7.97% despite its S$100 million private placement's issue price at the lower end of the range. DBS shares were down 0.45%, while UOB shares rose 1.04%. Other index stocks, including Singtel, were trading down. The Straits Times Index saw a 2.93-point increase, with 63 gainers outnumbering 43 losers.

site_title: China's May new home prices growth fastest in five months
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.7% in May, the fastest pace in five months, amid government stimulus efforts for a slowing economy. This marks the 49th consecutive month of price gains, with 67 of 70 cities reporting higher prices. Annual home prices increased 10.7%, unchanged from April, despite Beijing's calls to control runaway prices and concerns about further economic weakness. The market's resilience is attributed to easing credit conditions, pent-up demand, and implicit government support.

images.alt_text: New home prices in China rose at their fastest pace in five months in May, complicating government efforts to keep frothy housing markets under control as it rolls out more stimulus for the slowing economy.

site_title: Egypt ex-president Mohamed Morsi dies: official sources
summary: Egyptian ex-president Mohamed Morsi, 67, died in a Cairo hospital after fainting during a court session. He was speaking before a judge for 20 minutes before collapsing and was rushed to the hospital where he later died. Morsi was Egypt's first democratically elected president but was ousted in 2013 and spent years in prison on various charges, including espionage and terror plots. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan called him a "martyr" and a strong ally during his brief tenure as Egypt's leader.

site_title: Australian grocer Coles eyes A$1b in savings, shares jump
summary: Coles Group, Australia's second-largest grocery chain, plans to cut A$1 billion in costs over four years through automation and reducing duplication to offset rising labor and energy costs. The move aims to maintain market share in a competitive supermarket sector. Shares jumped 5% to a record high after the announcement. The company also plans to develop new revenue streams, including food exports to China and meal kits for delivery. CEO Steven Cain stated that maintaining share would be a "terrific result" given the competition.

site_title: Design Studio names new chief financial officer
summary: Design Studio Group appointed Lilian Tan Yin Yen as its new chief financial officer, replacing Ronald Kurniadi who resigned on June 8. Tan, 57, will oversee accounting and finance functions, including tax, treasury, and compliance matters. The appointment was made after the market closed on Monday evening.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Reit, OUE, Global Invacom, FCT, Sembcorp, HMI, 800 Super
summary: ESR-Reit plans to issue 194.2 million new units under a private placement to raise S$100 million, with an issue price of 51.5 Singapore cents. OUE has subscribed for shares of PT Deer Pine Indonesia, acquiring 99.91% of the company. ESR-Reit has requested to lift its trading halt.

site_title: Hong Kong reopens Central Government Offices after mass protests
summary: Hong Kong's Central Government Offices reopened after a historic protest on Sunday, with roads near the offices becoming accessible. The protest, attended by hundreds of thousands of protesters, called for leader Carrie Lam to resign over a bill allowing extraditions to China. Lam apologized for causing controversy, but China continues to support her. The government announced that the Executive Council, led by Lam, will be on recess and arrangements for her media session will be announced later. Despite the reopening, Lam remains under pressure to resign.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong reopened downtown government offices that had been blocked off after a historic protest on Sunday calling for leader Carrie Lam to resign over a bill allowing extraditions to China for the first time.

site_title: Fortis Healthcare drops plan to sell stake in RHT Health Trust, trustee manager
summary: Fortis Healthcare has closed the bidding process for its stake in Singapore-listed RHT Health Trust and its trustee manager, RHT Health Trust Manager, after receiving no commercially viable proposals. Fortis has a 27.82% interest in RHT, with FHIL and Stellant holding 25.14% and 2.68% respectively. The company will continue to explore options, including a new listing or winding up of RHT, which must meet Singapore Exchange requirements within 12 months. Fortis and its subsidiaries had previously intended to sell their interests, but now intend to consider alternative options.

site_title: Malaysian banks lead South-east Asian peers for board diversity
summary: Malaysian banks lead South-east Asian peers in board diversity, with women making up over 30% of the boards of top lenders. This surpasses Singapore (13%) and the Philippines (9%), according to Bloomberg data. Banks with high female representation tend to perform better in measures like return on assets, according to a US Federal Reserve study. Thailand's Kasikornbank Pcl is the best performer, with 40% female board members, although there is no compulsory requirement for women's representation. The country's corporate governance code is seen as a contributing factor to Malaysia's high board diversity.

site_title: US deploys 1,000 more troops to Middle East amid Iran tensions
summary: The US has approved the deployment of 1,000 additional troops to the Middle East amid escalating tensions with Iran. Acting Defence Secretary Patrick Shanahan cited "defensive purposes" and "hostile behavior" by Iranian forces as reasons for the deployment. The move comes after recent Iranian attacks on US personnel and interests in the region. The deployment is intended to address air, naval, and ground-based threats in the Middle East, and validates US intelligence on Iranian hostility.

site_title: Argentina opens probe into blackout causes
summary: Argentina's Energy Minister Gustavo Lopetegui announced an investigation into the cause of a massive blackout that left nearly 50 million people without power, mainly in Argentina and Uruguay. The blackout, which lasted over 10 hours, occurred on a Sunday when shops and offices were closed, and authorities said the economic impact was largely contained. Lopetegui admitted it may take two weeks to determine the cause, citing the need to analyze thousands of pieces of data from the "black boxes" of two companies responsible for electricity supply.

site_title: OUE subscribes for all shares of Indonesia investment holding firm for 11b rupiah
summary: Singapore-based property firm OUE has subscribed for all shares of Indonesian investment holding firm PT Deer Pine Indonesia for 11 billion rupiah. Through its subsidiaries, Tengara Holdings and OUE Coral, OUE acquired 99.91% and 0.09% of Deer Pine's shares, respectively. The move makes Deer Pine an indirect wholly owned subsidiary of OUE. The acquisition is expected to have a minimal impact on OUE's financials for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2019.

site_title: Scandal-ridden Brazil giant Odebrecht seeks bankruptcy protection
summary: Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht, embroiled in a bribery scandal, has filed for bankruptcy protection, seeking to negotiate debts of over $20 billion. The company, which admitted to spending nearly $800 million on bribes to win contracts in Latin America, filed the request with a Sao Paulo bankruptcy court. This move comes after years of investigations and allegations of corruption. Odebrecht's bankruptcy filing is a significant development in the ongoing saga of the scandal-ridden company.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index opens marginally lower
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.08% lower at 21,108.01 on June 18, 2019, ahead of US Federal Reserve meeting results. The broader Topix Index rose 0.05%. Investors took a cautious stance, likely due to US Federal Reserve meeting outcomes.

site_title: London named Europe's top 'tech for good' hotspot
summary: London has been named Europe's top 'tech for good' hotspot, according to EU-funded research by Nesta. The city ranked first due to its infrastructure, skills base, and varied funding landscape, which support for-profit tech companies, social enterprises, charities, and individual projects. Amsterdam ranked second, followed by Copenhagen, Stockholm, and Paris. The ranking is based on 32 factors across six categories, highlighting London's ability to foster digital social innovation and tech for good ventures.

site_title: Brain disease kills more than 100 Indian children
summary: More than 100 Indian children in the state of Bihar have died from a brain virus potentially linked to lychees, with 85 deaths reported at a government-run hospital and 18 at a private facility. The outbreak, known as Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES), has been linked to heat waves and has claimed 78 lives. This is the second-longest heat wave in India's history, and authorities have imposed restrictions to mitigate the effects. Outbreaks of AES have occurred annually in summer months since 1995.

site_title: Heathrow plans staged opening of third runway to cut costs
summary: Heathrow airport has unveiled final plans for its third runway, aiming to boost flights and maintain airport fees near current levels by 2026. The full project, set to be completed by 2050, includes an ultra-low-emissions zone and a 6 1/2-hour ban on scheduled night flights. The runway will be built by crossing the M25 highway via a bridge, avoiding costly tunnelling. The phased addition of capacity will help the airport stay competitive with rival bases in Paris, Amsterdam, and Frankfurt.

site_title: India doctors call off strike after government pledges better security
summary: Doctors in India's West Bengal state ended a week-long strike after authorities promised improved workplace security following violent attacks on medical staff. The strike, which affected 90 million people, was sparked by the assault of three doctors by a family who blamed them for their relative's death during treatment. The Indian Medical Association called for tougher punishments and better security measures, including more cameras and restricted visitor access. The government pledged to enhance security, leading to the call-off of the strike.

site_title: Sotheby's auction house to be taken private in US$3.7b sale
summary: Sotheby's auction house to be taken private in a US$3.7 billion sale led by French-Israeli telecommunications entrepreneur Patrick Drahi's BidFair USA. This deal reverses 31 years of public ownership, allowing Sotheby's to operate with more flexibility and avoid quarterly shareholder explanations. The acquisition comes after Sotheby's struggled to compete with Christie's, a privately held rival, in recent years, including high-profile sales of private collections and art pieces. Sotheby's shares jumped 58% in trading following the announcement, with the deal valued at US$2.66 billion in cash and US$57 per share.

site_title: Death toll from China quakes rises to 11
summary: China's death toll from two recent earthquakes has risen to 11, with 122 injured, according to state media. The quakes occurred on June 17, 2019, with the main quake having a magnitude of 5.8 and several aftershocks. Heavy rain has hindered rescue efforts in the affected areas near Yibin, where strong tremors are common. The US Geological Survey described the disaster as "extensive" and "widespread." Over 300 firefighters have been dispatched to the scene, with emergency supplies including 5,000 tents and 10,000 folding cots.

site_title: Big 3 banks can defend market share against fintech threats: Moody's
summary: Singapore's Big Three banks (DBS, OCBC, and UOB) can defend their market share against fintech threats due to their abundant financial resources and investments in technology. The banks' digitization efforts have improved efficiency and profitability, while fintech firms face challenges such as limited funding and inability to expand into deposit-taking and lending. To meet their cost targets, the banks must increase their digital customer base, while fintech firms often collaborate with banks to develop products and streamline internal processes.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge lower, Lufthansa drags after profit warning
summary: European stock markets closed marginally lower on Monday, with Lufthansa's profit warning dragging down airline stocks. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.1% as luxury stocks in France led gains, while IT company Indra Sistemas' decline took Spain's IBEX 35 0.7% lower. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, expecting a low probability of interest rate cuts, despite a recent swing in money market pricing towards up to three rate cuts this year.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% as economic worries outweigh tanker tensions
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday as economic worries outweighed tanker tensions. Brent crude futures dropped 1.73% to $60.94 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1.10% to $51.93 a barrel. The decline follows a 20% drop since April due to concerns over the US-China trade war and disappointing economic data.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: CEO for One Day
summary: Money FM's "Coffee with Claressa" podcast featured an episode where the guest, Claressa, was CEO for a day. The episode was recorded on June 17, 2019. Claressa shared her experiences as the temporary CEO, discussing her challenges and lessons learned during the day. The episode aimed to showcase the realities of corporate leadership and provide insight into the daily tasks and responsibilities of a CEO.

site_title: AEI inks framework deal to buy LNG on behalf of China's Zhongneng International Gas
summary: AEI Corporation, a Singapore-based aluminum producer, has entered into a framework agreement with Zhongneng International Gas Co (ZNI) to collaborate on liquefied natural gas (LNG) business activities. As part of the deal, ZNI will appoint AEI as its agent to purchase at least 6 million tonnes of LNG annually, and the two companies will establish a joint venture to undertake LNG trading and logistic activities. The proposed collaboration does not constitute binding obligations and is subject to definitive agreements. The deal aims to support ZNI's electrical power customers with LNG supply.

site_title: US preparing to send more troops to Middle East: sources
summary: The US is preparing to send additional troops to the Middle East in response to concerns over Iran, following attacks on oil tankers in May and a recent incident near the Strait of Hormuz. This would be in addition to the 1,500 troop increase announced last month. The deployment details have not been released, but the move is seen as a response to mounting threats to US forces and interests in the region. Iran denies the US accusations of being behind the attacks.

site_title: Asia: Equities on wobbling foundation as earnings outlook dims
summary: Asia's stock markets face a fragile foundation due to dimming earnings outlooks. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index's estimated 12-month forward earnings per share reached a 19-month low, with analysts cutting profit estimates by 5.4% this year. Trade tensions between the US and China have weighed on corporate profits, with the earnings downgrade phase in Asia still underway, particularly in the semiconductor sector. Despite some support from monetary easing and policy support, analysts expect earnings growth to remain stagnant or even negative if trade negotiations break down.

site_title: Population of Earth to reach 9.7b in 2050: UN
summary: The world population is projected to reach 9.7 billion by 2050, according to a UN report, with the global growth rate slowing due to declining fertility rates. By 2100, the population is expected to reach 11 billion. The report highlights countries such as India, Nigeria, and Indonesia as major contributors to population growth, while China's population is expected to drop by 2.2% between 2019 and 2050. The global fertility rate is expected to fall to 2.2 births per woman by 2050, close to the minimum needed to replace generations and avoid long-term decline.

site_title: US: Nasdaq leads US stocks higher ahead of Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks rose ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, with the Nasdaq leading the gain. Facebook surged 4.2% on anticipation of its cryptocurrency payment plan, lifting the Nasdaq Composite Index 0.6% to 7,845.02. Other tech companies, including Apple and Amazon, also advanced. The gains came despite uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's decision, which is expected to impact interest rates.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Trump imposes a 50% copper import tariff, affecting refined metal. This move is part of his efforts to protect domestic industries. The tariff impacts global markets, causing oil prices to rise over 2%. US stocks also edge down from record highs amid concerns over tariff threats and market volatility.

site_title: E-commerce growth to drive Singapore logistics services sector: Colliers
summary: Singapore's logistics services sector is expected to expand 48% to US$7.4 billion by 2022, driven by e-commerce growth, according to a report by Colliers International. The market is under pressure to deliver a better-quality service at a lower cost, with technologies such as AI and automation being used to bridge the gap. Warehouse vacancy rates remain high, with limited buying opportunities expected to lead to modest yield compression for logistics and warehouse assets.

site_title: Asian insurers need to embrace the low-carbon transition
summary: Asian insurers must adapt to the low-carbon transition amid rising natural disaster costs, warning that climate change will make some areas "uninsurable." Despite some Asian insurers making environmental commitments, none have stopped insuring coal projects, with 770 planned or under construction in the region. Insurers can accelerate clean energy breakthroughs by underwriting emerging technologies and stop insuring coal mines and power plants. A UN report warns that climate change will exacerbate natural disasters, making them twice as costly as in the previous decade, and insurers must take action to mitigate this risk.

site_title: Britain, France and Germany should step up to the plate in Mid-East crisis
summary: Britain, France, and Germany should increase their involvement in the Middle East crisis, following the recent attacks on oil tankers in the Persian Gulf. The US has stepped up patrols, but European countries, joint signatories to the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, have been slow to respond. Iran has denied responsibility, but warned of scaling back compliance with the nuclear deal unless other signatories ease sanctions. The situation has the potential for another "Tanker War II," which could disrupt global oil supplies and worsen the economic outlook, already affected by the Sino-US trade war.

site_title: First Sponsor in JV to develop mixed-used site in Guangdong
summary: First Sponsor Group has entered into a joint venture agreement with Poly Bay Area Investment Development Co and Shoucheng Dongguan Real Estate Co to develop three plots of land in Guangdong, China, worth approximately S$592 million. The joint venture company, Dongguan Baozhu Industrial Investment Co, will develop the Wanjiang Victory Land site. This marks First Sponsor Group's first joint venture in China.

site_title: Electronics exports hit 10-year low, heralding further pain ahead
summary: Singapore's electronics exports plummeted 31.4% in May, the largest drop since 2009, due to the US-China trade conflict and weakening global demand. This is the third consecutive month of double-digit declines, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) falling 15.9% and total trade shrinking 2.1%. Economists warn of a long winter for the electronics sector, with some predicting a severe economic downturn if the US-China trade war escalates. The US-China trade tension remains unresolved, and global appetite for chips wanes, further exacerbating the decline.

site_title: Why the G-20 in Japan may be memorable
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to meet at the G-20 summit in Japan, which may be a breakthrough opportunity for easing or escalating US-China trade tensions. The summit, attended by 20 world leaders representing 90% of global GDP and 80% of world trade, will focus on trade, climate change, and other global issues. Recent G-20 summits have been marked by divisions, but a successful meeting could be a rare success in recent global summitry. The event also comes at a critical time, with many G-20 countries imposing trade restrictive measures and the international trading system facing unprecedented challenges.

site_title: Significant potential for Reits in Asia, an 'emerging' asset class
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investment trusts (Reits) show significant potential, with listings growing strongly over the past decade, driven by emerging markets like the Philippines and India. The Philippines is poised to list its first Reit, with tax reforms and relaxed regulations expected to boost the market. India is also well-placed to list its first Reit, with the largest office Reit in Asia expected to be launched. Singapore and Australia lead the way in Reit markets, while Hong Kong's success story is attributed to Link Reit's transformation of under-rented assets. The region's long-term population and urbanization-led growth trends make Reits an attractive asset class with low volatility and above-market dividend yields.

site_title: Banks see gold in silver economy; more launching dedicated schemes
summary: Banks in Singapore, including Maybank, OCBC, and Standard Chartered, are launching dedicated schemes to cater to the country's ageing population. The schemes offer integrated packages of banking products, preferential savings rates, and lifestyle perks, targeting customers aged 50 and above. Maybank's Passion Plus programme, launched in May, is the latest to join the trend, with a focus on retirement planning and wealth protection. The move is seen as a response to the growing need for financial planning services among seniors, who will account for one in four Singaporeans by 2030.

site_title: ESR-Reit to buy warehouse, enhance 2 assets and raise funds
summary: ESR-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has announced plans to acquire a warehouse for S$225 million and undertake asset enhancement initiatives at two existing assets. The acquisition will be funded by a S$38.6 million contribution from ESR-Reit's trustee and S$40.2 million from logistics firm Poh Tiong Choon Logistics. The trust will also raise up to S$150 million through an equity fundraising to service debt and finance the transactions. The acquisition is expected to increase rental income and portfolio occupancy, and improve weighted average lease expiry.

site_title: Teheran will not cave to Trump's dealmaking
summary: US President Trump's diplomatic tactics, as seen in his dealings with North Korea, may not be effective in negotiations with Iran. Trump's "maximum pressure" policy, including economic sanctions, has led to increased tensions and Iranian resistance. Iran has continued to back its proxies in the region, attacking US interests and oil tankers. In response, Trump has reduced his attacks on Iran and is seeking a new nuclear deal, but the Iranians have rejected his overtures. With the US presidential election approaching, Trump faces a "damned if you do, damned if you don't" choice: make major concessions to Iran or risk a war.

site_title: Buyers mop up more new homes in May amid surge in launches
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged 29.5% in May, with 952 units sold, amid a record 9 new project launches. This marks a significant increase from April, despite fears of a trade war dampening market sentiment. Experts attribute the surge to buyers being "price sensitive and value conscious," with 62.5% of homes sold priced below S$1.5 million. The ultra-luxe segment remains active, with penthouse sales at projects like Amber Park and Boulevard 88. Developers expect sales to ease slightly in June but pick up again in July, ahead of the Hungry Ghost month in August.

site_title: How Japan turned against its 'bazooka'-wielding central bank chief
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan (BOJ), has pushed back its inflation target for the sixth time since 2013 under Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's "bazooka" monetary policy, a version of quantitative easing. Despite initially stimulating the economy with a 6.8% expansion and a 2.4% jobless rate, the BOJ's efforts have failed to achieve its 2% inflation target. The BOJ has been criticized for its inability to manage the costs of prolonged easing, and Governor Kuroda's authority has diminished, leading to a debate within the BOJ over its next steps. The BOJ's decisions have implications for the US Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, both struggling to unwind policies in response to the 2008 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Governor Haruhiko Kuroda, seen here at a news conference at BOJ headquarters in Tokyo in mid-2015, still argues that the costs of massive monetary easing are manageable.

site_title: Australian home price dive levels out as auctions lift market
summary: Australian home prices have finally found a floor, with Sydney on track for its first monthly gain in two years. Preliminary data shows home prices across capital cities were steady last week, breaking months of declines. In Sydney, prices edged up 0.3% for the month, with a 74.7% clearance rate at property auctions, the highest since April last year. The improvement coincides with lower mortgage rates and the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to relax lending rules, suggesting a potential price gain of 2-3% a quarter.

site_title: Paris rediscovers its appetite for bouillon fare
summary: Paris is experiencing a resurgence of interest in traditional "bouillon" restaurants, which serve classic French comfort food at affordable prices. These establishments, often located in historic buildings, offer hearty meals such as egg mayonnaise and rabbit terrine for under 20 euros. The trend is attributed to a desire for comfort food and a rejection of trendy, expensive cuisine. Several iconic bouillon restaurants, including Chartier and Bouillon Julien, are seeing a surge in popularity, with long queues forming outside their doors.

site_title: Huawei braces for 40-60% plunge in overseas smartphone sales
summary: Huawei is bracing for a 40-60% drop in overseas smartphone sales due to the US blacklisting, which restricts access to Google Android updates and software. The company may cut shipments of its Honor 20 model, set to launch in Europe on June 21, if sales lag. This would impact Huawei's international business, which accounted for nearly half of its 2018 shipments. The company aims to offset the decline by grabbing half of China's smartphone market by year-end and investing in marketing and distribution.

site_title: ECB will consider tiering if it cuts rates: exec
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may consider implementing a tiered deposit rate if it cuts interest rates, according to ECB board member Benoit Coeure. This would exempt banks from paying the ECB's 0.4% annual charge on their excess reserves, potentially boosting their profits. The move comes as banks struggle with a growth slowdown. Coeure's comments suggest the ECB is exploring options to mitigate the impact of negative interest rates on banks.

site_title: Luxury ranches in US still come at a premium despite lowered prices
summary: Luxury ranches in the US continue to command high prices despite a slight slowdown in sales, with only six of 38 listings over $10 million marked down in the past 90 days. Sellers are holding out for buyers willing to pay a premium for exclusive properties with desirable features such as mountain views, proximity to towns, and wildlife. Some sellers, like Morton Fleischer, are marketing their ranches at higher prices, citing the potential for long-term investment and the allure of a lifestyle in the US West.

site_title: Boris Johnson gets boost in race as ex-rival backs him
summary: Boris Johnson received a boost in his bid to become British Prime Minister as former rival Matt Hancock backed him, stating Johnson is "almost certainly" to win the contest. Hancock, who dropped out of the race, praised Johnson's disciplined campaign and said the party needs to unite behind him. Johnson won 114 votes in the first round, with Jeremy Hunt and Michael Gove trailing behind. The second round of voting will take place on Tuesday, with a constitutional crisis possible if parliament tries to block a no-deal Brexit, which Johnson has promised to lead the UK out of the EU with or without a deal.

site_title: What Singapore businesses need to get ahead in the AI race
summary: Singapore businesses need to overcome data silos and team disconnections to harness the power of artificial intelligence (AI). The country's pro-business environment and infrastructure make it well-positioned for AI adoption, but challenges persist. A recent survey found 96% of respondents cite data silos as the top challenge, while 80% struggle with collaboration between data scientists and engineers. To succeed, businesses must unify data and teams, leveraging Unified Analytics and closing the "1 per cent problem" gap. Those that do will be the real AI innovators, driving efficiency, productivity, and investment in Singapore's economy.

site_title: China's Xi to visit North Korea this week, ahead of G20
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to visit North Korea this week, marking the first time a Chinese president has visited the country in 14 years. The trip comes ahead of a G20 summit in Japan where Xi is expected to meet US President Donald Trump to discuss their trade war. Analysts believe Xi can use the visit to North Korea as leverage in talks with Trump, as China and North Korea have strengthened relations in the past year. The visit aims to push for a new chapter in their relationship and a political resolution of the Korean peninsula issue.

images.alt_text: A giant screen flashes a CCTV state media news report on the meeting between President Xi Jinping and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un at a shopping mall in Beijing in January.

site_title: Tough sell: Baijiu, China's potent tipple, looks abroad
summary: China's potent spirit, baijiu, is struggling to gain popularity abroad due to its intense, earthy flavor, which some describe as reminiscent of cow manure or industrial cleaning solvent. Despite being the most consumed spirit in the world, baijiu's popularity has been limited by its strong taste. However, manufacturers are adapting by creating milder varieties and single-serving mixed drinks, and some distilleries are now looking to export their products. In recent years, sales have recovered, and the market value of premium brands has surged, making China's Kweichow Moutai the world's most valuable distiller.

site_title: Weak start to the week for STI
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,207.99, easing 14.64 points or 0.5% on Monday due to investor caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's June meeting. Despite May's non-oil domestic exports figures beating consensus expectations, the market was little affected. The performance was attributed to defensive leanings, with investors waiting for interest rate decisions.

site_title: The march of digitalisation in Asia
summary: Asia's digital transformation has made significant progress in recent years, with leading industries such as retail, finance, and healthcare adopting digital solutions to improve efficiency and customer experience. According to Microsoft's studies, 85% of organizations in Asia-Pacific are already in the midst of their digital transformation journey, and the region is expected to see a massive jump in digital products and services, from 6% of GDP in 2017 to 60% in the next two years. However, challenges such as lack of confidence in and willingness to invest in technology, aversion to AI adoption, and creating motivation and developing the right competencies remain.

images.alt_text: "People use a lot of gadgets in Asia, which has driven many processes and services to become digitalised for use on handheld devices." - Dr Min Sun
"The biggest challenges are creating motivation and developing the right competencies from management to frontline staff." - Dr Keeratpal Singh
"Asia is moving to support enterprise efforts through planning, skills enablement, and regulation and programmes." - Saad Toma
"As organisations face mounting pressure to be more innovative, they should look at fostering a culture of collaboration." - Gustavo Fuchs
"There has been a lot of innovation in the region, and this is growing because of the demand for better experiences from consumers." - Dirk-Peter van Leeuwen

site_title: 2 GCBs at Bin Tong Park, King Albert Park up for sale
summary: Two good class bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore have been put up for sale via expression of interest. The first is a freehold estate at 5 Bin Tong Park in District 10, with a total land area of 2,611.4 square meters, while the second is a freehold estate at 22A King Albert Park in District 21, with a total land area of 3,387.6 square meters. The asking price was not disclosed, but the market has seen strong interest from developers and end-users, with a total sales value of S$1.03 billion in the GCB market in 2018.

site_title: Intel unit Mobileye sees self-driving taxis on the roads in 2020
summary: Intel's Mobileye unit expects to launch a trial of self-driving taxis in Israel by next year, with plans to expand globally. The company, which has been working on commercializing a robo-cab service with Volkswagen and Champion Motor Group, sees a nearly $300 billion market for autonomous cars. Intel CEO Bob Swan recently rode a Mobileye autonomous car through Jerusalem, saying he's more encouraged by progress than in the past. Software development is expected to be completed by the end of this year, and Intel is launching a 20-week program to aid Israeli startups working on AI and autonomous technologies.

site_title: Businesses clamour for Trump's ear as new China tariffs loom
summary: The US is set to impose new tariffs on Chinese imports, totaling $300 billion, sparking warnings from major businesses about job losses, price increases, and a decline in US industrial dominance. The tariffs, which would affect nearly all Chinese goods imported by the US, could cost two million jobs and cut US GDP growth by a full percentage point. Major industries, including steel and aluminum producers, support the tariffs, but most businesses are pleading with the administration to spare imports they depend on. The tariffs could have a sharp negative reaction from the public, leading to immediate price increases on consumer items.

site_title: UOBAM rolls out innovation equity fund for retail investors
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has launched the United Global Innovation Fund (UGIF), a new equity fund for retail investors, allowing exposure to innovative firms in various sectors, including healthcare, finance, and technology. The fund invests in enterprises seeking structural change and has a focus on climate action, with a minimal subscription sum of S$1,000 or US$1,000. The fund has achieved 8.89% returns year to date, outperforming the benchmark MSCI All Country World Index.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MindChamps PreSchool Ltd acquired the entire shareholding in MindChamps PreSchool @ Buangkok Private Limited from Zhao ShuZhen for S$3.2 million. The acquisition will be funded through a combination of initial public offering proceeds and an acquisition loan. This purchase will see MindChamps PreSchool Singapore acquire the Serangoon childcare centre.

site_title: Canadian town comes alive once a year, as thousands of snakes mate
summary: In Manitoba, Canada, thousands gather each spring to witness the annual mating ritual of tens of thousands of red-sided garter snakes, which inhabit a network of small caves created by erosion. The snakes emerge in late spring, typically in late May, and spend 10 days mating. The event, which attracts both snake enthusiasts and those who fear snakes, is considered one of the largest concentrations of snakes in the world. The snakes are harmless to humans and are protected by the Manitoba wildlife service.

site_title: Dollar hits two-week high as traders eye Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high on Monday as investors reassessed the Federal Reserve's potential for a rate cut. Strong US retail sales reduced the likelihood of a rate cut at the Fed's June meeting, lifting the dollar. Expectations of a rate cut have fallen to 20% but remain high for the July meeting. The dollar index hit a two-week high, while the euro remained little changed, awaiting ECB policymakers' speeches and eurozone inflation data. Analysts believe the path for rate cuts depends on US-China trade talks.

site_title: Levelling the field for women entrepreneurs
summary: Singaporean companies like Procter & Gamble (P&G) are promoting women entrepreneurship through initiatives and partnerships. The Women Entrepreneurs Development Programme, in partnership with WEConnect International, has enabled over 300 women-owned companies in 10 countries, including Singapore. P&G spends over $2.2 billion annually with diverse businesses, with half of that invested in women-owned companies. The programme aims to empower women with skills and training to grow and scale their businesses, promoting economic growth and contributing to the UN's Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Fewer cases of common cyber threats detected in Singapore in 2018
summary: Singapore reported a 70% decrease in website defacements, with 605 cases detected in 2018, compared to 2,040 in 2017. Phishing cases declined by 30% to 16,100, while ransomware cases dropped to 21 from 25 in 2017. Despite this, cybercrime cases remain on the rise, with 1,204 cases investigated under the Computer Misuse Act in 2018, up 40% from the previous year. The country continues to face increasingly sophisticated threats, with the need for collective efforts to defend against them.

site_title: Money FM chalks up 7% growth in digital listenership
summary: Money FM 89.3, Singapore's business and personal finance radio station, recorded a 7% increase in digital listenership between October 2018 and May 2019, with a 28% rise in listening time. This growth is in line with SPH Radio's overall digital listenership, which increased by 10% during the same period. The station's events, such as the "Spotlight: Career Disputed" symposium, also helped engage listeners. UFM100.3 was the most popular station digitally, with over 890,000 listeners tuning in via the SPH Radio application or website.

site_title: SMRT, SBS Transit sign MOU with ST Engineering
summary: SMRT and SBS Transit, Singapore's two rail operators, signed a collaboration memorandum of understanding with ST Engineering to work together on cost-effective development of engineering capabilities for rail operations and maintenance. The partnership aims to minimize duplication of resources and address technology gaps in the local industry. They will start working on repairing electronic cards on older trains, which have caused breakdowns in the past, and pool their knowledge and resources to diagnose and repair electronic cards more quickly and reduce service downtime.

site_title: Xi Jinping to visit North Korea this week ahead of G20
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will visit North Korea this week, marking the first trip by a Chinese president in 14 years. The visit comes ahead of the G20 summit in Japan, where Xi is expected to meet with US President Donald Trump to discuss their trade war. Beijing is seeking to remind Trump of its influence in Pyongyang, which has been working to improve relations with China in the past year. The visit is seen as a way for Xi to use the trip as a "bargaining chip" in the US-China trade war.

site_title: Italy's banks face more graft probes in wake of diamond scandal
summary: Italy's largest bank, UniCredit, and smaller rival Banco BPM are under investigation for corruption related to diamond sales. Prosecutors allege that the banks colluded with diamond brokers to sell diamonds at inflated prices, using the proceeds to boost profits. The investigation also involves Intesa Sanpaolo and Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena. If convicted, the banks could face fines, asset seizure, and temporary suspension. More than 100,000 people bought diamonds from Italian banks over 20 years, with allegations of coercion and intimidation used to secure investments.

site_title: TT International gives notice of three years of consecutive losses
summary: TT International, a consumer electronics retailer, has announced three consecutive years of losses, casting doubt on its ability to continue as a going concern. Its independent auditors have identified material uncertainties, prompting trading of its securities to be suspended. The company's financial struggles come amid market uncertainty and global trade tensions, including the US's 50% copper import tariff.

site_title: Alibaba plans stock split as it preps giant HK listing
summary: Alibaba Group Holding plans a one-to-eight share split, increasing the number of ordinary shares from 4 billion to 32 billion, as the e-commerce giant prepares for a potential Hong Kong stock listing worth up to $20 billion. The proposal will be discussed at its annual general meeting on July 15, with the split expected to take place by July 2020. The move aims to replenish the company's war chest and attract investors as tensions between China and the US escalate. Alibaba will seek to preserve its governance system in the Hong Kong offering.

site_title: Telecom titan Patrick Drahi is buying Sotheby's for US$2.7b
summary: Telecom titan Patrick Drahi is buying Sotheby's for US$2.7 billion, taking the auction house private after 31 years as a public company. The deal represents a 61% premium to the closing price and will be funded in part by selling a small piece of the US business for up to US$400 million. The acquisition will place the world's two leading auction houses under the control of French billionaires, with Sotheby's shares rising 57% to US$55.58 per share.

site_title: Boeing crisis, trade tensions cast pall over Paris Airshow
summary: The Paris Airshow, a major event for the commercial aircraft industry, is underway amidst concerns over Boeing's 737 Max crisis, trade tensions, and growing security threats. Despite bulging order books, analysts predict a slowdown in the industry due to global pressures and flagging economies. Boeing aims to reassure customers and suppliers about the plane's future, while Airbus plans to launch a new plane, the A321XLR, with potential support from major US buyers. Industry executives are worried about public confidence in air travel and the risk of a backlash that could drive a wedge between regulators and undermine the certification system.

site_title: H&M's sales growth fails to ease investors concerns about margin pressure
summary: H&M reported sales growth for a fourth consecutive quarter, with local-currency sales up 6% in Q2, beating expectations. However, investors remain concerned about margin pressure, citing increased investments in logistics and digital technology, and rising inventories. Despite this, analysts note an improved product offering is gaining traction, and the company may have gained market share in key markets. H&M's full Q2 earnings report will be published on June 27.

site_title: Nvidia to work with Arm chips in building supercomputers
summary: NVIDIA has announced a partnership with Arm Holdings to work together on building supercomputers, expanding their capabilities in AI and climate modeling. This collaboration will integrate Nvidia's chips with Arm's processors, enhancing their systems for complex computing tasks. The move deepens Nvidia's presence in the field of supercomputing, which is increasingly used for AI research and climate modeling.

site_title: MAS issues prohibition orders against ex-UBS banker
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against Paris Michele, a former UBS banker, for forging letters and e-mails to deceive the Swiss private bank about UBS clients' tax compliance in 2013. Michele's actions were part of his job to conduct due diligence on UBS customers.

site_title: Mercurius to buy 50% stake in Thai property developer
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment is set to acquire a 50% stake in Thai property developer Grand Bay Hotel for over $14.69 million. The acquisition will also involve joint development of the Sheraton Phuket Grand Bay Resort in Phuket, Thailand. Mercurius will pay 335 million baht (half of the land parcels' value) plus half of the construction costs incurred by Grand Bay. The purchase price will be paid in four instalments, with the final tranche transferred upon payment of the last instalment.

site_title: Digital retail banking levels the playing field, says Citi
summary: Citi's senior executive Charles Wong states that digital retail banking has leveled the playing field in Singapore, allowing branch-light banks to compete effectively. Traditionally, local banks had the upper hand due to their extensive branch networks. However, Citi's investment in digital tech and decreasing costs have enabled it to compete with larger banks, playing "like never before". This shift is attributed to the increasing adoption of digital retail banking, which has reduced the importance of physical branches in customer reach.

site_title: Pfizer acquires Array Biopharma, valued at US$11.4 billion
summary: Pfizer has acquired biotechnology firm Array BioPharma for $11.4 billion, with Pfizer offering $48 per share in cash. The acquisition aims to create a leading franchise for colorectal cancer and complements Pfizer's existing expertise in breast and prostate cancers. Array's portfolio includes two cancer drugs, Braftovi and Mektovi, which are effective in treating BRAF-mutant melanoma and colorectal cancers. The deal follows a trend of big pharmaceutical companies acquiring biotech firms for growth.

site_title: Erdogan's ally says Turkey needs 'new and fair' currency regime
summary: Turkey's economy needs a "new and fair" currency regime, according to Devlet Bahceli, a key ally of President Erdogan. Bahceli criticized the recent exchange rate fluctuations as a sign of confrontation, while the Treasury and Finance Ministry maintained that the country will never abandon its floating currency. The lira has depreciated nearly 10% this year, threatening to cripple demand and put strain on Turkish companies with a $315 billion foreign-currency debt pile. Bahceli's comments suggest a growing debate over the country's economic approach, which could lead to measures based on public opinion and bring an end to currency volatility.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cache Logistics Trust's tax settlement with CWT Pte Ltd results in a one-off Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) uplift of about 0.25 Singapore cents. The trust also recently acquired a warehouse in Victoria, Australia, and is studying the South Korean logistics market for potential acquisitions. ARA US Hospitality Trust, a pure-play on upscale select-service hotels, is recommended to buy with a target price of US$1.15, driven by asset enhancement initiatives and diversification through yield accretive acquisitions.

site_title: Abe turning his back on Kuroda-nomics
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is distancing himself from the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target, which was a key pillar of his "Abenomics" economic plan. Abe emphasizes the need to spur growth and create jobs, rather than focusing solely on inflation. The shift in tone comes as public concerns grow over the diminishing returns and rising costs of prolonged monetary easing. Analysts say the central bank has been forced to maintain loose monetary policy for longer than expected, and some, including economic adviser Koichi Hamada, now question the need to achieve the 2% target.

site_title: SMEs in Singapore need to move beyond clicks and mortar
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must prioritize creating consistent omnichannel brand experiences to stand out in a market where customer journeys are increasingly occurring across multiple digital channels. According to a Forrester Consulting study, businesses that focus on customer experience achieve an average revenue growth rate of 23%. To create seamless experiences, SMEs should start with a cohesive brand story, create a seamless experience across all touchpoints, make the most of every micro-moment, and connect micro-moments for an enhanced experience. Neglecting brand experience can lead to lost customers, while positive experiences can improve retention and acquisition rates.

site_title: China stands by HK leader after days of street protests
summary: China has reaffirmed its support for Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam amid ongoing protests over a planned extradition bill, with a source close to Lam stating that Beijing is unlikely to let her go even if she tries to resign. The protests, which have entered their second week, are calling for the bill to be killed and for Lam to step down. Demonstrators and opposition politicians are gathering near the government's offices, braving intermittent rain to express their demands.

site_title: Lee family gets over 90% of 800 Super shares, offer turns unconditional
summary: The Lee family's offer to take 800 Super Holdings private has turned unconditional after crossing the 90% threshold. As of June 17, 8S Capital Holdings received 162.4 million shares, representing 90.8% of issued shares. The offer, valued at S$161 million, was initially set at S$0.90 per share. KKR will finance the offer with debt and structured equity, and will also receive a board seat. The closing date has been extended to July 8, with no intention to extend beyond.

site_title: Faster, better, cheaper: leveraging fintech for remittance services
summary: In South-east Asia, fintech has grown significantly, but non-bank financial institutions (NBFIs) like money transfer operators and liquidity providers play a vital role in the remittance industry, providing access to financial services for the underserved community of 6.84 million migrant workers. NBFIs face challenges in delivering convenient and efficient remittance services due to lack of technology. Integrating fintech can bring these customers closer to a "frictionless" experience, increasing agility and flexibility for NBFIs to grow and scale their business. NBFIs can adopt ready-to-integrate solutions or partner with technology providers to leverage fintech and provide faster, better, cheaper remittance services, ultimately contributing to the region's growing remittance flow of $299 billion by 2025.
