images.alt_text: Many NBFIs lack a clear roadmap, strategy and guidance to leverage, amortise and profit from digital transformation.

site_title: Will revelation foil Pangolin's bid to block delisting?
summary: A Singaporean company, Challenger Technologies, is set to be delisted after a rival bid, led by Digileap Capital, was accepted by the company's majority shareholder. However, Pangolin Investment Management, a minority shareholder, is opposing the deal, claiming it is undervalued. Digileap has revealed that Pangolin had previously offered to sell its stake at S$0.435 per share, sparking questions about Pangolin's true intentions. The outcome of the June 27 EGM will determine whether the delisting is approved, with Digileap warning that failure to do so could lead to 12 months of uncertainty and thin trading liquidity.

images.alt_text: Two weeks before an anticipated showdown that will determine if Challenger Technologies will stay on as a listed company, the party making the exit offer has played what it hopes is its trump card.

site_title: Market watchers see China holding firm on yuan for rest of June
summary: China has set its daily yuan fixing at a stronger level than market expectations for the fourth consecutive week, with the currency trading at 6.9250 per US dollar. Market watchers expect the central bank to maintain this stance, citing the ongoing trade tensions with the US. The move is seen as a support measure for the yuan, which has weakened to its weakest level of the year on June 10. The G-20 summit between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping may also provide an opportunity for China to show good faith on the yuan, but a major trade deal is unlikely.

site_title: China, US pushed trade barriers to record high in 2018: EU
summary: The European Commission reported that protectionism across the globe reached a record high in 2018, with 23 non-EU countries introducing 45 new trade barriers. China and Russia had the most "problematic" trade measures, with 37 and 34 respectively. The barriers mainly affected the IT sector and precious metals, impacting 51.4 billion euros (S$79.1 billion) of EU exports. However, 123 foreign measures were eliminated since 2014, resulting in 6.1 billion euros of extra EU exports. The EU Trade Commissioner warned that protectionism is a global trend and may persist in the short term.

site_title: Lagerfeld's Chanel made US$11b in his last year
summary: Chanel reported nearly 10 billion euros (S$15.4 billion) in sales in its final year under Karl Lagerfeld, with profits reaching close to US$3 billion. Sales rose over 10% in 2018, driven by strong performances in leather goods and ready-to-wear. Despite investing US$1 billion in digital presence and supply chains, Chanel's perfume and beauty division also showed rapid growth. The brand's turnover ranks second behind Louis Vuitton, with an estimated worth of over US$20 billion. Chanel's results come ahead of Paris men's fashion week, where a special event will honor Lagerfeld.

site_title: Budget airline IndiGo orders 280 jet engines in US$20b deal
summary: Indian budget airline IndiGo orders 280 jet engines worth US$20 billion from a joint venture of General Electric and France's Safran, a move away from Pratt & Whitney following a series of glitches. The order includes service and maintenance for Airbus A320neo and A321neo aircraft, set to be delivered by 2020. This deal strengthens CFM's presence in India, a growing aviation market, and could be a reputational negative for Pratt's geared turbofan, potentially hurting future sales.

site_title: Health Management International in discussion for possible transaction
summary: Health Management International is discussing a possible transaction with a third party, but no decision or agreement has been made. The company has not commented on the outcome of these discussions and its shares closed unchanged at S$0.64. There is no certainty that the talks will progress or that a transaction will occur.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.5% on Monday amid cautious sentiment
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.5% lower at 3,207.99 on Monday, amid cautious sentiment due to the US Federal Reserve's June meeting and global economic slowdown. Investors remain concerned about US-China trade tensions and potential rate cuts by Asian central banks. Locally, telcos Singtel and StarHub gained, while NetLink NBN Trust and DBS Group Holdings had mixed performances. The market saw increased trading volume, with institutional buying possibly at play, particularly in defensive sectors.

site_title: Citi combines rates and currencies businesses
summary: Citigroup is combining its Foreign Exchange & Local Markets and G10 currencies businesses into one unit, aiming to drive better client service, risk management, and profitability. The groups already share similar product sets and resources, leading to the decision. This more streamlined operating model will help Citigroup to improve its services and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Fidelity considering demerger of venture arm Eight Roads
summary: Fidelity is considering demerging its venture arm Eight Roads, a significant investment firm in South-east Asia, from its core business. The move aims to align business goals with employee incentives and improve financial transparency. Eight Roads has invested over $6 billion in ventures since 2008, backing notable startups such as Alibaba and Pony.AI. Moody's Investors Service views the demerger as a credit-positive move, citing reduced earnings volatility and balance sheet risk. A final decision is expected later this year, pending regulatory and shareholder approvals.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Tee Land sells 15 out of 48 units at Lattice One preview weekend at around S$1,800 psf
summary: Tee Land sold 15 out of 48 units at Lattice One, a freehold condo, at an average price of S$1,800 psf, resulting in a 31% take-up rate. The units sold were two-bedroom, two-bedroom plus study, and three-bedroom units with floor areas ranging from 50 to 100 square meters. All buyers were Singaporeans.

site_title: KS Energy to not take delivery of rig after contract termination with ZPMC
summary: KS Energy's unit KS Drilling will not take delivery of the KS Java Star 3 rig after contract termination with Shanghai ZPMC. The contract, signed in 2014, was expected to deliver the rig 27 months after its effective date, but was amended in 2016 to allow for a deferral. The termination is expected to have a material impact on KS Energy's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the 2019 financial year. The rig's construction costs, previously valued at US$12.6 million, will be written off.

site_title: Tough sell: Baijiu, China's potent tipple, looks abroad
summary: China's national spirit, baijiu, is struggling to gain traction overseas due to its intense, earthy flavor. Despite being the world's most consumed spirit and generating significant revenue, baijiu's popularity abroad is hindered by its strong taste and unfamiliarity. Manufacturers are adapting by creating milder varieties and export-oriented brands, with sales growing overseas, but a long road lies ahead to make baijiu a global phenomenon. China's major distilleries are now focusing on promoting baijiu globally, but overcoming the initial hurdle of its intense flavor remains a challenge.

site_title: Australian shares end lower in muted trade; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares ended 0.35% lower, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 23.10 points to 6,530.90. Mining stocks, including BHP and Rio Tinto, declined, while financial stocks edged higher. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.6% as utilities and industrial stocks weighed down. The US Federal Reserve meeting later in the week is expected to influence investor sentiment.

site_title: Amazon, ExxonMobil called out over climate transparency
summary: Amazon, ExxonMobil, and Volvo are among 700+ companies targeted by investors backing a campaign for greater climate transparency. HSBC and Investec Asset Management, with $10 trillion in combined assets, are calling on companies to comply with CDP's environmental reporting process. The goal is to collect consistent, comparable data to inform investment decisions and benchmark performance, according to CDP's global director of investor initiatives, Emily Kreps.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks inch lower ahead of Fed meeting
summary: South Korea's Kospi index fell 4.68 points, or 0.22%, to 2,090.73 ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting this week and planned China-US talks at the G-20 summit. The won fell, and the benchmark bond yield rose. Investors remained cautious due to the uncertainty surrounding the Fed meeting and trade talks between the US and China. Foreigners were net sellers of 138 billion won worth of shares, and the won was quoted at 1,186.5 per dollar, 0.10% lower than its previous close.

site_title: H&M sales rise for fifth straight quarter
summary: H&M's revenue figures showed a slowdown in April and May, despite sales topping analysts' estimates. The Swedish clothing retailer's attempts to reduce inventory buildup are ongoing, with analysts estimating a 4% increase in stock-in-trade at the end of May. Despite this, H&M's sales rose 6% in local currencies in the period, with growth slowing to 5.5% in April and May. Analysts expect a 3% increase in operating profit for the second quarter, marking the first gain in two years.

site_title: Beauty World Plaza up for en bloc grabs again at reserve price of S$165m
summary: Beauty World Plaza owners are launching another collective sale tender at a reserve price of S$165 million, unchanged from their previous attempt in 2018. The site has an in-principle approval for redevelopment into serviced apartments and is zoned for commercial and residential use. Several new developments are planned for the area, including an integrated transport hub and amenities. The tender closes on July 17, 2019, with some nearby commercial buildings having sold for S$148 million and S$120 million. The location is expected to remain bustling due to improved public transport and amenities.

site_title: Deutsche Bank considers closing US equities trading in revamp
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering closing its US equities trading and creating a non-core unit to wind down up to 50 billion euros in unwanted assets. The move is part of a broader overhaul aimed at scaling back the troubled investment bank. CEO Christian Sewing is seeking to reduce trading operations, with cuts to the rates business likely. A non-core unit housing long-dated derivatives is also planned, with "deep cuts" to the equities business expected to focus on the transaction bank. The plan will be announced before the end of July.

site_title: Sembcorp to inject new equity in India energy business
summary: Sembcorp Industries plans to inject new equity into its India energy arm Sembcorp Energy India Limited (SEIL) to support growth in the renewable energy business. The company withdrew a draft prospectus and will re-file a revised one this year, considering market conditions. This move aims to support SEIL's growth in the Indian market.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up as market awaits Fed, G20
summary: US stocks were mostly higher early Monday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve meeting and the G20 summit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.1%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.6%. Individual companies like Array BioPharma surged 57.7% after agreeing to be bought by Pfizer, while Pfizer dropped 0.9%. Analysts do not expect a rate cut this week, despite the Fed's recent tone shift. The G20 gathering may provide an opportunity for US President Trump to meet with Chinese leader Xi Jinping in ongoing trade talks.

site_title: MindChamps buying Buangkok preschool branch from franchisee for S$3.2m
summary: MindChamps PreSchool Limited acquired the Buangkok preschool branch from franchisee Zhao ShuZhen for S$3.2 million. The acquisition, made through a wholly owned subsidiary, is part of the company's expansion plans and is expected to positively impact its earnings per share and net tangible assets. The purchase was funded using IPO proceeds and an acquisition loan.

site_title: Gene-therapy firm UniQure explores options including sale
summary: Gene-therapy firm UniQure is exploring options including a potential sale amid interest from pharmaceutical companies looking to expand in the gene therapy market. The company, which has seen its shares rise over 151% this year, is working with advisers to weigh options including a sale or partnerships. Major pharmaceutical firms, such as Novo Nordisk and Pfizer, are pursuing gene-therapy companies promising treatments for rare diseases, with UniQure's pipeline of experimental treatments for hemophilia and Huntington's disease attracting interest.

site_title: Malaysia share prices close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's share prices closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.23 points to 1,638.40. The market saw 1.6 billion lots traded worth RM1.4 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 537 to 255.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust completes preferential offering, updates slightly subscriptions
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust completed its preferential offering, receiving 56.73 million valid acceptances and excess applications for new units. This represents 196.8% of the available units, a slight decrease from the previously reported 196.9%. The balance of 3,450,179 units will be allotted to excess applications.

site_title: Europe: Markets ahead at open
summary: European stocks rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,355.29 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices gaining 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. The increases came ahead of interest rate decisions from the US Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, and Bank of England, as traders awaited news on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Alibaba plans stock split as it preps giant listing
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. plans a one-to-eight share split, increasing ordinary shares from 4 billion to 32 billion, in preparation for a potential stock sale in Hong Kong. The sale, which could raise up to $20 billion, would replenish the company's war-chest and attract investors amid escalating tensions between China and the US. The company will seek to preserve its governance system, potentially avoiding a waiver required for some Chinese issuers. A proposal will be discussed at its annual general meeting on July 15, with the split expected to take place by July 2020.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,221.36, down 0.04% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.04% to 3,221.36, with 151 losers outnumbering 147 gainers. NetLink NBN Trust and Mercurius were among the top gainers, while UOB shares rose 1.12% to surpass DBS' share price. In other markets, the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index rose 0.88% after the suspension of a controversial extradition law.

site_title: Weekending in the suburbs
summary: A New York couple, Jon Stein and his wife Polina, have been searching for a weekend home in the suburbs, seeking a more relaxed and scenic alternative to their city apartment. They initially explored destinations like Hillsdale and Long Island, but fell in love with Cold Spring, NY, after a two-year rental experience. Now, they're considering towns like Bedford and North Salem, aiming to balance their love of nature with shorter commute times. The family of four, including two young daughters, is looking for a more laid-back lifestyle without sacrificing their connection to the city.

site_title: ST Engineering to trial drones for aircraft inspection with Air NZ; in tie-up to be repair centre for Honeywell parts
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm has partnered with Air New Zealand to trial drones for aircraft inspection, with the goal of reducing inspection time from 6 hours to 1-2 hours. The drone system, DroScan, will produce high-definition images of aircraft surfaces and detect defects. ST Engineering will also serve as a licensed repair centre for Honeywell parts, becoming a Honeywell Channel Partner. This collaboration aims to improve inspection quality, reduce repair time, and optimize maintenance activities through data analytics.

site_title: MAS issues prohibition orders against ex-UBS banker over forged documents
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued three-year prohibition orders against Paris Michele, a former UBS banker in Singapore, for forging documents and falsifying emails. Michele, who conducted due diligence on UBS customers, forged letters from foreign law firms to deceive UBS into believing clients were tax compliant. He was previously convicted of forgery charges and fined $13,200. Michele is now prohibited from performing regulated activities and providing financial advisory services. MAS deemed Michele's deceitful behavior could have compromised UBS's processes to combat money laundering and terrorism financing.

site_title: Singapore developers sell 952 private homes in May, up 29.5% from April's 735 units: URA
summary: Singapore developers sold 952 private homes in May 2019, a 29.5% increase from April and 15.2% lower than the same period last year. 1,394 new private homes were launched in May, up from 444 units in April and 1,060 units in May last year. The top-selling project was Amber Park, with 155 units sold at a median price of S$2,475 psf.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei edges up with eyes on trade, central banks
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.03% to 21,124.00 on Monday, driven by gains in bluechip shares such as Sony and SoftBank. The broader Topix index fell 0.45%. Investors are watching the US-China trade war and key central bank meetings this week, offsetting declines in chip-related shares.

site_title: SMRT, SBS Transit to build rail competence together, sign MOU with ST Engineering
summary: Singapore's two rail operators, SMRT and SBS Transit, have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with ST Engineering to build rail competence together. The collaboration aims to minimize duplication of resources and address technology gaps in the local rail industry. The three partners will work on repairing electronic cards on older trains, which control various functions and can lead to breakdowns. This move is part of Singapore's strategy to grow its rail industry and provide a reliable public transport service.

site_title: Discounts at NTUC FairPrice for Merdeka and Pioneer Generation seniors from July 1
summary: Discounts for Merdeka Generation seniors (3% off every Wednesday) and Pioneer Generation seniors (3% off every Wednesday and Monday) will be available at over 140 NTUC FairPrice stores starting July 1. The discounts apply to purchases up to S$200 and will be available at various FairPrice outlets. The initiative aims to show appreciation to senior citizens who contributed to Singapore's development, with estimated savings of S$9.8 million this year. Shoppers must present their Merdeka or Pioneer Generation card at checkout.

site_title: Indonesian companies tap P2P funds in fintech boom
summary: Indonesian companies are tapping into peer-to-peer (P2P) funds as part of the fintech boom in the Asia-Pacific region. According to Mastercard and Moody's Investors Service, alternative finance has shifted from digital payments to wealth management, insurance, and P2P financing since 2017. This growth points to "untapped market opportunities" in financial markets, indicating more growth and change ahead.

site_title: Singapore's 3 big banks can defend market share against fintech threats: Moody's
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, can defend their market share against fintech threats due to their abundant financial resources for technology investments. Fintech companies face increasing competition for funding and are restricted from expanding into deposit-taking and lending, limiting their ability to disrupt the financial services sector. Instead, they collaborate with banks to develop products, enabling banks to streamline processes and expand their payment services in South-east Asia. Moody's notes that the banks' continued investments in digital transformation will help them defend competitiveness.

site_title: AEI Corp enters into framework agreement with China's Zhongneng Intl Gas for LNG business activities
summary: AEI Corp, an aluminum producer, has entered into a framework agreement with China's Zhongneng Intl Gas to collaborate on liquefied natural gas (LNG) business activities. The agreement, pending definitive agreements, involves AEI acting as Zhongneng's agent to purchase 6 million tonnes of LNG annually and establishing a joint venture to supply LNG for power generation. AEI will also participate in the investment and construction of port facilities and LNG projects along the Yangtze River. The deal aims to boost AEI's market value, which has been below the Singapore Exchange's requirement.

site_title: Layovers with built-In luxury
summary: The TWA Hotel at Kennedy International Airport in New York has opened, offering a unique blend of nostalgia and luxury. The hotel is built within the historic TWA Terminal, which was once the hub of Trans World Airlines. The hotel's design incorporates mid-20th-century style, complete with vintage decor and amenities. The hotel's success may be part of a larger trend, as 38 of the world's 50 busiest airports now have terminal-located hotels. These hotels can generate higher revenue per room than traditional hotels, and offer airports a new source of revenue.

site_title: UOB Asset Management launches innovation-focused equity fund for retail investors
summary: UOB Asset Management has launched the United Global Innovation Fund (UGIF), a new equity fund for retail investors. The fund invests in innovative firms across various sectors, including healthcare, finance, and technology, with the goal of driving structural change. UGIF aims to provide positive returns even in a slowing global economy and volatile market conditions. With a minimum subscription of S$1,000 or US$1,000, the fund is suitable for investors seeking long-term capital appreciation and comfortable with the associated risks. Wellington Management Singapore is the sub-manager of the fund.

site_title: Paris rediscovers appetite for its world-beating 'bouillons'
summary: In Paris, a resurgence of interest in traditional "bouillons" - cheap, hearty French comfort food - is underway, with many restaurants offering classic dishes at affordable prices. Bouillon Julien and Chartier, two historic eateries, are leading the trend, serving dishes like egg mayonnaise and rabbit terrine for under 6 euros. The revival is seen as a return to comfort food, with diners embracing the warm, nostalgic experience of eating traditional French cuisine. Experts attribute the trend to a desire for simplicity and value, with many restaurants cutting costs by using high-quality ingredients and traditional cooking methods.

site_title: Singapore residents can now use Nets cards for payments at Paradigm Mall Johor Bahru
summary: Singapore residents can now use their Nets ATM cards for payments at Paradigm Mall Johor Bahru in Malaysia, eliminating the need for foreign currency and reducing transaction risks. The collaboration between Nets and GHL Systems Berhad allows for cashless payments at over 100 stores, with competitive exchange rates and no currency conversion fees. This move is expected to encourage e-payment adoption and further boost Malaysia's economy, with an estimated 11 million Singapore residents visiting Malaysia annually.

images.alt_text: Singapore residents travelling to shop at Paradigm Mall Johor Bahru (PMJB) in Malaysia can now go cashless, and pay for their purchases using their Nets (Network For Electronic Transfers Singapore) ATM cards issued by the three Singapore banks.

site_title: Greek unemployment the big bogey in July 7 vote
summary: In Greece, ahead of July 7 early elections, unemployment and recovery from a near-decade crisis will be key battlegrounds between the outgoing leftist government and resurgent conservatives. However, in the working-class neighborhood of Perama, unemployment rates remain high, with 80% of shipyard workers and 60% of construction workers jobless. Residents face poverty, lack of health insurance, and unpaid bills, with many struggling to make ends meet, as the town's economic situation remains critical.

site_title: Singapore Mediation Centre names new executive director
summary: The Singapore Mediation Centre has appointed Ban Jiun Ean as its new executive director, effective July 1. He replaces Loong Seng Onn, who is leaving to pursue personal interests. Ban, a former policymaker at the Ministry of Law, aims to establish mediation as the primary dispute resolution mechanism in Singapore and strengthen the SMC's position as a leading alternative dispute resolution centre in Asia.

site_title: Rapid e-commerce growth to drive Singapore's logistics services sector: Colliers report
summary: Singapore's logistics services sector is expected to grow due to rapid e-commerce demand, with the market projected to expand 48% to US$7.4 billion by 2022. The country ranks 7th globally and 2nd in Asia in the World Bank's 2018 Logistics Performance Index. Warehouse space demand remains firm, with a 10.8% vacancy rate in Q1 2019. Colliers expects logistics rents to remain soft for the rest of 2019, driven by limited buying opportunities and technology innovations such as AI, cloud solutions, and blockchain.

site_title: Chinese power service provider eyeing Hyflux assets
summary: Distressed water treatment firm Hyflux has received a fourth non-binding letter of intent from a Chinese power service provider for a potential $400 million investment. The investment comes ahead of a June 17 deadline to sign a binding agreement with UAE utility Utico. Hyflux is in talks with at least seven investors, including Oyster Bay Fund and a large desalination company, and aims to enter into a binding term sheet by mid-June.

site_title: Swedish builder Skanska says days of massive writedowns are over
summary: Swedish construction giant Skanska says it has turned a corner after a tough 2018, with operating income expected to continue improving. The company, which last year suffered significant writedowns and restructuring charges, is now working to restore profitability by being more selective in project bids and improving risk controls. CEO Anders Danielsson expects no major surprises, and investors are cautiously optimistic about the company's turnaround, with the stock gaining 19% so far this year. Skanska has identified a "sweet spot" for profitable projects and is focusing on delivering stable profitability.

images.alt_text: Last year was a tough one for the Swedish construction giant, with operating income hit by project writedowns, goodwill impairments and restructuring charges totaling 3.1 billion kronor (S$448.4 million).

site_title: China says to roll out rare earths policies as soon as possible
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission announced plans to study and implement policies on rare earths as soon as possible. Spokeswoman Meng Wei stated the government opposes using products made with China's exported rare earths to suppress the country's development. No details on the policies were provided. This move comes amid growing concerns over China's control of rare earths, a key component in many high-tech products.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as miners retreat; New Zealand inches lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 13.80 points to 6,540.20, as mining stocks retreated after a 6% rally last week. Energy firms were pressured by uncertainty over oil demand. Early trading was subdued ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting starting Tuesday.

site_title: Police officer stabbed ahead of G-20 summit in Japan
summary: A 33-year-old man was arrested in Japan for stabbing a police officer in the chest and stealing his gun ahead of the G-20 summit. The officer, 22, remains in a coma. The suspect, who denies the charges, had an ID document showing he was mentally disabled. The incident has raised concerns about security measures for the summit, which will feature US President Donald Trump, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Over 25,000 police officers will be deployed for the summit, and authorities are assessing the impact on security plans.

site_title: Japan Display, in need of funds, says Taiwan's TPK decided not to invest
summary: Japan Display Inc. said it received a notice from TPK Holding that the Taiwanese screen maker will not invest the proposed US$230 million, affecting the company's cash injection plans. The decision comes as Japan Display seeks to recover from slowing iPhone sales and a shift to OLED screens. The company had planned to raise 80 billion yen from a consortium involving TPK, but also faces uncertainty from other consortium members. Japan Display's share price dropped 11% in Tokyo morning trade.

site_title: Oil rises on tensions after Middle East tanker attacks
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that the US will take all necessary actions to ensure safe navigation in the Middle East amid ongoing tensions following tanker attacks. This led to a 0.4% rise in oil prices, with Brent futures increasing to $62.28 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising to $52.69 a barrel. The move aims to address concerns and stabilize the market.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong rallies after extradition law U-turn as markets bounce
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied on Monday after the city suspended plans to push through a controversial extradition law, which sparked violent protests. The Hang Seng index rose, reversing three days of losses. Investors also await the Federal Reserve policy meeting and the G-20 summit, where US-China trade talks are set to take place.

site_title: Mobileye expects to see self-driving cabs hit the road in 2020
summary: Intel's Mobileye unit plans to launch a trial of self-driving cabs in Israel next year. CEO Bob Swan rode a Mobileye autonomous car through Jerusalem, praising the technology's progress over the past two years. This trial marks a significant step towards commercializing autonomous vehicles, with Mobileye expected to begin testing robo-cabs on public roads in 2020.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mercurius Capital, FSL Trust, First Sponsor, Memtech, Low Keng Huat
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include Mercurius Capital, which proposes raising S$6 million by issuing 150 million new shares. FSL Trust is making a mandatory cash offer for its units, while First Sponsor Group has entered a joint venture agreement for a Guangdong, China development project. Memtech International's independent financial adviser recommends accepting a cash offer of S$1.35 per share for delisting. Low Keng Huat posted a net profit of S$450,000 for the first quarter, down 91% from last year.

site_title: US biotechs line up to list in Korea amid jump in share prices
summary: US biotech firms are increasingly listing in South Korea due to the country's welcoming environment and strong valuations. At least four companies, including Avellino Labs, are seeking listings, marking a significant increase given the current 20 overseas firms listed in South Korea. The companies are attracted by investors' positive views of biotechnology stocks, and some are even considering a "homecoming" to tap into the local market. This trend is expected to continue as more US biotechs take advantage of South Korea's favorable conditions.

site_title: Google appoints new chief to oversee tumultuous China region
summary: Google appoints Stanley Chen as managing director of Greater China sales, based in Shanghai, in an effort to reset its relationship with Beijing amid rising tensions with Washington. Chen, who previously led Google's Taiwan business for eight years, will oversee a significant portion of Google's annual revenue from the Asia Pacific region, despite the company pulling its search engine from China around 2010 due to censorship concerns. Advertising from Chinese companies remains a vital business for Google.

images.alt_text: Stanley Chen will become managing director of Greater China sales, the company said Monday, taking up a post Scott Beaumont vacated after he was appointed Google's Asia-Pacific president in March.

site_title: Israel PM's wife convicted of misusing public funds
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's wife, Sara, was convicted of misusing public funds for meals, with a court ruling that she must pay a fine of 10,000 shekels ($3,836) and reimburse the state 45,000 shekels. The conviction was part of a plea bargain that dropped more severe charges, including graft. Netanyahu himself faces possible indictment for bribery, fraud, and breach of trust in the coming months.

site_title: Lufthansa lowers 2019 targets over 'low-cost' competition
summary: Lufthansa has revised its 2019 targets downward due to intense competition from low-cost carriers in Europe. The airline group now expects an operating margin of 5.5-6.5% and an operating profit of €2-2.4 billion. Long-haul business remains strong, but yields in European short-haul business are under pressure. Lufthansa accuses low-cost competitors of accepting significant losses to expand their market share. The revision comes after the airline reported a loss in the first quarter, despite still sticking to its annual targets.

site_title: China central bank injects funds, second phase of RRR cut takes effect
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has injected 150 billion yuan into the market through 14-day reverse repos to maintain stable liquidity levels by end-June. The move follows the second phase of a reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut, which freed 100 billion yuan worth of long-term funds. The RRR cut is part of efforts to support companies during China's economic slowdown. The third phase of the RRR cut is scheduled to take effect on July 15.

site_title: Boeing crisis, trade tensions cast pall over air show
summary: The Paris Airshow is underway amidst a backdrop of global economic uncertainty, with the commercial aircraft industry expected to slow down due to trade tensions and flagging economies. Boeing, facing a crisis over the grounded 737 MAX, aims to reassure customers and suppliers about the plane's future, while rival Airbus is distracted by its own corruption probe. Industry executives express concerns about public confidence in air travel and the risk of a backlash that could drive a wedge between regulators and the plane certification system.

site_title: ESR-Reit buying warehouse for S$225m; plans S$45.7m AEIs at two sites; proposes S$150m equity fundraising
summary: ESR-REIT, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (Reit), is acquiring a warehouse in Jurong for S$225 million through a joint venture with logistics firm Poh Tiong Choon Logistics. The Reit plans to conduct asset enhancement initiatives (AEIs) on two existing assets, valued at S$45.7 million, and is raising up to S$150 million in an equity fundraising to finance these transactions and repay existing debt. The acquisition and AEI plans are expected to increase the Reit's rental income and portfolio occupancy.

site_title: Hong Kong protest leader Joshua Wong released from prison: AFP
summary: Hong Kong protest leader Joshua Wong was released from prison on June 17, 2019, after serving time for his role in the 2014 "Umbrella Movement" democracy protests. Wong, 26, was mobbed by media and supporters upon his release. This marks the end of his 16-month prison sentence.

images.alt_text: Joshua Wong, the student leader who became the face of Hong Kong's "Umbrella Movement" democracy protests in 2014, was released from prison on Monday, an AFP reporter at the scene said.

site_title: Boeing's embattled chief faces tough crowd at Paris Air Show
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg is set to face a tough crowd at the Paris Air Show, where he aims to reassure airlines and industry partners about the safety of the grounded 737 MAX plane. The plane's automated anti-stall system has been linked to two fatal crashes, resulting in 346 deaths. Aviation regulators have yet to determine when the plane will be allowed to fly again, with some countries planning to conduct their own inspections. Boeing has estimated the crisis will cost it $1 billion, and airlines are calling for compensation.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.55% to 3,204.76
summary: Singapore stocks opened weaker on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.55% to 3,204.76. Losers outnumbered gainers 75 to 50, with 47.58 million securities changing hands. Banking stocks fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC losing 0.77%, 0.76%, and 0.19% respectively. Mercurius gained 9.52% after announcing plans to acquire a Thai private property developer. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.30 points to 1,638.93. Volume reached 22.26 million lots worth RM6.86 million, with 76 gainers surpassing 58 losers. The market's momentum follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which is set to be impacted by upcoming GDP data.

site_title: New Quebec law stresses migrants' skills, thousands must reapply
summary: The Quebec provincial legislature approved a new immigration law that prioritizes skilled workers over family ties. The law, similar to a proposed US plan by President Trump, will replace the current first-come, first-served system. Approximately 18,000 existing applications will be shredded, affecting around 50,000 people, and applicants will need to reapply. The new system aims to match skills with labor market needs, with expedited processing expected within six months. The law was passed with a 62-42 vote, despite opposition from all three opposition parties, and is seen as a significant shift in Quebec's immigration policy.

site_title: China 2018 thermal power investment lowest since 2004: association
summary: China's investment in thermal power construction decreased to 78.6 billion yuan (S$15.55 billion) in 2018, the lowest level since 2004, according to the China Electricity Council. Coal-fired capacity investment fell 8.8%, while solar power investment plummeted 27.4% due to policies aimed at curbing overcapacity. Total power investment declined 3.9% to 278.7 billion yuan, with hydropower construction rising 12.7% and nuclear investment inching down 1.6%. China aims to reduce its dependence on polluting fossil fuels and lower its coal share in the energy mix to 50-53% by 2025.

site_title: Indonesian seaweed farmers seek US$140m over oil spill in Australia
summary: Indonesian seaweed farmers are seeking over $137 million in damages from Thailand's PTT Exploration and Production for an oil spill in the Timor Sea in 2009. The spill, caused by an explosion at the Montara oil rig, allegedly destroyed the seaweed industry in Rote Ndao and Kupang, affecting over 15,000 farmers. The 10-week trial in Sydney will feature more than 30 witnesses, including farmers and experts. This case is one of several environmental damage claims filed by Indonesia against PTT and PTTEP, with a separate $1.9 billion lawsuit filed in 2017.

site_title: Sharapova has 'expectations' for return from five-month absence
summary: Maria Sharapova, a five-time Grand Slam champion, is set to return from a five-month injury absence at the Mallorca event next week. The 32-year-old Russian tennis star has struggled to regain top form since her 2017 doping ban, and her recent injury has left her frustrated but optimistic. Sharapova faces Slovakia's Viktoria Kuzmova in the first round and could play Angelique Kerber in the next round, after a lay-off that saw her drop from 29th to 86th in the rankings.

site_title: Bitcoin climbs above US$9,000 as Facebook reports buoy sentiment
summary: Bitcoin surged past US$9,000 as Facebook's planned digital currency release fueled optimism about mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies. The largest digital currency rose 7.4% and rival coins like litecoin and ethereum also gained. Bitcoin has increased by over 130% in 2019, with the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index doubling in value amid growing cryptocurrency services. Facebook's digital currency plans are believed to be driving investor interest towards bitcoin, pushing its value higher.

site_title: Businesses clamour for Trump's ear as US$300b in new China tariffs loom
summary: US businesses are urging President Donald Trump to reconsider a new $300 billion round of tariffs on Chinese imports, warning that it could lead to widespread job losses and economic downturn. Major companies, including Target and Walmart, have submitted written comments and testified at public hearings, citing the potential impact on consumer prices and the US economy. Economists predict a dire global growth outcome if the tariffs are implemented, with some warning that they could cut US GDP growth by a full percentage point and cost two million jobs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, tracking US market falls, amid concerns over the US-China trade war and central bank meetings. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.06% to 21,104.25, while the Topix index fell 0.24% to 1,542.96. The US Trade Representative's public hearings on potential tariffs on Chinese goods began, with investors monitoring the situation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at open on Monday, June 17, 2019, after the city's government suspended plans to push through a controversial extradition law that had sparked violent protests last week. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.49%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes declined 0.05%. The decision was seen as a positive step for the market.

site_title: From apples to almonds, India raises tariffs on US goods
summary: India has imposed higher tariffs on 28 US goods, including almonds, apples, and walnuts, in retaliation against the US withdrawal of trade privileges for New Delhi. The tariffs, which include a 120% hike on walnut imports, were announced after US President Donald Trump stripped India of its preferential trade status. The move is expected to escalate trade tensions between the two countries, with a meeting between Trump and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi scheduled for the G-20 summit on June 28-29.

site_title: Hunting for ranches like penthouses means perks, or forget it
summary: Luxury ranches, a symbol of American rural life, are experiencing a soft patch in the market. With only six out of 38 properties listed for over $10 million having been marked down in the past 90 days, buyers are having to wait for the perfect combination of features, including mountain views and proximity to towns and wildlife. The limited supply of properties with these desirable features is driving up prices, making it difficult for buyers to find the ideal luxury ranch.

site_title: Long-awaited London-Shanghai share listing project goes live
summary: The London-Shanghai Stock Connect project, launched on June 17, 2019, allows companies listed in Britain to sell shares in China and vice versa. This project, initiated by Finance Minister Philip Hammond, aims to deepen global connectivity. The first company to trade via the project is Huatai Securities, a Chinese brokerage backed by Alibaba Group, which made its London market debut on June 17. The move is seen as a vote of confidence in the UK market and provides London investors with the opportunity to trade Global Depositary Receipts in Huatai.

site_title: First Sponsor in joint venture to develop land in China's Guangdong province
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Hong Leong-linked property developer, has entered a joint venture agreement with Poly Bay Area and Shoucheng Dongguan Real Estate to develop three plots of land in Guangdong, China, valued at approximately $592 million. The joint venture, Dongguan Baozhu Industrial Investment Co, aims to leverage the expertise of Poly Developments and Holdings to develop the Wanjiang Victory Land. This investment aligns with First Sponsor Group's strategy to expand its presence in Dongguan and the Greater Bay Area.

site_title: Mercurius to buy 50% stake in Thai property developer, jointly develop Phuket resort
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment is acquiring a 50% stake in Thai property developer Grand Bay Hotel for over SGD 14.69 million. The deal also involves jointly developing the Sheraton Phuket Grand Bay Resort in Phuket, Thailand. Mercurius will pay SGD 335 million, including half of the construction costs, and conduct private placement exercises to fund the acquisition. The joint venture will be operated by Starwood Asia Pacific Hotels & Resorts upon completion.

site_title: Huawei prepares for 40% to 60% fall in international smartphone shipments: Bloomberg
summary: Huawei is preparing for a 40-60% drop in international smartphone shipments, citing poor sales of its latest model, the Honor 20. Executives are monitoring the launch and may cut off shipments if sales are poor. The company aims to offset the decline by grabbing up to half of China's smartphone market in 2019. The US government's trade blacklist, imposed due to national security concerns, has impacted Huawei's sales, with President Donald Trump suggesting US complaints could be resolved in a trade deal.

site_title: Australia's Vocus tumbles after AGL backs out of offer for second time
summary: Australia's Vocus Group shares plummeted 32% after AGL Energy Ltd withdrew its second proposal to buy the telecoms firm, citing a lack of certainty on creating value for shareholders. This is the fourth time a potential suitor has backed out of an offer for Vocus over the past two years. Analysts questioned the benefits of the potential takeover, given Vocus' turnaround efforts. Vocus CEO Kevin Russell expressed confidence in the company's strategy and ability to deliver value to shareholders in the medium to long term.

images.alt_text: Australia's AGL Energy Ltd withdrew a proposal to buy Vocus Group on Monday, just days after it offered A$3.02 billion (S$2.85 billion) for the telecoms firm, knocking Vocus shares down by a third.

site_title: Mexico detains 791 migrants, including 368 children under eight
summary: Mexico's National Migration Institute has detained 791 Central American migrants, including 368 children under eight, in the state of Veracruz. The migrants were being transported in four trailers and include 413 Guatemalans, 330 Hondurans, and 39 Salvadorans. Six alleged human traffickers were also captured. The detentions come as part of a 45-day agreement with the US to curb migration and avoid tariffs threatened by President Donald Trump.

site_title: Latest 'Men in Black' leads box office but fails to wow critics
summary: "Men in Black: International" leads the North American box office with an estimated $28.5 million, but received a lukewarm rating of 24% on Rotten Tomatoes. The film's overseas earnings of $73 million suggest it is doing better internationally. The film's box office performance fell short of studio expectations, and it takes the second spot behind "The Secret Life of Pets 2." The top 5 films are "Men in Black: International," "The Secret Life of Pets 2," "Aladdin," "X-Men: Dark Phoenix," and "Rocketman."

site_title: Deploying blockchain in durian trade is bearing fruit
summary: A partnership between Havenport Investments and DiMuto has successfully deployed blockchain technology in the durian trade, providing alternative trade financing options for companies in the supply chain. The technology offers end-to-end visibility of goods and money flow, mitigating risks of goods and invoice tampering. Havenport can now effectively manage and price risks, opening up new financing opportunities for small and medium-sized companies and private investors. This collaboration aims to address the global trade finance gap of US$1.5 trillion, particularly for SMEs, and create new investment opportunities for private capital.

site_title: Defiance and hope in Hong Kong as police cede streets
summary: In Hong Kong, protesters continued to occupy streets after a massive march on Sunday, with an estimated two million people demonstrating against a Beijing-backed extradition law. Despite police absence, protesters remained vigilant, singing, chanting, and playing music. The event marked the latest chapter in Hong Kong's battle for democracy, with many fearing China's increasing assertiveness is eroding the city's freedoms and culture. The protests follow the death of a protester who fell from a building during an anti-extradition protest on Saturday.

site_title: Singapore NODX extends decline in May; posts worst showing in more than 3 years
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined by 15.9% in May, the worst performance in over 3 years, due to global trade tensions and a fading electronics cycle. Electronic NODX fell 31.4% and non-electronic NODX decreased 10.8%, with declines in shipments to China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. Economists expect the decline to persist as the global tech downcycle continues and the US-China trade conflict escalates.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) slumped by double digits for the third straight month in May, as uncertainty from global trade tensions and the fading of the electronics cycle continue to bite.

site_title: British PM rivals clash over Brexit strategy
summary: British Prime Minister candidates clashed over Brexit strategy during their first debate, with frontrunner Boris Johnson avoiding confrontation. Four candidates, including Jeremy Hunt and Dominic Raab, said they would renegotiate the Brexit divorce deal, while Rory Stewart advocated for sticking to the current agreement. Stewart criticized his opponents for "machismo" and warned a no-deal Brexit would be "deeply damaging". The debate also touched on the candidates' backgrounds and past controversies. Johnson remains in the lead with 114 votes, ahead of Hunt, Gove, Raab, and Stewart, who will face a second round of voting on Tuesday.

site_title: FSL Trust's sponsor appoints Stirling Coleman Capital as IFA for cash offer
summary: FSL Holdings, the sponsor of FSL Trust, has appointed Stirling Coleman Capital as its independent financial adviser (IFA) for a S$0.0585 per unit cash offer. The offer represents a 33% premium to the last market price and is made by the sponsor and its concert party, holding 55.04% of FSL Trust units. The IFA will advise the trustee-manager, FSL Trust Management, who are considered independent for the purposes of the offer. The offer does not plan to change FSL Trust's business, but reserves the right to assess delisting options if the free float falls below the minimum requirement.

site_title: Gloves come off as UK PM hopefuls gun for Boris Johnson
summary: UK Prime Minister hopefuls, including those vying to replace Theresa May, have targeted Boris Johnson, questioning his pledge to leave the European Union by the end of October. The candidates have used airwaves to present their cases, focusing on Johnson. The Conservative Party leadership contest has shifted attention away from Johnson's low profile.

site_title: New poll shows Biden with big lead over Trump
summary: A nationwide Fox News poll shows President Donald Trump trailing former vice-president Joe Biden and other Democratic contenders in the 2020 election. Biden leads Trump by 49% to 39% among all registered voters nationwide, with other contenders, including Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Kamala Harris, also holding edges over the president. The poll comes ahead of Trump's official re-election campaign launch on Tuesday.

site_title: US chipmakers quietly lobby to ease Huawei ban: sources
summary: US chipmakers, including Qualcomm and Intel, have been secretly lobbying the US government to ease the ban on sales to Huawei, the world's largest telecommunications equipment company, due to national security issues. Executives from Intel and Xilinx attended a meeting in May with the Commerce Department to discuss a response. The ban bars US suppliers from selling to Huawei without special approval, which Huawei itself is avoiding typical government lobbying.

site_title: Sterling could get short-term BOE relief before Brexit pain returns
summary: The pound may experience short-term relief from Brexit uncertainty if the Bank of England becomes more hawkish, according to analysts from Nomura International, MUFG, and Union Bancaire Privee. However, longer-term prospects remain grim, and the risk of a hard Brexit in late October is expected to return. The central bank's statement this week could boost the pound by 1%, but market pricing suggests a possibility of a rate cut next year, which could drive the currency back down. The UK's Conservative leadership contest continues, with front-runner Boris Johnson indicating a willingness to take the UK out of the EU.

site_title: Tan to be List SIR's research and consulting director
summary: List Sotheby's International Realty has appointed former Knight Frank senior executive Alice Tan as its director for research and consulting in South-east Asia, effective July 1. Tan will lead market research strategy for the region and develop business opportunities for the company. Her appointment aims to strengthen List SIR's regional research and consulting capabilities and expand expertise into the regional investment market. Tan previously worked at Knight Frank for six years, while another executive, Han Huan Mei, will continue to focus on local residential and commercial markets.

site_title: 'Sea of black' HK protesters demand leader step down
summary: Hundreds of thousands of protesters in Hong Kong's financial center demanded that leader Carrie Lam step down, calling for her to resign over her handling of a bill allowing extradition to China. The bill was indefinitely delayed by Lam on Saturday, sparking widespread protests and a significant political turnaround. The protests, marked by clashes with police, have plunged Hong Kong into crisis, with critics warning of a threat to the city's rule of law and international reputation.

site_title: IMF proposes improvements to EU plan to develop capital market
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has proposed improvements to the European Union's Capital Markets Union (CMU) plan, focusing on increasing transparency, regulatory oversight, and insolvency rules. The IMF recommends instituting centralized electronic reporting for all issuers, improving regulatory consistency, and harmonizing insolvency practices. This would encourage companies to raise funds through stocks and bonds rather than bank loans, aligning with the US model where companies tap financial markets more evenly. The plan aims to strengthen the EU's capital market system and address differences with the US.

site_title: Massive power outage hits Argentina, Uruguay
summary: A massive power outage hit Argentina and Uruguay, leaving around 48 million people without electricity. The outage, caused by a collapse of the Argentine Interconnection System, affected Paraguay as well. Power companies reported that 40% of power supply had been restored by 1:00 pm local time, with 50,000 customers having power back. The outage was the first to affect both countries simultaneously, and generators were unable to compensate for the loss. Power restoration was ongoing, with some areas experiencing partial restoration by mid-day, but many areas remained without power, including public hospitals and private clinics.

site_title: China ready for long economic battle with US - party journal
summary: China is prepared for a long economic battle with the US, according to a Chinese Communist Party journal, stating that Beijing will not give way on major principles in negotiations. The journal, Qiushi, emphasized China's determination to defend its interests in trade talks with the US. This comes as the US has announced new tariffs, surprising Vietnam and the Asian garment industry. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, adding pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Brazil development bank chief quits, fueling political crisis
summary: Brazil's head of the state development bank, Joaquim Levy, resigned on Sunday after far-right President Jair Bolsonaro threatened to sack him, fueling a political crisis. Levy, a Chicago-educated economist, had clashed with Bolsonaro over the appointment of an official linked to the left-wing Workers Party. The sudden departure follows a tumultuous week of minister firings and a general strike over pension reform, which Bolsonaro's government is struggling to pass. The crisis is seen as a test of the government's ability to deliver on its economic reform agenda.

site_title: Same source behind tanker, airport attacks, says Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid Al-Falih, attributed recent attacks on ships near the Strait of Hormuz to the same source responsible for a missile launch on an airport in Saudi Arabia. The attacks on ships occurred after US President Donald Trump blamed Iran for the vessel attacks. Iran has denied culpability. Al-Falih warned that Saudi Arabia will take measures to protect its oil infrastructure and urged a "rapid and decisive response" to the threats on energy supply and market stability.

site_title: E-opportunities in Indonesia's Industry 4.0
summary: Enterprise Singapore's regional group director (Indonesia) Khairul Anwar discusses Indonesia's Industry 4.0 (I4.0) developments, aiming to raise the manufacturing sector's GDP contribution from 20% to 25% by 2025. The Making Indonesia 4.0 Roadmap focuses on boosting industry competitiveness through AI, robotics, and sensor technology. To support companies, Indonesia has rolled out the Indonesia Industry 4.0 Readiness Index and relaxed investment regulations. Singapore can collaborate with Indonesia to prepare the labour force for I4.0 and exchange learnings on I4.0 solutions. Key advice for Singapore companies entering Indonesia's I4.0 market includes finding local talent, engaging with business partners, and having the right expertise to diagnose manufacturing bottlenecks.

site_title: Singapore Open boost for local pros with extra spot
summary: The Singapore Golf Association (SGA) has announced an additional local professional spot for the 2020 SMBC Singapore Open, boosting local golfers' chances of competing in the Olympics. The move aims to encourage local professionals to improve their Official World Golf Ranking and increase their chances of representing Singapore in the 2020 Olympics. The SGA has also introduced a qualification criterion to direct young professionals towards better development.

site_title: Fruity contest by CDL execs raises S$227,175 for Assisi Hospice
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) executives led a charity cycling competition at Assisi Hospice's annual Fun Day, raising S$227,175 for the hospice. The event, dubbed "The CDL Challenge," drew about 10,000 visitors and aimed to raise S$1 million. CDL's contributions, including S$184,000 from last year's challenge, demonstrate the company's commitment to supporting the hospice's operating expenses. The event featured various stalls, rides, and games, and marked Assisi's 50th anniversary.

site_title: FDI in Singapore up in 2018 despite slowdown in global flows
summary: Singapore saw a 2.6% increase in foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2018, reaching US$78 billion, and rose to the 4th spot globally, according to the World Investment Report 2019. The US topped the rankings with US$252 billion in FDI inflows, while China remained in second place with US$139 billion. Outflows from Singapore declined by 15% to US$37 billion, contributing to the stagnating level of investment from ASEAN. Global FDI inflows fell 13% to US$1.3 trillion, but are expected to rebound in 2019.

images.alt_text: Foreign direct investments (FDI) continued to flow into Singapore last year, even when global FDI fell for a third straight year to its lowest since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: Shape-up or ship-out: Neymar in question as PSG chief blasts club's 'celebrity behaviour'
summary: Paris Saint-Germain president Nasser Al-Khelaifi warned highly-paid players, including Neymar, that they must "shape-up or ship-out" due to "celebrity behaviour" that won't be tolerated. Al-Khelaifi emphasized the need for players to take responsibility and work harder, stating that "celebrity behaviour" is no longer acceptable. He gave players an ultimatum, threatening to open the door to depart if they don't comply, signaling a shift in the club's approach to managing its star-studded squad.

site_title: Italian mafia using the old lira as its own parallel currency
summary: Italian mafia is using the old lira as a parallel currency for illicit transactions. The pre-euro currency ceased to be legal tender in 2002, but it still appears in domestic criminal organisations. A senior police officer revealed that liras are still part of illicit transactions, with the equivalent value of 1.2 billion euros transferred to the state years ago. The use of lira raises concerns about the proposal for mini T-bills to pay state creditors, which some fear could lead to a parallel currency and even an exit from the euro.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to grow footprint in Europe with Malmaison, Capri brands
summary: Frasers Hospitality plans to expand its presence in Europe by leveraging its Malmaison and Capri by Fraser brands over the next three to five years. The company aims to increase the number of Malmaison hotels in the UK and Ireland to 50 properties, with a focus on growth in the UK. Meanwhile, the Capri brand will expand in the Middle East and Europe, with potential locations in Western European cities such as Madrid and Zurich. This growth is expected to bring synergies and operational efficiencies, despite uncertainties surrounding Brexit.

site_title: Allied Tech appoints PwC as special auditor which will report to SGX RegCo
summary: Allied Tech, a Singapore-based precision engineering company, has appointed PwC as its special auditor to investigate potential breaches of regulations and review corporate governance and internal controls. The investigation follows a notice from SGX RegCo, which prompted Allied Tech to appoint a special auditor to look into the placement of $33 million in funds with law firm JLC Advisors, which reportedly went missing. PwC will report solely to SGX RegCo on its findings and propose remediation actions.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat - Angel investing: How risky is it for an investor?
summary: A growing number of angel investing clubs in Singapore are fueling a wave of investments in startups and unicorns in South-east Asia. Experts from AngelCentral, BANSEA, and Investible discussed the risks of angel investing, with Huang Shao-Ning, Ramesh Raghavan, and Veronika Kuznetsova sharing their insights. They emphasized the importance of due diligence, risk assessment, and a thorough understanding of the startup's potential for growth and scalability. The panelists also highlighted the potential for angel investors to diversify their portfolios and mitigate risks by investing in a variety of startups.

site_title: 31 director acquisitions filed while STI recovers 2.4%
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) gained 2.4% over the five trading sessions from June 7 to 13, bringing its 2019 total return to 7.2%. There were 31 director acquisitions and one disposal filed, with substantial shareholders filing 14 acquisitions and 12 disposals. Notable acquisitions include UOL Group's chairman Wee Cho Yaw increasing his stake to 36.87%, Oxley Holdings' Ching Chiat Kwong acquiring 42% of the company, and GSH Corporation's Sam Goi Seng Hui increasing his stake to 59.76%.

site_title: Samsung's Lee looks beyond next 10 years with 6G, system chips
summary: Samsung Electronics' vice chairman Jay Y Lee discussed potential investment in 6G mobile networks and system semiconductors, citing a rapidly changing global business environment. Lee stated that the company should challenge itself to make new foundations, moving beyond past achievements. He also reviewed risk-response plans for Samsung's chip business and discussed industry challenges. This comes as Samsung and rivals compete to commercialize 5G services, with no mention of ongoing trade tensions or bans on Huawei. Lee's comments mark the first public discussion on 6G technology for the company.

site_title: China stays mum as Hong Kong protests extradition bill
summary: China has largely remained silent about Hong Kong's protests against an extradition bill, with state media avoiding any mention of the demonstrations that drew an estimated 2 million people to the streets. Despite the massive protests, China's official Xinhua news agency reported that the bill's suspension was due to "strong and different views in society." The government's decision was seen as a climbdown, with critics fearing the bill would damage Hong Kong's reputation as a safe business hub. China has blamed the protests on external forces, while the People's Daily echoed the government's line that it opposes external intervention in Hong Kong affairs.

images.alt_text: Chinese state media remained largely silent as an estimated two million Hong Kong people took to the streets Sunday to protest an extradition bill, with social platforms scrubbed clean of any pictures or mentions of the rally.

site_title: After conquering Broadway, Hamilton eyes global tour
summary: The hit musical Hamilton is expanding globally, with plans for its first non-English production and tours in Europe and Asia. A German-language version is in development, while a production is expected to tour Australia in 2021 before heading to Asia. The show's producer, Jeffrey Seller, hopes the story's themes of revolution and ambition will resonate with audiences worldwide. With Hamilton's success in the US and London, international investments are being tailored to markets, with potential performances in Paris and Hamburg.

site_title: Moving from optical discs to accommodation
summary: Singapore-listed Centurion Corporation, a worker and student accommodation owner-operator, has transformed from an optical disc manufacturer. The company, led by CEO Kong Chee Min, has grown its portfolio to 62,656 beds through its purpose-built accommodation business, with a target to reach 68,756 beds by 2020. Centurion aims to expand into other accommodation assets, including senior living, co-living, and variations of worker accommodations, driven by Asia's industrialisation wave and growing demand for quality accommodation. The company targets a 50:50 split in revenues between its worker and student accommodation segments.

site_title: America's super rich snap up London's luxury homes
summary: American billionaires are snapping up luxury homes in London, with the proportion of sales to Americans doubling this year compared to 2018. Overseas buyers, particularly Americans and Chinese, are benefiting from a weak pound and discounts. US buyers spent an average of £7.3 million on prime central London properties, while Russians spent £9.1 million and Saudis £13.4 million. The London economy's strength and Brexit uncertainty have driven demand, with tech sector professionals and entrepreneurs contributing to the uptick in US property investment.

site_title: Digital transformation: big gaps between goals and reality
summary: A survey of over 3,800 senior executives in 14 countries found that only 18% of Singaporean organisations believe they make digital transformation decisions extremely well, ranking lower than the global average of 23%. The research identified four key factors in digital decision-making: people, processes, technology understanding, and partnerships. Singaporean organisations often focus too much on technology, neglecting people and processes. A company-wide approach to digital transformation is more likely to result in success, and organisations struggle most in digital transformation implementation, particularly in accessing information and support.

site_title: Mercurius proposes to raise S$6m through share placement to 12 individuals
summary: Mercurius Capital Investment is proposing to raise S$6 million through a share placement to 12 individuals, including existing shareholders. The company plans to use S$5.8 million for business investments and acquisition, and the remaining S$0.8 million for general working capital. The shares will be issued at S$0.04 per share, with six existing shareholders and six new investors, including medical practitioners and businesspeople.

site_title: Burn not out
summary: Business leaders can prevent burnout at work by recognizing its existence, understanding how individuals handle stress differently, and implementing strategies such as delegating tasks, promoting open communication, and encouraging work-life balance. Experts suggest setting realistic goals, providing employee support, and recognizing signs of burnout. Companies can also adopt flexible work arrangements, prioritize employee wellbeing, and utilize technology to manage workload and stress. By leading by example and fostering a culture of care, leaders can create an environment that promotes mental and physical health, reducing the risk of burnout.

site_title: SPH in pilot to use blockchain to ease life insurance claims
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is piloting an industry-first initiative with NTUC Income and MetLife to automate life insurance claims for bereaved families using blockchain. The Lifechain platform securely encrypts and shares data used for obituary placement to search for matching life insurance policies. If a match is found, the process is initiated within one working day, with family members informed of the outcome. The pilot, targeting 1,000 policyholders, will end in October and is free during the phase. The companies aim to expand the platform to include more insurers, increasing convenience and security for family members.

site_title: Saudi crude exporter Aramco to IPO as soon as next year
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company Aramco plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) as soon as next year, with Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman projecting a valuation of around $2 trillion. The company's financial performance revealed in April suggests a valuation closer to $1.2 trillion. Aramco aims to list its stock on the domestic Saudi exchange and at least one international bourse, with no decision yet on where the stock will trade.

site_title: The secret to building timeless brands? Evolution, says new WFA chief
summary: New World Federation of Advertisers (WFA) president Raja Rajamannar says the secret to building timeless brands is evolution, as technology increases the impact of marketing. Rajamannar, Mastercard's chief marketing and communications officer, believes technology can help marketers collect useful data, understand consumer behavior, and appeal to consumers. He emphasized the importance of using new technologies and data insights to transform brands and businesses, and to make a positive impact on the world.

site_title: Stocks rise ahead of Fed updates, G-20 outcome
summary: US stocks rose slightly ahead of key updates from the Federal Reserve and the Group of 20, as traders await the Fed's policy statement and potential rate cuts. Despite concerns about a weakening economy and trade war, data suggests a soft patch rather than a severe recession. Economists expect the Fed to send a signal of intent to cut rates in July, potentially sparking a sell-off in markets if ambiguity arises. The start of the last rate-cutting cycle in 2007 was before a historic collapse, making it unusual for the Fed to hint at changes without following through.

images.alt_text: US stocks have risen slightly last week as traders tread water ahead of key updates from the Federal Reserve and the Group of 20.

site_title: China's food is only going to get pricier
summary: China is facing a severe food shortage due to African swine fever, which has decimated its pig population, and the invasion of fall armyworm, threatening corn, wheat, and rice yields. This has raised prices, with pork prices gaining 18.2% and inflation expected to rise. China's economy is under pressure, and officials are under scrutiny for downplaying the crisis. To address the issue, Beijing needs to rapidly increase imports, potentially shifting the protein balance towards chicken and beef, and recognize the severity of the crisis.

site_title: Dollar gains on solid retail sales, ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: The US dollar index rose to its highest level in almost two weeks following the release of retail sales data for May, which showed a 0.5% gain, just below economists' expectations. The data eased fears that the US economy is slowing sharply ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. The dollar index is now at 97.35, up 0.53% on the day. Despite expectations of no interest rate cut in June, traders are watching for signals that a cut may come in July, with a 23% chance of a cut in June and 87% likelihood of at least one cut in July.

site_title: Mapletree eyes S$10b of deals a year as more funds planned
summary: Mapletree Investments aims to secure up to S$10 billion in deals annually over the next five years, focusing on logistics, student accommodations, office space, and data centers. The company plans to recycle capital by selling assets and will fund new investments through divestments of equivalent size. Mapletree is also exploring listing two real estate investment trusts (Reits) in the next four to five years, with a "sweet spot" of S$2 billion. The firm's CEO, Hiew Yoon Khong, expects prices to fall 10-15% in the next six to 12 months if the trade war worsens, making it a prime time to buy properties.

site_title: Hong Kong media say controversial extradition bill may be suspended
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to suspend a proposed extradition bill that sparked widespread protests, with leader Carrie Lam set to address reporters later in the day. The bill, which would have allowed Hong Kong residents to be extradited to mainland China, has faced intense opposition, with millions taking to the streets and police using tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse protesters. The suspension is seen as a concession to public pressure, but critics argue it does not address concerns about the rule of law and human rights in Hong Kong.

site_title: Circles.Life has a game plan for growth
summary: Circles.Life, a three-year-old mobile virtual network operator, has secured a funding round to fuel its expansion into new markets and products. Co-founder Abhishek Gupta plans to direct funds into acquiring talent to support growth, with the company already partnering with investors in Australia and Indonesia. Circles.Life aims to break into two more markets next year and introduce 5G networks in Singapore from next year, despite technical standards and wholesale rules still being decided by regulators. The company's growth plans are driven by a focus on digital, data-savvy consumers, and its offerings will remain similar across markets, with specificity required for each market's needs.

site_title: PBOC governor's boast of having 'tremendous room' to act to be tested soon
summary: China's PBOC governor Yi Gang faces a test of his policy flexibility as industrial output growth in May slowed to the weakest pace since 2002, highlighting headwinds from the trade war with the US. The central bank may dip into its war chest to boost the economy, with options including cutting the benchmark lending rate, lowering banks' short-term borrowing costs, or reducing reserve requirements. However, policymakers must carefully calibrate their actions to avoid a yuan depreciation overshoot or a debt-fuelled property market bubble. China's fiscal war chest of $3.65 trillion provides some cushioning, but the government and central bank must balance stimulus measures to support growth while maintaining currency stability.

site_title: Biden, Sanders to face off as 1st Democratic debate line-up set
summary: The Democratic Party announced its line-ups for the first presidential debate of the 2020 cycle, with 20 candidates set to participate in two nights of debates in Miami. Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders, the front runners, will face off on the second night, while Elizabeth Warren and Pete Buttigieg will lead the first night. Other notable candidates include Kamala Harris, Beto O'Rourke, and Andrew Yang, who will gain unprecedented public exposure through the debates.

site_title: War risk insurance spirals higher for Middle East tankers
summary: Middle East tankers face escalating war risk insurance costs after six vessels were targeted in 32 days, sparking a threat to merchant shipping not seen in decades. War risk premiums for supertankers have surged to at least $185,000, and charter bookings in the Persian Gulf have paused as owners re-evaluate risks. The US blames Iran for the attacks, while the country denies involvement. The Strait of Hormuz, a vital oil export route, is now considered unsafe, and shipping companies are diverting vessels or reducing supply. Industry groups warn of a potential shortage of oil supplies, with potential consequences for the Western world.

site_title: Coming soon to a digital screen near you
summary: A roundtable discussion on the evolution of television in the Asian media industry was held, exploring key trends impacting the industry. Moderated by Francis Kan, participants shared insights on emerging technologies and their potential impact on television. Topics included the rise of digital media players, changes in consumer viewing habits, and the integration of new technologies into traditional television. The discussion aimed to provide a platform for industry experts to share their perspectives on the future of television in Asia.

site_title: Court grants American Airlines' request to end "devastating" slowdown by unions
summary: A US federal court granted American Airlines' request to halt an alleged slowdown by its mechanics' unions, which the airline said had become "devastating" to its operations. The court ordered the two unions to stop interfering in American's operations, including refusing to work overtime or slowing job performance. The slowdown resulted in 722 flight cancellations and affected 11,000 passengers per day since June 7. The unions had allegedly directed the slowdown to strengthen their position in labor talks, with American trying to outsource maintenance jobs to cover increased wages.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
