The rapid rollout of new policies, such as making all new cars electric by 2035, will be required to achieve the target. The move is seen as a significant step towards limiting global temperature increases to 1.5 degrees Celsius, the "safe" upper limit identified by the UN's International Panel on Climate Change.

site_title: Media sector seeks new powers to challenge Big Tech
summary: Big Tech firms dominate online advertising, struggling traditional news organizations, prompting lawmakers to consider new powers to challenge them. During a House Judiciary Committee hearing, media representatives urged lawmakers to grant them authority to team up against online platforms. The goal is to level the playing field and ensure news organizations can compete in the digital age.

site_title: Cambodian farmers battle in landmark lawsuit against Thai sugar firm
summary: Cambodian farmers, including 3,000 people, have filed a landmark class-action lawsuit against Thai sugar company Mitr Phol in a Thai court, alleging violent forced eviction and destruction of their homes to make way for plantations. The lawsuit, led by a survivor of the Khmer Rouge regime, claims Mitr Phol's actions constitute human rights abuses. This is the first time a company from another country has been sued in a Thai court by plaintiffs from another country. The lawsuit seeks damages and compensation for the affected families.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise buoyed by mining stocks; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 6,562.0, driven by gains in mining stocks due to China's stimulus plans and supply concerns in commodities. The S&P/ASX 200 index has gained for a sixth straight day. China allowed local governments to use special bond proceeds for major investment projects to shore up its slowing economy amid a trade war with the US.

site_title: Nicholas Mak joins ERA Realty as head of research
summary: ERA Realty has hired industry veteran Nicholas Mak as its head of research and consultancy, as part of efforts to grow its data-driven research capabilities. Mak joins from ZACD and Knight Frank, where he previously worked for nine years. His role will involve producing publications, reports, and research for ERA's business units in Singapore and Asia Pacific. The move aims to expand ERA's research methodologies and support its consultancy department.

site_title: Trump Jr to give private testimony to US Congress on Wednesday
summary: Donald Trump Jr will testify before a Republican-led Senate committee on Wednesday, answering questions about his 2016 meeting with a Russian lawyer and potential ties to the Trump Organization. The session, expected to last four hours, follows a dispute over discrepancies in his original 2017 testimony. The committee aims to revisit some of his statements, including those about a proposed Trump Tower project in Moscow. Trump Jr had initially agreed to testify voluntarily but postponed, leading to a subpoena. The hearing is part of a broader investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 US presidential election.

site_title: Renault push to block Nissan governance shift 'endangering' alliance: source
summary: Renault is pushing to block a governance overhaul at Nissan Motor, potentially endangering the 20-year-old Franco-Japanese automaking alliance. Renault has demanded more say in the new system, prompting Nissan to call the demand "most regrettable." A person familiar with Nissan's thinking says Renault's actions are "endangering the alliance" and warns against antagonizing Japanese shareholders and people. The crisis follows a week of tensions between the two automakers, leaving the future of their partnership uncertain.

site_title: Challenger shareholder says close to getting 10% veto on Digileap's S$183m exit offer
summary: A minority shareholder in Challenger Technologies, Pangolin Investment Management, is close to obtaining votes from 9.8% of shares to block Digileap Capital's S$183 million exit offer for the electronics retailer. The offer, which is 56 Singapore cents per share, is considered too low by Pangolin, which values the company at S$1.15 per share. Challenger's independent directors recommended unanimously that shareholders accept the deal, but the exit offer will lapse if at least 10% of shareholders vote against it at the June 27 EGM.

site_title: No 'Endgame' for Marvel fan: he's seen 'Avengers' film 110 times
summary: A Marvel fan in the US has seen "Avengers: Endgame" 110 times, possibly setting a new Guinness record, in an effort to help the film become the highest-grossing movie in history. The movie has already earned $2.732 billion at the box office, putting it within range of beating "Avatar." Industry watchers note that the movie may lose steam with viewers, but fans like Agustin Alanis could potentially help it reach the top spot. Alanis' feat beats a previous record held by Anthony Mitchell, who saw "Infinity War" 103 times.

site_title: North Korean leader's brother was CIA informant, book claims
summary: Kim Jong Un's half-brother, Kim Jong Nam, was allegedly an informant for the US CIA before his 2017 assassination in Malaysia. According to journalist Anna Fifield's book, Kim Jong Nam met with CIA handlers in Southeast Asia before being poisoned with a nerve agent. The CIA's involvement in recruiting Kim Jong Nam was previously undisclosed, but US officials confirm the "nexus" between Kim and the agency. President Trump denies allowing the CIA to recruit Kim Jong Nam under his administration, but admits he doesn't know the details.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, Sembcorp Industries, Isetan, Challenger, RE&S, SATS, Mercurius
summary: Great Eastern Holdings is divesting a unit to Bank of Singapore for RM24.9 million, while Sembcorp Industries sold its 10.27% equity interest in Gallant Venture for S$62 million. Other notable developments include mandatory offer for PSC shares at S$0.40 a share and Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China flooding kills at least 19: state media
summary: Flooding in southern China's Guangxi region has killed at least 19 people, with 12 deaths reported in the region and 7 in neighboring Guangdong province. Heavy rainfall has triggered floods in six cities, affecting over 570,000 people, with houses collapsing and crops damaged. Rainfall is expected to intensify through Thursday.

images.alt_text: Flooding caused by torrential rains has killed at least 19 people in southern China, the official Xinhua news agency said on Wednesday.

site_title: US: Stocks edge down, snapping winning streak
summary: US stocks closed slightly lower on Tuesday, snapping a six-session winning streak, due to lingering anxiety over the US-China trade clash and buying fatigue. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1% to 26,048.51. Analysts attributed the market's exhaustion and digestion of recent gains as the primary factors behind the decline.

site_title: Quarter of pesticides used in US are banned in EU
summary: A study found that nearly a quarter of the pesticides used in US agriculture are banned in the European Union, with 72 out of 374 active ingredients authorized for use in the US also banned in the EU. Additionally, paraquat, a highly poisonous herbicide, is banned in Europe since 2007, and is also banned or being phased out in China and Brazil.

site_title: US states sue to block Sprint, T-Mobile deal
summary: US states, including New York and California, have filed a lawsuit to block the proposed $26 billion merger between Sprint and T-Mobile, citing concerns that the deal would harm consumers and lead to higher costs, potentially pricing out low-income users. The combined company would be one of the two largest wireless carriers in the US, surpassing Verizon and AT&T.

site_title: US House approves faster court enforcement of Trump admin subpoenas
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a resolution to facilitate enforcement of Trump administration subpoenas, allowing Democrats to bypass full House votes and pursue cases in court. The measure, passed along party lines, comes after the Department of Justice agreed to share documents from special prosecutor Robert Mueller's report. The resolution does not hold Attorney General Bill Barr and former White House counsel Don McGahn in contempt, as an earlier version did. The move aims to enforce subpoenas and obtain documents and testimony outside the scope of the agreement with the Justice Department.

site_title: Pakistan vows to raise revenues with new budget following IMF deal
summary: Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan's government has presented a budget aimed at reducing the country's fiscal deficit and increasing tax revenues. The plan includes slashing civil expenditure, freezing military spending, and collecting 5.5 trillion rupees in taxes. The government has also agreed to take a 10% salary cut for officials. The budget comes weeks after Pakistan reached a $6 billion bailout deal with the IMF, which is expected to have restrictions on the country's economic policies. The government faces opposition from vocal lawmakers who have criticized the budget as "unacceptable."

site_title: Macron says he would back Merkel if she runs for EU leadership
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron expressed support for German Chancellor Angela Merkel if she were to run for EU leadership, citing her vast experience and commitment to the EU. Macron stated that he would support her candidacy, as Europe needs strong personalities to embody the bloc's needs. Merkel, set to retire in 2021, has not ruled out a top EU job, but Juncker expressed skepticism about her changing her mind. Macron and Merkel both addressed the International Labour Organization in Geneva, but had no scheduled bilateral meeting.

site_title: Europe: China stimulus, German rally help stocks end higher
summary: European stocks rose for a third day, driven by a global rally after a holiday, with Germany's DAX index closing 0.9% higher. China's stimulus package boosted the basic resources sector, and US President Donald Trump's decision to hold off on imposing tariffs on Mexico also contributed to the gains. The Stoxx 600 index reached its highest level since May 17, with miners, auto stocks, and chemical companies leading the gains.

site_title: VW drops partnership with US self-driving car firm Aurora
summary: Volkswagen has dropped its partnership with US self-driving car firm Aurora, citing the conclusion of their activities. The decision comes as Volkswagen explores a broader alliance with Ford's self-driving unit Argo AI, with plans for cooperation progressing well. Volkswagen had previously collaborated with Aurora on autonomous vehicles and was also set to jointly build commercial vans and medium-sized pickups with Ford. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles has also partnered with Aurora, further indicating the shift in the industry's focus towards autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Uber names Melbourne as first non-US city for flying car programme
summary: Uber has selected Melbourne, Australia, as the first non-US city for its flying car programme, Uber Air, which aims to launch in 2023. Melbourne joins Dallas and Los Angeles as the third official pilot city. The service will offer aerial ridesharing as a multimodal option on the Uber app, with test flights starting in 2020 and electric aircraft expected to be similar in cost to the standard UberX car service. Uber plans to make the service available for the masses, with a pricing of around $6 per seat mile.

site_title: Trump inadvertently reveals more of US-Mexico migrant deal
summary: US President Donald Trump revealed a one-page agreement with Mexico that aims to halt Central American migrants. The agreement, signed on Friday, requires Mexico to take stronger legal action to stop migrants if initial efforts don't show results in 45 days. If results aren't met, Mexico will take necessary steps under domestic law to bring the agreement into force, giving it another 45 days to achieve that. The agreement doesn't specify measures Mexico must take, and the US wants Mexico to adopt a "safe third country" policy to deter migrants.

site_title: Oil steadies as demand concerns counter Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Tuesday, influenced by concerns over a global economic slowdown and Opec's potential supply cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $62.29 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose 1 cent to $53.27. The US Energy Information Administration cut its 2019 world oil demand growth forecast by 160,000 barrels per day. Opec's supply cuts are expected to be extended, supported by comments from Russian and Saudi Arabian officials. Oil prices have fallen roughly 20% from their 2019 peak due to concerns about slowing demand and economic growth.

site_title: GIC among backers of S Korean firm that reinvented 'love hotels'
summary: Yanolja, a South Korean firm that has transformed the 'love hotel' industry, has secured over $1 billion in valuation from investors Booking Holdings and Singapore's GIC Pte Ltd. The company aims to conduct an IPO next year, capitalizing on the global demand for short-stay accommodation. By offering modern and private 'love hotels,' Yanolja has dispelled the stigma associated with the industry, attracting budget tourists and young couples. The firm plans to expand globally, targeting markets in Southeast Asia, where it has already invested $15 million in ZEN Rooms.

site_title: World's most costly painting found on Saudi prince's yacht
summary: The world's most costly painting, Salvator Mundi, valued at $450 million, has been found on the yacht of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The painting, attributed to Leonardo da Vinci, was sold at Christie's in 2017 but has remained hidden since. According to art dealer Kenny Schachter, the painting was whisked away on the prince's plane and relocated to his yacht, the Serene, where it will remain until it is relocated to a cultural tourism destination in Al-Ula, Saudi Arabia. The painting's authenticity has been disputed, with some experts questioning its ownership and provenance.

site_title: Hong Kong gears up for protests, strikes as extradition anger boils over
summary: Hong Kong prepares for mass protests, strikes, and transport disruptions against a proposed extradition law that would allow people to be sent to China for trial. The law, set to be debated again on Wednesday, has sparked broad opposition at home and abroad, with business leaders warning that pushing through the bill could undermine investor confidence and erode Hong Kong's competitive advantages. Human rights groups have cited concerns over torture, arbitrary detentions, and access to lawyers in China, while thousands of people have announced plans to strike and rally against the bill.

site_title: Customer satisfaction in Singapore hits new high
summary: Customer satisfaction in Singapore has reached a new high, according to the Institute of Service Excellence (ISE) at the Singapore Management University (SMU). The annual Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) score rose to 73.5, the highest on record in the index's 12-year history. All eight industry sectors studied recorded higher customer satisfaction scores, with significant improvements in air transport, tourism, food and beverage, and finance and insurance. The study found that customer loyalty has decreased in some sectors due to increasing competition, but satisfaction levels continue to improve.

site_title: Plastic straws and bags no more: Canada aims to clean up its act
summary: Canada plans to ban single-use plastics like straws, bags, and cutlery by early 2021 to reduce waste and protect the world's oceans. The move follows the European Parliament's ban on similar products and comes after Canada's recent disputes with the Philippines and Malaysia over waste. Less than 10% of plastic used in Canada gets recycled, with an estimated $11 billion worth of plastic materials thrown away annually by 2030. The government has delayed implementation until 2021 to allow for a "science-based" decision on which plastics are harmful to the environment and human health.

site_title: Shell ships long-awaited first LNG cargo from floating Prelude plant in Australia
summary: Royal Dutch Shell shipped the world's first LNG cargo from its Prelude floating LNG plant off northwest Australia, marking Australia's top LNG exporter status. The 490-meter long ship, longer than four soccer fields, departed safely after a two-year delay due to teething problems. Prelude is expected to produce 3.6 million tonnes of LNG annually, with a joint ownership of Shell, Inpex, Korea Gas, and Overseas Petroleum. The shipment comes amid a global LNG supply surge, with spot prices at their lowest in over three years.

site_title: Trump threatens China with another round of tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose another round of tariffs on Chinese imports, worth at least $300 billion, if he doesn't make progress in trade talks with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the upcoming G-20 summit. The US has already imposed 25% tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods. China's foreign ministry has expressed openness to further trade talks, but no meeting has been confirmed. The escalating trade war has unnerved financial markets and raised concerns about a potential global recession.

site_title: Citi launches co-branded credit card with Grab in push for more customers
summary: Citi has launched co-branded credit cards with Grab, a move aimed at boosting its Asian customer base by 13% through partnerships with digital firms. This marks the latest step in Grab's push into financial services, and aligns with Citi's strategy of offering products within online ecosystems. The partnership aims to tap into the growing trend of consumers spending more time on smartphones.

site_title: BlueRed a bridge linking Israeli startups to Asia's wealthy
summary: BlueRed Partners, a venture firm connecting Israeli startups to Asia's wealthy business families, has raised US$75 million for its inaugural fund, aiming to reach US$100 million. The firm, co-founded by dual French-Israeli citizen Daniel Harel, targets growth-stage investments in deep-tech startups with a clear path to commercialization. With a portfolio including foodtech player DouxMatok and medtech firm EarlySense, BlueRed seeks to bridge the gap between Israel's startup scene and South-east Asia's prominent business families, who have shown interest in investing in Israeli technologies.

images.alt_text: From left: BlueRed Partners business development head Laurence Harel, CEO, co-founder and managing partner Daniel Harel, and co-founder and managing partner Yishai Klein.

site_title: Consumer habits need to change more fundamentally to be truly eco-friendly
summary: Consumer habits must change more fundamentally to be truly eco-friendly. While banning single-use plastics and promoting reusables have gained momentum, they often come with caveats, such as higher production costs and potential fueling of further waste. Reusables are only beneficial if used frequently enough to offset their environmental cost. Ultimately, reducing consumption is key, but there is no capitalist incentive to promote this. To achieve true eco-friendliness, consumer behavior must change fundamentally, and companies must prioritize sustainable practices over green marketing tactics.

site_title: Growing from strength to strength
summary: The Philippines' economy is growing, with a 6.8% GDP growth forecast for 2019, driven by sustained economic growth, a large and young population, and remittances from overseas workers. The country is an attractive destination for trade and investment, with Singapore being its seventh largest trading partner and largest export market in Asean. Investments in the country have surged, with the Philippines Board of Investments approving 286.7 billion pesos in total investments from January to April 2019, a 46.5% jump from the previous year.

site_title: YuuZoo, Harbin mayor agree on timetable for Nordic Sport Town project
summary: YuuZoo Networks Group has agreed with Harbin mayor on a definitive timetable for the Nordic Sport Town project, set to start on May 1, 2020. The project involves 85 hectares of river-fronting land for residential, commercial, tourism, education, and sports developments. Despite facing trading challenges and a Singaporean trading ban, YuuZoo has managed to raise funds and secured local support. The company's shares have been suspended since March 2018 due to auditor concerns and a subsequent investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Time to tighten digital banking metrics
summary: Singapore banks face pressure to prove the value of digital banking amid Big Tech disruption. A recent survey by UOB found that digital customers prefer offline channels for wealth and loan products, but online channels for research and comparison. Omnichannel customers, who use both offline and online channels, make 35 transactions per year and hold more products on average. However, digital-only customers may be less profitable due to lower product holdings. Other banks, such as DBS, report that digital customers offer higher revenue but may not be worth as much in dollar terms as traditional customers.

site_title: Japan to implement flexible policy if economic risks materialise
summary: Japan's government plans to raise the sales tax in October as scheduled, while prepared to take flexible macroeconomic policy steps if economic risks materialize. A mid-year policy roadmap states that the government will make all policy tools available to sustain a recovery trend, including easing monetary policy to achieve a 2% inflation target. The move comes amid global economic concerns, including a slowing China economy and trade tensions between the US and Sino-US. The government aims to balance growth and fiscal reform, closely monitoring external developments.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 0.4% in May, rising for fourth straight month
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.4% in May, marking the fourth consecutive month of increases. This follows a 0.8% gain in April and a 2.3% year-on-year increase. The city fringes saw the largest price gain, with non-landed private homes rising 0.8%. The volume of sales increased by 3% to 835 units, but remains 46.1% lower than in May 2018. Experts attribute the upward trend to a stabilizing market and new property launches with higher prices per square foot.

site_title: Children of Chinese elite toe a red line to 'perfection'
summary: In Shanghai, a class of elite children, aged 7-11, participate in etiquette and manners training, led by self-styled French doyen Guillaume de Bernadac. The children, including 10-year-old Danielle, learn social skills, dining manners, and deportment through exercises such as walking with a book on their head and keeping elbows off the table. Their parents, who pay 2,688 yuan for four hours of instruction, hope their children will develop into "perfect" individuals who can adapt to international environments.

site_title: Singapore hedge fund shorting US firms that risk retaliation from Beijing
summary: A Singapore hedge fund, APS Asset Management, is preparing for a potential "economic war" between the US and China, citing the trade war as the biggest risk for equity markets. The fund's CIO, Wong Kok Hoi, is shorting US firms at risk of retaliation from Beijing, including Apple, US-operated Macau casinos, and companies like Boeing and General Motors. Wong warns that if a trade war escalates, stocks could plummet, and investors should be cautious, as "politics can change overnight."

site_title: Chopper crash on NY tower triggers 9/11 fears, calls for curbs
summary: A helicopter crashed onto the roof of an office building in midtown Manhattan, triggering 9/11 fears and calls for increased airport security measures. The incident occurred in foggy conditions and burst into flames, causing damage to the building. Authorities are investigating the cause of the crash. The incident has raised concerns about the safety of air travel in the city.

site_title: Apple's US iPhones can all be made outside of China if needed
summary: Apple has a backup plan to manufacture iPhones in the US if the US-China trade war escalates. Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Apple's primary manufacturing partner, has enough capacity to make all US-bound iPhones outside of China. The company, which currently produces most smartphones in China, is prepared to support Apple if needed, according to a senior executive. This move could mitigate the impact of a potential trade embargo on Apple's US operations.

site_title: SATS opens private-jet centre at Seletar Airport
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based in-flight catering services provider, has opened its Business Aviation Centre (BAC) at Seletar Airport, offering personalized concierge, lounge, and passenger services to private-jet customers. The centre provides a "seamless passage" through the airport, with services including fine dining, special dietary meals, and express laundry. The centre has handled over 4,000 flights since its opening in 2018, with business aviation flights expected to grow 3-5% year on year.

site_title: Dealing with Kim: Trump's team needs to raise its game
summary: US President Donald Trump's team is struggling to achieve a successful outcome from the Singapore summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un, one year after the historic meeting. Despite Trump's optimism, the talks have failed to yield concrete results, with Pyongyang disputing the reasons for the collapse. The US president's inflated assessment of his abilities to broker a deal and his dependence on North Korea's geopolitics are major concerns. The lack of a comprehensive strategy and sequencing plan has hindered progress, and the US has yet to receive concrete concessions from Kim.

site_title: Citigroup unit suspended from Japan bond auctions for manipulation
summary: Citigroup Global Markets Japan Inc. was suspended from participating in Japanese government bond auctions for a month after being found to have manipulated futures prices. The Ministry of Finance ordered the exclusion following a fine of 133 million yen and an order to improve internal controls. The firm was accused of spoofing, placing orders without intending to execute them, which misled other investors. This is the second time a primary dealer has been suspended for a similar breach, following Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc. last year.

site_title: Ted Baker shares sink after warning of 'extremely difficult' start to year
summary: Ted Baker shares plummeted 25% in trading after the company warned of an "extremely difficult" start to 2019, citing unseasonable weather and promotional retail environment in North America. The UK fashion retailer expects underlying profit to be £10 million below analysts' estimates, at £50-60 million. The company aims to restructure and introduce new products to turn its business around, following a 43% drop in shares last year and a drop in annual profit since 2008.

site_title: Latest lessons from fixed income market
summary: Market volatility has returned, driven by protectionism as the major medium-term risk. Despite a rebound from the Q4 2018 sell-off, investors have under-participated in the rally, fearing the cost of hedges and defensive strategies. Key areas of value in fixed income markets include direct lending, hybrids, subordinated financials, and emerging market credit spreads. However, government bonds have moved down in rankings due to weakening global economic data and rate cuts. Investors are advised to remain flexible and consider the long-term, avoiding silos and focusing on the wider risk outlook.

site_title: Fewer ships lost, but still lots of accidents
summary: Shipping losses have declined by over 50% year on year, according to Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty's Safety & Shipping Review 2019. This marks the lowest level of large shipping losses in this century, with 46 ships lost in 2018 compared to 207 in 2000. Improved ship design, regulation, and risk management are driving the sector's long-term loss improvement. However, machinery damage remains a major concern, accounting for over a third of incidents, and fires on board are a growing risk, with 174 reported incidents in 2019.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Brokers have maintained their buy and hold recommendations for CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ) despite recent market volatility. CDLHT's earnings are expected to turn around in the coming quarters due to the return of refurbished rooms and the gradual ramp-up of Raffles Maldives Meradhoo. YZJ's share price has moved in line with the broader market, but is expected to recover in 2020 due to increased operational clarity in the International Maritime Organization's sulphur content cap regulation. Share price catalysts include yield-accretive acquisitions and increased contributions from newly refurbished properties.

site_title: Banks rethinking their branch concept
summary: Banks in Singapore are rethinking their branch concept to create more conversations with customers. Research by the Institute of Service Excellence found that customers with multiple banking accounts, credit cards, and investment products have higher satisfaction levels. In response, banks are evolving their branches into spaces for social interaction, offering services such as digital concierges, ambassadors, and lifestyle spaces. Examples include Maybank's MSpace, OCBC Bank's digital concierge, and DBS's café and branch concept. These innovations aim to deepen social interaction and provide customers with a more engaging banking experience.

site_title: Amazon dethrones Google as top brand: survey
summary: Amazon has surpassed Google as the world's most valuable brand, according to a survey by global market research agency Kantar. The brand value of Amazon surged by 52% to $315 billion, while Google's value dropped to $309 billion. Amazon's growth is attributed to key acquisitions, superior customer services, and its disruptive business model. The Seattle-based retail giant has taken the top spot, followed by Apple and Google, with Microsoft, Visa, and Facebook rounding out the top 10. This marks the first time Amazon has led the list.

site_title: Here's how to keep cars out of hackers' reach
summary: The automotive industry is vulnerable to car-hacking due to software vulnerabilities and lack of security measures. Modern cars are controlled by computer systems, making them susceptible to threats and vulnerabilities. The industry has drafted legislation and standards, but compulsory-compliance requirements have not been enough to prevent breaches. To address this issue, the industry must come together to share knowledge, create guidelines, and improve tools and talent. Embedding security, implementing rigid supply-chain management, and creating mature security practices are key steps to building robust and secure systems. Ultimately, the industry must prioritize security and collaboration to prevent devastating effects of car-hacking.

site_title: How merchants can benefit from a cashless society
summary: A cashless society has transformed payment processing into a multi-billion-dollar industry, but small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have been negatively impacted by high transaction fees, setup costs, and security concerns. Integrated merchant lending, which combines payments and lending, is emerging as a solution to provide fast, seamless, and efficient funding for SMEs. This approach uses data from payment processing to build self-tuning risk assessment profiles, allowing for real-time credit decisions and tailored loan structures. The result is a "zero human touch" borrowing experience, benefiting SMEs and strengthening the economy.

site_title: Prayut gets royal endorsement for Thai PM post
summary: Thailand's King formally endorsed Prayut Chan-o-cha as Prime Minister, five years after he seized power in a military coup. Prayut's coalition holds a slim majority in the lower House of Representatives and faces opposition from the Democratic Front, which claims electoral rules favored pro-army forces. Prayut vowed to promote a peaceful environment and safeguard the monarchy's dignity, aiming to unite the country and bring an end to confrontation between opponents and supporters of ousted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.

site_title: Budget airlines closing gap with full-service carriers
summary: Budget airlines in Singapore have narrowed the gap with full-service carriers in customer satisfaction, with a 2.7% improvement in scores to 73.1 points, according to the Institute of Service Excellence's Customer Satisfaction Index. For the first time in five years, budget airline customers have surpassed full-service airline customers in the "likelihood to repurchase" metric. Scoot, Singapore's leading budget airline, achieved the highest customer satisfaction score among budget carriers with 75.3 points. The study suggests that budget airlines are successfully offering high-quality services beyond price, prompting full-service airlines to differentiate their offerings.

site_title: Copper rises on demand hopes; nickel also up as steel surges
summary: Copper prices surged in Asian trading on Tuesday, reaching a two-week high, driven by expectations of increased demand from China. Benchmark copper on the London Metal Exchange rose 1.1% to $5,937 a tonne, while copper on the Shanghai Futures Exchange jumped 1.5% to 46,900 yuan a tonne. China's copper import premium has risen to $59 a tonne, indicating strong physical demand. The news comes amid a backdrop of easing financing rules in China and a possible cut in US interest rates, but trade tensions between the US and China remain a concern.

site_title: Asean outpaces global growth in May: IHS Markit
summary: Asean's manufacturing conditions improved in May, driven by stronger output and new orders, outpacing global growth, which contracted for the third year. The JPMorgan Global PMI fell to 51.2, while Asean countries' PMIs rose, with Indonesia's at 51.6 and the Philippines' at 51.2, signaling a brighter economic outlook for the second half of the year.

site_title: Mapletree Investments acquires first office property in Dublin
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired The Sorting Office, an 8-storey office building in Dublin's Silicon Docklands, marking its first office acquisition in the Irish capital. The property, valued at approximately 210,000 square feet, boasts flexible design and is located near major transportation hubs. The acquisition is consistent with Mapletree's strategy of diversifying earnings in scalable and developed markets. The property is expected to be completed in November 2019 and is expected to attract a diverse mix of tenants in the technology and financial sectors.

site_title: Self-ordering kiosks help raise quality at fast-food outlets
summary: Self-ordering kiosks at fast-food outlets have been found to increase customer satisfaction levels, with those who use kiosks rating their experience as simple and ordering process as higher than those who order at the counter. According to the Institute of Service Excellence's Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore, fast-food restaurants and restaurants scored 73.6 and 74.4 points, respectively, showing a 2.7% and 4% improvement in customer satisfaction. Industry experts believe that kiosks provide a standardized high level of service, educate customers, and offer quicker and more convenient experiences, paving the way for further improvements in the F&B sector.

site_title: Dalian iron ore futures surge 6% on supply crunch fears
summary: China's iron ore futures surged 6% on Tuesday due to fears of a supply crunch, despite easing steel prices. The Dalian Commodity Exchange saw iron ore futures hit a daily upper-trading limit, reaching 760.5 yuan (S$150.17) a tonne. Chinese steel production is expected to remain high, with mills making a profit despite moderation in demand. Inventory levels have fallen to 121.6 million tonnes, the lowest in two and a half years, and steel stocks continue to decline.

site_title: Environmental, social and governance principles gain traction in Asia-Pacific
summary: Global support for sustainable investing is growing rapidly in the Asia-Pacific region, with key environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics varying from those in the US and Europe. The Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission introduced voluntary guidelines for ESG policies, while general partners are signing the Principles for Responsible Investing (PRI) more quickly than limited partners. A survey found that over two-thirds of participants in the GP Asia-Pacific market collect ESG metrics, primarily driven by LP demands. ESG metrics in the region prioritize environmental policy, ESG policy, people diversity, and health and safety events, differing from those in the US and Europe.

site_title: NeNe Chicken, Ippudo owners to be key investors in franchisee's Catalist IPO
summary: ST Group Food Industries, an Australian-headquartered franchisee for various food brands, has lodged a draft prospectus for a Catalist IPO. The company, which owns exclusive rights to brands like NeNe Chicken, Ippudo, and PappaRich, plans to use the funds to expand its franchise network and introduce new brands. Cornerstone investors include Chikaranomoto Global Holdings and Hyein Foods, with the IPO expected to be a placement. The company reported a net profit of A$1.9 million in the half-year ended June 30, with revenue up 36.7% from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: ST Group Food Industries owns franchise and licence rights to the PappaRich, NeNe Chicken, Hokkaido Baked Cheese Tart, Gong Cha, Ippudo (above) and iDarts brands in various territories across Australia, New Zealand and Malaysia.

site_title: New award to recognise corporations, individuals in social enterprise
summary: A new award, the Social Enterprise Champion award, has been introduced in Singapore to recognize corporations and individuals contributing to the social enterprise sector. The award is part of the President's Challenge Social Enterprise Award (PCSEA) and aims to foster a win-win partnership between corporations and social enterprises. The award committee will evaluate applicants based on their contributions, value, and impact on the sector. Individuals and corporations can apply separately, with winners receiving S$70,000 and S$50,000 respectively. Applications close on July 12.

site_title: EU says Switzerland must endorse treaty before June 18
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warned Switzerland to endorse a new partnership treaty by June 18 to maintain Swiss stock exchange access to EU financial markets. The treaty, which governs relations between the EU and Switzerland, was negotiated over four years and requires Swiss endorsement before the current EU stock exchange recognition expires. Failure to endorse the treaty could damage Swiss ties with the EU, potentially disrupting commerce and cross-border stock trading. The Swiss government has demanded more information on several issues before signing off on the draft treaty.

site_title: Nissan extends olive branch to Renault as ties hit new low
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa extended an olive branch to Renault, calling for the companies to "make our peace" and "stabilise and reinforce" their partnership after an acrimonious dispute over governance changes. Saikawa emphasized the importance of their partnership, stating it was "the most important thing." This comes as ties between the two automakers hit a new low.

site_title: Latest tranche of Astrea PE bonds opens for public subscription
summary: The latest tranche of Astrea V PE Bonds, a US$600 million offering backed by a US$1.3 billion portfolio of 38 private equity funds, is open for public subscription. The bonds, similar in structure to the previous Astrea IV issue, cater to expected strong demand with a larger retail tranche.

site_title: UK leadership election starts on Thursday
summary: The UK leadership election for the Conservative Party begins on Thursday, with 10 candidates vying for the top spot. The election is aimed at Tory activist voters, with promises of tax cuts and a Brexit deal by October 31. The front-runners, Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt, have the support of key MPs and EU leaders, but the party's Brexit division and opposition MPs are at odds over the best approach. The candidates' plans for Brexit, including the possibility of a no-deal scenario, have sparked concerns about the UK's economic future.

site_title: Guoco Tower wins excellence award
summary: Guoco Tower in Singapore won the 2019 Urban Land Institute (ULI) Asia Pacific Awards for Excellence, marking the only Singapore winner out of 10 projects. The award recognizes best land use practice from across the region.

site_title: Tennis's golden trio tighten grip on men's game
summary: Tennis's "golden trio" of Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Novak Djokovic continue to dominate the men's game, with Nadal winning his 12th French Open title and Federer and Djokovic still seeking their 21st and 16th Grand Slam titles, respectively. The trio have accumulated 53 Grand Slam titles since 2003, with the last 10 titles shared among them. Their dominance has led to only seven other men winning a Grand Slam title in the last 16 years, with most being one-Slam wonders.

site_title: Hong Kong firm drops US$1.4b land purchase pact on economic worries
summary: Hong Kong-based Goldin Financial Holdings Ltd dropped out of a US$1.4 billion land purchase pact due to economic uncertainties, citing "recent social contradiction and economic instability" in Hong Kong. The move comes as the Asian financial hub's businesses face challenges from China's slowdown and the US-China trade war. Despite a slow first-quarter economic expansion, home prices rose for the fourth straight month in April, but analysts warn the trend may not be sustainable. The planned Kai Tak project's rental business could be hit by trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore 4G coverage hits 90.2%, up from previous 84.4%
summary: Singapore's 4G coverage has reached 90.2%, surpassing the 84.4% mark from the previous year, according to Opensignal. Singtel led the improvement with 91.2% coverage, while M1 and StarHub are close to reaching the same milestone. The country's 4G coverage ranks 14th out of 87 markets, and network operators have improved average download and upload speeds. The Infocomm Media Development Authority expects 5G deployment to begin in 2023, and the regulator may eventually shut down 3G services in the future.

site_title: CapitaLand to sell its holdings in three China shopping malls
summary: CapitaLand will sell its holdings in three Chinese shopping malls, CapitaMall Xuefu, CapitaMall Aidemengdun, and CapitaMall Yuhuating, to CRCT for 2.96 billion yuan (S$589.2 million). The transaction is expected to enlarge CRCT's portfolio and footprint to 10 Chinese cities. The sale marks a strategic move for CapitaLand, allowing it to focus on other business ventures.

site_title: FDA unveils new guidelines for e-cigarette makers
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has unveiled new guidelines for e-cigarette makers, covering issues like accidental nicotine exposure and battery safety. The guidelines aim to address public health concerns while designing e-cigarette products. Currently, there are no authorized e-cigarettes on the US market. The FDA's move follows a surge in e-cigarette use among teenagers, which the agency has sought to curb.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lion Global Investors is divesting its 70% stake in Pacific Mutual Fund Berhad to Bank of Singapore for RM24.9 million. RE&S Holdings has announced leadership changes, with Foo Kah Lee succeeding John Yek as CEO. Sembcorp Industries' subsidiary Sembcorp Development has sold its 10.27% equity interest in Gallant Venture for S$62 million. These moves are part of companies' succession plans and strategies to optimise returns and recycle capital.

site_title: Control of China Jinjiang to change after 1.6b yuan deal
summary: Controlling shareholders of China Green Energy, which owns 29.79% of China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company, are selling their interests for 1.6 billion yuan (S$322.3 million). Zhejiang Energy International and Zheneng Capital Holdings Co, both controlled by Zhejiang Provincial Energy Group Co, are the purchasers. This deal is expected to change control of China Jinjiang.

site_title: To Wall Street, it's 'when', not 'if' the US Fed will cut rates
summary: The US economy is showing signs of cooling, prompting investors to expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. Despite uncertainty from President Donald Trump's trade policies, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell signaled readiness to help prop up the economy. The jobs report showed slower job gains, and wages climbed only 3.1% in the year till May. Economists expect a rate cut by the end of July, with some predicting a 0.5 percentage point move in July and a 0.25 percentage point cut before the end of the year.

site_title: India to evacuate thousands as cyclone nears west coast
summary: Indian authorities are evacuating 300,000 people along the western coast as Cyclone Vayu is expected to make landfall in the state of Gujarat on Thursday. The cyclone, with gust speeds up to 135 kmph, could delay monsoon rains over the rest of India. The government has asked for military and disaster response assistance, and several refineries and ports are preparing for evacuation. The cyclone's impact comes after Cyclone Fani killed 34 people in May, and a super-cyclone killed 10,000 in 2004.

site_title: Interest in Reits, property counters lingers
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 3,209.58 on Tuesday, driven by risk-on sentiment and interest in property-related counters. Despite US President Donald Trump's threat to raise tariffs on China, markets were largely unaffected. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while CapitaLand posted its largest intraday gain in two months following the divestment of three malls in China to CRCT.

site_title: Oil rises with financial markets, as longer supply cuts expected
summary: Oil prices rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by anticipation of OPEC and its allies withholding supplies and firmer financial markets. Brent crude futures reached $62.56 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $53.75 per barrel. OPEC+ is expected to maintain supply cuts, but analysts warn of a limit to how long they can avoid addressing growing US production. Global crude oil demand growth is expected to drop below 1 million barrels per day in 2019, giving producers an extra 300,000-400,000 barrels per day of supply.

site_title: Australia cuts wheat forecast by 11% as drought threatens for third year
summary: Australia has cut its wheat production forecast for the 2019/20 harvest by 11% due to a drought threatening crops for a third year. The revised forecast is 14% below the 10-year average, with production expected to total 21.2 million tonnes. This will lead to lower-than-average exports, potentially forcing Australian millers to import wheat for the first time in over a decade. The drought will also damage the country's stuttering economy, which is already facing increased domestic demand from the livestock sector.

site_title: Mounting rate-cut bets cap dollar before G-20 meet
summary: The US dollar steadied above a recent two-and-a-half-month low as investors focused on a potential breakthrough in trade talks between the US and China at the upcoming G-20 summit. Despite dovish comments from Federal Reserve officials and weak economic data, markets are pricing in a 20% chance of a rate cut in June and over three rate hikes by mid-2020. The dollar's value rose 3.5% against its rivals in the first five months of 2019, but recent rate-cut bets have prompted investors to increase holdings of other currencies, such as the euro.

images.alt_text: The US dollar steadied above a recent two-and-a-half-month low on Tuesday as investors focused on a Group of 20 (G-20) summit later this month where Beijing and Washington might make some progress on trade talks.

site_title: UK PM candidate Leadsom against second Scottish referendum, but "never say never"
summary: UK Prime Minister candidate Andrea Leadsom stated she would fight against a second Scottish independence referendum, but left room for negotiation. In a 2014 referendum, Scotland voted against independence, but nationalists continue to push for a second vote. Leadsom expressed her opposition to another referendum but acknowledged the possibility of devolution and not ruling it out entirely.

site_title: Merkel's longtime rival Merz is Germany's new leader in waiting
summary: Friedrich Merz, a longtime rival of Chancellor Angela Merkel, is emerging as Germany's most probable replacement, with strong support from business leaders disillusioned with the current government. Merz, who was narrowly outvoted from becoming party leader in 2018, has gained momentum with a forceful speech calling for an Agenda 2030 to restore Germany's economic health. This has led to speculation that he will succeed Merkel in the next parliamentary elections in 2021, potentially sparking early elections and a break from the current "grand coalition" with the Social Democratic Party.

site_title: US underlying producer prices increase solidly in May
summary: US producer prices rose 0.4% in May, matching April's gain, driven by a surge in hotel accommodation and service costs. Core PPI increased 2.3% over the 12 months through May. Weaker energy and food prices partially offset the increase. The steady rise in underlying producer prices supports the Federal Reserve's view that weak inflation readings are transitory.

site_title: Inventor of guilt-free desserts is world's top pastry chef
summary: Jessica Prealpato, a 32-year-old French pastry chef, has been named the world's top pastry chef by the World's 50 Best Restaurants ranking. She is the creator of guilt-free patisserie, focusing on the taste and feel-good effects of her desserts rather than appearance. Prealpato uses unusual ingredients and eschews traditional sugar-based desserts, opting for natural flavors and acidity. Despite initial criticism, she has become known for her unique creations and has been crowned the world's best pastry chef.

site_title: Beijing mum on Trump-Xi meeting at G20 summit
summary: China has declined to confirm a planned meeting between President Xi Jinping and US counterpart Donald Trump during the G20 summit in Japan, amid an escalating trade war. Trump had stated that a meeting had been "scheduled" and expected Xi to attend. China's foreign ministry said it would release information about any meeting "in due time," while Beijing reiterated its willingness to negotiate but not be bullied into compromising on core principles. The US has threatened new tariffs on Chinese imports if Xi does not attend the meeting, which could mark a turning point in the trade dispute.

site_title: In the pursuit of progress
summary: The Philippines and Singapore celebrate 50 years of bilateral relations, with ambassador Joseph Del Mar Yap expressing hopes for greater cooperation and growth in areas like economic ties, tourism, and information technology. The two countries have reaffirmed their relations and launched official logos and taglines to mark the anniversary. The Philippines aims to promote itself as a destination for business, investment, and tourism, while Singapore looks to strengthen cooperation in areas like counterterrorism and multilateral forums. A year-long schedule of commemorative activities, including a state visit by Singapore's President Halimah Yacob, is planned to celebrate their ties.

site_title: Tokyo Electron 'to honour US blacklist of Chinese firms'
summary: Tokyo Electron, the world's No 3 supplier of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, will not supply to Chinese clients blacklisted by Washington, a senior executive said. The decision shows how US efforts to bar sales of technology to Chinese firms, including Huawei, are affecting non-American firms. Tokyo Electron, which has a long US partnership, cited the need to be seen as a fair company. Another Japanese chip equipment supplier is considering halting shipments to blacklisted Chinese firms, and executives are communicating with the Japanese industry ministry.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on China stimulus, Mexico tariff relief
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, rising 0.45% to near record territory, driven by signs of China's fiscal stimulus and relief from Mexico tariff tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 117.91 points to 26,180.59, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained 0.57% and 1.00% respectively. The gains followed a record close on Monday, as investors look to the US-China trade talks and potential easing of tensions with Mexico.

site_title: Oil woes have Calgary landlords turning empty offices into apartments
summary: In Calgary, oil industry job losses have led to a surge in office vacancies, with over 20% of downtown office space available for rent. To cope with the market, landlords are converting empty offices into apartments, with Strategic Group's conversion of an Alberta Health Services building into an apartment complex, called Cube, costing C$24.5 million. Other developers are following suit, with the city aiming to attract major companies to undo the damage from the oil downturn, which is expected to take 12-16 years to absorb vacant office space.

site_title: Bonds find favour with strategists in volatile times
summary: Market and investment strategists prefer fixed-income instruments like US Treasuries and emerging market bonds due to the volatile and uncertain investing backdrop. European private bank LGT noted a surge in demand for 10-year US government bonds, driving down yields to multi-month lows. This trend is attributed to traders hedging their portfolios ahead of trade conflicts between the US and its major trading partners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.27 points lower at 1,651.20 on Tuesday, with 2.2 billion lots traded worth RM2 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 455 to 348.

site_title: Exxon to proceed with oil development in Argentina
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to proceed with a 90-well oil development project in Argentina's Bajo del Choique-La Invernada block, potentially producing up to 55,000 barrels of oil-equivalent per day within five years. The project was initiated in 2016 after successful exploration results. Exxon holds a 90% interest in the block, with Gas y Petróleo del Neuquén holding the remaining 10%. The project's success could lead to a second phase producing up to 75,000 barrels per day. This development comes after Argentina awarded permits for hydrocarbon exploration in 18 areas off its southern coast.

site_title: Third US-North Korea summit possible, up to Kim says Bolton
summary: A third US-North Korea summit is possible, according to White House national security adviser John Bolton, who stated that the ball is in Pyongyang's court. Bolton said the US is continuing its "maximum pressure campaign" despite North Korea's pledge to refrain from nuclear tests. The two leaders' last meeting in Hanoi failed to yield a deal, and diplomatic efforts have stalled since. Bolton expressed readiness for a new meeting, but emphasized that Kim Jong Un holds the key to a potential summit.

images.alt_text: A third summit between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is possible but the ball is in Pyongyang's court, White House national security adviser John Bolton said on Tuesday.

site_title: TT International Ltd given more time to submit financial statements, hold AGM
summary: TT International Ltd received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to extend the release of its unaudited financial statements for FY2019 and FY2020 until October 30, 2019, and to hold its annual general meetings (AGM) for FY2018 and FY2019 until November 30, 2019. The company had previously requested these extensions due to unforeseen circumstances. Trading in the company's securities on SGX has been suspended since August 2017.

site_title: YuuZoo and Harbin mayor agree on definitive timetable for Nordic Sport Town real estate project
summary: YuuZoo Networks Group has agreed with Harbin's mayor on a definitive timetable for the Nordic Sport Town real estate project, set to start on May 1, 2020. The project, spanning 85 hectares of river-fronting land, will feature residential properties, hotels, sports arena, and commercial real estate. Despite facing trading challenges and a trading ban, YuuZoo has secured local support and funds to proceed with the massive project. The agreement comes after the company closed its Singapore-based subsidiaries and terminated employees due to its trading suspension.

site_title: Crocs to slash Chinese production for US market
summary: Crocs Inc plans to reduce its production of shoes and accessories in China for the US market by over two-thirds by 2020, aiming to produce less than 10% of products in China. This move is in response to the potential impact of President Trump's trade war with Beijing. The company, which has seen significant demand for its products, believes it can mitigate the effects of tariffs by diversifying its supply chain. Despite efforts by the company and other footwear manufacturers to influence the proposed tariffs, the potential tariffs are still expected to have a material impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: Crocs Inc will aim to cut the volume of its shoes and accessories produced in China for the US market by more than two-thirds over the next year, as it guards against the impact of President Trump's trade war with Beijing.

site_title: No meat please! Nestle may extend plant-based burger partnership with McDonald's
summary: Nestle, the Swiss food giant, is considering expanding its plant-based burger partnership with McDonald's beyond Germany. According to Nestle's CEO, Marco Settembri, the company has the capacity to handle a potential extension, but wants to plan and execute it well. The market for meat substitutes is expected to reach $140 billion over the next decade. Nestle has already launched its plant-based Incredible Burger in several European countries and plans to launch a similar product in the US later this year.

images.alt_text: Nestle could expand its plant-based burger sales partnership with fast food chain McDonald's beyond Germany and is also looking for other partners, the Swiss food giant's head said on Tuesday.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries disposed entire equity interest in Gallant Venture for S$62m
summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly owned subsidiary Sembcorp Development sold its 10.27% equity interest in Gallant Venture for S$62 million. The sale was made due to thinly traded shares and represents a non-core investment disposal. The proceeds were redeployed as general working capital. The transaction is expected to have minimal impact on Sembcorp Industries' earnings per share and net asset value per share for the 2019 financial year.

site_title: Lion Global Investors seeks to divest unit to Bank of Singapore for RM25 million
summary: Lion Global Investors, a subsidiary of Great Eastern Holdings, plans to sell its 70% stake in Pacific Mutual Fund Berhad (PMF) to Bank of Singapore for RM24.9 million. The sale is conditional on approvals from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Securities Commission Malaysia. The transaction is not expected to impact Great Eastern's net tangible assets or earnings per share for FY2019, and OCBC will maintain its indirect holding through Bank of Singapore's interest in PMF.

site_title: Sri Lanka MPs defy president to resume Easter attack probe
summary: Sri Lanka's parliament defied President Maithripala Sirisena to resume an investigation into security lapses surrounding the Easter suicide bombings that killed 258 people. The Parliamentary Select Committee began hearing testimony from Muslim leaders who claimed they alerted authorities to radicalisation warnings ignored by senior police and security officials under the president. The investigation, halted by Sirisena, reveals significant security lapses and raises questions about the government's handling of intelligence.

site_title: Singapore shares press on, adding 0.7% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.7% on Tuesday, closing at 3,209.58, driven by a risk-on sentiment and investors' hopes of US Federal Reserve rate cuts and China's economic stimulus measures. The Straits Times Index saw 21.47 points increase, with the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 2.6% to 2,925.72. Financials, tech counters, and real estate players also performed well, with benchmark index components advancing 245 to 170.

site_title: Apple's US iphones can all be made outside of China if needed
summary: Apple's primary manufacturing partner, Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., has enough capacity to make all US-bound iPhones outside of China if needed. The company's senior executive, Young Liu, stated that 25% of production capacity is outside China and can meet Apple's demand. Hon Hai is investing in India, and Apple has a backup plan in place, including building a facility in Wisconsin and starting production in India. The company will respond swiftly to the US-China trade war by localized manufacturing.

site_title: Planemakers race for wide-body orders in Asia showdown
summary: Airbus and Boeing are competing for wide-body aircraft orders worth over $10 billion at the upcoming Paris Airshow. Cebu Air, a Philippine budget airline, is leaning towards breaking its exclusive ties with Airbus to select Boeing's 787 Dreamliner for its requirement of up to 16 wide-body jets. Meanwhile, Airbus is seeking new buyers for its upgraded A330neo model, which is facing production glitches and delays. Korean Air is set to order Boeing's 777X long-haul jet, according to industry sources. The competitions highlight Asian carriers' need to renew their long-haul fleets amid robust passenger demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.33% and the Topix index up 0.54%. The rally was driven by a decline in the yen's strength, prompting bargain-hunting.

site_title: Mapletree Investments acquires first office property in Dublin
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired an 8-storey office building in Dublin's Silicon Docklands, its first office property in the city. The 210,000 sq ft building, known as The Sorting Office, is due for completion in November 2019 and will offer flexible design and collaboration spaces. The acquisition aligns with Mapletree's strategy of diversifying earnings in scalable markets. This marks the group's expansion into the Irish office market, following investments in the UK, Germany, and Poland.

site_title: India seeks bans for Deloitte, KPMG arm for alleged auditing lapses
summary: India is seeking to ban Deloitte Haskins Sells and KPMG affiliate BSR & Associates for five years for alleged auditing lapses at Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services (IL&FS), a unit the government took control of last year. The corporate affairs ministry alleges the firms "miserably failed" to fulfill their duties as auditors for IL&FS Financial Services. Both firms denied any wrongdoing, with Deloitte stating it would cooperate fully with authorities. The government took control of IL&FS in October after it defaulted on debt obligations, and fraud charges have been filed against IFIN and its former management.

site_title: Insomnia: In the still of the night
summary: Chronic insomnia affects 5-10% of older adults, leading to increased risks of hypertension, Type 2 diabetes, heart attack, depression, anxiety, and premature death. A study of over 9,000 Americans aged 65 and older found that shorter sleep durations increased the risk of hypertension and diabetes. Insomnia impairs cognitive performance, a possible risk factor for mild cognitive impairment and dementia. To alleviate poor sleep, experts recommend practicing good sleep hygiene, including avoiding caffeine and electronics before bedtime, exercising regularly, and managing stress.

site_title: RE&S announces leadership changes
summary: RE&S Holdings announced leadership changes as part of its succession plan, effective July 1. CEO John Yek will step down, succeeded by Deputy CEO and CFO Foo Kah Lee. Yek will remain on the board as executive director. Yap Fang Ling, current senior finance manager, will take on financial controller role, while Lim Shyang Zheng, COO, will join the board. The changes aim to ensure the group's long-term growth and sustainability, with outgoing CEO Yek praising the company's talent-grooming efforts.

site_title: Indonesia's planned drawdowns under its shelf programme assigned Baa2 ratings: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service assigned Baa2 ratings to Indonesia's proposed senior unsecured dollar and euro-denominated notes, with a stable outlook. The ratings are underpinned by Indonesia's emphasis on macroeconomic stability, narrow fiscal deficits, and low government debt ratios. However, downside risks include political challenges to economic reforms, while upside risks include potential improvements in competitiveness. The rating is unlikely to change in the foreseeable future, with certain events such as increased government revenue or strengthened institutions potentially putting upward pressure on the rating.

site_title: Be wary of fake S$50 and S$100 portrait series notes: Police
summary: The Singapore Police Force is warning the public to be cautious of counterfeit S$50 and S$100 portrait series Singapore currency notes, which lack security features. The counterfeit notes were found to have simulated kinegrams and a different embossed feel compared to genuine notes. Three men aged 25-29 have been arrested and charged with counterfeiting currency notes since May 25. Possession of genuine counterfeit currency notes can lead to an imprisonment term of up to 15 years. Anyone with information is advised to contact the police hotline at 1800-255 0000.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly rise at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 up 0.3% and the DAX 30 gaining 0.7%. The Paris CAC 40 remained flat. The rises were driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. In contrast, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: ST Group Food Industries plans Catalist IPO
summary: ST Group Food Industries, an Australian-headquartered franchisee for various food brands, plans to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange via an initial public offering (IPO). The company owns exclusive rights to brands such as PappaRich, NeNe Chicken, and Ippudo in Australia, New Zealand, and Malaysia. Proceeds from the share sales will be used to expand the franchise network and introduce new brands. The company reported a net profit of A$1.9 million in the half-year ended June 30, with revenue increasing 36.7% from the same period last year.

site_title: Hollywood treatment awaits country with knack for catching spies
summary: Estonia, a former Soviet Union country, is set to gain international attention with the upcoming release of Christopher Nolan's film "Tenet" in July 2020. The movie's plot is shrouded in secrecy, but it's expected to feature Tallinn and other locations in the UK and Italy. The film's production could bring in 16 million euros (S$24.5 million) for Estonia, boosting its tourism industry, which accounts for about 7% of the economy. The country has a history of unmasking Russian spies, including a high-ranking defense official captured in 2008, and is eager to capitalize on its reputation as a hub for espionage.

site_title: Victims of Formosa spill in Vietnam seek compensation
summary: Lawyers in Taiwan launched a multi-million dollar lawsuit against Formosa for the 2016 toxic spill in Vietnam, which devastated fish stocks and affected thousands of Vietnamese livelihoods. The Vietnamese government fined Formosa US$500 million in 2016 for pouring chemicals, including cyanide, into the ocean. The spill prompted rare protests and had a lasting impact on fishing communities along the coastline. The lawsuit seeks compensation for the victims, who are seeking justice for the environmental catastrophe that ruined their lives.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on China's funding boost; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.59% to 2,111.81 on Tuesday, driven by China's funding boost and a US decision to hold off import tariffs on Mexico. The Korean won strengthened, while bond yields rose. China's bluechip index jumped 3% after local governments were allowed to use special bonds for major investments. Foreigners bought 69.1 billion won worth of shares, and the won was quoted at 1,180.4 per dollar, up 0.41%.

site_title: New Zealand selects Lockheed C-130J as preferred military transport replacement
summary: New Zealand has selected the Lockheed C-130J Super Hercules as its preferred military transport replacement, following a selection process among multiple aircraft. The choice aligns with its closest allies, including the US, UK, Australia, and Canada. The government will seek detailed costing information through the US foreign military sale process, with a previously estimated cost of over NZ$1 billion. No final contract decision has been made, with a business case expected to progress to cabinet next year.

site_title: Defying law, Indian farm group says it planted unapproved GM cotton seeds
summary: An Indian farm group, Shetkari Sangathana, has defied the law by planting unapproved genetically modified (GM) cotton seeds, which could result in up to five years imprisonment. The seeds, developed by Bayer's Monsanto unit, have been cultivated by at least 10% of India's 12.2 million hectares of cotton acreage in 2018. The group's president, Anil Ghanwat, claims it's a civil disobedience movement to highlight oppressive government laws, despite India approving GM cotton seeds in 2002 and 2006.

site_title: Remittance firms must stop granting loans: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has prohibited remittance firms from granting loans, effective September 10. The prohibition does not affect existing loans, and MAS will monitor lending activities closely. This move comes after concerns over remittance firms exploiting a loophole in regulations, and industry observers noting that loans are unusual for their primary role of transmitting money overseas. The prohibition was issued before the new Payment Services Act comes into force, which will prohibit licensees from granting loans to individuals.

site_title: Chinese city tells property developers to cease offering drastic price cuts
summary: The Chinese city of Enshi has urged property developers to stop drastic price cuts to stabilize house prices amid a worrying property slump. A three-page document issued by the Enshi Real Estate Association warned that developers who continue to cut prices "wrongly" could face punishing measures. The document listed 10 "tricks" used by developers to cut prices, citing concerns from the society and a negative impact on Enshi's property market.

site_title: SATS opens private-jet centre offering personalised services at Seletar Airport
summary: SATS, a catering services provider, has opened a Business Aviation Centre (BAC) at Seletar Airport, offering personalized services to private-jet customers. The centre provides swift baggage handling, security checks, and immigration clearance for a seamless passage. Private-jet travellers can also enjoy fine dining, special dietary meals, express laundry services, and a personal shopper. SATS aims to support Changi Airport's plan to grow Seletar Airport into a hub for business travelers, with operations managed by a joint venture involving SATS and Swiss business aviation services provider Jet Aviation.

site_title: Ted Baker warns on 2019 profit after "extremely difficult" start
summary: Ted Baker warns on 2019 profit, citing a "challenging" start to the year, with underlying profit expected to be at least 10 million pounds below analysts' estimates. The company attributed the warning to difficult trading conditions, unseasonable weather, and a highly promotional retail environment. Shares are expected to sink 25% at opening. Ted Baker expects underlying profit before tax for 2019 to be 50-60 million pounds, down from 63 million pounds last year.

site_title: Abuse, neglect of multilateral trading system will benefit few: Tan Chuan-Jin
summary: Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin warned that abuse and neglect of the multilateral trading system will primarily benefit a few, hindering the growth of other countries. He emphasized the importance of updating the system to accommodate growing trade in services and digital economies. Noting Singapore's success in a rules-based system, Tan Chuan-Jin cautioned that deterioration of the system would obstruct similar growth in other countries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their gains, rising 0.76% to 27,789.34 on the Hang Seng Index, following a healthy lead from Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.58% and the Shenzhen Composite Index surged 3.71%. The gains were attributed to investors monitoring the China-US trade standoff, with stocks rallying despite US President Trump's new tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese stocks rallied Tuesday, extending gains and tracking a healthy lead from Wall Street, as investors keep tabs on developments in the China-US trade standoff.

site_title: Despite 5G fanfare, mobile operators still boosting older network connections
summary: Singapore's mobile operators have achieved 90.2% 4G access, surpassing the 90% milestone for the first time, according to Opensignal. Market leader Singtel led with 91.2% coverage, followed by M1 and StarHub. The country ranks 14th in 4G coverage globally. Average download speeds reached 39.9 Mbps and upload speeds 13.1 Mbps, making Singapore the second-fastest in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite 5G fanfare, operators are still focusing on improving the mobile broadband experience.

site_title: Australia shares hit over 11-year high as global trade worries ease; NZ up
summary: Australian shares reached an 11-year high, closing 1.6% up at 6,546.30, driven by financials and resource-based stocks as US-Mexico trade tensions eased. The metals and mining index rose 1.3% on higher iron ore and base metal prices. Financials gained for a fifth straight session, while healthcare stocks hit a nine-month closing high. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 1.1% to 10,139.15, driven by a lift in manufacturing sales volumes.

site_title: Helicopter crash atop foggy Manhattan skyscraper kills pilot
summary: A helicopter crashed onto the fog-shrouded roof of a midtown Manhattan skyscraper, killing the pilot, Tim McCormack, on Monday. The Agusta A109E helicopter, flying in a rainstorm in tightly controlled airspace, crashed 11 minutes after taking off from a heliport on Manhattan's east side. No injuries were reported to people in the building or on the ground. The cause of the crash is under investigation, with the Federal Aviation Administration stating it did not handle the flight, but a pilot with local knowledge and experience was identified as the victim.

site_title: Stink bugs could be unleashed to battle China's fall armyworms
summary: Chinese scientists are exploring the use of predatory stink bugs to control fall armyworms, which threaten to devastate the country's grain crops. The stink bug, Arma chinensis, is a natural enemy of the caterpillar and can exterminate up to 41 larvae per day. A field trial in Yunnan province found the stink bug's killing powers to be impressive. Researchers plan to breed 10 million stink bugs annually to sustainably manage the pest, reducing reliance on pesticides. The fall armyworm has already affected 18 provinces in China, with predictions it will spread to the entire country's grain-producing area in the next year.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,202.69, up 0.46% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon, with the Straits Times index up 0.46% or 14.58 points to 3,202.69. Advancers outnumbered decliners 177 to 127, with Genting Singapore leading gains. Banking stocks rose, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB. CapitaLand gained 3.02% after announcing the sale of three Chinese malls.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CapitaLand agreed to sell three Chinese malls to CapitaLand Retail China Trust for 2.96 billion yuan. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US's surprise tariff announcement, seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia plans to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Other news includes Citigroup's target of 1,150 for the global equity index by mid-2026 and Thai Prime Minister Thaksin's confidence in his daughter's suspension being cleared. The UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: Huawei executive says goal to be world's top phone maker some time off
summary: Huawei executive Shao Yang says the company's goal to become the world's top phone maker may take longer than expected. Originally aiming to achieve this in the fourth quarter of 2019, Huawei now believes it will need more time due to US sanctions that barred it from doing business with US companies without government approval. Despite this, Huawei still sells 500,000 to 600,000 smartphones daily, and analysts estimate the sanctions could push its smartphone shipments down by a quarter this year.

site_title: Delay the 'dot plot'? Federal Reserve policymakers face communications quandary
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers are considering delaying the release of their "dot plot" interest rate projections to avoid giving analysts a sneak peek of future policy. The chart, released quarterly, sometimes overshadows the monetary policy statement, causing confusion. A compromise to delay its release is being explored, but a resolution is unlikely until next year, amid broader discussions of improving Fed communications.

site_title: Amazon dethrones Google as top global brand: survey
summary: US retail giant Amazon has become the world's most valuable brand, surpassing Google and Apple, according to a survey by global market research agency Kantar. Amazon's brand value surged 52% to $315 billion, driven by key acquisitions, superior customer services, and a disruptive business model.
