The Seattle-based company's growth shows no signs of slowing, with the top ten companies dominated by US firms. Alibaba, a Chinese e-commerce leader, beat Tencent to become the most valuable Chinese brand for the first time.

site_title: Citi launches co-branded credit cards with Grab in push for more customers
summary: Citi has launched co-branded credit cards with ride-hailing firm Grab in a push to boost its Asian customer base by 13%. The cards will be issued in the Philippines and Thailand, with plans to expand to other Southeast Asian markets. This partnership follows Citi's strategy to offer its products within online ecosystems, where consumers spend more time on smartphones. The move aims to increase Citi's customer base in Asia from 16 million to 18 million in the next few years.

site_title: China to boost funding support for projects as economy slows
summary: China plans to allow local governments to use proceeds from special bonds as capital for major investment projects, aiming to support its slowing economy amid a trade war with the US. Local governments can invest in projects such as highways, gas and power supply, and railways, with the goal of increasing effective investment and stabilizing demand. The move aims to strengthen macro-policy coordination and maintain market liquidity. China's economy, which slowed to a 28-year low in 2018, is expected to continue cooling this year.

site_title: Deskera, Funding Societies team up to offer digital financing solutions for SMEs
summary: Deskera, a cloud company, has partnered with Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer financing platform, to offer digital financing solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The partnership integrates Deskera's cloud-based product suite with Funding Societies' platform, allowing SMEs to apply for funds quickly without paperwork. Funding Societies uses this information to approve loans, providing quick cash flow to SMEs. The partnership offers various loan options, including invoice financing, property-backed loans, and business term loans, with interest rates ranging from 6 to 16%. Both companies are based in Singapore.

site_title: Viking Offshore calls for trading halt; Court hearing of winding up proceedings scheduled for June 14
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine (VOM) has called for a trading halt due to winding up proceedings against the company by individual Wang Qi, who is seeking S$800,000 in a loan. The hearing was initially set for May 31 but has been adjourned to June 14. VOM had initially agreed to the loan but claimed further demands from Wang and her husband, Zhang Yi, owner of China Stem Cell Group Shanghai Biotech Co., were unreasonable. The company's shares were unchanged at S$0.004 prior to the halt.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares gain as US-Mexico deal eases trade worries
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% on Tuesday, driven by a boost in sentiment after the US-Mexico tariff agreement eased global trade tensions. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 81.10 points to 6,525.00, with mining and financial stocks leading the gain. A jump in China's iron ore prices also boosted miners. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 1% to 10,128.97.

site_title: Hong Kong leader defiant as city gears up for fresh protests, strikes
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Carrie Lam, is pushing ahead with a proposed extradition law despite mass protests and strikes, including transport disruptions and picnics. Hundreds of thousands protested against the bill two days ago, citing concerns about China's alleged human rights abuses. The bill is set for a second round of debate on Wednesday, with a pro-Beijing majority controlling the Legislative Council. The city's economy is bracing for more disruptions, with nearly 2,000 shops, schools, and workers announcing strikes.

site_title: China central bank to issue bills in Hong Kong to stabilise weakening yuan
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, announced plans to sell yuan-denominated bills in Hong Kong in late June to stabilize the weakening yuan. The yuan has dropped 2.6% since May, its worst monthly performance in 10 months, amid the Sino-US trade dispute. The bill auction aims to improve the yuan bond yield curve and counteract depreciation expectations. The move is seen as a warning against yuan short-sellers and a signal to stabilize the currency. The central bank has set a tight range for the official midpoint fixing, which has been persistently firmer than market consensus.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said on early Tuesday it will sell yuan-denominated bills in Hong Kong in late June, in a move that some market analysts believed was aimed at stemming a sharp decline in the yuan currency.

site_title: Diet for one? Scientists stalk the dream of personalised nutrition
summary: Scientists have made significant progress in understanding personalized nutrition, with a new study revealing that genetic differences play a limited role in how individuals process fats and carbohydrates. The Predict study, involving 1,000 participants, found that environmental factors such as sleep, stress, and gut microbiome diversity are more important in determining metabolism. The study's findings suggest that personalized nutrition advice, rather than one-size-fits-all dietary guidelines, could improve public health. While the study's results are promising, experts caution that further research is needed to validate its findings and ensure its potential impact on preventing diet-related diseases.

site_title: China may allow more meat imports to fill gap left by pig fever
summary: China is considering lifting restrictions on importing buffalo meat from India, live cows and sheep from Mongolia, and pork from Russia to address potential pork shortages caused by African swine fever. The move aims to boost domestic meat production and reduce smuggling. China's pork production may decline 30% in 2019 due to the outbreak, which could be equivalent to Europe's entire annual supply. The country is also expected to expedite the resumption of UK beef imports, which had been delayed since 2018.

site_title: Nuclear stalemate one year after Trump-Kim summit: analysts
summary: A year after the historic Trump-Kim summit in Singapore, diplomatic efforts to denuclearize North Korea remain stalled. The second meeting in Hanoi ended in failure, with the US and North Korea unable to agree on what Pyongyang would give up in exchange for sanctions relief. Analysts say the two sides have sobered up, and the stalemate is likely to continue unless both sides can come to grips with the reasons for the impasse. Pyongyang has accused Washington of acting in "bad faith," while US officials have expressed frustration over the North's silence.

site_title: Malaysia's April factory output rises 4.0% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index rose 4.0% in April from a year earlier, beating the 2.7% median estimate by nine economists. The growth was driven by gains in the electricity, manufacturing, and mining sectors, with electricity output rising 5.8% and the manufacturing sector index increasing 4.3%. This surpasses the 3.1% growth in March. Malaysia's exports also rose unexpectedly in April, after two consecutive months of declines.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.31% to 3,197.90
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.31% to 3,197.90 on Tuesday, driven by positive US and European market sessions. The Straits Times Index gained 9.79 points, with 23.4 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 68-35, led by Golden Agri-Resources, DBS Group Holdings, and CapitaLand. Other index stocks, such as Singtel and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, also saw gains.

site_title: Irish fiscal watchdog urges 'prudence account' for corporate tax windfall
summary: The Irish Fiscal Advisory Council recommends that the government set aside part of its corporate tax revenue, as the high levels of revenue are temporary and should not be used for current spending. The council estimates that 3-6 billion euros of the 10.4 billion euros raised by corporate taxes in 2018 are excess and should be placed in a "prudence account" to limit government spending. This move aims to ensure fiscal sustainability and avoid over-reliance on corporate tax revenue.

site_title: Sarine Tech's partner programme traces diamond supply-chain online
summary: Sarine Technologies has launched a partner programme allowing retailers to source certified diamonds from a group of suppliers and track their journey online. The programme uses verifiable imagery and information, with 15 initial approved suppliers. Each diamond comes with a provenance report, including a 3D-printed model and interactive documentary, to boost authenticity. CEO David Block expects significant growth for the programme, which will enable retailers to integrate reports into their sales experience.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with fresh gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with fresh gains on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.39% to 27,685.59. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, driven by investor interest in the China-US trade saga. The gains come despite US President Trump's latest tariff threats, which have been brushed off by traders.

site_title: At Men's Fashion Week in London, less angst, more celebration
summary: London's Men's Fashion Week showcased a mix of designs, with many collections focusing on unity and coexistence amidst Britain's divided society. Designers such as Alexander McQueen, Charles Jeffrey, and Martine Rose presented collections that blended heritage with modern twists, while exploring themes of identity and community. Meanwhile, newcomers like Samuel Ross and Craig Green made a strong impression with their refined and commercial takes on luxury streetwear and utilitarian workwear. The event offered a respite from the country's Brexit uncertainty, with many designs celebrating British culture and heritage.

site_title: UK construction firms report smaller orderbooks: Bibby Financial
summary: British construction firms report a 30% decrease in pipeline work, with 19 weeks of projects to fall back on, down from 27 weeks last year. Brexit and the collapse of larger contractors, such as Interserve and Carillion, are major concerns. Many subcontractors have not prepared for Brexit, citing it as the most commonly cited threat. The sector is also affected by late payment problems and the dominance of large contractors, leading to a slowdown in annual growth to 2.4% in April.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.33 points to 1,655.80. Volume reached 28 million lots worth RM10.38 million, with 86 gainers surpassing 36 losers. The market's performance follows a global trend, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks near record highs despite tariff threats.

site_title: Japan PM Abe to meet Iran's Khamenei, Rouhani during visit this week: Suga
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to visit Iran from June 12-14, marking the first visit by a Japanese sitting prime minister in 41 years. Abe will meet with Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and President Hassan Rouhani amid escalating tensions between Iran and the US. The visit comes after US President Donald Trump and Abe discussed Iran, among other topics, and follows Japan's offer to help the US in dealing with the crisis. Abe's trip aims to strengthen ties between the two countries.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 0.4% in May, rising for 4th straight month: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.4% in May, marking the fourth consecutive month of gains, according to SRX Property. This increase follows a 0.8% gain in April. Price gains were led by the city fringes, with non-landed private homes rising 0.8%.

site_title: Ubisoft plays into streaming trend at E3 video game event
summary: Ubisoft unveiled a new subscription service, Uplay+, at E3, allowing players to access its library of games on personal computers for $14.99 monthly. The service will also be available on Google's Stadia streaming platform next year. The company showcased a new game, "Watch Dogs Legion," set in a post-Brexit Britain where players can recruit and play as any character in a resistance against an authoritarian regime.

site_title: Inflation rate of Singapore worker health insurance in 2018: 10%
summary: Singapore's employee medical insurance claims inflation rate is projected to rise 0.1 percentage point to 10.1% in 2019, slightly lower than the Asian average. This is the sixth highest among 11 Asian economies surveyed, with Vietnam at 14.5% and Malaysia at 13.4%. The report highlights the need for proactive integrated healthcare offerings to control future medical cost increases, particularly among high-risk groups.

site_title: China Jinjiang controlling shareholders sell 29.79% stake to China energy enterprise
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company's controlling shareholders are selling their 29.79% stake in China Green Energy to Zhejiang Energy International and Zheneng Capital Holdings Co for 1.6 billion yuan (S$322.3 million). The selling parties, Dou Zhenggang and Wei Xuefeng, have interests in 49.99% of China Green Energy. Their daughter Jennifer Wei holds 50.01% of the interests, maintaining control over the company. The sale marks a significant shift in the company's ownership structure.

site_title: Facebook to unveil new versions of Portal video chat devices this autumn
summary: Facebook plans to release new versions of its Portal video chatting devices this autumn, according to Andrew Bosworth, the company's vice-president of AR/VR. Bosworth mentioned that the new devices will have new form factors, but did not provide details on sales or features. This announcement comes after the launch of Portal in the US late last year.

site_title: Trump renews threat on French wine imports
summary: US President Donald Trump renewed his threat to impose tariffs on French wine imports, citing unfair trade barriers. Trump stated that France charges high tariffs on American wine while exporting low-priced French wine to the US. He vowed to work on opening the European market, repeating his previous accusations against France. The move comes amid rising tensions between the US and France over trade policies.

site_title: Australia business confidence bounces even as activity sags: survey
summary: Australia's business confidence rose 7 points to +7 in May, boosted by the re-election of the centre-right government and expectations of interest rate cuts. However, the National Australia Bank's index of business conditions fell 2 points to +1, below the long-run average, due to weak sales, profits, and trading conditions. Despite this, forward-looking indicators suggest the bounce in confidence may be short-lived, and conditions are unlikely to improve soon. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates by a quarter point to 1.25% amid concerns about unemployment.

site_title: Jiggs Kalra, food writer who elevated Indian fine dining, dies at 72
summary: Food writer and gastronome Jiggs Kalra, who elevated Indian fine dining and promoted local culinary traditions, died at 72 due to heart failure. Kalra's efforts to chronicle and promote Awadhi cuisine changed Indian restaurant menus worldwide, and his book "Prashad: Cooking With Indian Masters" is considered a bible of Indian cooking. He never claimed to be a chef, but his extensive research and travels yielded numerous recipe collections, and his son Zorawar Kalra continues his legacy with the Masala Library restaurant line, which serves modern Indian cuisine.

site_title: Pompeo restricts gay pride flags at embassies, US confirms
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has restricted US embassies from flying the rainbow flag of the gay pride movement on flagpoles, citing only the American flag should be flown there. Despite this, diplomats overseas were free to display rainbow flags elsewhere during Pride Month, which marked the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall uprising. The move sparked outrage among gay rights advocates, who criticized it as a "blatant attack on LGBTI rights" and demanded the Trump administration explain the decision.

images.alt_text: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has barred US embassies from flying the rainbow flag of the gay pride movement on flagpoles, the State Department confirmed on Monday after criticism.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on uncertainty over trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on June 11, 2019, due to uncertainty over US-China trade tensions. US President Donald Trump warned that he would impose huge new tariffs on China if Xi Jinping does not attend the G-20 summit on June 28-29. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 0.22% to 21,088.48, while the Topix index was down 0.10%. Trump's comments raised concerns about the potential for further US tariffs on Chinese imports, which could have a significant impact on global markets.

site_title: Alibaba picks CICC, Credit Suisse to lead Hong Kong offer: sources
summary: Alibaba has selected China International Capital Corp (CICC) and Credit Suisse Group AG to lead a planned Hong Kong share sale, which could raise up to $20 billion. The offering would be Hong Kong's largest share sale since 2010, and Alibaba aims to preserve its existing governance structure. The company plans to file a formal listing application with the Hong Kong stock exchange in the coming weeks. This deal could bolster Hong Kong's status as a destination for Chinese tech listings and boost Alibaba's cash pile amid a costly war with Meituan Dianping.

site_title: South Korean firm Yanolja that reinvented love hotels gets Booking, GIC funding
summary: Yanolja, a South Korean firm that reinvented love hotels, has secured US$180 million in funding from Booking Holdings Inc and Singapore's GIC, valuing the company at over US$1 billion. The company aims to go public as early as next year, capitalizing on the globalization of short-stay accommodation. Yanolja's modern, franchised love hotels have transformed the industry, drawing in guests who previously avoided them due to stigma. The firm plans to expand globally, entering the Southeast Asian market and competing with Indian budget hotel operator Oyo.

images.alt_text: Yanolja's gentrification of South Korean love hotels has brought the company a valuation of more than US$1 billion from investors keen to capitalise on the globalisation of a novel approach to short-stay accommodation, its chief executive told Reuters.

site_title: Trump renews Mexico tariff threat amid row over migration deal
summary: US President Donald Trump renewed his threat to impose tariffs on Mexico, citing a need to address the migration deal between the two countries. The deal, which Mexico agreed to review in 45 days, includes provisions to bolster security on Mexico's southern border and expand its policy of taking back asylum-seekers. Trump accused Mexico of not fully disclosing the deal's terms, including a "safe third country agreement" that would require migrants to apply for asylum in Mexico rather than the US. The agreement has drawn criticism from human rights groups, and markets breathed a sigh of relief after Trump granted a reprieve from tariffs three days earlier.

site_title: CapitaLand to sell 3 China malls for 2.96b yuan to CapitaLand Retail China Trust
summary: CapitaLand is selling its entire stake in three Chinese malls to CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) for 2.96 billion yuan (S$589.2 million), generating proceeds of around S$239.9 million and a net gain of about S$37.6 million for CapitaLand. The transaction is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2019, with CRCT expanding its portfolio and diversifying its footprint in China. The acquisition is expected to be yield-accretive and increase CRCT's distribution per unit, with the malls having a total gross floor area of 248,282 square meters and a 99% average occupancy rate.

site_title: Euro falls back from 2 1/2-month highs
summary: The euro fell 0.2% to US$1.1306, reversing its 2 1/2-month highs, after European Central Bank policymakers hinted at cutting interest rates if the bloc's economy stagnates. The move was driven by a US-Mexico deal on migration and a weakening dollar. The euro had surged last week after the ECB indicated it would keep interest rates steady until mid-2020.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, CRCT, Sarine Tech, JEP, UMS, Aoxin Q&M Dental, Eneco Energy
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks saw new developments on Tuesday, including CapitaLand's sale of three Chinese shopping malls to CRCT for S$589.2 million, generating S$239.9 million for CapitaLand and a net gain of S$37.6 million. Sarine Technologies launched a diamond sourcing program. JEP Holdings and UMS Holdings faced criticism from an independent financial adviser over their offer terms, with JEP Holdings advised to reject the offer. Aoxin Q&M Dental Group entered into revised non-compete agreements, and Eneco Energy appointed an independent reviewer to investigate a payment made to an Indonesian broker.

site_title: Quebec will not invest in Bombardier's regional jet programme: minister
summary: Quebec's economy minister, Pierre Fitzgibbon, has ruled out investing in Bombardier's regional jet programme, citing concerns over job protection in the aerospace sector. The programme, which is assembled near Montreal, has struggled with weak sales. Mitsubishi Heavy Industries has been in talks to buy the programme, but no decision has been made. Fitzgibbon stated that investing $2 billion in the programme would be "foolish" and instead plans to work with Bombardier to maintain employment in the aerospace sector.

site_title: Huawei denies being bound by Chinese spy laws
summary: Huawei's cyber security chief, John Suffolk, told the UK parliament that the company is not obligated to spy for Beijing under Chinese laws. Suffolk stated that Huawei has consulted its attorneys and Chinese advisers, who have confirmed that there is no requirement to conduct foreign intelligence work. The company has been working with the UK government on cyber security threats since 2010 and provides the most advanced 5G technology in the world. Suffolk's testimony came as the UK prepares to publish guidelines for the rollout of 5G networks, amid concerns over Chinese laws on domestic companies' cooperation with the government on security matters.

site_title: Watergate figure Dean details Trump-Nixon parallels
summary: John Dean, former White House counsel for Richard Nixon, told Congress that there are "remarkable" similarities between Nixon's illegal behavior and alleged acts of obstruction by Donald Trump. Dean cited parallels in obstruction of justice, particularly involving former White House counsel Don McGahn, who was a main source for the Mueller investigation. Dean's testimony came as congressional Democrats debate impeaching Trump, who responded with an angry attack on Twitter, calling Dean a "sleazebag attorney" and denying any wrongdoing.

site_title: US renews concern on Hong Kong extradition law after mass protests
summary: The US State Department has renewed concerns over Hong Kong's extradition law, urging the territory to engage with residents and stakeholders on the issue. The department expressed opposition to the law, citing massive protests that showed widespread public opposition. The law could damage Hong Kong's business environment and expose US citizens to China's judicial system. The US calls on Hong Kong authorities to consult a broad range of stakeholders to address the concerns. The continued erosion of the one-country, two-systems framework poses a risk to Hong Kong's special international status.

site_title: Plastic straws and bags no more: Canada aims to clean up its act
summary: Canada plans to ban single-use plastics like straws, bags, and cutlery by early 2021 to reduce non-recyclable waste and protect oceans. The move follows similar actions by the European Parliament and comes amid a national election where climate change and pollution are top issues. Less than 10% of plastic in Canada is recycled, and an estimated $11 billion worth of plastic will be thrown away annually by 2030 without change. The government has delayed implementation to allow for a science-based decision and give businesses time to adjust.

site_title: Pompeo to boost ties with Modi on India visit
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo plans to visit India on June 24 to strengthen ties with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, focusing on cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region and defense. Pompeo aims to "broaden our partnership" with Modi's India, which has supported growing US-India cooperation. However, trade tensions remain, with the US imposing sanctions on India over its energy imports from Iran and Venezuela. Pompeo will also visit Sri Lanka to express solidarity after Easter Sunday attacks, and join President Trump at the Group of 20 summit in Osaka.

site_title: Oil falls 1% amid US-China trade dispute, uncertainty on supply cuts
summary: US-China trade tensions continue to impact oil prices, with Brent crude futures falling 1.6% to $62.29 a barrel and US WTI crude losing 1.4% to $53.26 a barrel. US President Donald Trump is ready to impose additional tariffs on Chinese imports if no trade deal is reached at the Group of 20 summit. Major oil producers Saudi Arabia and Russia have yet to agree on extending an output-cutting deal, contributing to the bearish market outlook.

site_title: Europe: FCA-Renault deal hopes, Mexico tariff relief lift shares
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by trade relief after the US and Mexico struck a deal to avoid tariffs on Mexican goods, and signs of revived merger talks between Fiat Chrysler and Renault. US President Donald Trump abandoned plans to impose a 5% tariff on Mexican goods, boosting investor sentiment. Despite this, concerns about the Sino-US trade conflict kept sentiment in check, and European stocks fell nearly 6% in May, their worst month in over two years.

site_title: Japan's Q1 GDP grows at faster pace, but trade war blunts outlook
summary: Japan's economy grew 2.2% in Q1, stronger than initially estimated, thanks to increased capital spending. However, analysts warn that global trade tensions, particularly the US-China trade war, remain a significant drag on growth and pose risks to the export-reliant nation. Consumer spending remains weak, and a worsening sentiment among employees suggests caution among consumers. The government plans to proceed with a sales tax hike despite concerns, citing stimulus steps to mitigate its effects.

site_title: Synagie partners WeChat vendor to help SMEs tap China's social e-commerce market
summary: Synagie, an e-commerce solutions vendor, has partnered with Weimob, a WeChat solutions provider, to enter China's social e-commerce market. The partnership aims to help SMEs in Singapore and South-east Asia break into China's social e-commerce market. Synagie will create an end-to-end solution covering commerce value-chain, including setting up WeChat official accounts, digital store management, and smart supply chain. The Singapore Exchange saw a 46% increase in derivatives traded in May, while the US Treasury Secretary stated that freeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from US control would require significant changes to the nation's housing finance system.

site_title: The expertise and experience of retail brokers should be valued
summary: DBS Bank plans to transfer its retail stockbroking trading arm to the main bank by end-2019, sparking debate about the fate of remisiers. The move is seen as a response to declining commissions, the rise of online trading, and changing investor demands. Remisiers argue that their experience and loyalty should be valued, while others see their service as archaic and irrelevant. The issue has been ongoing for 20 years, with declining commissions and increased competition from online platforms contributing to the marginalization of remisiers.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Impossible Foods via Deliveroo
summary: Claressa from Money FM's podcast "Coffee with Claressa" discussed Impossible Foods via Deliveroo. The conversation centered on the growing demand for plant-based food options in Singapore. Claressa highlighted the challenges faced by Deliveroo in partnering with Impossible Foods, but ultimately concluded that their collaboration could lead to increased adoption of plant-based food. The discussion also touched on the potential for startups to drive innovation in the food industry.

site_title: Record London tech funding shows huge gap with rest of UK
summary: London's technology sector attracted a record £2.56 billion in venture capital investment through May 31, 2019, accounting for four-fifths of the UK's £3.17 billion in technology VC funding for the year. Despite cities like Cambridge and Edinburgh also being hubs for tech firms, London's dominance highlights the need to develop a more diverse industry to maintain its position as a global leader. Concerns about the UK's competitiveness and north-south divide remain, with mounting evidence of economic disparities between the regions.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on Mexico immigration accord
summary: US stocks rose for the sixth consecutive session, driven by a deal between the US and Mexico to address illegal immigration, which boosted risk assets and led to gains in equities globally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all rose, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.1%. However, trade tensions with China remain, with US President Trump warning of new tariffs if Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping doesn't attend the G-20 summit.

images.alt_text: The Dow advanced for the sixth straight session on Monday with leading banking and technology companies gaining after the US called off planned tariffs on Mexico.

site_title: Mnuchin dashes investor dreams of quick Fannie-Freddie windfall
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated that freeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac from US control won't happen without a major overhaul of the nation's housing finance system. This move potentially dashes investors' hopes for a quick windfall from their stakes in the mortgage giants. Mnuchin emphasized that the administration won't let the companies build up their capital buffers without a legislative fix, casting doubt on the administration's ambitious plans for reform.

site_title: SGX derivatives traded volume surges 46% in May on trade-war woes
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 46% surge in derivatives traded volume in May, driven by global investors seeking to manage Asian exposures and macro risks amid trade-war woes. Trading volumes of SGX FTSE China A50 Index futures spiked 82% year on year, while SGX iron ore derivatives volumes surged 87%. Defensive sectors and share buybacks were also notable, with institutional investors favoring communication services, Reits, and consumer staples.

site_title: Economic rebound seen in Saudi Arabia, UAE
summary: Business conditions in Saudi Arabia and the UAE have shown significant improvement, signaling a possible economic recovery in the Arab world's two largest economies. In May, Emirates NBD Purchasing Managers' Index rose to its highest since 2017, surpassing the 50 threshold separating contraction from growth. The UAE's index reached 59.4, while Saudi Arabia's reached 57.3, indicating a possible shift towards growth. This improvement may be a positive sign for the region's economy, which has faced challenges in recent years.

site_title: Nissan could hold the key to restarting FCA-Renault merger: sources
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) and Renault are exploring ways to revive their collapsed merger plan, with Nissan Motor Co Ltd poised to urge Renault to significantly reduce its 43.4% stake in the Japanese company. In exchange, Nissan may support the FCA-Renault tie-up. The deal, which was withdrawn after the French government blocked a vote by Renault's board, could create the world's third-largest carmaker with five billion euros in promised annual synergies. However, Renault has threatened to block key governance reforms, and Nissan is likely to press for a substantial reduction in Renault's stake, potentially leading to a breakthrough or stalemate.

site_title: British candidates for PM take aim at favourite Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has stepped down, and 11 candidates have launched their campaigns to replace her. The candidates, including Boris Johnson, promise to solve the Brexit crisis, with most vowing to secure a deal by the end of July. Johnson is the bookmakers' favorite, but his rivals have taken aim at his pledge to raise income tax to 80,000 pounds annually. The Conservative Party's 1922 Committee will hold the first round of voting on Thursday to narrow the field, with the winner expected to be in place by the end of July.

site_title: Fiat teams up with Silicon Valley's Aurora on self-driving vehicles
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has partnered with Silicon Valley startup Aurora Innovation Inc to develop and deploy a fleet of self-driving commercial vehicles in the US. The deal integrates Aurora's self-driving platform into FCA's commercial vehicle lines, aiming to catch up with other carmakers investing in autonomous technology. The partnership comes as FCA faces competition and financial uncertainty, following the collapse of talks to merge with Renault SA. FCA's CEO, Mike Manley, stated the partnership will address customer needs in a rapidly changing industry.

site_title: Monetary loosening 'may be enough for Asia-Pac economies for now'
summary: Most Asia-Pacific economies may not need fiscal stimulus unless a full-blown trade war between the US and China escalates, economists say. Monetary loosening may suffice for now, with some countries, like Malaysia and the Philippines, having already cut policy rates and reserve requirements. However, if trade tensions worsen, economies like South Korea and Taiwan may need fiscal support, and Singapore may introduce targeted stimulus measures to mitigate the impact on local exporters. Economists expect rate cuts in several countries, including the Reserve Bank of Australia, Bank Indonesia, and the US, to address global market risks and chronically below-target inflation.

site_title: Asia markets close higher on positive signs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to close at 3,188.11, driven by positive market sentiment due to the US suspending Mexico tariff plans, hopes of US Federal Reserve rate cuts, and better-than-expected Chinese trade data. Other Asia-Pacific markets, including Australia, China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Malaysia, also closed higher. Local tech stocks rebounded, with some companies seeing significant gains, and property developers benefited from cheaper borrowing. Market analysts attributed the risk-on sentiment to the easing of trade tensions and the possibility of Fed rate cuts.

site_title: Some innovation strategies for Singapore SMEs
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges in an increasingly competitive business environment, with failure to innovate and meet customer needs being a major risk. The government has launched initiatives such as the "Go Digital" programme and the Automation Support Package to help SMEs innovate and grow. Expanding beyond the domestic market, finding creative financing solutions, and mitigating liquidity risks are key strategies for SMEs to thrive. Despite government support, SMEs still need to find innovative ways to stay relevant in a rapidly changing business world.

site_title: United Technologies, Raytheon merger will create US$121b firm
summary: United Technologies and Raytheon agreed to merge, forming a US$121 billion conglomerate that spans commercial aviation and defense procurement. The deal, expected to close in 2020, will create a new company led by United Technologies CEO Greg Hayes and Raytheon CEO Tom Kennedy. The combined business is expected to generate over US$1 billion in cost synergies and return US$18-US$20 billion to shareholders in the first three years. The merger aims to create a more competitive landscape, but may face opposition from Boeing, Airbus, and the Pentagon, which could seek concessions from suppliers.

site_title: Favourite Johnson vows tax cut as race to succeed PM May starts
summary: Boris Johnson vows to cut tax rates for higher earners if he becomes Britain's next prime minister, with a proposed cut to 40% income tax threshold from £50,000 to £80,000. The pledge, which would cost £9.6 billion annually, is part of his campaign to succeed Theresa May, who stepped down as leader on Friday. The Conservative leadership race, dominated by Brexit, has narrowed the field, with Johnson seen as the clear favourite among party members and bookmakers.

site_title: APAC Realty invests in proptech startup
summary: APAC Realty, a Singapore-based real estate company, has invested S$1 million in proptech startup Dots Connected through a three-year convertible note. The investment comes with no interest and allows for conversion into equity. This move aims to support the growth of proptech in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Monetary loosening 'may be enough for Asia-Pac economies for now'
summary: Asian economies, particularly those in the Asia-Pacific region, may not need to rely heavily on monetary loosening due to their relatively low policy rates, but could benefit from fiscal stimulus. If trade tensions persist, governments and central banks may introduce stimulus measures and ease monetary policy. Regional exporters, such as Taiwan and South Korea, may benefit from fiscal support, including income tax rebates, lower trade financing costs, and tax deductions for machinery investments. Some Asian economies, like Singapore, are in a strong fiscal position to implement countercyclical policies if needed.

site_title: Shooting beyond wedding photos
summary: Annabel Law, a female wedding photographer, initially faced misconceptions about women taking up photography professionally. However, in recent years, more women have entered the field, changing the industry. Law's experience serves as a testament to the growing presence of women in photography.

site_title: Trump shoots himself in the foot in Mexican standoff
summary: US President Donald Trump tweeted a statement claiming Mexico had agreed to buy large quantities of agricultural products from American farmers, but the statement was later revealed to be false. The tweet was seen as a "Mexican standoff" where Trump threatened tariffs on Mexico unless they agreed to his demands, but ultimately backed down after Mexico reiterated its existing promises. This move has weakened the US' credibility and respect on the world stage, and experts warn that Trump's threats may not be taken seriously by other countries, including China and Europe.

site_title: Q3 business outlook ticks up after falls in 3 straight quarters
summary: Singapore's business sentiment improved slightly in Q3 2019, with the Business Optimism Index rising to +6.91 percentage points, up from +5.08 in Q2. The services sector, particularly domestic-oriented firms in health, education, and social services, remained resilient. However, the financial services sector lost ground, and construction and manufacturing saw declining indicators. Despite the slight rebound, economists remain cautious due to ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertain global growth outlook.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Revez Corporation has resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board after a trade suspension. The company completed its acquisition of Revez Group, a creative technology provider, in a reverse takeover deal. Revez Corp will specialize in new technology, immersive multimedia, and artificial intelligence. Eneco Energy appointed an independent external reviewer to investigate a payment made by a subsidiary to an Indonesian broker, following a discovery by its independent auditors Ernst & Young.

site_title: Bulls beware: The 2020 oil market is turning ugly
summary: Oil prices are expected to decline in 2020 due to persistent surpluses, not the deficit predicted earlier. Rising shale production, a slowing global economy, and the prospect of a deepening trade war are the main culprits. Oil consultants and traders forecast supply exceeding consumption, with some predicting a surplus of 800,000 barrels per day. This bearish outlook poses a problem for the Opec+ alliance, which may be forced to extend output cuts to prevent a surge in global oil inventories.

site_title: Cleaner gold mining from breakthrough technology
summary: Clean Mining, an Australian tech firm, has launched a patented technology that eliminates the use of toxic chemical cyanide in gold mining. The process uses a non-toxic reagent containing thiosulphate to recover gold, comparable to cyanide usage, and can dry stack tailings, eliminating the need for tailings dams. The technology has shown promising results in a pilot test in Western Australia, and the company is in talks with four to five gold mining corporations to adopt the solution, which could help increase the supply of gold while complying with regulations.

site_title: Kheng Leong buys property in Jalan Besar conservation area for S$38.71m
summary: A fully-owned unit of Kheng Leong Company has bought a building near Lavender Street in Singapore for S$38.71 million, planning to turn it into apartments with commercial units on the ground floor. The property, with 20,100 sq ft of freehold land, can have a maximum GFA of 60,301 sq ft. Kheng Leong plans to build 50-60 residential units and commercial spaces, with a potential launch in the next year.

site_title: Google made US$4.7b off the news industry's work in 2018: study
summary: Google generated $4.7 billion from news publishers' work in 2018 through search and Google News, surpassing the combined ticket sales of the last two Avengers movies. The News Media Alliance, representing over 2,000 newspapers, argues that journalists deserve a cut of this revenue. According to the alliance's president, David Chavern, this highlights the need for fair compensation for news creators.

site_title: Pets tops X-Men in tale of underperforming sequels
summary: The Secret Life of Pets 2 and Dark Phoenix, two underperforming sequels, led ticket sales in the US box office over the weekend. The Secret Life of Pets 2 took the top spot with $47.1 million in ticket sales, while Dark Phoenix sold $33 million. Both films fell short of expectations, with The Secret Life of Pets 2 earning less than half of its predecessor's opening weekend. The X-Men sequel Dark Phoenix, which cost $200 million to make, also underperformed, with a 22% fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

site_title: How the US might go about tackling the rise of China
summary: The US may need to reassess its approach to China, as "getting tough" could accelerate its own relative decline and hand China a semi-hegemony. Tariffs, trade bans, and other measures may inflict significant damage on the US, while China would suffer less. The US should instead focus on domestic reforms, such as improving its high-tech sector, healthcare system, and infrastructure, to demonstrate its competitiveness and ability to govern effectively. By addressing its internal challenges, the US can regain respect and diplomatic power to forge a constructive relationship with China.

site_title: 'Big Bang reforms' must not fizzle out
summary: The new Modi government has announced plans for "Big Bang reforms" to address unemployment and slowing economic growth, but its effectiveness remains uncertain. The proposed reforms include changes to labor laws, privatization, and creation of land banks for new industrial development. Critics argue that previous promises, such as "Make in India," have failed to materialize, and that the government's record on job creation and economic growth is mixed. The government's ability to deliver on its promise will depend on its ability to correct past mistakes and institute genuine reforms.

site_title: How a real estate concept as old as the Middle Ages can still backfire
summary: A mortgage broker and real estate agent, Robert Herr, shares his regret over buying a quarter-share in a beachfront condo, citing the high costs and aggravation of owning a portion of a property. He opted for a timeshare, which allowed him to use the property for 13 weeks and cover his costs. This concept, dating back to the Middle Ages, can still backfire due to its limitations and potential for financial strain. Herr's experience highlights the risks associated with investing in a timeshare.

site_title: Emerging markets spoil IMF optimism
summary: The International Monetary Fund's optimism about emerging markets rebounding in the second half of 2019 is misplaced due to several factors. Argentina's currency crisis and Turkish economic issues are unlikely to be resolved soon, and Brazil's public finances are on an unsustainable path. The IMF's expectation of early resolutions may be unrealistic, and the global economy may need alternative solutions, such as resolving the US-China trade dispute. This suggests that the IMF's hopes for a world economic revival may be misguided.

site_title: Kuroda says BOJ has enough ammunition, wary of side effects
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank has enough ammunition to deliver further monetary stimulus if necessary, but must be cautious of side effects on the financial system. Kuroda emphasized the economy's health and that the BOJ doesn't need to act now, but will respond swiftly if momentum toward its 2% inflation target is lost. The yen weakened after the remarks, and analysts expect the BOJ to lower its negative interest rate to -0.3% in September. Kuroda cited four policy options, including cutting the negative rate further or boosting asset purchases, to achieve its inflation target.

site_title: Q3 hiring in Singapore 'stable but weaker than elsewhere in Asia-Pac'
summary: Singapore's Q3 hiring prospects are expected to be stable but weaker than in other Asia-Pacific economies, with 15% of employers planning to add staff, 3% expecting a decrease, and 77% making no change. The island nation's net employment outlook remains stable at +12%, unchanged from the previous quarter. Japan and Taiwan anticipate the strongest hiring activity, while employers in all seven industry sectors expect to add staff. Large companies report a +59% net employment outlook, while small firms expect a +12% increase.

site_title: Green bonds for a climate-resilient future

The IFC aims to catalyze $13 billion annually for climate-friendly projects by 2020, with the goal of supporting climate action in emerging markets. The market's growth is driven by strategic partnerships between IFC and institutional investors, as well as pioneering initiatives in local capital markets and renewable energy.

site_title: IFAs give their verdicts on offers for JEP, 800 Super Holdings

The offer for JEP Holdings closes on June 24, while the 800 Super Holdings offer closes on the same day.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit regains control of Paris site, to receive compensation from govt
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (E-Reit) has regained control of its Paris logistics property, Parc des Docks, after the French government agreed to compensate the trust for lost rental income. The government will pay 907,128 euros (S$1.4 million) for marketing and leasing activities halted during deliberations on expropriation. The trust has renewed marketing efforts, with strong interest from logistics and e-commerce businesses, and expects a substantial increase in occupancy rate and rental reversion due to the property's accessibility and proximity to Paris's central business district.

site_title: London will need more than pomp to woo Donald Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's recent visit to the UK, centered around the 75th anniversary of D-Day, was seen as a promising start to new US-UK ties. However, concerns remain over Trump's "America First" agenda, which may prioritize his own interests over core UK concerns. Key areas of potential disagreement include trade, security, and defence, particularly on issues like Huawei and Russia. Despite this, both governments hope the visit may breathe new life into the "special relationship" and pave the way for a post-Brexit trade deal.

site_title: Trump believes China will make trade deal, but tariffs ready

Trump expressed readiness to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Osaka summit, but China has not confirmed the meeting.

site_title: US consumers' inflation view weakest since late 2017
summary: US consumers' inflation expectations have weakened to their lowest levels since 2017, according to a Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey. The one-year inflation outlook fell to 2.5% and the three-year inflation measure decreased to 2.6%. This weakening may influence the Federal Reserve's decision on lowering interest rates to boost US price growth towards the 2% goal. The survey's decline also reflects uncertainty in consumers' views on jobs and family finances.

site_title: G-20 puts onus on US and China to solve their trade row
summary: The Group of 20 finance ministers' statement notes that trade tensions have intensified, raising risks to global growth, and puts the onus on the US and China to solve their trade dispute. The US and China have levied tariffs on each other's goods amid negotiations to address unfair trade practices. The G-20 statement stopped short of calling for a resolution to the US-China trade conflict, and the planned meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G-20 summit in Osaka later this month is seen as a potential opportunity for a breakthrough.

images.alt_text: Mr Moscovici hopes the US and China can reach an agreement at an upcoming G-20 leaders' summit in Osaka.

site_title: Raising SME productivity: when push comes to shove
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are increasingly relying on technology to boost productivity and sustain growth amid a challenging business environment and severe manpower crunch. The government's focus on increasing productivity and staying competitive has encouraged companies to adopt digital solutions. Industry experts highlight the need for SMEs to invest in digital tools, revamp work processes, and develop their people to stay competitive. The tightening of foreign worker quotas is seen as a signal that companies need to wean off foreign manpower more quickly.

site_title: Hudson's bay to sell Europe assets as take-private bid launched
summary: Hudson's Bay Co is selling its European operations for C$1.5 billion as a group of investors, led by Chairman Richard Baker, launches a take-private bid valued at C$1.74 billion. The offer represents a 48% premium to the retailer's closing share price. The sale will allow the company to focus on its North American operations, including Saks Fifth Avenue and Hudson's Bay. A special committee will review the proposal, and the company has formed a plan to strengthen its balance sheet by paying down a term loan.

site_title: Group of 5 Kampong Glam shophouses on sale at indicative price of S$23.8m
summary: A group of five adjoining shophouses in Singapore's Kampong Glam conservation area are up for sale at an indicative price of S$23.8 million, or S$2,970 per square foot. The sale is expected to garner interest from savvy investors and owner-occupiers seeking to benefit from future rental upside and capital appreciation.

site_title: Trump says Federal Reserve is 'very, very destructive' to economy
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve, calling it "very, very destructive" to the economy by raising interest rates too quickly. Trump claimed the Fed's actions hindered his ability to negotiate with China, but he believes the tariffs imposed on Chinese goods have given the US a competitive advantage. Despite the Fed's independent decision-making, Trump has named three Fed board members and expressed frustration with the central bank's policies. The Fed is set to announce its next policy decision next week, with some economists predicting a rate cut to support economic growth.

site_title: Eneco Energy appoints independent investigator regarding missing payment of S$3.88m
summary: Eneco Energy has appointed an independent investigator to look into a missing S$3.88 million payment made by a subsidiary to an Indonesian broker. The payment was initially recorded as due from the broker but was later written off due to queries about its recoverability. The company's independent auditors, Ernst & Young, raised concerns about the commercial rationale of the arrangement and the nature, existence, and recoverability of the amount. The identity of the investigator and the scope of the investigation will be decided by the company's audit committee.

site_title: China exports grow despite US tariffs, but imports slump most in nearly three years
summary: China's exports unexpectedly grew 1.1% in May, defying market expectations, despite US tariffs. site_title: Britain's Tesco to raise store staff wages by 10.45% over two years
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest private sector employer, announced a 10.45% pay rise for store and distribution centre staff, with hourly-paid staff to see their rate increase to £9.30 (S$16.15) by October 2020. The increase will be implemented in two stages, replacing a staff bonus with the higher hourly rate. The move is part of a two-year wage boost, with the first increase set for September 1 this year.

site_title: Trump vows to 'do something' about EU wine duties
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to "do something" about EU wine duties, criticizing France for unfair tariffs on American wine exports. Trump claimed that France charges the US high for wine while the US charges France little for its wine. The US and EU are set to begin negotiations on a trade deal, but EU officials have said they won't discuss agriculture. The US imported $4.5 billion in European wine in 2017 but only sold $553 million to Europe.

site_title: Salesforce to buy Tableau for US$15.3b in analytics push
summary: Salesforce has agreed to buy Tableau Software in an all-stock deal valued at US$15.3 billion, marking the company's largest acquisition to date. The deal aims to provide customers with more data analysis capabilities, helping Salesforce reach its annual revenue goal of US$28 billion by 2023. The acquisition positions Salesforce as a major player in the analytics market, intensifying its rivalry with Microsoft. Co-CEO Marc Benioff has been aggressively expanding the company through acquisitions, with over 60 deals in 20 years.

site_title: Renewed M&C offer lifts CDL shares 5.9% higher
summary: CDL shares rose 5.9% to S$8.97 after the company renewed its offer for all remaining shares in London-listed subsidiary M&C hotels. The offer price of 685 pence (S$11.86) per share is a 37% premium over M&C's five-year high. Analysts believe the revised offer will gain traction with minority shareholders, who felt the previous offers did not reflect the value of M&C's property portfolio. The deal is seen as attractive for CDL, which will acquire M&C's assets at a discount, and could help reposition CDL's ageing hotel assets.

site_title: China may allow more meat imports to fill gap left by pig fever
summary: China may allow more meat imports to fill potential pork shortages caused by African swine fever, according to the China Meat Association. The country may lift restrictions on buffalo meat from India, live cows and sheep from Mongolia, and pork from Russia. This move aims to reduce smuggling and address animal protein shortages, with no timetable set for the changes. China's pork production may decline 30% in 2019 due to the disease, and Beijing seeks to expand potential sources of tested and certified meat.

site_title: Singapore 2018 healthcare cost inflation hits 10%, 10 times the economic inflation rate: Mercer report
summary: Singapore's medical cost inflation reached 10% in 2018, 10 times the country's economic inflation rate of 1%, according to a Mercer report. The report highlights the need for employers to adopt proactive integrated healthcare offerings, preventive wellness measures, and early intervention to control medical costs and improve employee health and productivity.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M, Q&M Singapore to enter into revised non-compete agreements

site_title: APAC Realty to invest S$1m in proptech startup UrbanZoom parent Dots Connected

Dots Connected's AI-driven auto-valuation platform predicts residential unit values with a median error of less than 3%. APAC Realty plans to use part of its IPO proceeds to invest in Dots Connected, enhancing its technological capabilities. The investment aims to boost productivity and professionalism for ERA agents, and the company expects no material impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: London Mayor frustrated with attempts to 'make city poorer'
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan expressed frustration over the government's plan to make the city poorer, citing a record £2.56 billion in venture capital investment for tech startups in London. Despite other cities like Cambridge and Bristol also having top tech firms, London dominated the UK's technology VC funding. Khan suggested increasing powers to other cities to skill up their workforce and addressing the north-south divide in Britain, which has seen growing economic disparities.

site_title: Favourite Johnson pledges tax cut as race to succeed PM May starts
summary: Boris Johnson, a leading Brexit advocate, has pledged tax cuts for higher earners if he becomes Britain's next prime minister. Johnson, the bookmakers' clear favourite to succeed Theresa May, outlined his plans in a newspaper column and interview, including raising the point at which workers begin paying 40% income tax to £80,000. The move would cost £9.6 billion a year. Johnson's pledge comes as the contest to replace May officially kicks off, with 11 candidates vying for the position, promising to solve the Brexit conundrum in just three months.

site_title: New 'digital telcos' start to feel the burn
summary: Singapore's crowded telco market is experiencing a price war, with mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) like Circles.Life feeling the pressure. As MNOs like Singtel, StarHub, and M1 overhaul their plans to compete with MVNOs, the market is becoming increasingly homogenous. MVNOs face the challenge of standing out, as they rely on leasing frequency from MNOs, which may become a sellers' market. Despite this, MVNOs like Circles.Life and MyRepublic are exploring new markets, but may face competition from MNOs with regional presence, such as Singtel's Optus.

site_title: UMS Holdings' offer for JEP Holdings "not fair and not reasonable": IFA
summary: Independent financial adviser Provenance Capital advises JEP Holdings' independent directors to recommend rejecting UMS Holdings' S$0.15 per share offer and S$0.074 warrants offer, citing "not fair and not reasonable" financial terms. The offer represents a 12.8% discount to JEP's last traded share price and a 26.5% discount to the revalued adjusted net asset value per share. Warrant holders are advised to let the warrants lapse due to the mutually exclusive nature of the offers.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rally on expectations of Fed rate cut; auto firms zoom
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 1.31% on Monday, its third consecutive gain, driven by growing expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate cut. The domestic auto sector also benefited from Beijing's stimulus measures and a trade deal with Mexico. The KOSPI has risen 2.86% this year, reversing a 6.7% decline in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: PODCAST: How to start investing with just $100 a month (Money Hacks, Ep 46)
summary: OCBC Bank's senior investment strategist Vasu Menon shares practical tips on how to start investing with just $100 a month in a podcast series. Key takeaways include: automating investments with unit trusts, creating a simulated portfolio, and attending workshops to gain knowledge. Menon emphasizes the importance of knowledge and time diversification in a blue-chip investment plan, and advises against letting emotions affect investment decisions. The podcast aims to encourage young adults in their 20s to move beyond insurance and good bank accounts and start investing for long-term gains.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, building on pre-weekend gains. London's FTSE 100 index increased 0.4% to 7,358.16 points, while the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.3% to 5,382.29 points. The gains followed weak US jobs data and expectations of a potential Federal Reserve interest rate cut.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.14 points to 1,655.47. Volume reached 2.3 billion lots worth RM1.79 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 613 to 276, marking a positive trend.

images.alt_text: Malaysian stocks closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 6.14 points at 1,655.47.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 0.7% on Monday as risk-on sentiment returns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% on Monday, closing at 3,188.11, driven by risk-on sentiment in the region. The gains were fueled by US President Donald Trump's suspension of tariff plans on Mexico, weak US job data, and strong Chinese export data. Local tech stocks, which were heavily sold off last month, also made strong gains, with Venture Corporation and AEM Holdings rising 2% and 9.3% respectively.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit maintains rents under Ngee Ann City's Toshin master lease
summary: Starhill Global Reit has maintained the base rent under its 12-year master lease for Ngee Ann City's Toshin at unchanged levels for the next three years, starting from June 8, 2019. The lease accounts for 21.9% of the Reit's portfolio gross rent. The rent review mechanism only allows for upward adjustments, and the decision maintains the status quo.

site_title: Indonesia's May inflation at highest in over a year
summary: Indonesia's annual consumer inflation rate reached 3.32% in May, the highest since April 2018, due to increased spending during Ramadan festivities. Analysts had expected a 3.17% rate. The core inflation rate, excluding food prices, was 3.12%. Bank Indonesia's target for 2019 inflation is 2.5-4.5%. The increase in food and transportation prices contributed to the higher inflation rate.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump on speculation over US rate cut
summary: Tokyo stocks jumped 1.20% on Monday, following Wall Street's rally after a weak US jobs report bolstered expectations of a US interest rate cut. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 21,134.42, driven by bluechip exporters such as Toyota and Honda, and a strengthening dollar. The deal between the US and Mexico to avoid tariffs on Mexican goods also boosted investor confidence, according to chief strategist Masayuki Kubota.

site_title: Healthtech startup Plano raises undisclosed sum from billionaire Peter Lim
summary: Local healthtech startup Plano has raised an undisclosed sum from philanthropist and investor Peter Lim's investment holding company Meriton Capital Limited. Plano, a science-based parental application, has over 100,000 registered families worldwide and aims to expand into 10 more countries, including China and the US, within the next year.

site_title: Australia firm's breakthrough technology eliminates cyanide from gold mining
summary: Australian tech firm Clean Mining has launched a breakthrough technology to eliminate cyanide from gold mining, a toxic chemical used in ore processing. The non-toxic reagent containing thiosulphate recovers gold at a rate comparable to cyanide usage, eliminating the need for tailings dams and associated environmental risks. The technology has been tested successfully at a pilot site in Western Australia and is in talks with four to five gold mining corporations to adopt it, potentially increasing gold supply and compliance with regulations.

site_title: Group of 5 Kampong Glam shophouses on sale with S$23.8m indicative price
summary: A group of five adjoining Kampong Glam shophouses in Singapore are up for sale with an indicative price of S$23.8 million, or S$2,970 per square foot. The properties are fully tenanted with existing food and beverage approvals and offer a 60-metre triple-road frontage. The sale is expected to attract savvy investors with a medium to long-term investment horizon, seeking rental upside and capital appreciation. The expression of interest exercise closes on July 16.

site_title: Hot stock: CDL shares add 5% after renewed offer for M&C
summary: CDL shares rose 5% after the company made a renewed offer for Millennium & Copthorne hotels (M&C), a 37% premium over the previous offer. Analysts believe the revised offer will gain traction with minority shareholders, who felt previous offers undervalued M&C's property portfolio. The deal is seen as attractive for CDL, which will benefit from a 10.4% discount on M&C's net asset value and improved asset management.

site_title: Sim Lim Square goes online with new e-commerce platform amid collective sale
summary: Sim Lim Square, a popular IT mall in Singapore, is launching a new e-commerce platform on July 1, allowing its tenants to run their own online businesses. The initiative, in collaboration with local digital agency Addpetizer, aims to develop new channels for customer outreach and engagement. Currently, around 50 tenants are on board, with a goal to bring on 300 tenants, and will offer full autonomy to manage their online shops. The platform is not in response to the mall's collective sale and is seen as a bid to meet the changing buying behavior of digital-savvy customers.

site_title: Air New Zealand drops ban on staff tattoos amid discrimination concerns
summary: Air New Zealand has dropped its ban on staff having visible tattoos, citing growing acceptance and criticism that the policy discriminated against Maori employees. The ban, which restricted staff from applying for roles like flight attendants with visible tattoos, was seen as culturally insensitive, particularly among Maori people who wear tattoos as a means of cultural expression. The airline's decision comes after a five-month review of the policy, with the company's CEO stating that non-offensive tattoos will be allowed, marking a shift towards greater cultural acceptance.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,192.62, up 0.83% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.83% to 3,192.62 on Monday, driven by gains in the financial sector, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC banks advancing. Other key gainers included Rex International and Genting Singapore. The rally followed positive moves in other Asian markets, as US President Donald Trump dropped threatened tariffs against Mexico and weak US jobs data boosted expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut.

site_title: Wavemaker Partners hits US$60m first close of US$100m SEA-focused fund, bags Temasek and IFC as investors
summary: Wavemaker Partners, a venture fund focused on enterprise and deep tech startups, has reached a US$60 million first close of its US$100 million Southeast Asia-focused fund. Investors include Temasek, IFC, and family offices of Microsoft and Facebook co-founders. The fund aims to invest in 60 new startups with initial cheque sizes of US$500,000, building on the firm's existing experience and network in the region. This move allows Wavemaker to continue investing in enterprise and deep tech founders in Southeast Asia, where 81% of its investments since 2012 have been made.

site_title: Revez Corp lists on Catalist at 14.8 S cents following reverse takeover deal
summary: Revez Corp, formerly Jason Holdings, resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at 14.8 Singapore cents after a 3-year suspension. The company completed a reverse takeover deal worth S$42.7 million, acquiring creative technology provider Revez Group. Revez Corp specializes in new technology solutions and has a market capitalization of S$61 million. CEO Victor Neo expressed optimism for the company's future, citing a focus on research and development in a knowledge-driven economy.

site_title: Brazil's Lula jailed to keep him from 2018 election: report
summary: Brazil's former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva was jailed to prevent him from contesting the 2018 election, according to a report by The Intercept. Leaked documents show Justice Minister Sergio Moro collaborated with prosecutors to convict Lula on corruption charges, despite internal doubts about the evidence. Lula denies the charges, which led to his conviction and reduced prison sentence. The report claims Moro secretly collaborated to design the case against Lula, sparking accusations of political motive.

site_title: NZ: Shares edge lower, bleak China import data weigh
summary: New Zealand shares declined 0.2% on Monday, snapping three straight sessions of gains, due to disappointing Chinese import data. China's imports declined 8.5% in May, the largest drop in nearly three years, indicating weak domestic consumption. The US decision to suspend 5% tariffs on Mexican goods also lifted market sentiment. Weaker consumer demand in New Zealand's largest trading partner and the US Federal Reserve's expected policy easing were seen as negative for the South Pacific island's economy and global growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets, peso rally as Trump drop Mexico tariffs threat
summary: Asian markets rose as US President Donald Trump dropped the threat of tariffs against Mexico, while the Mexican peso rallied over 2%. The news sparked hopes of a US interest rate cut next month, with the dollar retreating against high-yielding currencies. However, the US-China trade dispute remains unresolved, and analysts warn that tensions could rise ahead of the G-20 summit. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo rose, while Singapore, Seoul, and Taipei also saw gains, with oil prices extending their gains due to Saudi Arabia and Russia's output caps.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm Group-IB opens global HQ in Singapore
summary: Cybersecurity firm Group-IB has officially opened its global headquarters in Singapore, relocating from Moscow, Russia. The firm, which investigates and prevents cybercrime, now houses a team of experts from its digital forensic lab, cyber investigations, and threat intelligence departments. Group-IB has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Singapore Institute of Management and aims to groom local talent. The company's CEO, Ilya Sachkov, stated that Singapore is a priority for Group-IB's business development, citing the country's favorable location and commitment to staying up-to-date with the latest cybersecurity technologies.

site_title: China exports unexpectedly returns to growth in May; imports shrink
summary: China's exports unexpectedly rose 1.1% in May, beating analyst expectations, despite higher US tariffs, while imports fell 8.5% due to weak domestic demand. The unexpected export growth may not ease fears of a longer US-China trade war, which could push the global economy towards recession. China's trade surplus increased to $41.65 billion, highlighting the need for stimulus measures to support the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong government will not withdraw extradition bill: leader
summary: Hong Kong's pro-Beijing leader Carrie Lam refused to scrap a controversial extradition bill, despite massive protests on Sunday, and said it will be debated in the legislature as planned. The bill, which would allow extraditions to mainland China, has sparked widespread opposition, with organizers estimating up to a million people attended the protest. Lam denied ignoring public backlash and claimed her administration had made concessions to protect Hong Kong's freedoms and human rights. The decision sets the administration on a collision course with opponents who have vowed to escalate protests if their demands are not met.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Monday with significant gains, driven by easing global trade concerns after US President Donald Trump dropped threatened tariffs against Mexico. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.89% to 27,206.61, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The market reaction was largely attributed to the reduced uncertainty surrounding trade tensions, allowing investors to re-engage in the market.

site_title: Synagie partners WeChat vendor to help SMEs tap China's social e-commerce market
summary: Synagie, an e-commerce solutions vendor, has partnered with Weimob, a WeChat solutions provider, to enter China's social e-commerce market. The partnership will help Singaporean and Southeast Asian small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) break into China's social e-commerce market. Synagie's end-to-end solution will cover commerce value-chain services, including digital store management, content translation, and digital marketing. The solution will be launched in the third quarter of 2019, marking Synagie's first foray into China. Weimob will provide e-commerce solutions and domain expertise in China's e-commerce market.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler, Renault revival may hinge on Nissan stake cut: sources
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) and Renault SA are exploring ways to revive their collapsed merger plan, with Nissan Motor poised to urge Renault to significantly reduce its 43.4% stake in the Japanese company. Nissan representatives are expected to pressure Renault for a substantial reduction, potentially as low as 10%, in exchange for supporting the FCA-Renault tie-up. The French government's opposition to the initial deal has led to strained relations between Renault and Nissan, and it remains unclear whether a revived merger can succeed.

site_title: SGX derivatives traded volume surges 46% in May on trade-war woes; daily securities traded value down 18%
summary: SGX derivatives trading volume surged 46% in May, reaching 24.2 million contracts, as investors sought to manage macro risks amid trade-war woes. Daily securities traded value fell 18% to S$1.1 billion, while structured warrants and leverage certificates declined 42%. Trading volumes of futures contracts for Asian equity indices, such as the FTSE China A50 Index, spiked 82% year on year. Iron ore derivatives volumes also increased 87% to 1.9 million contracts. Despite market volatility, defensive sectors like communication services and Reits saw positive returns.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit regains control of Paris site; to receive 900,000 euro compensation from government
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (E-Reit) has regained control of its Paris logistics property, Parc des Docks, after the French government agreed to compensate the trust with 907,128 euros for lost rental income due to non-expropriation. The Reit will resume marketing efforts to secure new leases, with current and prospective businesses showing strong interest in the site. The property's occupancy rate is expected to increase, driven by its accessibility and proximity to the Paris central business district.

site_title: Alpha Energy restructures ING loan, to repay US$13.3m loan balance in instalments
summary: Alpha Energy, a Catalist-listed company, restructures a US$13.3 million loan from ING Capital, originally taken in 2015 to fund the Mustang field's tax credits. The loan will be repaid in quarterly instalments of US$600,000 starting June 15, 2020, and the default interest will be discharged if no default occurs. The restructuring reduces the company's net current liabilities and aligns payments with tax credit receipt and production proceeds. This is the second loan restructuring for the parties, following a 2018 term sheet.

site_title: China FX regulator says sound fundamentals will underpin stable reserves
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator stated that sound economic fundamentals will support stable forex reserves. Foreign exchange reserves rose modestly in May due to valuation effects and changes in asset prices. The regulator noted uncertainty in global conditions and potential volatility in financial markets, but expressed confidence in China's ability to counteract external shocks. This stance aims to maintain stability in the foreign exchange market despite global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.52 points to 1,651.85 on Monday, with 143 gainers surpassing 36 losers. Volume reached 46.34 million lots worth RM17.03 million.

site_title: Regal International gets extension to release FY2018 sustainability report by July 31
summary: Regal International, a Singapore-based property developer, has secured a two-month extension to release its FY2018 sustainability report by July 31, up from the original May 31 deadline. The company initially delayed its Q1 2019 results by two months to July 15 due to issues with finalizing its FY2018 audited financial statements. Regal attributed the delay to differing views on accounting standards and property valuations, which impacted the accuracy of its FY2018 results.

site_title: Some big tech firms cut employees' access to Huawei, muddying 5G rollout
summary: Major tech firms such as Intel, Qualcomm, InterDigital Wireless, and LG Uplus have restricted employees from informal conversations with Huawei, amid US blacklisting concerns. This move could slow the 5G rollout, as engineers rely on discussions to set technical standards. The US Commerce Department has authorized US companies to interact with Huawei in standards bodies through August, but companies are still taking precautions to avoid potential issues. The restrictions may hinder global cooperation on 5G development and have significant implications for the rollout of 5G networks.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.32% to 3,176.43
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.32% to 3,176.43, driven by gains in Genting Singapore, Spackman Entertainment Group, and Singtel. Banking stocks like DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank also saw gains. The gains followed a Wall Street rally after a weak US jobs report boosted interest rate cut expectations.

site_title: Oil prices rise on likelihood of ongoing Opec+ supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on June 10, 2019, due to Saudi Arabia's likelihood of Opec+ supply cuts and relief over the averted US-Mexico trade war.
