site_title: Deutsche Bank's investment banking boss said to be among staff in tax refund probe
summary: Deutsche Bank's investment banking head, Garth Ritchie, is among staff facing scrutiny in a German probe into a widely used tax scam, cum-ex trades. The probe, which has already targeted two former employees, has expanded to include current and former staff, as well as some management board members. Ritchie received an email in 2007 explaining how trades could take advantage of German tax laws, and a meeting was held in his office to discuss cum-ex transactions. The bank denies participating in the organized market and claims the probe is a "purely procedural measure" with no changed assessment of the facts.

site_title: Accrelist axes AI retail tech launch; extends MoU deadline with F&B software firm
summary: Accrelist, a Singapore-based corporate accretion services provider, has shifted its focus from launching Artificial Intelligence retail tech solutions at its WE9GO retail store to facial recognition verification services. The company will no longer proceed with its AI retail tech launch.

site_title: SGInnovate and NUS unit to boost deep tech in Singapore
summary: SGInnovate and NUS's Centre for Quantum Technologies (CQT) have signed a Memorandum of Intent to boost the quantum tech ecosystem in Singapore. The joint effort aims to increase awareness of quantum technologies and promote talent grooming. Events and workshops will be hosted to address the potential of quantum tech in areas like navigation and security. SGInnovate is also seeking investments from the VC community, with CQT aiming to establish the industry in Singapore within the next few years, despite the country's small size.

images.alt_text: Steve Leonard (far left) and Artur Ekert inking an MOI to promote quantum tech and boost the commercialisation of quantum innovations.

site_title: Allied Tech has S$9.9m in kitty; to start new escrow account with local bank
summary: Singapore's precision engineering firm Allied Tech has S$9.9 million in cash reserves as of end-May, down from S$45.3 million in May 1, mainly due to S$33.2 million pending recovery from law firm JLC Advisors. Managing partner Jeffrey Ong, linked to the missing funds, was caught in Malaysia and is in remand. Allied Tech is opening an escrow account with a local bank, with independent chairman Chin Chee Choon and CEO Leow Wee Kia Clement as signatories. The company will monitor the situation and protect its interests.

site_title: All Beyond Meat does is win - for now
summary: Beyond Meat's shares have soared 163% since its IPO, reaching over $100, the company reported revenue of $40.2 million and operating loss of $5.3 million, exceeding preliminary estimates. The company's valuation has raised concerns, with some warning it's unreasonably lofty despite being a leader in the growing market for healthier and sustainable food options. The stock jumped 20% in after-hours trading, fueling investor enthusiasm for the company's plant-based products.

site_title: Gold clocks 4-month high over rate-cut expectations
summary: Gold prices surged to a 4-month high as investors anticipated US rate cuts amid growing global economic concerns. The precious metal gained strength due to dovish signals from the US Federal Open Market Committee, boosting safe-haven demand. Investors expect a prolonged Sino-US trade dispute to weigh on risk assets, while US monetary policy dovishness may alleviate risk-off sentiments. Spot gold prices jumped to $1,302, with technical analysis suggesting a bullish trend if the metal breaks above $1,346.

site_title: Reits
summary: US President Trump's 50% copper import tariff is expected to affect refined metal prices, potentially increasing costs for real estate projects. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore will test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents reached a record, with further increases anticipated. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Goldman Sachs acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. Meanwhile, New World Group is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal.

site_title: The next trade-war casualty may be the M&A market
summary: Trade tensions between the US and China may impact the M&A market, with a potential Boeing jetliner deal worth over $30 billion at risk. The US-China trade spat has led to a slowdown in global dealmaking, with large mergers and acquisitions in the $20 billion and up range showing a record trend. Transactions in the $1 billion to $5 billion range have slowed significantly, and experts warn that if big deals falter, the M&A market could dry up. Confidence issues, influenced by supply chain disruptions and cross-border concerns, are also affecting corporate decision-making.

site_title: Changi has world's 2nd most valuable airport brand: report
summary: Changi International Airport has the world's second most valuable airport brand, valued at US$754 million, according to a report by consultancy Brand Finance. It ranks second only to London's Heathrow Airport, valued at US$919 million. Changi Airport also holds the strongest airport brand, with a Brand Strength Index (BSI) score of 86.9 out of 100, thanks to its world-class amenities and ease of access for passengers.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Changi International Airport has the world's second most valuable airport brand value of US$754 million and also the world's strongest airport brand, according to a report by consultancy Brand Finance.

site_title: JTC to launch tender for Tuas South Link reserve list site
summary: JTC will launch a tender for an industrial site in Tuas South Link 3 with a minimum committed bid price of S$2 million. The site, zoned for Business-2 use, has a 20-year tenure and a site area of 0.45 hectares. The tender period is six weeks, with the site's public tender scheduled for June 25. This is part of the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) Programme, following the successful award of a site in Woodlands Avenue 12 to developer Soon Hock Investment Group for S$82 million in April.

site_title: Europe's 5G to cost US$62b more if Chinese vendors banned
summary: A ban on buying telecoms equipment from Chinese firms would add approximately $84.6 billion to the cost of 5G networks in Europe and delay the technology by 18 months, according to a GSMA report. The estimated costs and delay stem from a loss of competition and the need for operators to replace existing infrastructure. A full ban on Huawei and ZTE would also widen the gap in 5G penetration between the EU and the US by more than 15 percentage points by 2025.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on rate-cut hopes, China tariff delay
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by hopes of a US interest rate cut and a delay in China's tariff hike. The Dow Jones rose 0.19%, the S&P 500 gained 0.33%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.49%. The weak May payrolls data increased expectations of a rate cut, while the China tariff delay added to the gains, pushing stocks to fresh records.

site_title: FSL Trust gets cash offer of S$0.0585 a unit from sponsor
summary: FSL Trust, a Singapore shipping trust, has received a mandatory general offer from its sponsor FSL Holdings for S$0.0585 per unit, representing a 33% premium to the last transacted price. FSL Holdings now controls 55.04% of the trust's issued units and has made a conditional offer to buy out the trust's US$7.25 million convertible bonds at S$1,413.89 per US$1,000 principal amount. The offeror intends to maintain the trust's mainboard listing.

site_title: Tencent Music insiders have to weigh whether to sell after slump
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group's 180-day lockup expires on Monday, forcing insiders and early backers to decide whether to sell amid a 34% decline in the stock since its peak in mid-March. The stock now trades at pennies above its IPO price of $13. Despite this, most analysts, including Bloomberg Intelligence, rate the company's prospects as bright, citing its ability to generate sustainable profit and monetize users through social entertainment. A buy rating and $19 price target have been initiated by Loop Capital, with some analysts predicting a price target of $20.

site_title: How investors might approach the modern breed of companies
summary: Investors should approach modern network-building platforms like Netflix, Uber, and Airbnb with caution. These companies generate tremendous value through their network effects, but their business models vary wildly in terms of viability. Most platforms are asset-light and grow rapidly, but their profit margins are not necessarily high. A closer analysis of Porter's Five Forces Framework reveals differences in supplier power, which can impact gross margin. Long-term investors should consider factors like execution, successful pivots, and signs of structural advantage when evaluating these companies. Higher gross margin companies and those with better execution may be more likely to succeed in the long term.

site_title: Ford ready to sell Russian plants, says companies have shown interest
summary: Ford Motor Co is ready to sell its idle Russian plants after a joint venture closed two assembly plants and an engine factory in March. The company's Europe chairman, Steven Armstrong, stated that Ford has received interest from several companies. Ford is open to discussing potential sales, with Armstrong noting that companies have shown interest in acquiring the idle facilities.

site_title: Investment grade bond funds suck in record US$12.3b as investors ditch stocks: BAML
summary: Investors poured a record $12.3 billion into investment-grade bond funds and $17.5 billion into bond funds overall, seeking safe-haven bets amid trade tensions and economic concerns. This marks the second-largest week of inflows on record, with sovereign securities drawing in $8.9 billion. In contrast, equity funds suffered $10.3 billion of outflows, with tech-oriented funds losing $1.1 billion and defensive stocks seeing inflows. The risk-off mood also affected emerging markets, which lost $2.1 billion on equity and $700 million on debt. The "Bull & Bear" gauge has fallen to 2.5, indicating a bearish cross-asset positioning.

site_title: Putin says 'role of dollar' should be revisited in global trade
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin called for a reevaluation of the US dollar's role in global trade, citing declining trust in the currency. He accused the US of seeking to dominate the world and accused the global financial system of not serving future interests. Putin's comments come amidst ongoing US sanctions against Russia, which he claims is an instrument of pressure by the US on the rest of the world. The remarks were made at an economic forum alongside Chinese President Xi Jinping, highlighting the growing tensions between the US and its global partners.

site_title: Nakamura's making waves in the wrestling ring
summary: Japanese professional wrestler Shinsuke Nakamura will headline a WWE "live" event in Singapore on June 27, attempting to win the WWE Universal Championship belt. Nakamura, a former mixed martial artist and three-time Heavyweight Champion in New Japan Pro-Wrestling, is seeking his first WWE championship title. He will face defending champion Seth Rollins in a rematch of their classic battle at the Survivor Series event. This event marks a milestone in Nakamura's career, and he is determined to be patient and give it his all to achieve his goal.

site_title: UK's May quits as Conservatives party leader, starting succession race
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May steps down as Conservative Party leader, triggering a succession race to replace her and attempt to deliver Brexit. May will remain prime minister until a new leader is chosen, likely in late July, and has relinquished control over the EU departure process. Eleven Conservative MPs, including Boris Johnson, are vying to replace her, with a winner expected to decide on a Brexit plan within months.

site_title: Shell expands Bukom refinery storage by around 1.3m barrels
summary: Shell has expanded its storage capacity at its Singapore Bukom refinery by approximately 1.3 million barrels, with two new crude oil tanks built using automated welding technology. This upgrade aims to increase the company's flexibility in oil-trading activities, competitiveness, and ability to capture stronger margins in a volatile market. The move is part of Shell's broader storage and logistics investment strategy, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region. The expansion positions Shell to better manage market volatility and capitalize on expected increases in demand for oil products over the next two decades.

images.alt_text: Shell says bumping up its storage capacity on Pulau Bukom will give it greater flexibility in optimising its oil-trading activities.

site_title: SPH outdoor advertising unit to install mega LED screen at One Raffles Place
summary: SPH outdoor advertising unit, SPHMBO, has partnered with One Raffles Place to install a 100 square meter mega LED screen on the facade of the integrated commercial development. The screen will be located above the main entrance, overlooking Raffles Place Park, and is expected to enhance the mall's visual appeal and promote advertising opportunities.

site_title: Ayondo CFO quits in under a year over 'differences with management'
summary: Ayondo's CFO, Sean Downey, quit the company in under a year due to differences with management over the disposal of its unit Ayondo Markets Limited. Downey left over "differences with management" and "discontent with treatment and working relationship." The issues included regulatory capital requirements and the timing of changes related to the sale of AML. The company had completed the sale despite regulatory hurdles and had suspended its shares from trading since February.

site_title: Education: Not what we think it is
summary: Education is evolving beyond traditional classroom settings and teacher-student relationships, adopting creative approaches to equip people for development and progress. However, a breakdown in trust in institutions, including educational ones, poses a challenge. Distributed trust, enabled by technology, is shifting power away from single sources and towards sharing it across a wider range of sources. Education must extend beyond mere technical skills to include creative arts, history, and philosophy to keep up with technology and promote human development. Employers must become more active participants in education, providing coaching, mentoring, and interactive learning experiences to extract latent potential and foster wisdom.

site_title: UBS switches stance with plan to offer US$113m tax settlement in Italy
summary: UBS is set to agree a $113 million settlement in Italy for money laundering and tax cases, a contrast to its handling of a similar case in France. The Swiss bank is battling court cases across Europe, with a 4.5 billion euro penalty awarded in France. UBS has denied wrongdoing and is appealing the decision. The Italian settlement could help the bank receive lighter treatment from local prosecutors. The investigation in Italy is pending settlement, with prosecutors having gathered scant evidence. The agreement resembles one struck by Swiss rival Credit Suisse in 2016.

site_title: US extends deadline for Chinese imports before increasing tariffs
summary: The US has extended the deadline for Chinese imports to June 15, giving exporters two more weeks to enter the US without a 25% tariff. This move comes as the US Trade Representative aims to increase tariffs on certain Chinese products. The extension applies to products that were initially due to be subject to the tariff on June 1.

site_title: Hedge fund buys struggling book retailer Barnes & Noble
summary: Barnes & Noble, the largest US brick-and-mortar bookseller, has been sold to hedge fund Elliott Management for an estimated $683 million. The deal includes the assumption of Barnes & Noble's debt. After the close of the transaction, Barnes & Noble and Waterstones, owned by Elliott Management, will operate independently but share a common CEO. James Daunt, CEO of Waterstones, will lead Barnes & Noble, citing the need for investment to compete with online commerce and digital platforms like Amazon.

site_title: FSL Trust gets cash offer of S$0.0585 per unit from sponsor
summary: FSL Trust, a shipping trust, received a mandatory general offer from its sponsor, FSL Holdings, at S$0.0585 per unit, representing a 33% premium to the last traded price. The offeror, FSL Holdings, now controls 55.04% of the trust's total issued units, and approximately 49.59% of the maximum potential total units. The offer is conditional upon receiving acceptances of more than 50% of the voting rights attributable to the maximum potential total units.

site_title: SGInnovate, Centre for Quantum Technologies tie-up to boost quantum tech startups in S'pore
summary: SGInnovate, a Singapore government-owned innovation platform, has partnered with the Centre for Quantum Technologies (CQT) to boost quantum tech startups in Singapore. The two-year collaboration aims to commercialize quantum innovations and transform quantum science into industry solutions. CQT will introduce researchers to SGInnovate, providing technical expertise and support for forming, launching, and scaling startups. The partnership also includes joint events and workshops to promote quantum technologies and awareness among industry partners and investors, with a goal of reaching over 2,000 individuals in the deep-tech ecosystem.

site_title: Judges throw out Brexit case against UK PM candidate Johnson
summary: UK judges have thrown out a case attempting to prosecute Boris Johnson for allegedly lying about Brexit, claiming Britain would be £350 million a week better off outside the EU. The decision, made by judges Anne Rafferty and Michael Supperstone, comes after Johnson's legal team argued the prosecution was "politically-motivated" and a "long-shot." The ruling effectively ends campaigner Marcus Ball's attempt to bring a prosecution, which was deemed "irresponsible and dishonest" by Ball.

site_title: China has lots of policy room if trade war worsens, PBOC chief says
summary: China's central bank governor, Yi Gang, has stated that the country has "tremendous" room to adjust monetary policy if the trade war worsens, signaling readiness to support the economy. Yi also signaled a willingness to allow the yuan's value to be set by market forces. This comes ahead of a meeting with US officials, including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, in Japan for the Group of 20 meetings. Yi described the talks as "productive," but acknowledged the trade war topic would be uncertain and difficult to discuss.

site_title: Trump may delay Mexico tariffs if talks progress, aide says
summary: The US plans to issue a notice today to implement 5% tariffs on Mexican imports, set to take effect Monday, but President Trump may delay the move if talks progress. Negotiations between the US and Mexico resume in Washington on Friday to address the surge in illegal migration. A White House aide stated that while progress has been made, "there's a long way to go" and the legal teams are discussing the issue. The outcome of the talks will determine whether the tariffs are delayed or implemented.

site_title: US job growth slows sharply in May; wage gains moderate
summary: US job growth slowed sharply in May, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 75,000 jobs, below the expected 185,000. Wage gains moderated, with average hourly earnings rising 0.2% and the annual wage increase slowing to 3.1%. The slowdown in hiring and wage gains suggests the economy is losing momentum, potentially increasing calls for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates this year, amid escalating trade tensions with China and Mexico.

site_title: Oxley receives aggregate S$210m from first completion of Chevron House sale
summary: Oxley Holdings has received S$210 million from the sale of Chevron House, a 32-storey commercial development, after transferring 82.35% of its stake to Golden Compass (BVI). The sale, which was part of a S$1.025 billion deal, also included costs for asset enhancement works. Oxley still owns 17.65% of Oxley Beryl, the company that owns Chevron House, after the transaction.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on trade optimism
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index advancing 0.53% to 20,884.71, driven by investor optimism over potential delays to US tariffs on Mexican imports. The broader Topix index also rose 0.49%. The positive sentiment followed rallies on Wall Street.

site_title: Boardroom free float falls below 10% threshold
summary: Boardroom's free float, a measure of shareholder ownership, fell below 10% after Salacca, a unit of GK Goh Holdings, made a takeover offer. As of June 5, Salacca controlled 84.8% of Boardroom shares, with the offer remaining open until June 28. The company announced it will not restore the free float requirement and will seek to delist Boardroom.

site_title: Allied Tech reports S$9.9m cash balance, opens escrow account with local bank
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering firm, reported a cash balance of S$9.9 million as of end-May, down from S$45.3 million in May. The decrease is largely due to S$33.2 million pending recovery from law firm JLC Advisors, where managing partner Jeffrey Ong is alleged to have disappeared with the funds. Ong was arrested in Malaysia and is currently in remand, facing a cheating charge related to another firm. Allied Tech is also opening an escrow account with a local bank to secure its funds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.84 points to 1,650.93 at 9am on Friday, with gains beating losses 127 to 39. Volume was 30.34 million lots worth RM20.46 million.

site_title: Opportunities in Indonesia's Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore companies looking to enter Indonesia's Industry 4.0 market are advised to develop the right talent who understand market nuances and speak the local language. They should also engage in patient business partnerships, have the right expertise to diagnose bottlenecks, and support workers on the shop floor. Resources available to Singapore companies include Enterprise Singapore, which signed a Memorandum of Understanding with Indonesia's Ministry of Industry to facilitate partnerships. Companies can also participate in the upcoming Industrial Transformation Asia Pacific (ITAP) event in Singapore to exhibit their offerings and engage with regional clients.

site_title: Pound may slide to 2-year low with a Brexiteer prime minister
summary: The pound may drop to a two-year low if a hardline Brexiteer becomes UK Prime Minister, with a possible 2% slide to US$1.24. A Bloomberg poll predicts a hard Brexiteer has a 70% probability of taking office, but lawmakers are expected to block a no-deal exit. Sterling has already slumped 3% in the past month, and analysts expect a range of outcomes, with some predicting a snap general election or second Brexit referendum.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.24 points to 1,649.33, with 490 gainers and 303 losers. The index closed higher on Friday, with a volume of 1.6 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains as global easy money hopes boost sentiment
summary: Australian shares rose 5% on Friday, driven by a domestic rate cut and expectations of global central banks easing monetary conditions to support growth. Stocks with attractive dividend payouts, such as big miners and banks, led gains. Investors are awaiting a key US jobs report for further clues on interest rates. Global oil prices rose, boosting energy stocks, while New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.3%.

site_title: Accrelist axes launch of AI retail tech, extends MoU deadline with F&B software firm
summary: Accrelist, a corporate accretion services provider, has shifted its focus from launching AI retail tech solutions to facial recognition verification services. The company has renamed its subsidiary WE9 Pay to Accrelist A.I. Tech and will no longer launch its WE9GO retail store. Accrelist has also extended the deadline for its non-binding MoU with Liaoning Mealplus Technology, a developer of food and beverage industry software, to July 13. The company had initially agreed to acquire Liaoning Mealplus with a cash consideration of S$791,000 and the issuance of Accrelist shares.

site_title: Pacific Star's independent director, 2 non-executive directors step down
summary: Three directors, including independent director Heng Su-Ling Mae and non-executive directors Peh Siong Woon Terence and Tan Hai Peng Micheal, stepped down from Pacific Star Development's board amid a strategic shift to property development. The move comes after the company's appointment of new executive chairman Ying Wei Hsein and independent directors Leow Chin Boon and Bob Low. The company is now focused on fulfilling the minimum requirement of having three non-executive directors in its Audit Committee within three months.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open ahead of US jobs data
summary: European stocks rose at the open on June 7, 2019, ahead of US jobs data, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 also up 0.4%. The gains were attributed to easing trade war tensions and a report that the US might delay its plan to hit Mexico with tariffs, which also lifted Asian stocks. Markets were awaiting US monthly jobs data, which could impact global economic sentiment.

site_title: Singapore shares extend gains on Friday, up 1.6% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed at 3,166.29, up 20.11 points or 0.6% on Friday, marking its first weekly gain in five weeks. Risk-on sentiment returned due to hopes of delayed US tariffs on Mexico and dovish central banks' rate cuts. Technology and consumer cyclical sectors led the charge, with Singtel and DBS Group Holdings gaining. Trading volume was lower due to holidays, but regional markets, including Australia, Japan, and Malaysia, closed higher.

site_title: Teen climate activist Greta Thunberg gets Amnesty prize
summary: Teen climate activist Greta Thunberg received the Amnesty International Ambassador of Conscience Award for mobilizing global opinion on climate change. The 16-year-old activist praised the honor, saying it recognizes the efforts of those inspired by her "Fridays for Future" movement. Thunberg has become a figurehead for young climate activists, and her work has been recognized by international organizations, including a recent appearance alongside Arnold Schwarzenegger at a climate change conference. The award acknowledges her efforts to raise awareness about the urgent need to address climate change.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for international collaboration and a whole-of-society approach for a sustainable future. Meanwhile, Shell boosted Singapore's Bukom refinery storage by 1.3 million barrels, while Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust secured up to A$170m in loan facilities. In business news, Singapore shares extended gains, and the Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,166.29, up 20.11 points or 0.6%. Overseas, the US announced tariffs on Vietnam, the Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: SPHMBO partners One Raffles Place to install mega LED screen
summary: SPHMBO, the outdoor advertising arm of Singapore Press Holdings, has partnered with One Raffles Place to install a 100 sq m mega LED screen on the mall's facade. The screen will be strategically located above the main entrance, overlooking Raffles Place Park. The partnership aims to deepen SPHMBO's brand position as the leading digital outdoor media owner in Singapore. The collaboration is expected to make the surrounding area more vibrant, showcasing the dynamic synergy between SPHMBO and One Raffles Place.

site_title: Saudi energy minister says Opec close to agreeing oil pact extension
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih said Opec and its allies are close to agreeing to extend oil production cuts beyond June, maintaining current levels. The current deal, which cuts 1.2 million barrels per day, ends this month, but a rollover is "almost in the bag." Al-Falih stated that the kingdom aims to drive down inventories, and prices below $60 a barrel would not offer enough confidence for oil firms to invest. The deal's outcome will influence oil prices, which have risen 16% this year due to the Opec+ agreement.

site_title: How a Brit got Asia to fall for Macau's Portuguese egg tarts
summary: A British pharmacist, Andrew Stow, introduced Macau's Portuguese egg tarts to the Chinese community by experimenting with a heavier British custard filling and Portuguese pastry techniques. Initially met with skepticism, the creation gained popularity and now Macau's Lord Stow's bakery churns out 21,000 egg tarts daily, with franchises in Japan and Manila. The success of the egg tarts has also led to a rival business being sold to KFC, introducing the hybrid dessert to hundreds of millions more consumers across China.

site_title: Toyota to launch ultra-compact battery vehicle, tie up with China's CATL
summary: Toyota plans to launch an ultra-compact, battery-powered car for two people by 2020, aiming to electrify half of its global sales by 2025. The company will partner with Chinese battery maker CATL to meet its growing battery needs. Toyota also announced a partnership with Subaru to develop a battery-electric SUV. The ultra-compact car will have a maximum speed of 60 km/h and a range of 100 km on a single charge, addressing the gap between Toyota's battery needs and its own production capabilities.

site_title: Trump says Federal Reserve's rate increases restrained stock market growth
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases, stating that the stock market would be 10,000 points higher if rates were kept lower. Trump's criticism comes after the Fed's rate hikes in 2018, which he had previously threatened to fire Fed Chairman Jerome Powell over. However, Trump expressed confidence in Powell later. Recently, Powell signaled an openness to cut interest rates if necessary, amid trade disputes with major trading partners. Trump's comments reflect his ongoing disagreement with the Fed's monetary policies.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,159.23, up 0.41% on day
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher, with the Straits Times Index increasing 0.41% to 3,159.23, driven by gains from Blumont Group, Genting Singapore, and Chasen Holdings. Trading volume was high, with 247.8 million securities changing hands. The gains come ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hold weekly gains as markets front-run Federal Reserve
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars have held gains from the previous week, with the Aussie steady at US$0.6975 and the kiwi at US$0.6614. The currencies benefited from the Federal Reserve's anticipated rate cuts, with US yields diving 29 basis points in two weeks. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's Assistant Governor Christian Hawkesby's comments that rates were on hold for the foreseeable future also contributed to the kiwi's gains.

site_title: A US$2b illicit meat market damaged by pig virus
summary: China's tightened border controls to combat African swine fever have significantly reduced the US$2 billion illicit meat market, with buffalo shipments from India to China decreasing by 50% to around 1,000 containers per month. Stricter controls are expected to alleviate a protein shortage in China. The All India Meat and Livestock Exporters Association is seeking to allow direct sales from India to China, which it believes will help address the shortage.

site_title: Australian, NZ shares higher as traders eye global rate cuts
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth straight session, driven by resource stocks, as investors focused on potential interest rate cuts at home and abroad. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut rates earlier this week, and other major central banks signaled more accommodative policy amid global trade risks. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished 1% higher at 6,443.9 points.

site_title: JPMorgan amps up hedges against recession risk flashed by bonds
summary: JPMorgan is advising clients to boost hedges against potential US recession, citing a 53% probability of a recession over the next year based on declining Treasury yields. The bank recommends increasing holdings in government bonds and curbing exposure to commodities, while introducing a long position in the Japanese yen and overweight position in precious metals. This defensive posture is a second iteration, following a similar move in April that proved prescient after global stocks shed $4 trillion. The strategy aims to address the persistent disconnect between equity and credit markets.

site_title: Sanofi names drugmaker Novartis' executive Paul Hudson as next CEO
summary: Sanofi has appointed Paul Hudson, a 51-year-old British executive, as its new CEO, replacing Olivier Brandicourt. Hudson previously led Novartis' pharmaceuticals unit since 2016 and aims to bolster Sanofi's pipeline of treatments, particularly in cancer and genetic diseases. He will take over on September 1, aiming to address growing US pressure on drug prices and catch up with competitors. Hudson's strong track record at Novartis was a key factor in the decision, with investors expressing confidence in his ability to launch new drugs.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly lower; STI down 0.05% to 3,144.50 on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly lower on Friday, down 0.05% to 3,144.50, as markets awaited confirmation of a Mexico tariff delay. About 25.7 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 52 to 43. The Straits Times Index reversed small gains made earlier in the week. This follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: German industrial production falls in April
summary: German industrial production declined 1.9% in April, marking the first drop since January, according to official data. The decline is attributed to global uncertainty and trade wars. Economist Carsten Brzeski described the drop as a "horrible start to the second quarter for German industry." The news highlights the challenges faced by manufacturers in the country amidst ongoing trade tensions and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Rate cut will depend on timing: Bank Indonesia deputy governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank is considering a rate cut but is waiting for the right time due to economic uncertainty. Deputy governor Dody Waluyo stated that the policy rate will depend on timing and the central bank needs to be cautious. The US-China trade war may hurt Indonesia's growth prospects, but textile exporters could benefit. Bank Indonesia raised interest rates six times last year to bolster the rupiah and policymakers are treading carefully to avoid undermining the currency.

site_title: International collaboration, whole of society approach needed for sustainable future: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for international collaboration and a whole-of-society approach to achieve a sustainable future. He cited the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area and the Belt and Road Initiative as examples of partnerships that can drive sustainable development. Heng also stressed the importance of countries working together to address climate change and economic development, as well as enabling all societal sectors to contribute to sustainability efforts.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust secures up to A$170m in loan facilities
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has secured up to A$170 million in loan facilities from DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The refinancing replaces an existing A$170 million loan due in June 2019, following the trust's divestment of two Australian properties. FLT units remained unchanged at S$1.18. The new facilities will support the trust's planned refinancing, with OCBC acting as the green loan coordinator and DBS as the facility agent.

site_title: Foxconn plans management overhaul as chairman Gou seeks Taiwan presidency: source
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract manufacturer, is planning a management overhaul to give senior executives more control over daily operations. The move comes as chairman Terry Gou seeks Taiwan's presidency and plans to step down from the company. A new "operations committee" will be established, involving senior executives from various Foxconn units, and will report to a proposed new board. The committee will aim to address concerns about Gou's approach to transparency and succession plans.

site_title: Asia: Markets climb on hopes of Mexico tariff delay
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, following US gains after a report suggested the US may delay its plan to impose tariffs on Mexico. US stocks bounced back after Bloomberg News reported the potential delay, while Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard said talks with US officials had yielded progress. This lifted Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul by 0.5% and Singapore and Kuala Lumpur by 0.4%. The news eased concerns about the US-China trade war and its impact on the global economy, with investors relieved by the ECB's decision to extend eurozone interest rates for at least six months.

site_title: Japan's household spending, wages weakness cloud economic outlook
summary: Japan's household spending rose 1.3% in April, below market forecasts, while real wages declined 1.1% from a year earlier, adding to concerns about consumption and economic growth. The weaker-than-expected data, combined with a slump in exports to China and a planned sales tax increase, raises worries about the impact on the economy. The Bank of Japan needs to see improvement in domestic consumption to achieve its 2% inflation target. Global trade frictions, including the Sino-US trade war, also weigh on the economy.

site_title: UK opposition Labour fight off Brexit Party to retain parliament seat
summary: The UK opposition Labour Party retained the parliamentary seat of Peterborough in eastern England, defeating the Brexit Party's Nigel Farage. Labour candidate Lisa Forbes won with 10,484 votes, while the Brexit Party came second with 9,801 votes. Prime Minister Theresa May's governing Conservatives came third with 7,243 votes. This victory marks a significant win for Labour in a by-election triggered by the ousting of the incumbent Labour lawmaker.

site_title: Russia, China to show united front at economic forum
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to attend Russia's Saint Petersburg Economic Forum as a guest of honor, marking a united front between the two nations amidst shared troubles with the US. The visit comes five years after Moscow's annexation of Crimea, and has seen the signing of dozens of commercial contracts in various sectors. Despite Russia being China's second-largest trade partner, the EU remains the largest foreign investor in Russia. Analysts predict China will make significant investments in Russia over the next few years, particularly in the New Silk Road projects, but note the significant economic and demographic disparities between the two countries.

site_title: 'Giant' Denzel Washington celebrated by Hollywood
summary: Actor Denzel Washington was honored by Hollywood with the American Film Institute's (AFI) Life Achievement award, the highest honor for a film career, at a gala event in Los Angeles. The 64-year-old was celebrated by fellow Oscar winners Morgan Freeman, Jamie Foxx, Mahershala Ali, and A-list black leading men Chadwick Boseman and Michael B Jordan, who paid tribute to his trailblazing career spanning five decades and two Oscars. This recognition marks a milestone for Washington, who has opened doors for a generation of black movie stars.

images.alt_text: Actor Denzel Washington accepts the 47th AFI Life Achievement Award at the gala honouring him in Los Angeles, California on June 6, 2019.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Pemex debt to 'junk' in fresh blow to Mexico
summary: Fitch downgraded Pemex's debt to 'junk' status, changing its credit rating from investment grade to speculative grade, with a negative outlook. This move comes a day after Fitch downgraded Mexico's sovereign debt, and is a setback for President Lopez Obrador's plans to revive the struggling state-run oil company. The downgrade affects Pemex's debt rating to BB+, while Mexico's sovereign debt rating remains at BBB.

site_title: JTC to launch tender for Tuas South Link reserve list site
summary: JTC will launch a tender for a 0.45-hectare industrial site at Tuas South Link 3 (Plot 19) with a minimum committed bid price of S$2 million. The site, zoned for Business-2 use, has a 20-year tenure and a maximum building height of 63.5 meters. The public tender is scheduled for June 25 with a six-week tender period. This follows the rejection of a bid for a site at Tampines North Drive 3 (Plot 2) due to a price below the reserve price.

site_title: Netanyahu fails to get postponement of corruption court hearing: reports
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's request to postpone a corruption court hearing was rejected by the attorney general. The hearing, scheduled for October 2 and 3, will not be delayed "not even for one day". Netanyahu is facing possible indictment for bribery, fraud, and breach of trust and is reportedly seeking immunity through new legislation. The attorney general had previously pushed back the deadline for Netanyahu's response to allegations against him to October. Netanyahu's request to delay the hearing was denied due to "exceptional circumstances" of the upcoming elections.

site_title: Shell boosts Singapore's Bukom refinery storage by around 1.3m barrels
summary: Shell has increased the storage capacity at its Singapore Bukom refinery by nearly 1.3 million barrels by building two large crude oil tanks. The move aims to improve competitiveness and flexibility in oil trading activities, as demand for oil products is expected to rise globally over the next two decades. The new facilities will allow Shell to buy more oil when market conditions are attractive, capturing stronger margins and better managing market volatility. The project uses automated welding technology, reducing costs and welding time by 60%.

images.alt_text: By increasing storage capacity at Pulau Bukom, Shell will have greater flexibility in optimising its oil trading activities.

site_title: Japan minister says high heels 'appropriate' in response to call for ban
summary: Japan's Health Minister Takumi Nemoto has stated that requiring women to wear high heels at work is "necessary and appropriate" in the workplace, responding to a petition signed by over 21,000 people calling for a ban. The petition, led by 32-year-old funeral parlour worker Yumi Ishikawa, aims to address the pain and injuries caused by high heels in the workplace. Nemoto's comments sparked debate, with Ishikawa saying the remarks might prompt women to speak out against the practice, which she considers "power harassment".

site_title: Pompeo to visit Bangkok, commit to Southeast Asia: official
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will visit Bangkok, Thailand, from July 29 to August 3, to recommit the US to supporting Southeast Asian nations in the face of rising China. He will lead talks on the Lower Mekong Initiative, promoting economic growth and coordination among Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam. Pompeo aims to counter China's Belt and Road Initiative, which he says could lead to overdependency. He will also coordinate US efforts with allies Australia, Japan, and South Korea in the Mekong region.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, Kingsmen Creatives, HC Surgical Specialists
summary: ST Engineering established a joint-venture company in Vietnam with Vietnam Airlines Engineering Company, securing US$3.9 million in funding. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust secured up to A$170 million in loan facilities from DBS, OCBC, and UOB. Kingsmen Creatives signed a licensing agreement with Hasbro International to expand its US licensing agreement. HC Surgical Specialists partnered with Medistar Services Pte Ltd to incorporate a medical services subsidiary.

site_title: Boardroom calls for trading halt amid sale offer exercise
summary: BOARDROOM Limited has called for a trading halt pending an announcement about a sale offer from Salacca, a unit of GK Goh Holdings, at S$0.88 per share. The offer is unconditional and may result in delisting if Boardroom's free float falls below 10%. The halt was initiated at 9:54am on Friday.

site_title: Australian police in record A$1.2b haul of drug 'ice'
summary: Australian police seized a record A$1.2 billion worth of the drug "ice" hidden in stereo speakers shipped from Thailand. Border Force agents found 1.6 tonnes of methylamphetamine and 37kg of heroin in vacuum-sealed packages inside the speakers after the shipment arrived in Melbourne. This is the largest meth bust in Australian history, according to the border force commander.

site_title: UK firms raise spending on temporary staff by least in 6 years: REC
summary: UK firms reduced spending on temporary staff by the least in 6 years, according to the Recruitment and Employment Confederation. This decline, along with fewer permanent staff hires, suggests the robust labour market may weaken. The slowdown in demand for staff was attributed to Brexit uncertainty, despite the job market performing strongly since the 2016 referendum. Unemployment remained low at 3.8% and wage growth was strong, but starting salaries for permanent staff grew at the weakest pace in over two years.

images.alt_text: British employers increased their spending on temporary staff at the weakest rate in more than six years and hired fewer permanent staff, recruiters said, suggesting Britain's robust labour market will weaken.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on June 7, 2019, following Wall Street rallies amid a report that the White House may delay tariffs on Mexican imports. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.44% to 20,864.60, while the Topix index increased 0.25% to 1,528.75.

site_title: Maduro axes electricity minister amid ongoing Venezuela blackouts
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro replaced his electricity minister, Freddy Brito, amid ongoing prolonged power blackouts. Brito, an electrical engineer, will continue the recovery of the national electric system. He replaces Igor Gavidia, appointed just two months ago, and follows a series of crippling blackouts that have caused major disruptions. Maduro blames the blackouts on sabotage by the US and Venezuelan opposition, but experts attribute it to poor maintenance.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong and Shanghai were closed on Friday for a public holiday. In contrast, European markets saw a decline, with bank and healthcare stocks dragging down shares, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. In Asia, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, a mandatory offer was made for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share.

site_title: SBI Offshore exploring options to repatriate and place China funds in escrow
summary: SBI Offshore, a Catalist-listed company, is unable to repatriate US$3.2 million in funds from China due to foreign exchange regulations. The company is exploring options to open a China escrow account by July 2019, or it may consider repatriating the funds through capital reduction and/or liquidation of its Chinese subsidiary. As of February 28, SBI Offshore had US$15.8 million in cash, with US$12.6 million in Singapore and US$3.2 million in China.

site_title: Rare-earths giant Lynas to prioritise US military's needs
summary: Lynas Corp, the world's largest rare-earth producer outside of China, plans to prioritize the US military's needs for its new plant in Texas, according to CEO Amanda Lacaze. This move comes as China signals potential restrictions on rare-earth shipments to the US. Lynas has been in talks with the US Department of Defense and Defense Logistics Agency, citing the military's successful creation of "viable supply chains" across the industry. This shift highlights the growing importance of rare earths in defense applications.

site_title: Beyond Meat sees sales more than doubling in 2019, shares jump 21%
summary: Beyond Meat Inc reported a 215% increase in net revenue to $40.2 million in Q1 2019, exceeding analyst expectations. The company expects to more than double its revenue to $210 million for 2019, with shares jumping 21%. Beyond Meat attributes its success to its plant-based burgers, which mimic the taste, smell, and feel of real meat, and its conservative forecast excludes current trials with fast-food chains. The company aims to underprice animal protein and capture market share.

site_title: Obamas sign deal to produce podcasts for Spotify
summary: Barack and Michelle Obama's production company Higher Ground has signed a deal with Spotify to create a series of podcasts for the music streaming service. The deal aims to diversify Spotify's content and provide an opportunity for productive dialogue, entertainment, and education. The Obamas, who have already signed an exclusive deal with Netflix, will produce podcasts that amplify underrepresented voices. This move follows Spotify's efforts to shift its podcast production model towards paid content, with several other major players also exploring similar strategies.

site_title: Petrobras, Brazil government dodge bullet as Supreme Court approves asset sales
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court ruled that state-run firms don't need congressional approval to sell subsidiaries, a victory for President Jair Bolsonaro and Petrobras. This decision allows Petrobras to proceed with its plan to divest $27 billion of non-core assets by 2023, aimed at reducing its bloated debt load. The ruling also reverses a suspension of the $8.6 billion sale of Petrobras' TAG pipeline unit to France's Engie SA. The decision is seen as a significant step for Petrobras to reduce its debt and improve its financial health.

site_title: Democrats ask Federal Reserve to scrutinise Deutsche Bank over Trump transactions
summary: US Senate Democrats asked the Federal Reserve to scrutinize Deutsche Bank over suspicious transactions linked to President Donald Trump and his son-in-law Jared Kushner. The letter follows reports of whistleblowers accusing senior Deutsche Bank staff of suppressing warnings of suspicious activity. Deutsche Bank was one of the few lenders to keep Mr. Trump afloat after his repeated bankruptcies in the 1990s. The Federal Reserve has received the letter and plans to respond, while Deutsche Bank denies wrongdoing. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has also asked the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network to review the matter.

site_title: Caesars is in advanced talks to merge with Eldorado Resorts
summary: Caesars Entertainment is in advanced talks to merge with Eldorado Resorts, with the potential deal valuing Caesars at over $11 per share. The discussions come after activist billionaire Carl Icahn pushed Caesars to consider a sale. A deal could still fall apart if financing can't be secured, and Eldorado wasn't the only suitor, with Golden Nugget owner Tilman Fertitta previously proposing a merger. The move aims to alleviate Caesars' debt, which was left from a 2008 leveraged buyout.

site_title: Google cloud gaming service to launch in 14 countries this year
summary: Google's Stadia gaming service will launch in 14 countries starting in November, including the US, UK, and several European nations. The service, which offers a Netflix-style subscription, will allow users to access games on any device powered by the internet cloud. The launch will include a "founders edition bundle" hardware pack for $129 and a monthly subscription price of $9.99. The service will offer free games, including Destiny 2, and blockbuster titles from Ubisoft. This move aims to disrupt the gaming industry by eliminating the need for consoles and game software.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Privacy Awareness Week: Have we made progress?
summary: The Money FM podcast "Mind Your Business" discusses Singapore's progress in addressing data protection during Privacy Awareness Week. Annabel Lee, policy manager at BSA The Software Alliance, highlights the importance of robust data protection frameworks and regulations in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region, particularly with the increasing reliance on cross-border data flows. The conversation emphasizes the need for transparency in personal data collection and the impact of this on the booming Asian digital economy.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on report of possible Mexico tariff delay
summary: US stocks rose for a third consecutive session as the White House reportedly delayed tariffs on Mexican imports, giving more time for talks on illegal immigration. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.7% higher at 25,720.66. The positive move followed a Bloomberg report that the US could push back the June 10 tariff plan to permit more time for talks. This delay lifted market sentiment and helped major indices add to their gains.

site_title: Madonna says she feels 'raped' by New York Times profile
summary: Pop icon Madonna expressed feelings of being "raped" by a New York Times profile, calling the newspaper "one of the founding fathers of the patriarchy." The article, "Madonna at Sixty," focused on her age, which Madonna argued would not have been a focus if she were a man. She took issue with the journalist's emphasis on trivial matters and criticized the paper for perpetuating patriarchal norms. Madonna stated that the experience made her feel "raped" and vowed to continue fighting against the patriarchy.

site_title: Mexico scrambles to slow migrants as Trump tariffs loom
summary: Mexico scrambled to slow the flow of Central American migrants to the US as talks continued in Washington over President Trump's threat of tariffs on Mexican goods. Mexico City blocked a new caravan, detained migrant rights activists, and froze bank accounts of suspected human traffickers. US negotiators remained far apart on asylum application procedures and financial aid for Central American countries. Despite efforts, the talks yielded no significant progress, leaving the US on the verge of imposing tariffs on Mexican goods.

site_title: Transition to circular economy key to a sustainable future
summary: Singapore - A circular economy is crucial for a sustainable future, according to panellists at the Ecosperity Conference. Circularity involves making products robust and recyclable, reducing material scarcity and waste. Companies like H&M Group and Miniwiz are adopting circular economy practices, with H&M planning to source 100% sustainable materials by 2030. Experts stress the need for collaboration across industries and consumers to scale up solutions and make a substantial impact. A swifter approach to research and development is also necessary to transition to a circular economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit by firm euro as Draghi shoos away hopeful doves
summary: European stocks fell 0.2% on Thursday, hit by a stronger euro after the European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged, disappointing investors' hopes for a dovish outlook. The stronger euro trimmed the value of eurozone companies' overseas earnings, affecting their profitability. European lenders, including German and French banks, fell 1% as the ECB did not detail a generous cheap loan lending program. The Stoxx 600 index marked time, while utilities stocks rose 1.3% as a defensive sector.

site_title: Aviva's new CEO to split firm, cut 1,800 jobs
summary: Aviva's new CEO, Maurice Tulloch, has announced plans to cut 1,800 jobs and reduce expenses by £300 million by 2022 to restore the company's fortunes. Shares have risen 12% this year, recouping half of last year's losses, after Tulloch's strategy seemed to be working. The company will split its UK life and general insurance units, with Colm Holmes taking over general insurance and Angela Darlington leading life insurance. The move aims to streamline costs and improve efficiency, but has sparked concerns from British union Unite.

site_title: Inflatable Art
summary: The ArtScience Museum in Singapore is hosting the exhibition "Floating Utopias" featuring over 40 inflatable objects and artworks by international and local artists. The show explores the history of inflatable art and its use in social activism and architecture. The exhibition includes works by artists such as Dawn Ng, Luke Gerram, and Ahmet Ogut, and runs from June 6 to September 29.

site_title: Oil jumps 2% as possible delay of US tariffs on Mexico boosts equities
summary: Oil prices jumped 2% on Thursday, reversing a 5-month low, following a report that the US may delay tariffs on Mexico, boosting equities. Brent crude futures rose to $61.67 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $52.59 a barrel. The US stock market also surged after the news, as investors weighed market outlook and tariff implications.

site_title: Investment opportunities abound in Belgium
summary: Belgium is a hub for investment opportunities, with three regional agencies promoting international business relations. Flanders Investment & Trade, AWEX, and Hub Brussels support Belgian companies in exporting to Singapore, Malaysia, and Brunei, and attracting investments from these countries. The Flemish government agency promotes the petrochemical sector, while Wallonia focuses on industries like the low-profile property trust. The agencies have representatives in Singapore, aiming to capitalize on the country's growing importance in the region. This investment-friendly environment makes Belgium an attractive destination for businesses and investors.

site_title: Singing in the Streets
summary: Wayang, a form of Chinese street opera, originated in Singapore in the 1850s with the arrival of Chinese immigrants. Despite authorities' attempts to restrict performances, theatres were constructed and the art form continued to thrive. However, urbanization, economic instability, and language shift led to its decline by the 1970s. However, the government and cultural associations have since preserved and promoted Wayang, allowing it to continue being performed in Singapore today, now recognized as a valuable contribution to Chinese culture and considered critically endangered.

site_title: Swiss regulator fines US, UK banks US$91m over running of FX cartel
summary: Switzerland's Competition Commission fined US and UK banks a total of 90 million Swiss francs (S$123.5 million) for their roles in running foreign exchange trading cartels. Barclays was fined 27 million francs, Citigroup 28.5 million, and JPMorgan Chase 9.5 million. The cartels, involving traders from multiple banks, used chatrooms to fix currency exchange rates over six years. This fine follows similar fines of 1.07 billion euros (S$1.46 billion) paid by five banks to the European Union for their forex collusion.

site_title: Huawei executive's extradition hearings set for 2020 in Vancouver
summary: A Vancouver judge has set the hearings for the extradition of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou to the US to face accusations of violating Iran sanctions to begin on January 20, 2020. The five-day hearing aims to wrap up by October or November 2020. Meng, the daughter of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei, was arrested in Vancouver in December 2018 on US charges of fraud and lying about violating Iran sanctions, a claim her lawyers dispute.

images.alt_text: Hearings on whether a top official with Chinese telecoms giant Huawei should be extradited to the United States to face accusations of violating Iran sanctions will begin on January 20, 2020, a Vancouver judge decided on Thursday.

site_title: Balli Kaur Jaswal
summary: Novelist Balli Kaur Jaswal's third novel "Erotic Stories For Punjabi Widows" was purchased by HarperCollins, leading to film rights being bought by Ridley Scott's production company and Reese Witherspoon's book club. Her fourth novel "The Unlikely Adventures Of The Shergill Sisters" has received glowing reviews and a high reader rating on Goodreads. Jaswal attributes her international success to tapping into global markets, rather than writing solely about Singapore, and credits the growing interest in stories from Southeast Asia. Despite the literary system being "brutal" and unpredictable, Jaswal remains hopeful by focusing on her work and staying committed to her craft.

site_title: Preparing for an independent director-led board
summary: Singapore is preparing for a phase where independent directors lead corporate boards with majority voting control, following the revised Code of Corporate Governance issued in 2018. As of January 2022, Provision 2.2 requires independent directors to make up a majority of the board, unless the chairman is independent. Companies must ensure their boards remain strong and effective, and independent directors are properly trained and equipped to take on a more active role in decision-making. The appointment of independent chairmen may also be a way to skirt compliance, but companies must ensure they have the necessary training and competence for the role.

site_title: Tech backlash misses the real damage tech giants do
summary: The techlash has begun, with the Federal Trade Commission and Justice Department launching investigations into tech giants like Facebook, Google, and Amazon. However, the author argues that this is a long-overdue response to the sector's immense power and lack of regulation. They believe that timely action a decade ago could have prevented the current issues of disinformation, privacy breaches, and addictive elements in tech. Instead, the author suggests that regulators are being too feeble and that a more proactive approach is needed to address the sector's impact on society, including creating jobs, promoting diversity, and combating existential issues like climate change.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) maintains its hold rating with a fair value of S$2.33 after announcing Funan's early opening on June 28, ahead of its original schedule. The mall's pre-committed occupancy is 92% for retail and 98% for office blocks. CMT's property brokerage business is expected to see earnings growth driven by organic revenue expansion, commission rate expansion, and inorganic growth through strategic alliances. The sector is considered asset-light and lower-risk, with an estimated FY2019-2021 CAGR of 4.4% and double-digit return on equity.

site_title: Free Spirits
summary: Three Singaporean bar owners, Sue-Shan Quek, Peter Ng, and Phillipe Chin, are redefining the drinking experience with their unique concepts. Telok Ayer Arts Club, launched by Quek, combines art, music, and food in a curated space featuring local and regional talents. Maduro, owned by Ng, is a listening lounge dedicated to classical music and supporting local musicians. Drunken Farmer, run by Chin, is a natural wine bar with a focus on sustainability and community engagement. These establishments aim to make art and wine more accessible to a wider audience, promoting a more active role in promoting and supporting the arts.

site_title: Trump calls for Mexico to 'step up' as trade talks make some progress
summary: US President Donald Trump urged Mexico to "step up" as trade talks resumed on Thursday, amid a looming deadline to avoid tariffs. Trump announced that tariffs on Mexican imports would begin on Monday if no deal is reached, with monthly increases up to 25%. Despite this, Mexico's Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard expressed optimism about a potential agreement, citing a "good meeting" with respectful positions from both sides. The US and Mexico are negotiating to address migrants entering the US and Mexico's role in stemming the flow.

site_title: Special Feature: East-West Discovery
summary: This article highlights the diversity of attractions across North America and Asia. The US east coast offers iconic cities like New York and Austin, while Canada beckons with its natural beauty and vibrant cities like Vancouver. Meanwhile, Malaysia is reinventing itself through its dining scene, with Kuala Lumpur's food trucks and Penang's beachside restaurants. China is known for its grand scale, with the Great Wall and modern wonders like the CCTV tower in Beijing. The article emphasizes the importance of authentic experiences and local connections, offering Pan Pacific DISCOVERY members access to over 2,300 Local Experiences in destinations worldwide.

site_title: DS 7 Sportback review: What the French know that you don't
summary: The DS 7 Sportback is a luxury car from French manufacturer DS Automobiles that offers an alternative to well-known premium brands. The DS 7 is equipped with advanced features, including a 12-inch touchscreen infotainment system, massage chairs, and a rearview camera, making it a better value than comparable German luxury SUVs. The car's design is characterized by French craftsmanship and flair, with a focus on textures and motifs. While the driving experience may be unfamiliar to some, the DS 7 is surprisingly surefooted and comfortable, making it a strong contender in its segment.

site_title: COE prices end mostly lower except for small cars
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended mostly lower in the latest tender, with the only exception being cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp, which rose to $30,009. Cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp and open COEs decreased to $39,728 and $42,002, respectively. Commercial vehicle COEs fell to $25,502. Dealers attribute the subdued car market to economic uncertainty from the US-China trade war.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) prices ended mostly lower in the latest tender on Thursday, as a plunge in premiums in the previous exercise sent buyers of smaller cars back to showrooms.

site_title: Saudis, Russia meet with future of Opec+ cuts still unresolved
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia meet in St Petersburg to discuss extending Opec+ production cuts, but Russia's non-committal stance on the matter has created uncertainty. Saudi Arabia wants to extend the cuts beyond the current deadline, but Russia's interests are unclear, with President Putin saying a price of $60-$65 per barrel suits Russia, while Saudi Arabia seeks a higher price. The meeting comes as market volatility surges due to US trade wars and supply disruptions from Iran to Venezuela, making it difficult for the two countries to agree on a decision.

site_title: Expansion of microalgae production to improve Singapore's food security
summary: Singapore's Life3 Biotech partners with Temasek Polytechnic to expand microalgae production, aiming to improve food and nutrition security. The partnership aims to develop a special cultivation medium using food by-products to enhance microalgae growth and nutritional profile. This will help increase the production scale of plant-based seafood alternatives, addressing concerns about Singapore's food security. The project involves building large-scale vertical bioreactor tanks, with the first phase already completed and the second phase underway, targeting completion by December this year.

site_title: State-linked EDBI invests in Circles.Life
summary: State-linked EDBI has invested in Singapore telco startup Circles.Life, leading a funding round. EDBI holds 7.22% of Circles.Life's preference shares, while Founders Fund and Sequoia Capital India also participated. The mobile virtual network operator plans to use the funds to hire more tech talent and expand overseas, aiming to enter at least five markets by 2020. EDBI CEO Chu Swee Yeok expressed support for Circles.Life's growth, calling it a regional champion.

site_title: More resale flats sold in May, with slight dip in prices: SRX
summary: Singapore's resale flat market saw a 7.5% increase in sales in May, with 2,075 units transacted, compared to 1,931 in April. Resale prices dropped 0.2% month-on-month and 1.2% year-on-year. The median transaction over X-Value (TOX) remained unchanged at negative S$1,000. Prices in mature estates dipped 0.1%, while non-mature estates saw a 0.2% decrease.

site_title: Europe's parliament comes alive at last
summary: European Parliament elections saw a significant increase in voter turnout, with over 50% participating, the highest in 20 years. This surge was driven by rising support for EU membership and a desire to counter the threat of populist forces. Despite gains by populist parties, the pro-European centre largely held its ground, with a fractured coalition needed for a majority. The election highlighted the need for reform in the European Parliament's structure, which disproportionately represents smaller member states, and may have taken a step towards becoming a true expression of Europeans' popular will.

site_title: Thai PM faces economic woes amid fragile coalition majority
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha faces a fragile coalition majority, raising concerns about passing legislation and disrupting public spending on large investment projects. The country's economy grew 2.8% in Q1, the weakest since 2014, amid rising global trade tensions and political risks. Investors are worried about political uncertainty, which may lead to policy discontinuity and weigh on growth. The government's instability will continue to affect market sentiment, and a stable government is crucial for improving investment and foreign trade negotiations.

site_title: Catalist-listed Ayondo completes sale of Ayondo Markets
summary: Ayondo, a Singapore-based fintech company, has completed the sale of its entire stake in Ayondo Markets Limited (AML) for £5.7 million (S$10.2 million) to Netherlands-registered BUX Holdings. However, shares in Ayondo remain suspended until the company addresses going concern and business viability issues, following intense scrutiny over its financial sustainability. The sale is aimed at reducing liabilities, and Ayondo has engaged with regulatory bodies to address compliance concerns.

site_title: Investors make a play for Reits
summary: Investors flocked to real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore, driving up trading volumes and outperforming the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) on June 6, 2019. The STI rose 0.1% to 3,146.18, while Reits saw significant gains, with top gainers including CapitaLand Mall Trust and Mapletree Commercial Trust. The Fed's potential rate cut was seen as a key driver of Reits' performance, with analysts citing the falling treasury yield as making them more attractive in a low-yield environment.

site_title: Power play in the electricity market
summary: Singapore's electricity market liberalization has sparked competition, leading to significant savings for consumers. However, many households remain loyal to their existing providers, while others have already dropped out. The market is expected to consolidate further.

site_title: Toyota, Subaru team up to develop electric SUV
summary: Toyota and Subaru are partnering to develop a battery-electric sport-utility vehicle, with each brand selling the vehicle under its own label. The joint project aims to split the cost of production and utilizes Subaru's all-wheel-drive technology and Toyota's vehicle electrification technology. The move follows Toyota's efforts to reduce capital investment in developing new technologies, while Subaru seeks to improve its lower-emissions vehicle offerings. The partnership highlights the challenges faced by Japanese carmakers in competing with global rivals in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Oil steadies above Jan lows, but under pressure from surging supply and economic slowdown
summary: Oil prices steadied above January lows on Thursday, but remained under pressure due to surging global supply and a slowing economy. Front-month Brent crude futures rose 0.3% to $60.79 per barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose 0.3% to $51.84 per barrel. Despite Thursday's gains, oil markets are moving into bear territory due to a 20% fall from recent peaks. Rising US production and a global economic slowdown are contributing to the downward trend.

site_title: Quick Change
summary: Fashion experts recommend 13 pre-fall style tips for men, including workwear overalls, extra-large totes, sleek briefcases, and luxury streetwear. The season's key trends include combat boots, cargo trousers, chunky boots, and prints on blazers. Ponchos and funnel necks are also popular alternatives to traditional coats and scarves. The focus is on practicality and versatility, with a mix of high-end and streetwear influences. Key brands such as Jil Sander, Givenchy, and Dior Men are featured in the article.

site_title: Shopee ups entertainment ante; still favours growth over monetisation
summary: Shopee, a Singapore-based e-commerce firm, is focusing on enhancing user stickiness with interactive features such as live streaming and quizzes to boost engagement, rather than prioritizing monetization. The company aims to increase user retention without significantly increasing marketing costs. Shopee's efforts come as competitors, including Alibaba-owned Lazada, also introduce similar features to attract users. Despite growing revenue, monetization remains a secondary priority for Shopee, with the company focusing on long-term user growth.

images.alt_text: Mr Zhou believes that investing in interactive elements can boost user stickiness.

site_title: Artists in Architecture
summary: Four Singaporean architects, Richard Hassell (WOHA), Lee Hui Lian (FARM), Tay Yan Ling (Ta.Le Architects), and Juliana Chan (ACG Design Studio and NS Chan Studio), are also accomplished artists. They create artworks in their free time, often incorporating elements of math, science, and nature into their designs. Hassell's intricate tilings have been incorporated into WOHA projects, while Lee Hui Lian's synaesthesia influences her colorful paintings. Tay Yan Ling's grapheme-colour synaesthesia also inspires her art, and Juliana Chan's architecture background has improved her art, allowing her to break down complex details into simpler forms. Their art and architecture are intertwined, and they hope to continue pursuing both passions.

site_title: GIC's ex-chief economist to join Grab
summary: GIC's former chief economist, Leslie Teo, is set to join Grab's data science unit in mid-August. Teo, 50, will work alongside high-profile hires, including former Singapore Tourism Board CEO Lionel Yeo. Teo, who retired from GIC in April, expressed a desire to pursue other interests, including understanding technology more closely. He will begin work at Grab after a decade-long stint at the sovereign wealth fund, where he rose through the ranks to become chief economist.

site_title: Ecosperity: PUB to seek proposals for solar panel systems on Tengeh Reservoir
summary: Singapore's water agency PUB plans to build the world's largest single floating solar PV system on Tengeh Reservoir, with a 50 megawatt-peak capacity. The system will power water treatment processes and reduce the country's carbon footprint. Two smaller systems will also be deployed at Bedok and Lower Seletar Reservoirs. PUB aims to adopt a circular economy approach and has implemented a carbon tax, with plans to launch initiatives such as NEWSand to reuse construction materials.

site_title: Picture Perfect
summary: Local artists Lyn Ng and Carlyn Law will guide participants in a pet painting and woodcraft workshop at Studio Mu Yu on June 16. The three-hour workshop, priced at S$120, covers basic woodworking skills and techniques for painting pet portraits in watercolor and acrylic. Participants will receive their artwork after the workshop. To secure seats, email eattodraw@gmail.com. The event takes place at #02-09, Katong Point, 451 Joo Chiat Road.

site_title: Last US cruise ship leaves Cuba as new Trump sanctions bite
summary: The last US cruise ship, Empress of the Seas, left Cuba on Wednesday as new US sanctions, imposed by President Donald Trump, took effect. The ship had docked in Havana on Tuesday, taking passengers by surprise, as the new sanctions banned group educational travel, cruise ship, and private yacht visits to Cuba. The move is expected to affect nearly 800,000 reservations and could significantly impact Cuba, which saw a record 250,000 US visitors in the first four months of 2019.

site_title: SGX to boost derivatives, target S-E Asia unicorns
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) plans to expand its derivatives business and offer a platform for South-east Asian unicorns to list shares and bonds. CEO Loh Boon Chye stated that the exchange aims to diversify its offerings beyond IPOs, focusing on multi-asset strategies to sustain growth. This move is part of a broader effort to attract and support the region's rapidly growing unicorns.

images.alt_text: Mr Loh: "IPO is not a destination, it's only a process. Our secondary fundraising typically is three to four times of the IPO market."

site_title: Govt pares land supply for private homes amid demand and supply concerns
summary: The Singapore government has reduced the private housing supply for the second half of 2019, with a total of 6,430 units available, compared to 6,475 units in the first half of the year. This is the lowest supply since 2007. The move comes amid muted demand and a glut in supply, as the market continues to face challenges. The reduced supply is aimed at stabilizing the market and preventing a further decline in prices.

site_title: 2019 Volkswagen Touareg review: Bigger than yours
summary: The 2019 Volkswagen Touareg is a flagship model in Singapore, boasting a large size and imposing presence. Despite its size, the car offers advanced safety features, including front cross traffic detection and autonomous emergency braking, to help navigate tight city streets. The R-Line trim also features height-adjustable air suspension and all-wheel steering, making it a comfortable and nimble handler. However, its size is still a challenge, particularly in tight turns and carparks, and the interior is dominated by a large infotainment display. With a price tag of S$319,900, the Touareg is a demonstration of how carmakers can balance size and advanced technology.

site_title: ECB pushes back rate hike again as outlook dims
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) postponed its first post-crisis interest rate hike, citing dimming economic outlooks overshadowed by a US-China trade war.
